column2: Almost the last thing on earth the Dominican Republic needs at this point in its troubled history is Gen. Elias Wessin y Wessin as a candidate for President. A Wessin campaign would immediately reopen the wounds of the 1965 civil war if not the war itself. It would undo overnight the considerable progress toward national reconciliation achieved under President Joaquin Balaguer.

Kenneth G. Germann, a former football player and coach at Columbia, was named director of athletics by the university yesterday. Germann, the assistant director at Rutgers, will succeed Ralph J. Furey, who retires July 1. Furey will become a special assistant to the Columbia president, supervising work on new athletic facilities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of a New York law that requires all teachers in public schools and in private schools with tax-exempt status to swear to uphold the Federal and state constitutions.

MARTIN GOTTFRIED, the chief drama critic for Women's Wear Daily, is a good man to have on your side. His opinions are forceful, clearly stated and strongly held. He is a writer of muscular prose and is an observer with an eagle's-eye view of the contemporary theater. He is a polemicist whose arguments are continually buttressed by volleys of citations, references, examples.
In a move to help meet New York's chronic shortage of blood for medical needs, two organizations merged their voluntary blood programs yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The Legislature approved today a bill that would permit New York City to sell bonds at a maximum interest rate of 6 per cent, instead of the present 5 per cent ceiling.
George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., has been named chairman of the recently established David Dubinsky Foundation.
Striking long-distance telephone operators and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company sought an arbitration formula yesterday that would end their dispute over scheduling.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The United States acknowledged today that a United States-South Vietnamese patrol had made a limited intrusion into Cambodian territory during a clash last Thursday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 22 (UPI) -- A state Senator accused the administration of Gov. Raymond P. Shafer today of suppressing information on a report that six college students had been blinded by the sun during an LSD "trip."
THE problem with the show that opened last night at the Village Gate is summarized in the last two words of its title -- "Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris."

BONN, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The office of President Heinrich Lubke said today that an article in the magazine Stern charging that Dr. Lubke had signed plans for a Nazi concentration camp "deals with an old matter that has been denied many times in the past."
The Department of Commerce has been asked to formulate specific "restraints" upon investments by American companies in foreign-flag shipping.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Representative H. R. Gross, charged today that the Johnson Administration had overruled Government experts and had made a "scandalous" $13.3-million deal for three-wheeled mail trucks with a now defunct Minnesota concern.

Why are there 39 milion fat Americans? Medical researchers, dissatisfied with the pat answer that pepole are fat because they eat too much, are pressing a search into the underlying causes of obesity.
Following is a list issued by the Defense Department of previous accidents involving nuclear weapons that were carried on Air Force planes:
Madison Square Garden, which has a new sports and entertainment complex, office building and basketball and hockey teams among other interests, has decided to get out of the soccer business.
The head of a parents association stood on a temporary wooden walkway leading to a new Harlem school building yesterday and, motioning to the unfinished rubble-strewn school yard said:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Senator John L. McClellan expressed strong doubt today that Congress would appropriate funds to continue work on the Navy's F-111B fleet-defense plane.

Lovell Thompson, recently retired executive vice president of the Houghton Mifflin Company, is taking a gamble and calling it a gambit. Gambit Incorporated, to be exact. That is his name for a new Boston publishing concern whose formation he will announce tomorrow.

Thoroughbred racing horsemen told Governor Rockefeller yesterday they would drop their right to seek a larger share of the pari-mutuel handle if the Governor withdrew his budget request that the state's take-out from the handle be increased.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union, West Germany and Norway each won one of the three gold medals up for grabs today in the 1968 Winter Universiade Games -- but the victoryless United States was shut out again.
DENVER, Jan. 20 -- A sign saying "Draft Rockefeller" is about to go up on the front of the Shirley-Savoy Hotel, a stone's throw from the State capitol.
DALLAS, Jan. 22 -- France replied today to radio editorials attacking that country and President de Gaulle on monetary matters.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 22 -- A comment made Friday by Eugene V. Rostow, the United States Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, concerning prospective security arrangements in the Arab-Persian Gulf region has generated bitter Arab reaction.

The United States Commission on Civil Rights reported recently that the condition of the Negro in big-city slums is deteriorating and that his hopes of escape are diminishing. The commission said an attack on slum problems should be the nation's "first priority."
FAIRCHILD CAMERA, which traded as high as 123 5/8 in 1967, floated in a backwater yesterday that carried the stock to a bi-year low.
The opening of three new community colleges was approved last night by the city's Board of Higher Education.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A Government study cautioned today that Lake Michigan could become another Lake Erie unless water pollution was checked.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Anthony J. Travia, Speaker of the Assembly, announced today that at his request Theodore W. Kheel would study the Taylor Law with a view to recommending changes.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 22 -- Two Laotian Army battalions have taken up defensive positions about midway between the royal capital of Luang Prabang and the fallen outpost of Nambac as a precautionary measure against a possible Communist offensive.

Record earnings were achieved by the Xerox Corporation in 1967 for the 16th consecutive year with a 22 per cent gain, while operating revenues, up 31 per cent, set a new high for the 18th straight year, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- After several years of interparty stalemate, support is mounting in the Legislature this year for the creation of new judgeships to end serious congestion of court calendars, particularly in New York City.

Bruce Jay Friedman, the novelist, who scored with his first play, "Scuba Duba," will adapt his best-selling novel, "A Mother's Kisses" (1964), for the musical stage. Songs have been written by Richard Adler, who did the same job for "The Pajama Game" and "Damn Yankees."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Federal Open Market Committee, key policy-making body of the Federal Reserve System, decided at its meeting of last Oct. 24 to keep monetary policy unchanged because of impending Treasury financing operations, it was disclosed today.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges said today he was "in total disagreement" with Governor Rockefeller on gun-control legislation.
Trading in palladium began yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in one of the wildest opening-day sessions ever experienced by a commodities exchange.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 -- Sixty-five faculty members in South Vietnam's university system have signed a petition calling for immediate negotiations and an indefinite truce in the war.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 22 -- Eartha Kitt defended today her remarks made at a White House luncheon last Thursday when she linked juvenile delinquency in the streets to the war in Vietnam. She asked, "How can the truth be construed as rudeness?"
CHRISTCHURCH, N. Z., Tuesday, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -- The first Antarctic cruise ship, the Magga Dan, was freed today from a shoal in McMurdo Sound, Antarctica.
LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 -- The United States Army is warning soldiers that Australia may be eliminated as a rest and recreation area unless they stop carrying marijuana from Vietnam.
Public hearings to consider abolishing the city marshal system are being planned by state and city officials.

JACK DONOHUE, the Holy Cross basketball coach, is the man who coached Lew Alcindor when they were coach and player at Power Memorial High School in New York. Now he is the man who must coach against Alcindor and the other University of California, Los Angeles, basketball players at the Bruins' next game. Holy Cross and U.C.L.A. meet at Madison Square Garden Friday night.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reported yesterday that its profit last year fell about 20 per cent from the 1966 level.

NORWICH, Vt., Jan. 22 -- The Colonel's sauce triggered the hunt. It was served on blue goose from Canada and woodcock form Vermont, both species shot by Hanson Carroll of Norwich, a freelance photographer, outdoorsman and lover of good food.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An Air Force B-52 bomber carrying four hydrogen bombs crashed in flames into the ice off Greenland yesterday while attempting to make an emergency landing at the Thule Air Force Base.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The crash of a jetliner into a New Orleans motel last March killing 19 persons, was attributed today by Government investigator to a flight instructor's over-confidence in the pilot.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Commerce Department issued today a "general authorization" for American companies to guarantee foreign borrowings by their subsidiaries, and to pay dollars in case a guarantee is invoked.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Administration is concerned over what it regards as a severe public rejection by North Vietnam of President Johnson's conditions for beginning talks to end the war.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 22 -- The liberal Peace and Freedom party, an anti-Vietnam war group, qualified today for a place on the California election ballot. As expected, George C. Wallace's American Independent party also qualified.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Senator Robert P. Griffin said today that if newspaper strike leaders in Detroit were involved financially in publishing a temporary paper "this is nothing less than labor racketeering."

A team of five Philadelphia physicians presented evidence yesterday linking smoking with a sharp increase in secretions by the adrenal glands' cortex, which controls a wide variety of vital functions, including metabolism and resistance to infection.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The major industrial countries today examined the post-devaluation economic program of the British Government and found it still lacking in the bite necessary to prevent new troubles for sterling.

Stock prices tumbled on a broad front yesterday at the start of a new series of abbreviated trading sessions designed to help brokers cope with the pile-up of paperwork that has resulted from the heavy trading in recent months.
Only one-quarter of the nation's police departments screen recruits for emotional fitness, but those that do report that "an amazing number of applicants are dropped," according to Look magazine.

SOME unremarkable footage was added to the New York art scene yesterday -- 17 1/2 feet at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 36 feet at the Museum of Modern Art. Both represented museological excursions into the realm of commercial art.

In his State of the Union address, President Johnson broached the subject of the frustration, restlessness and feeling of meaninglessness which has recently been plaguing the American spirit [editorial Jan. 19].

The Metropolitan Opera has canceled -- at least for next summer -- its opera festival in Newport, R. I., because the event's local sponsors could not provide a covered pavilion and a sufficient financial guarantee. Last year's Verdi Festival at the resort resulted in a $100,000 loss to the Metropolitan, partly because of uncertain weather.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- A Buster Keaton Festival has opened at the National Film Theater here and will continue for nearly a month.
The United States figure-skating team, strong in talent and depth, leaves here tonight to compete in the Winter Olympic Games opening Feb. 6 at Grenoble, France.

The impressions left by the National Hockey League's greats on the Madison Square Garden ice have been scraped away after each game, but the Rangers announced yesterday they would keep the all-stars' memory alive with the most formidable line-up of talent in the league's history.

Dr. Howard J. Brown, who submitted his resignation in December as the city's $40,000-a-year Health Services Administrator, went back to work yesterday as an informal committee continued to search for a successor.

In an attempt to curb over-speculation in low-priced issues, a number of brokerage firms have recently been instructing their registered representatives not to solicit orders for such stocks from their customers.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Tuesday, Jan. 23 -- An engine misfiring in earth orbit marred the unmanned flight debut of the nation's bug-shaped lunar module spacecraft, designed for ferrying astronauts to and from the moon's surface.

CAIRO, Jan. 22 -- The Egyptian Government charged today that craven military men and former Cabinet ministers plotted its overthrow last year by setting up a stronghold near the pyramids and preparing to seize four key military headquarters and a number of Government leaders.
MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- Prime Minister Wilson spent more than four hours in discussions today with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 22 (Agence France-Presse) -- The military command of the South Vietnamese National Liberation Front has ordered the "annihilation" of all pacification teams in South Vietnam and of the forces supporting them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The recent sharp decline in the six-month Treasury bill rate was reversed at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The rate on three-month bills continued to drift slightly lower.

Basketball's most glamorous single event, the annual East-West All - Star game of the National Basketball Association wil have an appropriately glamorous setting tonight when it takes place at Madison Square Garden and is televised nationally by the American Broadcasting Company (Channel 7).
A panel of 10 priests and laymen is looking into complaints seeking removal of the Right Rev. Joseph S. Minnis of Denver, Episcopal Bishop of Colorado.

WHEN Joseph Gleason Gavin Jr. began engineering studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the late nineteen-thirties, a friend recalled yesterday, one of his major interests was the aerodynamics of biplanes.

In terms almost as strong as those we have already used in these columns, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York has now voiced its protest against the infamous trial of 35 South-West Africans under South Africa's "Terrorism Act."

Former President Eihenhower's criticism of the "thin" antiballistic-missile system (ABM) which Washington has set out to build gives the Administration an opportunity to slow down the arms race, make a substantial budget saving and free funds for under-financed social programs.
Given an hour and a half less time to trade, investors were unable yesterday to maintain last week's pace on the American Stock Exchange.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The right of 25 Labor members of Parliament to attend party meetings was restored by the liaison committee of the Labor party tonight pending a hearing on their case.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Life is too depressing this evening to write about. The following letter, which arrived in the morning mail, will explain why:

ATHENS, Jan. 22 -- Chances that Mikis Theodorakis, the imprisoned Greek leftist politician and composer, will soon be freed increased today when an Athens appeals court removed the legal obstacles to his release.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide if states can deny welfare benefits to dependent children of mothers who are found to have had extramarital sexual relations.
The Hebrew Arts School for Music and Dance was picketed yesterday by angry tenants who charged they were being harassed by poor services to make them move from four school-owned buildings.
SEA ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 22 (AP) -- An economist and shipping official assured Great Lakes shipping operators today that their future was bright.
Trading was active but prices were on the downside at the close of trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
The Health Department reported yesterday the first drop in the recorded number of deaths since the outbreak of influenza about six weeks earlier.

A GROUP of children's furniture at the Children's Workbench, 217 East 51st Street, represents the kind of contemporary, unfussy design to which an increasing number of furniture designers are turning their talents.
Trustees of the Rockefeller University, a pre-eminent scientific research and teaching institution here, have begun looking for a successor to Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, the university's president.

" Private Lives '68,' the second annual dinner dance of the junior committee of the Lila Motley Cancer Foundation, will be held Sunday at El Morocco. Proceeds from the event will be used to purchase a radiation machine for the treatment of children who are patients at New York University Medical Center's cancer treatment branch.

The city's Council Against Poverty has told a Puerto Rican - dominated antipoverty agency in the Bronx to appoint 13 Negroes as members of its board of directors "to bring about ethnic balance" -- and to do so within 30 days.

Greenland, the world's largest island if Australia is considered a continent, is a landmass of 840,000 square miles of which 727,360 square miles are covered with ice the year round. The island is 1,650 miles long and almost 800 miles wide at its widest point. Its population of about 22,000 people is largely concentrated along the west coast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- President Johnson said today that the foreign aid program was designed "to keep conflict from starting by helping to remove its causes and thus assure our own security in a peaceful world."
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The Foreign Office confirmed today that a group of Persian Gulf rulers had made an offer "in general terms" to finance a continuing British military presence in the Gulf area.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A Federal judge ordered stock brokers today to repay $295,000 in commissions and interest that an elderly widow was charged during what he described as "excessive trading" in her account.

Wagner's "Lohengrin," which was given a new production, last season at the Metropolitan Opera, was sung for the first time this season last night. The staging is still a mixed blessing, but the performance has improved considerably in musical terms, it was one of the better offerings in the company's repertory -- assuming the listener finds "Lohengrin" appealing.
The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned yesterday that if the Congress failed to increase taxes this year, the nation would run the risk of another 1966-style credit crisis.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 22 -- Iowa Republicans got a "peace" candidate for United States Senator over the weekend and their first candidate for one of the two House seats they failed to win in 1966.

TO college basketball coaches and scouts, the Rev. Ed Visscher is more than a Lutheran minister, principal of Long Island Lutheran High School and the basketball coach. In the eight years the school has been in existence, he has gained a national reputation for turning out outstanding court talent.
PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Sixteen nuns at St. Joseph's School here won one of the four $100,000 top prizes in New York State's December lottery today.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Kathy Kusner, the 27-year-old member of the United States Equestrian Team who is seeking to become a licensed jockey, advised stewards at Pimlico Race Course today that she was ready to work a horse in a display of her riding proficiency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Following is the text of President Johnson's message to Congress today proposing a job-training program:
WOMEN intending to start or resume careers may be interested in a number of new how-to-go-about-it publications.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Newman E. Wait Jr., president of the Adirondack Trust Company of Saratoga Springs, tonight was elected president of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.

NIAMEY, Niger, Jan. 23 -- President Diori Hamani of Niger ended a conference of 14 French-speaking African nations here today by commending his fellow heads of state for the atmosphere of moderation, wisdom and responsibility in which they had worked together for the last two days.
MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- Prime Minister Wilson said today that the differences over Vietnam had "narrowed," and he called on Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union to join in resolving them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- In a case that the Federal Communications Commission says is the first of its kind, New York University and Fairleigh Dickinson University are vying for a license to operate an FM educational radio station.
PITTSBURGH Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Travelers Insurance Company sued Blue Cross of Western Pennsylvania today to stop what it called "unreasonable restraint of competition" and "monopolistic practices."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The United States resumed "normal" diplomatic relations with Greece today, six weeks after King Constantine failed in his attempt to oust the military regime.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Republicans in Congress told the American people tonight that President Johnson's policies had led to riots, crime and inflation at home and loss of influence and prestige abroad.
The use of cargo containers is changing rather than eliminating the cargo larceny problem, the retiring president of the Security Bureau, Inc., told its annual meeting yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- North Korean patrol boats seized a United States Navy intelligence ship off Wonsan today and took the vessel and her 83 crew members into the North Korean port.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills told the Administration "no" again today on the tax increase.

Control of pollution from city apartment house incinerators, which has been stymied by a strong but unenforceable law was delayed again yesterday when the Lindsay administration and the City Council failed to agree on what kind of legislation would work.
Borough President Herman Badillo of the Bronx accused the city's Council Against Poverty yesterday of creating "dissension instead of a united front" among ethnic groups.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 23 -- The American Film Institute will provide $500,000 over the next two and a half years for the production of short films by American students and independent filmmakers, the institute's director, George Stevens Jr., announced here today.
MIAMI, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Larry Adams escaped injury today when his mount broke down and fell with 70 yards to go in the first race at Hialeah.
The Soviet Union is striving to become the leading maritime power in the world, the Commander in Chief of the United States Naval Forces in Europe asserted last night.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Kathy Harter of Seal Beach, Calif., and Mary Ann Eisel of St. Louis gained the third round today in the Australian national tennis championships.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Helmerich Payne, Inc., the largest Sunray DX Oil Company stockholder, formally requested today access to the list of company stockholders.

Apart from its effort to curtail speculation and to catch up with its paperwork by reducing trading hours, the New York Stock Exchange has finally made some reasonable proposals for changing its fixed commission rate structure on all purchases and sales of stocks.
The head of Air France has called for reduced fares from Europe to the United States as a means of cutting the "travel gap" in the United States balance of payments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- North Korea's seizure of the United States intelligence-gathering ship Pueblo was condemned in Congress today as an act of war. Some lawmakers demanded a quick military response.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk expressed the hope today that public rejection by the North Vietnamese of President Johnson's "San Antonio formula" for peace talks did not represent "their last word."
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it would make available shortly to American ship operators four more C-4 troop ships for conversion to commercial cargo carriers.
Tim Wood, who surprised America's figure skating fraternity last weekend in Philadelphia, scored another first yesterday enroute to the Winter Olympic Games in Grenoble, France.
Joe Medwick, the rough-and-tumble outfielder of St. Louis's Gashouse Gang of a generation ago, was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday.

The New York Yankees were drumbeating in the suburbs and beyond yesterday while their third baseman, Charlie Smith, was in Lenox Hill Hospital recuperating from an operation that will keep him on the sidelines three months.
THERE'S a little secret to charity benefits these days. It's called Truman Capote.

On Jan. 25 the Board of Estimate will meet to determine the long-range future of the Bronx by acting on the matter of continuing the lease of the MABSTOA bus lines to the New York City Transit Authority. Intimately involved in this question is the restoration of bus-transfer privileges which were withdrawn from these lines by the city administration in February 1962.

It is rather disturbing to note the triumphant tone of Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes's announcement that 497 more curbside parking meters will be increased from 10 cents to 25 cents. He justifies this on the ground that it will discourage long-term parking.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Negotiations toward a resumption of diplomatic relations between West Germany and Yugoslavia opened here today. They were blanketed in secrecy, but the assumption on both sides was that they would end favorably.
The taking of the Pueblo by Korean forces had a bizarre and little known precedent in 1866, when an American sailing vessel was set afire, by order of a Korean monarch and its crew massacred.
Eartha Kitt is to be commended for her courageous direct speaking to Mrs. Lyndon Johnson.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Jan. 24 -- The American commander of the United Nations Command demanded at a meeting of the Mixed Armistice Commission today that the Pueblo and her crew of 83 be returned immediately by North Korea.
The time: two weeks or so ago. The place: an advertising agency. An account executive has called two copywriters into his office to discuss a new account.
QANTARA, the United Arab Republic, Jan. 23 -- The last of the prisoners captured in the Arab-Israeli war returned home today in a final exchange across the Suez Canal.
A high city official has suggested that the New York Shakespeare Festival help defray its operating costs by charging admission to its free performances in Central Park, according to Joseph Papp.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The forthcoming World Economic Development Conference in New Delhi may see "agreement in principle" on a new plan to compensate automatically countries with approved development plans for losses of exports beyond their control, the Secretary General of the conference said today.

BONN, Jan. 23 -- Edda Goring, only child of the Nazi Air Marshal, Hermann Goring, has lost a new round in her 15-year legal battle over a $50,000 painting that the city of Cologne gave her father as a present for her christening in 1938.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 -- There is a serious political and philosophical argument going on here among the Kennedy liberals at Harvard. It is not the tiresome personal dispute that we are having in Washington between President Johnson and the Kennedy clan, but an argument among the Kennedy supporters about Presidential power, the condition of the nation and whether Senator Robert Kennedy of New York can do anything about these things.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 23 -- President Johnson faces a difficult task in trying to sell the American voters on a tax increase at this time. He is also likely to meet with as much opposition from the rank-and-file of his own party as from others, according to the Gallup Poll.

Theodore C. Sorensen has suggested that Congress should suspend the "equal time" requirement of the Communications Act as it applies to Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates for the duration of this year's national election campaign.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Carl Yastrzemski of the Boston Red Sox, fulfilling what he called the thrill of a lifetime, met President Johnson in the White House today.

According to a letter to The Times (Jan. 16), the United States decision to deploy a thin ABM system is presumed to be the result of "the pressuring of the Johnson Administration" by "the military-arms industry complex,"

A hearing in Bronx Criminal Court will be conducted today to decide whether Joseph Porter, a Transit Authority employe who doubles as manager of the Square Theater, on Westchester Square in the Bronx, should be tried for showing two allegedly obscene films at the theater Dec. 9.

Two automatic ticket vending organizations yesterday announced plans for selling tickets. Ticket Reservation Systems, which was organized in 1965, expects to have 30 agencies connected with box offices in the metropolitan area by March 15, and the same number by that date in Los Angeles. Around May 15, 30 will be installed in Chicago and 15 more in Montreal.
The Boeing Company has completed arrangements with 40 banks for a revolving credit for $200-million, according to information filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Following is a transcript, as recorded by The New York Times, of the Republican rebuttal broadcast last night to President Johnson's State of the Union Message:

Prices and trading volume declined in unison for the third session in a row on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. It was the second day of abbreviated trading -- four hours instead of the usual five and-a-half hours -- aimed at clearing a backlog of work in brokerage houses.
" GO WEST, YOUNG MAN!" and 13 years ago George Balanchine took the hint, on behalf of the New York City Ballet. The result, "Western Symphony," has been continuously in the repertory since then.

BASEL, Switzerland -- The gathering of monetary leaders of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development this week in Paris focuses attention on the Basel Club -- a group of central bankers that holds regular meetings here to keep watch on world monetary affairs.
The president of a trucking company refused to testify before a grand jury yesterday about alleged fraud in the company's handling of a city antipoverty program to train young men as truck drivers.
Soybeans and grain futures prices advanced yesterday in moderate trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The treatment of cancer through the centuries has been studded with reports of promising cures that have never quite lived up to their initial promise.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 23 -- Willie Shoemaker, the world's leading money-winning jockey, suffered the most serious injury of his 19-year riding career today. Shoemaker fractured his right femur, the bone that extends from the hip to the knee, when his mount in the second race at Santa Anita stumbled over a fallen horse and threw the 36-year-old jockey.
KHESANH, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 -- More than 5,000 United States marines have been concentrated at Khesanh amid indications that one of the major battles of the Vietnam war may be in the offing.
Esquire, Inc., will acquire the Globe Book Company, a publisher of schoolbooks, under a purchase agreement that will be completed in March.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- A State Senator from Brooklyn introduced a bill in the Legislature today that would require professional ice hockey players to wear protective helmets during games.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Three United States soldiers were slightly wounded today in a clash with North Korean raiders fleeing from Seoul after an abortive attempt to kill President Chung Hee Park, military sources reported.
The capture of the Pueblo by North Korean patrol boats recalled yesterday the Chesapeake Affair of 1807.

A lawyer representing Local 350 of the Bakery, Confectionery and Food Workers, headed by Daniel J. Motto, presented evidence yesterday in an effort to show that the union is a bona fide labor organization.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A Federal board said today that a railroad accident in New York City in which six persons were killed showed that new safety legislation might be needed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Virtually every drug originally manufactured in America between 1938 and 1962 will have to be relabeled to tell exactly what ailments it is effective against, the Government told the drug industry today.

Eartha Kitt's display of bad manners might have sorely embarnassed the other Negro guests at the White House; but the wrongness of her message should be seriously analyzed by our armies of psychologists and urban designers.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Two legislative investigations into the use of narcotics by students on campuses of the State University were announced here today after senators and assemblymen expressed anger and concern about the situation.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 -- Harvard University named new deans today of the divinity and law schools.

KHESANH, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 -- Working under the dim glow of flashlights, a young Navy doctor removed an explosive portion of a North Vietnamese mortar shell from the abdomen of an American marine Sunday.

The result was the expected one, but the manner of its achievement was not, as the East routed the West, 144-124, in the 18th annual midseason All-Star game of the National Basketball Association. A crowd of 18,422, a record for the event, filled Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The North Korean Government has been calling on world Communists to create diversionary problems that would turn United States energies away from the war effort in Vietnam.
BUFFALO, Jan. 23 -- Medicaid is being used by some counties as a "scapegoat to cover up increased taxes," the Republican chairman of a legislative committee said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- In the political life of Premier Kim Il Sung of North Korea, whose navy seized a United States vessel today, two facts stand out: His love of Korea and his hatred of the Japanese.

" The wilderness and primitive areas of this nation are a priceless heritage," President Johnson declared in a message to Congress last spring. "That heritage is ours to preserve or to destroy." But as the highway planners and private economic interests push road projects that despoil the wilderness, the Administration is not living up to the President's expressed ideals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Chief of Naval Operations, in a letter made public today, said Capt. Richard G. Alexander's handling of himself in a Navy controversy "raised serious questions" about how he would follow orders as the commander of a ship at sea.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that by the end of the year the city would install 200 emergency call boxes enabling persons on the street to talk with a policeman or fireman.

The bankruptcy trustee for the Yale Express System, Inc., has asked the Federal District Court here to approve the appointment of Robert L. Lalich as president of the troubled trucking company's freight forwarding subsidiary, the Republic Carloading and Distributing Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The nation's freight forwarders opened a campaign today to get legislative equality with their major competitors -- motor carriers -- in making contractual rate and operating arrangements with the railroads.

The Consolidated Edison Company has canceled and is closing out as rapidly as possible all contracts to companies owned by Henry Fried, who is under Federal indictment as the man who allegedly paid a $40,000 kickback in the Marcus case.
Hanoi's harsh public response to President Johnson's stand on peace talks does nothing to advance hope for a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war.
Eleven conductors who were contestants in the Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition have protested the manner in which the winners were selected.

Industrial shares dropped slightly yesterday but recovered to close above their lows on the London Stock Exchange, where trading was generally easier in apparent reflex action from the previous day's drop on Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Following are two handwritten letters from Mrs. Abraham Lincoln in 1867 to Alphonse Donn, White House guard, to whom she gave the clothes that President Lincoln wore on the night he was assassinated. The letters were with the clothes, which the Government acquired for $25,000.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 23 -- The Social Democratic party, in power for the last 15 years, was defeated tonight in a huge protest vote.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday new highs in 1967 revenues and net income and announced a planned preferred stock offering to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Representative Charles A. Halleck, after 33 years of continuous service in the House, has decided to retire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Clark M. Clifford emphasized today that as Secretary of Defense he would oppose any cessation of the bombing of North Vietnam under present political and military circumstances.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia -- For most of Africa, last year was discouraging, but it also brought the stirrings of a new spirit of self-reliance in the first moves by the continent's developing nations to form regional economic communities.

ST. GERVAIS, France, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Fernande Bochatay of Switzerland scored an upset over the heavily-favored French skiers in the Grand Prix slalom, prelude to next month's Winter Olympics, today. Kiki Cutter, a teen-ager from Bend, Ore., finished an impressive third.
BLANTYRE, Malawi -- "I would do business with the devil himself to further the interests of the four million people of my country."
GENEVA, Jan. 25 -- A Frenchman walked into the Geneva office of New York's First National City Bank today with a 2.2-pound gold bar tucked in the inside breast pocket of his blue suit.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Hurry Up Dear, a son of Dark Star, returned to competition after a five-week rest and won the $7,000 featured allowance race today at Hialeah Park. He was a 34-1 shot.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -Testimony that organized crime has moved into Wall Street prompted House Republicans to day to push for adoption of Federal curbs on loan-sharking.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 -- Three days before the opening of Powell Symphony Hall, the new home of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, passers-by would have bet vast sums that it would not open on time.
DON ARONOW, an inboard man from way back, looks for outboards to flex their competitive muscles dramatically this year on the offshore powerboat scene.
MOGADISHU, Somalia -"May Allah divert from us the kick of the passing year and the head-on collision of the coming year. Amen."
KAMPALA, Uganda -- Slow but sure progress is being made by this East African republic toward development of diversified agriculture.

Talks to avert a strike in 650 Manhattan and Bronx parking garages set for midnight tomorrow by a teamsters local will be held today as union and management negotiators agreed to sit down with Vincent D. McDonell, chairman of the State Mediation Board.
KINSHASA, the Congo -Though tremendous wealth lies quite literally just beneath the surface, this is going to be a year of austerity for the Congo.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- South Africa's economic predominance radiates from here to the three ministates of Botswana, Lesotho and Swaziland.
CAIRO -- Seven months after last June's war the Government of the United Arab Republic is still unable to cope with the economic after-effects.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania -- The goal of building a new society based on "love, sharing and work" was set last year for the more than 12 million citizens of this East African nation.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, one of the nation's largest banks, announced yesterday an agreement in principle to purchase L. F. Dommerich Co., Inc., a privately-owned factoring company, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 25 (Reuters) -- North Vietnamese troops strengthened their hold on an area around the Vietnamese -- Laotian border by capturing a Laotian outpost nine miles west of the embattled United States marine camp at Khesanh Laotian Army sources reported today.
The National Trust for Historic Preservation has received a gift of $500,000 from the Rockefeller Brothers Fund.

A $10,000 reward will be paid jointly by the Consolidated Edison Company and the William J. Burns International Detective Agency for information leading to the conviction of the slayer of a Burns security guard assigned to the utility's office at 32 West 125th Street, a spokesman for the two companies announced yesterday.

The first Episcopal bishop to preach in St. Patrick's Cathedral disclosed yesterday that a Council of Churches of the City of New York would soon be established to embrace Protestants, Roman Catholics and Eastern Orthodox congregations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- Arthur J. Goldberg presented the United States request here tonight for a Security Council meeting tomorrow on what he called "a series of dangerous and increasingly aggressive actions by North Korea," culminating in seizure of the Pueblo.

DAKAR, Senegal -- For Americans, "peanuts" are a minor pleasure. Not for the Senegalese. The size of their peanut crop can mean a good year with some carefree feasting, or a bad one with a dull, "hungry season."
BOSTON, Jan. 25 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that corruption, "brazenly practiced,'' was infesting the government of South Vietnam.

The 18th annual Animal Kingdom Ball for the benefit of the adoption service of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (A. S. P. C. A.) was held in the Colonnades of Essex House last night and attended by some 400 guests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -State Department officials hailed a proposed new International Coffee Agreement today as a big improvement over the present one. They expressed confidence that the last remaining issue would be settled by mid-February and the accord approved at that time.

CAIRO -- James W. Vanderbeek, a career executive with Standard Oil (Indiana), was in a boat on the Gulf of Suez where his company is exploiting an offshore oilfield when the Arab-Israeli war broke out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -There is an air of crisis in the capital these days. The talk is of a harder war and maybe even of more war over the capture of the U.S.S. Pueblo in North Korea, but the anxious talk and the big headlines could easily be misleading.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 -- Bombs exploded today in three Miami business establishments, two of which specializes in shipping packages to Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -President Johnson ordered 14,787 Air Force and Navy reservists to active duty today as a military backdrop to determined diplomatic efforts to recover an American ship seized Tuesday by North Korea.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -President Johnson received and accepted "with regret" today the formal resignation of John W. Gardner as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
LOME, Togo -- The economy of Togo, struck by a year of sharp political change, is marking time.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Prime Minister Wilson returned home from Moscow today and promptly reported to the House of Commons on his conversations with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and other Soviet leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Jan. 20 fell 2.1 per cent from the comparable 1967 week. Intercity truck tonnage for the corresponding period registered no change.
Earnings of the Aluminum Company of America last year rose 1.2 per cent above the 1966 level to set a record, the company reported yesterday.
The Procter Gamble Company achieved record sales and earnings in the six months ended Dec. 31, it was reported yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- There are definite signs here that the vision of former Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd of a "Southern African Common Market" is being given careful consideration.

All the properties on the west blockfront of the Avenue of the Americas between 46th and 47th Streets have been purchased by a group of realty investors and a skyscraper will probably be built on the site, one of them said yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 25 -- The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was given approval here today for a continuing program of acquisitions.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The number of auto workers made idle by strikes and resulting parts shortages rose to 72,200 today at General Motors and Chrysler in the United States and Chrysler in Canada. More layoffs are planned for tomorrow.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 25 -Twelve young New Jerseyans filed suit in Federal District Court here today to challenge the constitutionality of a memorandum issued on Oct. 26 by Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service.
" You can't be a hamburger all your life," Bob Seagren said last night after he set a world indoor record of 17 feet 4 1/4 inches in the pole vault in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.

The Board of Estimate agreed yesterday to renew the operating franchise of the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority until Feb. 15, on the condition that it provide free transfers to the subways in the Bronx and begin reduced fares for the aged in the Bronx and Manhattan.

Net income of the Union Railroad last year fell to $102,133,037, or $4.42 a share on the Interstate Commerce Commission basis, from 1966's $109,791,622, or $4.76 a share, the line announced yesterday.

KHARTOUM, Sudan, despite a series of crises -- including the repercussions of the Arab-Israeli war, a severe food shortage and devaluation of the pound -- the Government reported progress toward prosperity for Sudan last year.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast -Still conspicuously the most prosperous country in West Africa, the Ivory Coast is preparing to give her lately lagging growth rate a new push forward.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- The South African economy has shown that it is prepared to face the specter of inflation -- and that it has the means to control it.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 25 (AP) -Three United States women, including Mrs. Billie Jean King, advanced today to the third round of the double in the Australian tennis championships.

The Danakil nodded and jumped in, carefully setting his vintage rifle on the seat. Thirty miles farther, the dirt track would wind up into Awash Station. With the sun not half-way up, the ride would leave plenty of time for "magela," the market.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has ruled that the American Tobacco Company is liable for the death by cancer of a cigarette smoker and has ordered the case submitted to another jury to decide the damage award.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 -- The opening last night of St. Louis's new Powell Symphony Hall is making waves far beyond the Mississippi. The hall is a bold experiment in the conversion of an old movie theater at a time when the building of extravagant new cultural centers has reached epidemic proportions in the United States.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 25 -While the seemingly simple question of how to give a couple of helicopters to the International Control Commission team in Cambodia has been bedeviling diplomatic negotiations in several capitals this month, the commission team in neighboring Laos has been quietly looking for buyers for two helicopters it has not been able to use much.

YAOUNDE, Cameroon -- An ambitious new development effort by this West African country made promising progress last year toward its goal of doubling agricultural production by 1971.
