MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Vic Elford, a 32-year-old Briton who had been dogged by bad luck in other rallies, won the Monte Carlo rally today in a Porsche. The victory was the first in the classic for the German car.
Arthur A. Cohen has resigned as vice president and editor in chief of Holt, Rinehart Winston to devote full time to his own writing.

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Jan. 26 (AP)--Snow removal operations began early today at Narragansett Park to get the course in readiness for resumption of racing tomorrow. Mike Giordano, the track superintendent, said the track definitely would be ready for tomorrow "barring another storm, of course."

Lister Hill has done more for the health of Americans in modern times than any man outside the medical profession. The son of a distinguished surgeon who named him for Lord Lister, noted British physician, Senator Hill made politics his career and improved medical care his cause.

SEARCY, Ark., Jan. 26 (UPI) --Senator J. W. Fulbright said tonight that American ships involved in the Gulf of Tonkin incident had been spying and at least once had violated the territorial waters of North Vietnam.
LONDON, Jan. 26--Britain's largest banking group is being formed in the consolidation of the Westminster Bank and the National Provincial Bank, according to a surprise announcement today.
ATHENS, Jan. 26 -- Thirtythree Greek generals and colonels have been dishonorably discharged from the army for having backed King Constantine's coup attempt Dec. 13, it was disclosed today.
Port interests were notified yesterday that the Interstate Commerce Commission had suspended an increase in motor carrier rates proposed by the Middle Atlantic Conference.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 -- Nearly 118,000 workers at General Motors Corporation plants in the United States and Canada were out of work today because of strikes at three G.M. foundries and parts shortages resulting from the strikes.
The New York Stock Exchange has reported changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)--A special census will be taken this fall in Trenton, N.J., in a dress rehearsal of the new mail technique that will be used to count two-thirds of all Americans in 1970, the Bureau of Census announced today.
BERLIN, Jan. 26--Jean Rey, president of the European Common Market, said here today that he favored a "step-bystep procedure" to bring about Britain's eventual entry into the European community.
Earnings of Owens-Illinois, Inc., were down sharply in 1967, despite a rise in sales, the report disclosed yesterday.

A strike threatened by the state's 350 parole officers was averted early yesterday after eight hours of continuous negotiations established the basis for a settlement of differences, according to Nathan Grant, president of the Parole Officers Association.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP) --The new Peace and Freedom party petitioned the California Supreme Court today for a writ of mandate permitting it to run a complete ticket of candidates in this year's elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -The National Guard Bureau and the Army Reserve Office in the Pentagon have been directed to make a rapid but exhaustive study of the readiness of all their major combat and combat support units, authoritative sources disclosed today.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 26 (AP)--Six United States Governors arrived here today for a five-day visit as guests of the Israeli Government. They were John A. Volpe of Massachusetts. Warren P. Knowles of Wisconsin. Robert E. McNair of South Carolina, Hulett C. Smith of West Virginia, Charles L. Terry Jr. of Delaware and Ralph M. Paiewonsky of the Virgin Islands.

William J. Parks, an assistant tax officer for the Fiduciary Trust Company, has been appointed a tax officer, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Parks, who joined Fiduciary Trust in 1949, is a major in the United States Army Reserve who saw service in the Alaskan theater during World War II.
Treasury bills and other short-term securities advanced sharply in yesterday's credit market session, driving their interest rates down some more.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 27 -- A week-long cease-fire proclaimed by the Vietcong began early today and a half-hour later, South Vietnamese spokesmen said, enemy guerrillas attacked a Government militia post near Saigon.
Donald J. Speck has been named by the Crosby Corporation as vice president for products and market development, the distributor for the Fidelity Group of mutual funds announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--At first glance, it looks like the Walter Cronkite newsroom millions of Americans see on television every night.

MEGEVE, France, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Billy Kidd, the Olympic gold-medal hope of the American men's ski team, showed today that he was reaching his peak for the Olympics next month by capturing the second giant slalom of the international meet here.

SHARPSBURG, N. C., Jan. 26 (UPI)--Representative L. H. Fountain, Democrat of North Carolina, suffered cuts on his forehead and injuries to the right shoulder and chest in an automobile accident today. A spokesman at the Edgecombe General Hospital, where the 54-year-old Mr. Fountain was taken, said the injuries were not considered to be severe.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Defense Department officials said tonight that a Soviet intelligence -gathering vessel was shadowing the nuclear aircraft carrier Enterprise off the coast of South Korea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--President Johnson called on the North Koreans today to "recognize the gravity of the situation which they have created," to release the American intelligence ship Pueblo and her crew and to end their "course of aggression" against South Korea.

Negotiators for the United Steelworkers of America asked the union's president, I. W. Abel, yesterday to authorize strikes against the American Can Company and the Continental Can Company. Two weeks of negotiations failed to bring agreement on new contracts to replace those scheduled to expire at midnight next Wednesday.

ALGIERS, Jan. 26 -- Algeria will impose a state monopoly on the marketing of oil and gas, informed oil sources said here today. All foreign companies were told they would have to hand over their operations within 90 days, the sources added.
The appointment of John L. Bates, Charles F. Hayward, Howard C. Morgan and John D. Strong Jr. as vice presidents in the metropolitan division of the First National City Bank was announced yesterday.

The crisis over the seizure of the intelligence ship Pueblo interrupted some television schedules yesterday, first for the brief comment by President Johnson and then for the meeting of the United Nations Security Council.

The North Korean seizure of the United States naval vessel Pueblo was briefly debated in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday by a judge and a 27year-old Manhattan man he sentenced to three years for draft evasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) --The United States Information Agency said today that Barry Zorthian would stay on in Saigon as a special assistant to Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker. Mr. Zorthian, 50 years old, had been slated to transfer to Tokyo after four years as head of the U.S.I.A.'s operation in Vietnam.

The evidence that at least twice this month, after seizing South Korean vessels, North Korea had warned that it might also take countermeasures against nearby American "spy boats," raises serious questions about the American command and control system that permitted the Pueblo to be captured.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26--The executive director of the National Committee Against Mental Illness criticized private insurance companies and Blue Cross today on grounds that their policies did not provide adequate coverage for mental patients.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -The United States Conference of Mayors endorsed today President Johnson's request for a Federal tax increase.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- United States and British Amateur golf champion Bob Dickson chose his 24th birthday last night to announced his intention to become a professional.

Joseph J. Marcheso, a partner in the New York law firm of Christy, Bauman, Christy and Marcheso, has been elected a director of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, the bank announced yesterday.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 25-The Rotary Club of Vientiane held a soiree last Saturday night under the patronage of the Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, who needless to say is an honorary Rotarian.

The police said yesterday that Aloysius Bauman and Antonio Musachio, who were arrested Tuesday on conspiracy charges in the holdup of a Queens gas station manager and identified as cab drivers were in fact gypsy cab drivers. Drivers of gypsy cabs may carry passengers who call them at the drivers' places of business. They may not pick up passengers on the street as regular licensed cab drivers do.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26-Alvin A. Spivak, director of information for the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, said tonight that Dr. Etzioni was "apparently misinformed" about the use of social scientists by the commission.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Four people were killed here early today when an avalanche thundered down a mountain near this popular ski resort, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -The young president of the Perfect Film and Chemical Corporation was granted a patent this week for his permanent camera flash unit. Called the Perma-Cube. It is offered as a successor to the rotating cube, which has to be replaced after its four flashes are gone.

Peter Elser, a 47-year-old investment broker, was awarded yesterday the New York franchise in the North American Soccer League. The league was recently formed by the merger of the National Professional Soccer League and the United Soccer Association.
NORTH BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 25--A Columbia University sociologist charged here today that the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders was failing in its task.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26 (AP) -Stockholders of the Peabody Coal Company approved the sale of the concern to the Kennecott Copper Corporation at a special meeting here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- Following are excerpts from remarks delivered in the Security Council today by Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States representative, and, in unofficial translation, from those of Platon D. Morozov, the Soviet delegate:

The season's first performance of Donizetti's "L'Elisir d'Amore" will be given by the Metropolitan Opera on March 1, during the 24th week of the season. The cast will include Renata Scotto as Adina, Alfredo Kraus as Nemorino, Mario Sereni as Belcore and Fernando Corena as Dulcamara. Fausto Cleva will conduct.
An unemployed 37 - year - old man was arrested at Metropolitan Hospital last night and charged with attempting to poison his mother, a patient at the hospital.
The Director of the New York State Bureau of Narcotic Control accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of ignoring his department and the entire question of narcotics law enforcement.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 26--The United States today called a special meeting of the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to brief its European allies on the Pueblo crisis. Harlan Cleveland, the United States Ambassador, emphasized the gravity of the situation.
Mayor Lindsay signed a bill yesterday that will raise the cost of taxi rides here by about 25 per cent, beginning at 12:01 A.M. Monday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) --The Defense Department raised today the allowance it gives to families of dead servicemen to bury them.

In the vocabulary of power politics large nations are referred to as "powers," the assumption being that the truly important function of a nation is not the maintenance of law and order, nor the advancement of human welfare within its borders, but the exercise and expansion of power beyond its frontiers--to which function all others are necessarily subordinate.

Carl Yastrzemski, who has been spending the winter going up and down the countryside collecting awards for his baseball feats in 1967, was unable to be present yesterday to receive the Van Heusen Outstanding Achievement Award at the Americana Hotel.
BONN, Jan. 26--Twelve minors were killed today in an underground explosion that destroyed a 300-foot deep shaft of an iron-ore mine at Lengede, near Brunswick.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Jan 26 (AP) -- Four fires broke out and three cars were destroyed today as 800 coal miners resumed picketing at a nonunion mine. Fifty state troopers were brought in.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 26 (Reuters) -Australia scored 254 runs for the loss of six wickets today before darkness halted play 54 minutes early on the first day of the fourth and final India-Australia cricket test match. Australia made a strong start, but lost four wickets for the addition of only 23 runs late in the day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP)--The leader of a national legal defense organization that has been active in supporting civil rights said today his group was shifting its emphasis to defending the rights of all poverty-stricken groups, including Indians living on reservations.
BOSTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -Elgin Baylor, Archie Clark and Gail Goodrich teamed for 83 points tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers downed the Boston Celtics, 118-112.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 26 (UPI)--Lieut. Gen. James H. Gavin, retired, an opponent of the United States policy in Vietnam, said today he was "appalled" that a captured United States intelligence ship had no air cover. He advocated force if necessary to get the Pueblo back.
The United States ice hockey team, younger and heavier than last year's world tournament team, left yesterday to compete in the Winter Olympic Games at Grenoble, France, starting Feb. 6.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Rockefeller took two steps today that had the effect of shelving the proposal by his brother Laurance for the creation of a national park inside the state's sprawling Adirondack Park.

City and state mediators tried last night to avert a strike set for midnight tonight in 650 Manhattan and Bronx parking garages. The mediators said they would try to keep the parties talking "round-the-clock, if necessary."

BOYSTOWN, Neb., Saturday, Jan. 27, (UPI)--The head of Boys Town yesterday compared the handwriting of Commander Lloyd Bucher with a copy of the "confession" North Korea asserts he wrote and called the "confession" a "lousy, phony thing." The document was transmitted by press agenciese.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 26--The United States appealed to the Security Council today to obtain the safe return of the American intelligence ship Pueblo and her crew from North Korea and to restore the Korean armistice agreements to full effectiveness.
U.S. Industries, Inc., made an offer yesterday to buy all 423,476 outstanding shares of Wyatt Industries, Inc., Houston, at $54 a share in cash. The transaction would involve a total of $22,867,704.
MONTREAL, Jan. 26--Charles Frederick Wilson, who has been described as the mastermind of the biggest cash robbery in history, was ordered deported to Britain today.
Senator Jacob K. Javits called last night for a prompt Congressional inquiry into the Pueblo incident and other foreign policy issues.
Three records were set last night as Hunter College moved into a tie for first place in the Knickerbocker Basketball Conference with a 114-95 victory over Pratt at the winner's gym in the Bronx.
BUFFALO, Jan. 26 (AP)-Benny Russell, who spent the 1967 season as the Buffalo Bills' taxi-squad quarterback, was among the Air Force reserves called to active duty.
Portions of this Sunday's "The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour" have been elimininated by network censors as being in bad or questionable taste.

An East Harlem woman and her 6-year-old child were killed in a fire yesterday. The blaze started when an unidentified girl, holding a match as she looked under her bed for a shoe, set the mattress ablaze.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (Reuters)--Official sources in Tel Aviv tonight confirmed that the Dakar had disappeared, but issued no official statement.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 26--The favored Drambuie had to turn in the fastest mile of the Roosevelt Raceway meeting tonight to defeat Smart Money by three-quarters of a length in the second division of the second-round competition in the Early Bird Pacing Series.
The National Council on the Arts is planning to make grants that would enable small art museums across the country to present exhibitions with art works lent by major museums.
Antonio and the Ballets de Madrid will be presented by S. Hurok for two weeks starting Feb. 6 at the New York City Center.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 26--Thirty South-West African tribesmen were found guilty today of terrorism but will escape the death penalty.

The executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association acknowledged last night that the club owners had accepted an "unconditional agreement" to raise the minimum salary level to $10,000 and to grant other fringe benefits.
Roger D. Lapham Jr., president of Frank B. Hall Co. of California has been elected a director of the concern's parent company, Frank B. Hall Co., it was announced yesterday.
Prices came back a bit yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but volume declined.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- A noncommissioned Army officer and his wife received humanitarian awards from the Vatican today for adopting 12 racially mixed children and finding homes for 50 others.

OTTAWA, Jan. 26 (AP)--Foreign Minister Paul Martin suggested today that a United Nations representative be sent to North Korea to seek a peaceful settlement of the crisis over seizure of the American intelligence ship Pueblo.

Formation of a new cargo-security police squad to stem the mounting volume of freight thefts at Kennedy International Airport, where more than $2-million worth of goods was stolen last year, was disclosed yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (UPI) --Art Heyman scored 8 of his 31 points in the final 4 minutes tonight to spark the Pittsburgh Pipers to a 115-107 victory over the Minnesota Muskies. The victory moved the Pipers into a tie with the Muskies for the Eastern Division lead in the American Basketball Association.

MANY tournament players have an understanding that the lead of a jack against a no-trump contract denies possession of a higher honor. With a suit headed by acejack-ten or king-jack-ten the ten is led.

THE hurdy-gurdy is perhaps the humblest of musical instruments--always excepting the paper-and-comb, the jukebox, and the mighty Wurlitzer. Yet Haydn's Concerto No. 1 in C, as unlikely as it sounds, was scored, and this is where contemporary conventional musicians bleed a little, for a hurdy-gurdy.
One of off-Off Broadway's veteran playwrights -- a term that isn't the paradox it sounds since the movement is a good five years old -- is Leonard Melfi.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 (UPI) --Three game officials of the American Football League were among witnesses called today at a Federal grand jury investigation reportedly attempting to determine the roles of bookies in betting on professional and collegiate sports.
LONDON, Jan. 26--Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones, Britain's No. 1 women's tennis star, threatened today to boycott open tennis unless women got a bigger share of the prize money.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP)--Students posted a "declaration of indigestion" today and then placed about 30 trays of tuna casserole and squash on the floor at the administration hall at California Institute of Technology. The students, who said they did not like the food, left their lunches in front of the office of the president, Lee A. DuBridge, who was out of town.
The Federal Government has placed a lien of $3,627,870 for unpaid taxes against a man described as the mastermind of a $300-million a year narcotics operation.

The shortcomings of the private agencies that rate the credit status of municipalities have been underlined by Standard Poor's decision to discontinue the grading of cities for which it does not receive a fee.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (AP)-Two hundred chanting, flagwaving students, most of them of draft age, marched through downtown Pittsburgh today in support of war.
A $25-million plan for widening the busiest five-mile stretch of the Long Island Expressway in Queens from 6 to 10 lanes was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Gov. James A. Rhodes signed a Congressional redistricting bill today and sent it to the United States District Court in Cleveland, which had imposed a 4 P.M. deadline for today. The Governor's action followed approval early today of a plan ironed out in a 16-hour legislative session.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26--Jordan and Israel accused each other today of having touched off the shooting incident yesterday on the Allenby Bridge spanning the Jordan River. Two Red Cross officials were among those injured.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) --President Johnson praised today Gen. Wallace M. Greene Jr., retired Commandant of the Marine Corps, for his part in preparing America's marines now fighting below the demilitarized zone in Vietnam.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -Llewellyn E. Thompson, the United States Ambassador, made another trip today to the Soviet Foreign Ministry to seek Soviet intercession in the crisis over North Korea's seizure of the American intelligence ship Pueblo.
The Consumers Power Company reported yesterday new highs in sales of electricity and gas, revenues and net income for 1967.

COLOGNE, West Germany, Jan. 26--Cologne's sprawling fairgrounds have been turned this week into the world's biggest dwelling, whose dazzling decorations may set the trends in furnishing for the next two years.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26--The South Korean First Army, consisting of nineteen divisions of front-line troops facing North Korea, was ordered into full combat status today as casualties continned to rise in clashes with infiltration from North Korea.

The management of "Before You Go," the two-character comedy by Lawrence Holofcener, has decided to continue its run at the Henry Miller Theater for "at least another week." Peter Moreau and Jay Leff, the producers, had considered closing the show after tonight's performance.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 26-The second round of the $100,000 Los Angeles open today developed into a scoring jam for the lead. Billy Casper, Al Geiberger, Dave Marr, George Archer and Dave Stockton finished at the halfway mark with 36-hole aggregates of 137.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 (AP)--Mitey Prince led the race to the wire in the feature race at Pimlico today, but was disqualified for bothering the runner-up, Rockem Back, in the stretch.

The mass slaughter and even extinction of dinosaurs, aquatic reptiles and marine amphibians at different times in the last 600 million years might have been caused by huge doses of radiation bursting from bright stars that exploded relatively near the earth, two scientists said yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (Reuters) --The Board of Trade is considering whether the proposed merger should be referred to the Monopolies Commission, a Board of Trade spokesman said tonight. "This always happens with all mergers or proposed mergers if they would lead to a monopoly or if they would lead to taking over gross assets of more than 5-million," he said.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Fran Curci, a University of Miami assistant coach, accepted a three-year contract today as the head football coach at the University of Tampa. Curci succeeds Sam Bailey.

Sooner or later, every choral conductor of stature gets around to doing Bach's Mass in B minor if the resources for it are available, and last night Abraham Kaplan finally got his chance with the Collegiate Chorale.

Young Rubicam, the world's third-largest advertising agency with billings last year of about $400-million, announced yesterday that Edward L. Bond Jr., the 54-year-old president, had been made board chairman while remaining chief executive.

DANANG, Jan. 26 (UPI)-Both marines were promoted today--Lance Corporal Nelson going to Corporal and Private Roha to Lance Corporal--and orders were issued reassigning them to duty in the United States until their enlistments run out.
A series of discussions between the public and community business leaders will be flavored by demi-tasses of espresso romano on the house.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 26 (AP) -Four merging railroads and the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employes announced today an agreement aimed at assuring lifetime jobs, earnings and other benefits for some 10,000 workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Darold Knowles, one of the few major league athletes to be affected by President Johnson's reserve call-up, took the transfer to military life calmly today, even though the Washington Senator pitcher believes he may lose $100,000 in the process.

JULICH, West Germany, Jan. 26 -- Prof. Rudolf Schulten, one of West Germany's leading nuclear physicists, is the picture of a happy scientist these days -- his brainchild, a startlingly novel atomic reactor, has been operating without a hitch since before Christmas.
GENEVA, Jan. 26--The International Committee of the Red Cross said tonight it was making inquiries of the North Korea Red Cross concerning the crew of the Pueblo.

The 50th anniversary of the City Gardens Club of New York City, founded by a group of nature-loving Gramercy Park residents, will be celebrated Monday at a reception in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Melville, 1020 Fifth Avenue.

Civil Aeronautics Board hearings on what airlines will fly between six northern New England cities and Cleveland, Chicago and Detroit will open at Bedford, N. H., on Tuesday. The New England points are Presque Isle, Bangor and Portland, Me., Lebanon and Manchester, N. H., and Burlington, Vt. The three candidate airlines are Northeast, Mohawk and Trans-East.

TOKYO, Jan. 26 (AP)--Official broadcasts from Peking said today that the Pueblo had "put up an arrogant resistance" before she was captured by North Korean patrol craft. The broadcasts, breaking a four-day silence, echoed North Korean charges that the intelligence ship had intruded into North Korean territorial waters. This has been denied by the United States.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's televised report yesterday afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times:

OPELIKA, Ala., Jan. 26 (AP) --A Circuit Court jury that deliberated nearly three hours convicted Edward Seibold of murder today for the second time in six days and sentenced him to die in the electric chair.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 -- Two young United States marines told today of two weeks of captivity by the North Vietnamese, who, they said, tried to be friendly.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 26--Campaign aides of Gov. George Romney called today for prompt ruling by the Oregon Attorney General on whether Mr. Romney's Mexican birth bars him from the Presidency.
Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, said yesterday he supported President Johnson's efforts in attempting to recover the intelligence ship Pueblo.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Rockefeller has decided to endorse the proposals made this week by a state commission to broaden the authority of policemen and private citizens to shoot to kill when confronted by criminals and suspects.

PARIS, Jan. 26--The French Government was reported tonight to have reacted noncommittally so far to American requests for diplomatic support in the United Nations over the Pueblo affair. The requests are understood to have been made both here and at the Nnited Nations.
The American Cyanamid Company announced yesterday an immediate price cut of between 4 and 6.5 cents a pound for XT polymer, used in plastic bottles and containers.

Ramon Blanco of Venezuela made a successful debut in the United States last night when he scored a split decision over Mike Cruz of Puerto Rico in the 10-round main event between lightweights at the National Maritime Union Hall.

MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Angel Cordero Jr., the leading ridder at the meeting, rode three winners at Hialeah today to raise his victory string to 11 in nine days, three more than the runner-up, Ron Turcotte.
TOKYO, Jan. 26---North Korea warned today that if the "American imperialists take more high-handed measures" North Korea will be ready to adopt decisive counter-measures against them.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--A doctor who specializes in weight reduction said today he saw nothing wrong in accepting commissions from a drug company on its sales to doctors he had helped train.

SALVADOR, Brazil, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- A bus skidded off a highway into a lake near Conquista today and 13 passengers drowned. The bus was en route to Sao Paulo from Ilheus when it disappeared. Divers searched for the bodies.

A SPECIAL display of historic glassware--from an Egyptian goblet made more than 3,000 years ago to an English one made in 1959-was organized by the Corning Museum of Glass for the Winter Antiques Show. The show is open through tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street.

A steel girder, four feet long and a foot wide, fell eight floors yesterday at 1:55 A.M., landing on an unoccupied truck. No one was injured. The accident occurred at 165 Broadway at Fulton Street where a building is under demolition.

MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Government icebreakers succeeded yesterday in freeing the last two freighters caught in the ice of the St. Lawrence River, but feelings of bitterness against the icebreakers continued to rise in a flooded community 45 miles downstream from Montreal.

PARIS, Jan. 26--A man shot up from his white cube seat this morning in the Courreges haute-couture salon and began to peel off his trousers so fast the ladies around him didn't even have time to let out a gasp.

The Metropolitan Museum's Young Artists Series has long boasted a remarkably high talent average, and last night's guest performer did more than his share to maintain the standard. He was Tsuyoshi Tsutsumi, a Japanese cellist who has lived in the United States since 1961, studying with Janos Starker and teaching at Indiana University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -Some code changes have been made as a general precaution by the United States Navy and other Government agencies since the intelligence ship Pueblo was seized by North Korea Tuesday. American officials said today.

To augment their limited concert repertory, cellists sometimes have no other recourse than to write music for themselves. So Mihaly Virizlay, principal cellist of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, followed a time-honored tradition when he played his own Sonata for Unaccompanied Cello at his New York recital debut last night in Town Hall.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 27 (AP)-President Nguyen Van Thieu has granted leniency to nearly 500 political and other prisoners in South Vietnam in honor of Tet. the lunar new year, which begins Tuesday, his office announced today.
An anonymous donor has sent $5,750 to the Mayor's Commission on Youth and Physical Fitness to pay Robert S. Collier for working as a recreation leader at the Tompkins Square Community Center.

Eastern Airlines passenger traffic out of Newark Airport topped the million mark for the first time in 1967. The exact figure was 1,014,690 passengers, of whom 493,742 took shuttle flights to Boston or Washington, compared with a previous high of 844,852 in 1965, the company said.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Jan. 26 (AP)--Marc Hodler, Swiss president of the International Ski Federation, said today that manufacturers names were to be barred from all skis and ski poles used by competitors at the Grenoble Winter Olympics next month.
SHEFFIELD, England, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Wilson ran into noisy demonstrators against the Vietnam was here tonight when he arrived to make a speech about rent controls.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26 (AP)-Cazzie Russell scored 21 points in the final quarter tonight as the Knickerbockers staged a rally, but it wasn't enough as the St. Louis Hawks gained a 103-94 victory over New York in a National Basketball Association game.

MIAMI, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- A record price of $154,000 was paid for a colt called Raise A Dancer, a great-grandson of Native Dancer, as the annual Florida breeders sale ended last night. W. E. Kidd, a Baltimore investment banker, bought the colt from Charles F. Kieser.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP)-The Gulf American Corporation filed a $16-million suit today against Dow Jones, Inc., two aides of Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida, the director tor of the Florida Land Sales Board and a newspaper reporter.

LONDON, Jan. 26--The Admiralty announced tonight that the Israeli submarine Dakar had been reported missing in the eastern Mediterranean, about 150 miles north of Alexandria, United Arab Republic, and that an international search had begun.
KRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 26 (UPI)--Millard West, standing beneath a bronze statue of Abraham Lincoln, became the first Negro state trooper in the history of Kentucky today.
The fifth Family Planning Clinic to be run by a community antipoverty corporation and financed by the city's Human Resources Administration was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 22 men killed in action in Vietnam. The list included the following men, all of the Army: Specialist 4 Ronald A. Galante, of Ridgewood, Queens; Specialist 4 Ernest P. Palcic of Staten Island; Pfc. Peter L. Lovett of the Bronx and Specialist 4 Frederick A. Pine of Trenton.
Three major lumber associations reported a decrease of 9.2 per cent in the production for the week ended Jan. 20, compared with the level in the corresponding 1967 week.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (UPI) --The union is seeking a top minimum of $200 weekly for journeyman reporters and photographers, who currently receive $174. The newspaper assertedly offered a pay increase of $13.

A porter standing in the chill outside the Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday pointed inside and said: "Let the thermometer go down and we have a full house with them bums."
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 26 --Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman came to a six-state political workshop here today with a message to gladden the hearts of Farm Belt Democrats.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., obtained approval of its stockholders yesterday to proceed with a $500-million tender offer for the Greatamerica Corporation and its subsidiary, Braniff International Airways, Inc.
NORTHPORT, N. Y.--Mrs. Donald R. Clarke put on a peasant costume from the Harma region of her native Finland recently to be hostess at a voileipapoyta--a Finnish bread and butter table.

Willard W. Cole, president of Henry C. Lytton Apparel Stores, Chicago, subsidiary of Cluett, Peabody Co., has been elected president and chief operating officer of the retail stores division of Cluett, Peabody, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Cole also was elected a vice president of the parent company.
PARIS, Jan. 26--Two young American soldiers, armed and in uniform, drove a jeep from West Germany into France yesterday and asked for asylum as deserters.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 26 (UPI)--Billy Gaines, the former New Jersey high school star now running for the Santa Clara Youth Village, beat Charlie Greene for the third time in less than a month tonight in the 60-yard dash. Gaines won the event at the Athens invitation track and field meet in six seconds flat.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 26--Powerful support for new man-made monetary reserves came today from the National Bank of Belgium in a statement that challenges the gold theories of French President de Gaulle.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 26 (Reuters)--King Hussein of Jordan arrived today for a 10day state visit to Pakistan that will include talks with President Mohammad Ayub Khan about the situation in the Middle East.

SANTHA RAMA RAU'S adaption of E. M. Forster's "A Passage to India" was presented last night at 8:30 on the National Educational Television network -including Channel 13 here-in a superb British Broadcasting Corporation production.
The Theater Society of Long Island, a nonprofit organization formed 10 months ago to support year-round live theater in Mineola, announced plans yesterday to form its own repertory company.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 26 (AP)--The Netherland Gas Union, distributor of all natural gas found in Dutch fields, has ordered three gas turbines for a new compressor station from the Rotterdam Drydock Company, a member of the Dutch Rhine-Scheldt group of drydock, shipbuilding and engineering companies.

MUFULIRA, Zambia, Jan. 26 (Reuters)--Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, arrived here today from the Congo on his 12nation African tour. Mr. Brooke, the sole Negro in the United States Senate, drove from Lubumbashi, Katanga Province, accompanied by United States consular officials, to the Zambian border.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) --The Post Office Department plans to join the Government's campaign against cigarette smoking next month. The department will place on its trucks about 55,000 posters that say, "100,000 doctors have quit smoking cigarettes. Maybe they know something you don't."

The spectators will be watching Bob Seagren tonight in the 79th annual Boston Athletic Association indoor track meet at the Boston Garden. But the event that has fascinated the athletes themselves is the Lapham 1,000-yard run.
The stock market finished the week on the upside yesterday, with price advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering declines for the first time in six sessions.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a seat for $450,000, unchanged from the previous transaction.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 26--The South African terrorism trial and the North Korean incident have provided a stormy introduction to the Security Council Presidency for Agha Shahi of Pakistan.

VASTERAS, Sweden, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Diane Towler and Bernard Ford of Britain, twice world champions, won their third straight dance title today in the European figure skating championships.

ATLANTA, Jan. 26 (AP) -The number of deaths from pneumonia and influenza continued to increase throughout much of the nation during the third week in January, the National Communicable Disease Center reported today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (AP)--The head of South Vietnam's pacification program has submitted his resignation from the army, a spokesman for the Vietnamese Joint General Staff said today.

WIRES of brokerage houses were buzzing yesterday with news of Freeport Sulphur's mineral finds in Australia and Indonesia. The market had already responded when the reports started making the rounds. The stock just kept going up.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 26 (AP)--King Frederik IX today named Hilmer Baumsgaard, spokesman of the Radical Liberal party, to try to form a new government after the election defeat of Premier Jens Otto Krag's Social Democratic regime.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 26 -- A small nuclear device threw soil and rock high into the air today when the Atomic Energy Commission set off a detonation 170 feet in the earth as part of its program to find peaceful uses for nuclear explosives.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26--Superior Court Judge Richard Schauer refused today to order the return to Louisiana of Lawrence Howard Jr. one of three Californians sought by the New Orleans District Attorney, Jim Garrison, in his inquiry into the assassination of President Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -Imports increased about $l50million in December to a record high and exports dipped by almost $l00-million, the Commerce Department reported today.

Judge Irving I. Schreckinger of the Bronx Criminal Court spent most of yesterday afternoon in a midtown Manhattan screening room viewing two allegedly obscene films, "Infidelity, American-Style" and "Housewives on Call." The films had been seized by the police at the Square Theater in the Bronx Dec. 9.
Soybeans and grains futures continued to rise yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade because of tension over North Korea.
Tonnage and dollar value of United States imports of steel set records last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

President Johnson's call-up of Reserves has had little apparent effect nationally on business and industry so far. Only the individuals involved and their families have been disrupted to a great extent.

GENEVA, Jan. 26--The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that it would supervise no further exchanges of civilians between Israel and Jordan until the safety of its representatives was guaranteed by "all the responsible authorities."

MIAMI, Jan. 26--The defending champion, Dick Stearns of Chicago, sailed his new fiberglass Star Class sloop past Tom Blackaller's boat an instant before they crossed the finish line today in the final race of the Bacardi Cup series.
NEWARK, Jan. 26--Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois supported tonight President Johnson's effort to exhaust diplomatic negotiations before other courses are taken to rescue the Pueblo.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 26 (UPI)--Avalanches trapped a passenger train with 83 passengers near Iatvan, in eastern Turkey, last night, reports reaching Istanbul said today. Heavy snow prevented rescue parties from reaching the train today. Military planes dropped food and blankets to the passengers.

The State Conservation Department has put forward some poor reasons for opposing Laurance Rockefeller's proposal to create a national park in the heart of the Adirondack Forest Preserve. Nevertheless, its objections have achieved the desirable result of postponing this project as well as intensifying public debate on it.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 26 (AP) --Commander Bucher's wife said the picture transmitted from North Korea resembled her husband but said: "It is impossible to be sure."

No name graces the plain paneled door that leads to a suite of offices in a corner of the fourth floor of 521 Fifth Avenue. There is not even a listing for it on the big directory in the marbled lobby of the office building at 43d Street.

A single-engine seaplane made an emergency landing in the Hudson River near 125th Street yesterday afternoon because of a frozen fuel line. Neither the pilot, Louis Haslbeck of Little Ferry, N. A flock of brilliantly colored metallic birds was suspended from the ceiling of the Pierre's Grand Ballroom last night, where some 700 guests attended the annual Petroushka Ball to aid the Russian Children's Welfare Society.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (Reuters) --The Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic signed a trade protocol today calling for up to the equivalent of $312million worth of exchanges this year. Many of the techniques of 19th-century fiction -- spaciousness, a coherent theme, subplotting, touches of allegory -- are hardly possible in modern fiction. Eunice Luccock Corfman displaces them with adjacent techniques that perform similar service -abrupt cutting, irony, antiheroics, distortions of perception. The resulting book is trenchant and superb.

It is no cause for alarm that in Denmark a leader of a party critical of his country's participation in NATO has been asked to form a new Government, and no surprise that the political weight has simultaneously shifted to the right. Hilmar Baunsgaard is unlikely to try to take Denmark out of the alliance and his effort to govern with a center-right coalition would collapse if he advocated such a move.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- The French submarine Minerve disappeared in the Mediterranean with 52 men aboard yesterday about 25 miles southeast of the naval base of Toulon. No trace of the craft had been found tonight.

Simon and Garfunkel, those artful troubadours to the college set, performed at Carnegie Hall Saturday night. The singers offered a recital of their established hits along with a sprinkling of Mr. Simon's new compositions.
LISBON, Jan. 28 -- The President of Portugal sailed this evening for Portuguese Guinea, where there is considerable guerrilla activity.

The Hospitals Department will seek a $1-million renovation of Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, whose administrators deplored the institution's overcrowding and disrepair in a recent letter to the Bellevue Medical Board.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Scott Pyles of Frisco, Colo., took the men's downhill race today as the United States captured one gold medal and one bronze on the final day of the 1968 Winter World Student Games.

" Business Needs You," a second annual forum to help, and perhaps inspire, the mature woman to return to work was held here last week. Once again, more than 1,100 women packed the auditorium of Stern Brothers department store, as they did a year ago.

Leonard Cohen is fairly young -- 33 years old -- Canadian, Jewish, and very, very sad. On the ailenation scale, he rates somewhere between Schopenhauer and Bob Dylan, two other prominent poets of pessimism.

Members of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms are going to hire 50 high school dropouts beginning next month and, with the help of the city's Human Resources Administration, train them for jobs as typists, clerks and stenographers.

Police emergency crews and scuba divers searched the waters of the Narrows yesterday for the body of a 10-year-old girl presumed drowned with five members of her family in an auto accident late Saturday
The value of contracts for future construction -- one of the prime economic indicators -- has signaled a possible downturn in building activity during 1968.

A LEGEND came face to face with reality at the Theater de Lys last night. The legend was the Truman Capote and Harold Arlen musical, "House of Flowers." On Broadway this house never found a home; it opened at the end of 1954 and managed 165 performances.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- A nostalgia that lingers among some Russians, mainly of the older generation, for the hero-leadership days of Stalin has been expressed in verse by a Soviet poet, Feliks Chuyev.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 28 (AP) -- John Balfanz of Denver, the top man on America's Olympic team, won the 21st annual Blackhawk ski-jumping tournament at Tomahawk Ridge today.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Ramon C. Sanft, 22 years old, knew even while recovering from wounds he suffered in Vietnam that he would face deportation from the United States upon getting out of the Marine Corps.

FROGMORE, S. C., Jan. 28 -- At the first meeting of its kind ever held in South Carolina, about 100 grassroots-level Negroes unanimously adopted today a resolution calling for all black people to work together on problems of education.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 -- American marines upset a North Vietnamese ambush near the demilitarized zone yesterday, touching off a fierce battle that lasted two and a half hours, a Marine spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Johnson Administration, confident that it has a strong legal case in the capture of the intelligence ship Pueblo by North Korea, solicited diplomatic support today but continued its military build-up in case no diplomatic solution materialized.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- President Johnson attended the annual Roman Catholic red mass for the nation's lawyers today.
Taxicab riders will be greeted today with window stickers listing fares about 25 per cent higher than those in force until last night.

Two Democratic Representatives from New York State urged yesterday the closing of what they regard as loopholes in Federal income tax laws so as to ease the burden on low-income and middle-income taxpayers.

PITTSBURGH, Monday, Jan. 29 -- Thousands of members of the United Mine Workers Union went on strike in the Western Pennsylvania coal fields at midnight yesterday, protesting the use of state police to put down mass picketing in a union organizing dispute. Picket lines went up at scores of mines.
INZELL, West Germany, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Erhard Keller of West Germany set a world speed skating record today in winning the 500-meter race in 39.2 seconds.

Dr. Benjamin Spock and the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., two of five antiwar figures who face charges in Boston Federal Court today on advising young men how to evade the draft, reiterated yesterday their objections to the American position in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- George C. Wallace, former Governor of Alabama, will carry his third-party Presidential campaign north and west from his home state this week with a four-state, 20-station television appeal for votes, funds and workers.
The Treasury securities market, which rose last week despite the Pueblo crisis, this week expects to find out the Government's plans for its next major financing operation.
HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- The Cuban Communist party announced today that nine members of a pro-Soviet "micro-faction" in the party would be tried as "traitors to the revolution."
NASHUA, N. H., Jan. 26 -Eighteen women sat in the redcarpeted living room of Emile Chagnon's gray ranch-type home at 19 Ashland Street the other day waiting for Gov. George Romney.

ROSENDALE, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- Operating under a damp coastal-type overcast, the Rosendale Nordic Ski Club ended its two-day jamboree today with Per Coucheron, a Norwegian - bred graduate student from Dartmouth, named the Class A winner.
The outlook for labor peace in New York City in 1968 is not very bright, Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the New York State Board of Mediation, said yesterday.

The chairman of the Fort Greene antipoverty agency in Brooklyn has resigned on demand of fellow board members, who have been angered by his criticism of the board as ineffective and his proposal to city and Federal officials for a new community election.

Walter Kidde Co., Inc., expects to acquire United States Lines as a "building block" for an extensive and possibly world-wide system of intermodal transportation, Kidde's chief executive officer said yesterday.

" We are working with an investment house on the Street on a refinancing program," Robert E. Healy said Friday. The chief executive of the Interpublic Group of Companies since November added, "We're in the process of working out an arrangement."

Bill Cosby took a full house at Philharmonic Hall last night on an uproarious tour of North Philadelphia and a brief exploration of the Bible. He appeared on a program with the Pair Extraordinaire, a vocal and instrumental duo.
The city announced yesterday that it would begin removing controls late next month from apartments that rented for $250 or more a month on April 1, 1965.
Interest rates, ranging from short-term Treasury securities to long-term tax-exempt bonds, continued to decline yesterday.
Grove Press has obtained the American book and magazine rights to the memoirs of H. A. Philby, the former British counter-intelligence official who spied for the Soviet Union.

The Competitive Capital Fund filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of five million shares priced at $10. Hayden, Stone, Inc., will be the principal underwriter for the new mutual fund.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Dean Rusk retells the story of Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego:

TRENTON, Jan. 30 -- The Republican majority in the State Senate today brought back the old practice of, senatorial courtesy, a controversial system under which a Senator could secretly blackball nominations by the Governor.
A gunman was shot to death yesterday afternoon after wounding a policeman and holding up three liquor stores in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn within a 30-minute period.

THE time for making Seville orange marmalade is at hand once again and the season is all too short. The oranges are available this week at Martin's Fruit Shop, 1264 Third Avenue (at 73d Street) for $2.40 to $3.50 a dozen, depending on the size. Charles Co., 340 Madison Avenue (at 43d Street) expects a shipment next week.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. asked today for a rise in the sales tax to provide $400-million to improve education and reduce property taxes.

Dr. Avraham Biran, Israeli Director of Antiquities and Museums, said yesterday in New York that "we have done everything to facilitate the work of the American Schools of Oriental Research in Jerusalem."

Negro athletes, with few exceptions, have agreed to boycott the New York Athletic Club's indoor track meet. In many cases, colleges have told their athletes to decide for themselves whether they will compete.
THE over-the-counter market is taking new steps to cope with soaring volume.
WASHINGTON, Jan 29 -- A new wave of embarrassing disclosures of illegal "bugging" by the Justice Department is expected to follow a Supreme Court ruling issued today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- When Samuel Maurice Cohn joined the Math Club at the Simon Gratz High School in Philadelphia in the nineteen-thirties, his future was determined. His interest in economics had already been stimulated by the fact that the school had been named for a descendant of a financier of the American Revolution.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 29 -- Washington has agreed to accelerate material aid for the South Korean effort to counter an intensified espionage and subversion campaign directed by North Korea, Defense Minister Sung Eun Kim disclosed today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- The United States is prepared to discuss all aspects of the Korean dispute with North Korea provided the men from the Pueblo are not held as hostages during the talks.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Millions of Asians observed Tet, the lunar new year, with firecrackers and celebrations today.

GRENOBLE, France, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Peggy Fleming, America's two-time world champion, and other figure skaters complained today about the color of the ice at the Stade de Glace, where the Olympic gold medals wil be decided, starting Feb. 7.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- A profesional National Tennis League has been formed by George MacCall of Los Angeles, the former Davis Cup captain.

TOKYO, Jan. 29 -- Observers here are unable to find a satisfactory explanation precisely why North Korea seized the American intelligence ship Pueblo last week, but they feel sure that the action is one manifestation of the state of division, stalemate and frustration now afflicting the Pyongyang regime.
The application of the European plan to ocean travel was announced here yesterday by Diners-Fugazy Sales Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Except for water pollution control, a major hold-down in spending for conservation of natural resources is reflected in the President's budget today.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will file with the Federal Communications Commission within the next few days a proposal to increase sharply the rates it charges television and radio broadcasters for use of lines to carry their programs. The new rates would go into effect April 1.

In an expansion of its activities in real estate brokerage, cooperative sales and residential management, the Arthur-Hardgrove Company, Inc., has added a number of brokers and sales personnel and has appointed John D. Cook to head the company's management department.

President Johnson's Budget Message to Congress yesterday contained the expected cuts in appropriations for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and grants for the construction of facilities for noncommercial television stations.

The merger of the United Hunts Racing Association and the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association was announced here yesterday by Thomas H. McKoy Jr. and F. Eugene Dixon Jr., the chairman and president, respectively, of the steeplechase association.
ONLY a record goal-scoring pace has kept the Boston Bruins at or near the top in the National Hockey League's East Division.

Canadian dollars, traded actively yesterday in moderate business on New York's foreign exchange market, fluctuated from a low of 92.09 United States cents to a crest of 92.18 and closed at 92.11 cents for a 6-point advance over the close last week.
GENEVA, Jan. 29 -- The World Health Organization reported today that the plague had spread in South Vietnam in "epidemic proportions."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- President Johnson's Budget Message to Congress today estimates there will be 82.1 billion pieces of mail in 1968 and 85.2 billion pieces in 1939. This would be an increase of 3.8 per cent over previous years but less than the rates of the last two years.
Taxicabs were in plentiful supply here yesterday as new fare rates went into effect, raising the cost of a ride about 25 per cent.

The New York City Opera will open its 47th season on Thursday evening, Feb. 22, when Julius Rudel conducts a double - bill of Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex" and Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana" at the New York State Theater.

On the eve of pro football's annual draft of college players, the New Orleans Saints traded their regular quarterback Gary Cuozzo, yesterday to the Minnesota Vikings for two first- round choices, one to be used today and the other in 1969.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 29 -- The Appellate Division of Rhodesia's High Court was divided today on the legal status of Prime Minister Ian P. Smith's Government, although a majority held that it was the government in fact -- de facto -- in internal affairs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Department of Defense and colleges and universities across the country are lobbying for a change in new and controversial draft regulations relating to graduate students.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The United States and the Soviet Union spent approximately the same percentage of their gross national product on military expenditures in 1965, the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency reported today.

A CONDENSED version of John Osborne's play "Luther," which was seen on Broadway in 1963, had many moments of forceful eloquence last night in a televi sion adaptation starring Robert Shaw over the American Broadcasting Company network. But the pressures of the clock so common to TV, including the unfortunate commercial interruptions, ultimately caused the study of the Reformation leader to lose momentum.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday a new computer, Model 85, that can process data up to three times faster than the next largest model in its System 360 line.

The intensely competitive quest for new pop music groups starts with the professional connoisseurs, who make their rounds of club, coffee house and campus with the fidelity of postmen and the discriminating eye of diamond merchants.
Film rights to "Mame," now in its second year at the Winter Garden, will bring what is beieved to be the second highest, price to be paid for a Broadway musical, next to "My Fair Lady."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Reversing a downward trend of recent years, spending on atomic weapons will increase substantially next year, largely because of the need to produce hundreds of nuclear warheads for a missile defense system.
Indrani and the Dancers of India will appear Friday and Saturday at the Hunter College Playhouse in a program of Indian dance.
Silver futures dropped yesterday on the Commodity Exchange and dragged down the prices of metals such as platinum and palladium on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- Dr. Benjamin Spock, the author and pediatrician, and the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., chaplain of Yale University, were arraigned today in Federal District Court with three other defendants on a charge of conspiring to help young men evade the draft laws.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- The man Mayor Lindsay has picked to lead the city's battle against dirty air, dirty streets and dirty waters keeps at the back of his mind -- like a horrible object lesson -- the image of those mounds of garbage known as kitchen middens that were left behind by pre-historic man.
The National Steel Corporation, one of the nation's six largest steel producers, announced yesterday a 3.2 per cent decline in profits in 1967 on a 3.1 per cent dip in sales.

Since George Washington's day the Senate has refused to confirm Presidential nominations to Federal office when objection is raised by the Senators of the state immediately concerned. William Howard Taft, speaking from rueful experience, said: "The appointing power is in effect in their [the Senators] hands, subject only to a veto by the President."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee threw his support behind a tax increase today, but he said that Congress must first trim President Johnson's budget.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29 -- Two South Vietnamese Army officers dismissed from Government positions last fall on corruption charges have been placed in desirable army jobs, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Forty-six bus companies failed to convince the Supreme Court today that airlines were violating Federal aviation law by flying military personnel at half fare.
HOWIE JONES, the Boys High basketball coach, went skiing at Stowe, Vt., last weekend because, he said, "I need a change of pace from basketball, it's making me grayer by the day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The President's Consumer Advisory Council condemned today what it called the practice of "tricking" charge account customers into buying credit life insurance.

Mayor Lindsay called last night for the abolition of the 312-year-old city marshal system and said the city would make an annual profit of $750,000 if the marshals' duties were transferred to the city Sheriff's office.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Johnson proposed today a sharp cut in the Maritime Administration budget that would stretch out the naion's subsidized ship construction program by one year.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 -- Israeli security forces today arrested 71 persons suspected of belonging to an underground terrorist organization in the Gaza Strip.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Maternal and infant care, mental health and efforts to cope with the rising spiral of medical costs get high priority in the health portion of the proposed Federal budget.

Alfred A. Giardino, president of the Board of Education, 250 high school students, representatives of parent-teacher groups, and principals and teachers from 20 high schools will attend a special performance of the avant-garde "Hamlet" at 1:30 P.M. today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Johnson reaffirmed, today the hope that Americans would reach the moon next year and pledged not to "abandon the field of planetary exploration."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Supreme Court declined today to review an appeal that charged the Miami law firm of Smathers Thompson with violating legal ethics by switching sides from a small client to a wealthy adversary.

The American Electric Power System became in 1967 the first investor-owned electric utility to sell more than 50-billion (B) kilowatt hours of electricity in a single year. Donald C. Cook, president, said electric sales reached a new high of 50.1-billion kilowatt hours, or 12.3 per cent more than in 1966.
A spokesman for scheduled airline industry contended yesterday that the nation's air carriers were "not greatly concerned" at the loss of pilots in the current call-up of military reservists.
LENINGRAD, Jan. 29 -- An auctioneer sang out, "$5.60, $5.60, $5.60 -- any more? Upstairs $5.70. Five dollars and seventy cents." The gavel banged.

President Johnson's budget for fiscal 1969 is presented in an entirely new form covering all Federal receipts and expenditures. Unlike the three different budgets that proved so confusing and misleading in the past, the new unified form provides a reasonably comprehensive picture of the Administration's economic plans and expectations.
ROME, Jan. 29 -- Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, South African heart transplant pioneer, received today the congratulations of Pope Paul VI for his surgical advances.

WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 29 -- Michael Gale, whose stable has produced sporadic winners at Roosevelt Raceway in the last 10 years, agreed today to the request by John Cashman Jr., the racing secretary, to remove his three horses from the grounds within three days.

Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., is negotiating the sale of 113,000 shares of stock in Austin, Nichols Co. to the Bohemian Distributing Company, a privately held wholesale liquor distributor based in Los Angeles.

The Associated Press story in The Times of Jan. 15 stating that the town of Medford, Ore., had "passed an ordinance prohibiting glue sniffing and deliberate inhaling of poisonous vapors" makes it apparent that they are attacking the effect and not the cause, at least in this instance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- President Johnson moved today to ease the effects of last summer's Arab-Israeli war on oil supplies to petroleum refineries in the United States.

The stock market started off on a strong note yesterday but finished on a weak one. Price advances were well ahead of declines in the first hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange but the margin faded steadily as the session continued.
Preventing the common cold, heading off influenza epidemics before they really get started and squelching a virus infection in its very early stages are all hopes.

ATHENS, Jan. 29 -- The Greek regime tonight dropped the charges of defiance of martial law and of insulting the authorities that it had brought against Mrs. Helen Vlachos, conservative publisher of two Athens newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Federal Reserve Board today proposed four technical changes in the method by which banks compute their required reserves, with the aim of more certainty and less money market fluctuation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 30 -- Vietcong raiders drove into the center of seven major Vietnamese cities early today, burning Government buildings, freeing prisoners from provincial jails and blasting military installations and airfields with rockets and mortars.

The embroilment of the Pueblo, the intelligence-gathering ship, off the coast of Korea cannot be dismissed as a miscalculation on the part of the Communist captors. Within the labyrinthine Communist logic there was room to plan and execute the hijacking of the American vessel on the high seas.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 27 -- "Always beware of the nearest sword," a Burmese proverb warns. The nearest sword for Burma belongs to Communist China and now with the Peking radio calling for the overthrow of the military regime of General Ne Win, it seems to have been unsheathed.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 29 (UPI) -- The Green Bay Packers' coach, Vince Lombardi, invited newsmen today to a dinner and news conference here Thursday.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 29 -- A tentative agreement was reached today in a Long Island school bus strike, which has affected 55,000 public and parochial school pupils since Jan. 15.

The New York Knickerbockers, with a chance to regain fourth place in the Eastern Division, meet the Baltimore Bullets tonight at 9 o'clock in the second half of a National Basketball Association double- header at Madison Square Garden.
The shutdown of 650 struck garages here caused thousands of motorists inconvenience yesterday, but the vision of drivers on a treadmill searching for parking space never developed.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller described himself today as a man on a tightrope when it comes to taking positions on international issues.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A suspected Army deserter is really in Vietnam, the Army admitted today and apologized for its error.

" WHO'S WHO, BABY?" is nowhere, man. The show that opened last night at the Players Theater starts out as a spoof of a drippy musical, and in about five minutes becomes irrevocably the thing it is supposed to be spoofing.

The first major project of Operation Pyramid, a campaign in which 1,000 men and women will be responsible for raising $100 each, has been started by the American Foundation of Religion and Psychiatry.

Prompted in part by a surge of complaints during the recent cold spell from girls who were barred from school because they wore slacks, the New York Civil Liberties Union has prepared a five-page memorandum on alleged violations of student rights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Johnson presented to Congress today a budget of $186.1-billion -- the biggest ever and one that he said required a tax increase to reduce the deficit and the Government's need to borrow.
It is urgent that Governor Rockefeller instruct his Public Service Commission to comply with recent Supreme Court rulings and accept jurisdiction over gas pipeline routes in New York State.

The Interpublic Group, the world's largest advertising concern, is negotiating to sell a 30 per cent interest in its business as part of a $10-million refinancing program, William Taggart, chief financial officer of the company, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Supreme Court declined today to review a third appeal brought by James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, to challenge his conviction for jury tampering.

HOW long does it take to make a ballet company Or, to be more specific, how long does it take to make a ballet company with wares worth showing in New York? It seems that with the Pennsylvania Ballet company, which last night opened a week's season at the New York City Center, the answer must be five or fewer years.
Former Vice President Richard M. Nioxn said yesterday he would disclose his decision Thursday on whether he would seek his party's nomination for President.
GRENOBLE, France, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Women athletes from 38 countries started arriving in France today for the Winter Olympics amid speculation about the sex test.
The table above shows the over-all budget totals under the new unified accounting system, begun in the 1969 budget, with previous years' budgets recalculated on the new basis, to permit comparisons.

The Westchester County Planning Commissioner has been appointed general manager of the recently established State Parks Commission for the City of New York, which plans to build at least six parks here.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 29 -- The principal of the Brien McMahon High School made a class-by-class inspection of haircuts today and then suspended 53 boys whose hair he said was too long.

THE declarer in a no-trump contract usually develops his longest combined suit immediately, but considerations of timing can make it necessary to postpone normal suit development. A fine example of this type of play was reported by George Partos of New York from a recent game at the Evander Bridge Club, which holds duplicate games each Thursday night at 840 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A net loss of $1,960,000 is expected in the operation of the St. Lawrence Seaway for the fiscal year starting July 1, making an accumulated deficit of $26,937,000.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Virginia Senate passed today a bill to permit localities to vote on whether they wanted the sale of whisky by the drink. The vote was 24 to 16.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday it had agreed to acquire the Pennsylvania Glass Sand Corporation through an exchange of shares worth about $112-million.
PARIS, Jan. 29 -- Yves Saint Laurent and Coco Chanel didn't set the fashion world on fire today with their new spring-summer collections, but there was certainly more smoke in his salon than in hers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King, America's tennis queen from Long Beach, Calif., captured the Australian women's national singles title today by overwhelming Mrs. Margaret Smith Court of Australia, 6-1, 6-2. She thus won the first of the four world championships making up the grand slam.
Faced by an embarrassment of talent, Leonard Bernstein decided not to decide at last night's New York Philharmonic concert at Philharmonic Hall.

HOUSTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Elvin Hayes scored a season high of 48 points tonight and led the University of Houston, the nation's No. 1 college basketball team, to a 108-76 victory over the Fairfield (Conn.) Stags.
MADRID, Jan. 29 -- Spain cracked down today on rebellious students, arresting about 100 of them and punishing thousands of others by increasing tuition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -Consumers, as taxpayers, will pay more for clean meat in the years ahead, even if their actual meat bill doesn't go up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Administration believes that a rapidly growing economy this year will increase individual incomes substantially and also relieve the "profit squeeze" that hit business last year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Johnson plans a moderate increase in Federal assistance to the poor in the coming year, with training and employment rating a high priority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren can spend $10.000 on his automobile next year, but House Speaker John W. McCormack will be able to splurge with $14,000. The widows of lighthouse keepers will receive $509,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The United States appeared reconciled today to the likelihood that diplomatic efforts to free the 83-man crew of the intelligence ship Pueblo, held by North Korea, would take at least two or three weeks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The new budget presented today by President Johnson manages to salvage some growth for research in the face of many constraints.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A request for $2.92-billion for the basic foreign aid program went to Congress today in the Administration's budget estimates for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- New York City would get a new post office for Murray Hill and some additional money to deepen ship anchorages in the harbor under President Johnson's proposed budget.

FREIBURG, West Germany, Jan. 29 -- The Free Democrats, West Germany's only parliamentary opposition party, opened their 19th annual congress here today with an "extraparliamentary opposition" of 1,000 demonstrators at the door.
Manuel Santana, one of the world's top amateur players, said yesterday he would bypass professional tennis and the first Wimbledon open tournament this year.

A "Salute" supper ball to benefit the United States Olympic Committee will be held at the Tavern on the Green next Monday following the premiere of the movie "Olympic Torch" at the Plaza Theater. The film stars the ski champion, Toni Sailer.
A check with the ad men at magazines yesterday showed that while generally the year is beginning gloomily there is a glimmer of hope.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court refused today to examine the appeal of a citizen group that contends racial discrimination was practiced in the routing of a highway through a Negro district in Nashville, Tenn.

More than 4,000 persons filled Manhattan Center last night to pay tribute to Dr. Benjamin Spock and Michael Ferber. They heard addresses that sharply scored the Johnson Administration's Vietnam policy and what was described as its attempts to repress the anti-draft movement.
BERLIN, Jan. 29 -- East Germany said today that Moscow had submitted to Bonn a draft treaty for the renunciation of the use of force between the Soviet Union and West Germany.
The 14-story apartment house with a penthouse at 1160 Park Avenue, at the northwest corner of 92d Street, has been converted to cooperative ownership in a transaction involving more than $4-million.
Retailers here sought yesterday to plug the "believability gap" that prevents many Negro college graduates from exploring career opportunities in the service industries, particularly retailing.
Community leaders in the six New York slum precincts with the city's largest number of reported crimes of violence called yesterday for major new city, state and Federal programs to reduce crime.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- President de Gaulle has defined French military strategy for many years to come as that of "all azimuths," meaning the ability to reply to attack from any quarter by delivering nuclear weapons to any point on earth.

American League baseball teams will give up a total of 60 players to stock the new Kansas City and Seattle franchises, which begin play in 1969, it was announced here last night by Joe Cronin, the league president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The United States has directly informed North Vietnam that it would be willing to stop bombing North Vietnamese territory and talk peace if Hanoi did not take advantage of this move to raise the infiltration of men and supplies to South Vietnam beyond "normal" levels.
DENVER, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A gunman in a supermarket holdup was arrested and his four hostages were rescued unharmed today after the gunman had spent a wild day trying to escape.
Ten policemen pleaded not guilty at a hearing yesterday to charges of violating Police Department rules by accepting Christmas gratuities.
Carl Yastrzemski yesterday added to the many baseball honors he has recently received by winning the S. Rae Hickok Professional Athlete of the Year award.

THULE AIR FORCE BASE, Greenland, Jan. 29 -- "Go inside and don't touch anyone," the Air Force sergeant with a revolver on his hip says at the hangar door to a visitor returning from the site where four hydrogen bombs were blown into pieces eight days ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Johnson's $79.8-billion defense budget that went to Congress today represents an increase of about $3-billion over expected spending for the current fiscal year.
Mayor Lindsay helped dedicate yesterday a middle-income apartment cooperative in Yorkville and a moderate-income housing development on the Lower East Side.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Johnson's new budget, assuming passage of his requested tax increase, contemplates total Government borrowing in the 1969 fiscal year of $8-billion, of which $4-billion would be in the form of participation certificates.
MIAMI, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Lucretia Bori closed with a rush between horses today to beat Guest Room by a head in the $25,000 added Jasmine Stakes at Hialeah.
The letter "Frozen Hudson Cited" (Jan. 20) bothered me sufficiently to take me to the records of The Old Farmer's Almanac to see what I could learn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- -- President Johnson proposed substantial increases today in three controversial programs -- public housing, rent supplements and model cities -- in an effort to begin construction of 300,000 homes and apartments for low and moderate income families in the fiscal year 1969.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Army said today it would sharply reduce its controversial, multi-million dollar support of civilian marksmanship clubs affiliated with the National Rifle Association. It said it would cut to "near zero" sales, loans and gifts to N.R.A.-affiliated groups of .30 and .45 caliber military weapons and ammunition.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said last night that he had decided not to run for the United States Senate.
Fires in Brooklyn and on the Lower East Side claimed the lives of three women, a child and a teen-ager late last night and early this morning.
