WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -- The United States put new defense orders for British industry into cold storage today pending a review of all contracts for military equipment awarded to British manufacturers.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 30 -- Israeli and Egyptian forces exchanged artillery fire across the Suez Canal today in a dispute over the clearance project that began Saturday for the release of 15 vessels trapped in the waterway since June.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Raul Cespedes was taken by ambulance to Arcadia Methodist Hospital today following a spill in the seventh race at Santa Anita race track, where Willie Shoemaker broke a leg one week ago in a similar mishap.

FREIBURG, West Germany, Jan. 30 -- The Free Democratic party, whose 50 deputies make up the opposition in the 518-member Bundestag or lower house of the Bonn Parliament, took a gingerly step to the left today in hopes of gaining votes in next year's federal election.
The Uniformed Sanitationmen did not strike yesterday in their contract dispute with the city, but they did put ino effect a policy of strict adherence to previously unenforced safety rules.

OTTAWA, Jan. 30 (Canadian Press) -- A highly placed informant said today that a Canadian destroyer chased a Soviet submarine halfway across the Atlantic in 1965 and forced it to seek refuge at Tangier, Morocco.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The state's welfare rolls have increased sharply since the introduction of Medicaid largely because many persons were informed of their right to welfare payments while enrolling in the health program, a joint legislative committee was told today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 31 -- A 17-man Vietcong squad seized parts of the United States Embassy in the center of Saigon and held them for six hours early today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Willie Mays, who had his worst major league season in 1967, signed a contract for $125,000 today to play center field with the San Francisco Giants for his 18th season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today to re-examine the Administration's account of the Gulf of Tonkin incidents by calling Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara for further testimony.
SOUTHAMPTON, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Coast Guard reported today that two Soviet fishing vessels were fishing 65 to 70 miles southeast of here in violation of a treaty.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A spokesman for the nation's smaller airlines accused the large trunk airlines today of trying to squeeze the smaller ones out of lucrative new route awards.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Farm product prices increased three-fourths of one per cent during the month ended Jan. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.
BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Thomas F. Johnson, former Maryland Congressman convicted last week on conflict of interest charges, was sentenced today to six months' imprisonment.
The National Broadcasting Company is thinking of banning simulated news flashes on entertainment programs. Some viewers apparently take the humorous messages seriously.
A 59-year-old telephone operator was beaten to death in a walkway under an apartment house in Astoria, Queens, as she returned home from work early yesterday morning.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Gov. George Romney accused President Johnson today of simultaneously pursuing an anti-inflationary tax policy and an inflationary spending policy.

ISMAILIA, United Arab Republic, Jan. 30 -- A spokesman for the Suez Canal Authority said today that efforts to free the 15 foreign vessels stranded in Suez Canal would be suspended indefinitely as a result of the exchange of fire with the Israelis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The failure of government to prevent rioting, despair and "threatened anarchy" in the nation's large cities has brought the Federal system to the brink of its greatest crisis since the Civil War, a Government study commission declared today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A Federal agent testified today that some weight control doctors were reaping fabulous profits through boot legging and distributing pep pills and goof balls to patients they might never see.
Most commodities futures prices retreated yesterday in routine trading on the nation's exchanges.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Britain's rundown economy has long been patched up with policies such as temporary tax changes and bank rate adjustments. But an industrial remodeling job is now under way in the form of giant mergers, suggesting more lasting improvement.

The International Business Machines Corporation introduced yesterday a new electric typewriter that types in Braille. It is said to be the only powered typewriter for individual use originating in Braille, the international language for the blind.
Tom Seaver, the clubhouse Spanky MacFarland of the New York Mets, signed his 1968 contract yesterday after some momentary haggling and brought considerable relief to Our Gang at Shea Stadium.
The Borden Company confirmed yesterday negotiations on the possibility of acquiring L'il General Stores, Inc., Tampa, a convenience-food store chain.

Unable to maintain in Madison Square Garden the success that had marked their three weeks on the road, the New York Knickerbockers couldn't quite produce the victory that would have brought their home record to 500 last night.
Behind Bill Langheld's 30 points, Fordham routed Wagner, 93-71, last night before 2,515 fans in the Rose Hill Gymnasium. The victory was the Rams' 12th in 15 starts.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 30 -- A dozen angry parents of boys suspended from high school yesterday because of their long hair stormed out of a Board of Education meeting tonight in protest.

GRENOBLE, France, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -- A report submitted today by a fact-finding committee to the International Olympic Committee apparently brightened South Africa's chances of being admitted to the Olympic Games at Mexico City in October.
The credit markets forged ahead again yesterday, continuing to push interest rates downward and causing investment bankers to bid aggressively for new issues.

ASPECTS OF PROVENCE. By James Pope-Hennessy. 162 pages. Little, Brown. $6.50. In Provence, the mistral blows with fury, whipping the cypresses planted along the road to break its path. Frequently, the land is rock-studded, desolate and formidable. But at other times, the sweet scent of mimosa is in the air, or the wild lavender is in bloom and the sky is an endless blue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A Government report on the possibility of desalting Pacific Ocean water and lifting it across the mountains to augment the water supply of the Lower Colorado River was described today as "foolish."

TRENTON, Jan. 30 -- A lawyer is suing the photographer at his wedding, saying that pictures of his bride were "so grotesque and repulsive" that they got him in trouble with in-laws and hurt his practice.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- United States Navy recovery specialists have been called into the search for four hydrogen bombs off Greenland.
MEMBERS of the Cosmopolitan Club, Rochdale Village, Queens, came close to winning all three titles at the American Bridge Association tournament held Saturday at the Sheraton Atlantic Hotel.

Patrice Munsel, former Metropolitan Opera star, said yesterday she would make her Broadway debut next season in a musical version of "The Women," Clare Boothe Luce's 31-year-old comedy. The entire cast will consist of female players.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 28 -- Three weeks after the Czechoslovak Communist party ousted Antonin Novotny from its leadership, many Czechoslovaks hopeful of greater liberalization remain exhilarated but they are becoming increasingly wary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Senate sent to President Johnson today a bill tightening Government regulation of savings and loan holding companies. Congressional action on the measure was completed with Senate acceptance of House amendments added when the House passed the bill a week ago.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 31 -- The Vietcong terrorist attack on the United States Embassy ended this morning with a gun battle between an embassy official and a guerrilla on a staircase.

ROME, Jan. 30 -- The work of a commission of Cardinals created to study the new Dutch catechism has been completed, but the modifications it proposed have yet to be made, authoritative Vatican sources said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Johnson Administration, encouraged by the growing public interest in consumer and safety legislation, will begin a drive tomorrow for the nation's first comprehensive industrial safety law.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 1 (AP)--Vietcong soldiers and agents were said to be circulating openly in some heavily populated parts of Saigon today after it was reported that the National Liberation Front had announced formation of a revolutionary council to run Saigon.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 31--Sarah Lawrence College announced today it would become co-educational next week.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 31--Once-beaten St. Peter's College gained its 14th victory of the season tonight by defeating Manhattan College, 109-89.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--American conversations for '68: "Oops! Sorry about that." "Is something the matter, sir?"

Sweeping nine events, the Fordham swimming team trounced St. Francis, 56-23, last night in a Metropolitan Conference meet at the victors' pool. Fordham has won three straight in the conference and has a 4-3 won-lost record over-all. The Terriers are 0-5.
The enemy's Tet offensive, which penetrated even into the United States Embassy in Saigon, offers further painful proof of the limitations of American power in Asia.

CHAMROUSSE, France, Jan. 31 (AP)--Penny McCoy of Bishop, Calif., a bronze medal winner in the 1966 world championships, was dropped from the United States Olympic women's Alpine skiing team because of injuries, the American coach, Bob Beattie, said today.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday endorsed direct state aid to private colleges and universities, including many that are under religious sponsorship.

Pete Toro, 153 pounds, of Puerto Rico stopped Gil Diaz, 165, with a flurry of punches at 2:41 of the fourth round last night in the scheduled 10-round boxing feature at Sunnyside Garden in Queens. Unbeaten David Melendez, 149 1/2, of Puerto Rico outpointed Dave Dittmar, 153 1/2, of White Plains, in the eighth-round semi-final for his ninth victory.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 31 Brown University's hockey team took third place in the Ivy League by trouncing Yale, 8-2, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) --Two Democratic Senators, Robert F. Kennedy of New York and Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma, introduced legislation today to repeal restrictive public welfare provisions written into the Social Security Act of 1967.
Trading was quiet but prices managed to rally a bit from their early lows on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 (UPI)--A Federal judge prohibited a white union today from striking to deny Negro employes equal employment opportunities at the huge Crown Zellerbach paper mill in Bogalusa, La.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Representative Kenneth J. Gray, Democrat of Illinois, announced today he would not seek re-election. Citing the physical burden of campaigning, the 43-year-old Congressman said he spent $23,000 of his $30,000 salary in 1967 for office expenses and travel to his district.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York called yesterday for the abolition of the 312-year-old city marshal system in a report that charged some marshals with practicing law without a license.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 (UPI)--A Federal grand jury indicted today David V. Harris, 22 years old of Fresno, Calif., and a former Stanford University student body president, for refusing to report for induction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, proposed today that Congress enact promptly a $6.5-billion income tax increase and an $8-billion cut in President Johnson's proposed budget.
The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday record-breaking results in 1967 and the declaration of a 5-cent cash dividend increase to 67 1/2 cents quarterly.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 31 (AP)--Hilda White, the 32-year-old housewife who underwent South Africa's first double heart valve transplant last week, died today. Dr. H. Van Wyk, medical superintendent of Johannesburg General Hospital, said a post-mortem would be held tomorrow to establish the cause of death.
A crowd of several thousand spent the noon lunch hour yesterday watching the Loyal Order of Moose battle the Knights of Columbus on the Rockefeller Plaza outdoor ice-skating rink.
William Styron's "The Confessions of Nat Turner," the No. 1 best-selling novel, is stirring bitter controversy among Negroes.
A young mother, the wife of a fourth-year medical student, was slain yesterday apparently after being raped in her apartment in a sedate, middle-class neighborhood of Brooklyn.
Mayor Lindsay will propose today that the city subsidize small parcels of land for industrial use to keep factories from leaving the city.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 31 (Agence France-Presse) -- The Communist party newspaper Nhan Dan carried a dispatch from the Vietcong press agency today that said the Vietcong had struck during the Lunar New Year holidays, despite the announced seven-day holiday truce they had begun on Saturday, because the United States had "openly torpedoed the cease-fire order of the front."
Directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday increased the quarterly dividend by 2.5 cents a share, to 40 cents, payable March 9 to holders of record Feb. 13.
A strike yesterday by maintenance workers at the New York University Medical Center shut off the flow of food and drugs to 730 patients in two hospitals, but there was little effect on patients.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 31--More than 100,000 students and others held a rally in 20-degree weather today to demand United States and United Nations aid in preventing a recurrence of North Korean commando raids like the one that culminated in an attempt to assassinate President Chung Hee Park on Jan. 21.
Two opponents of the war in Vietnam left Kennedy International Airport last night for Hanoi to return with three American pilots expected to be freed by the North Vietnamese.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday the reassignment of 290 of the department's 352 policewomen to local station houses.
Both Bonn and Belgrade have good reason to be satisfied with their agreement to renew the diplomatic ties severed by the former in October 1957.
ROME (AP)--The Government has decreed that Italy will observe daylight saving time this year from May 26 to Sept. 22.
About 300 persons were guided through thick, acrid smoke to safety along subway tracks yesterday after a fire in a cable caused the power to be cut off.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -The House strengthened a comprehensive "truth - in lending" bill today in what proponents termed a major victory for consumers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Social Security Administration will stop sending monthly benefit checks after June 30 to about 15,000 aliens in about 40 countries, an agency spokesman said today.

Barney's, the clothing store, announced yesterday the appointment of Gerald Levy to the new post of executive vice president. He had been vice president, treasurer and a director of Bond Stores, Inc. Melvin Ocean, formerly general manager of Barney's, was named operations vice president.
Many motorists, who have found that happiness is a parking space during the continuing garagemen's strike here, will find their search less frustrating today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 31 (UPI)--Minnesota hammered in three goals against a badly outskated Los Angeles Kings team in the second period to win, 6-1, in a National Hockey League game tonight. The triumph lifted the North Stars to within 2 points of West Division leader, Philadelphia.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31--California Democratic leaders, recovering from a dismal year of disunity in 1967, are increasingly encouraged over President Johnson's prospects in both the primary and the fall election here.

James J. Bauchat, who has been elected vice president of the American Tobacco Company, also has been elected president and chief executive officer of Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., which was acquired by American Tobacco in May, 1966. Elliott Brownlee, former president of Sunshine, becomes chairman of the board.
MUNCIE, Ind., Jan. 31 (UPI)--The police fired tear gas cartridges three times today to break up scuffles between Negro and white students at the Muncie South High School.

Five hundred members of the City College Alumni Varsity Association paid tribute last night to 10 former C.C.N.Y. sports notables at the group's second annual athletic hall of fame induction dinner at the Hotel Americana.
TOKYO, Jan. 31 (UPI)--Communist China said that two United States planes intruded into its territorial air space today.
TOKYO, Jan. 31 -- Premier Eisaku Sato implied today that his Government would not permit United States submarines equipped with Polaris nuclear missiles to visit Japan.

Ticket for the new Madison Square Garden's first boxing program on March 4 -- the championship double - header between the undefeated heavyweights, Joe Frazier and Buster Mathis, and the middleweights, Emile Griffith and Nino Benvenuti, will go on sale tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 31--Five African and Asian members of the Security Council proposed today that they meet North Korean envoys in Geneva to negotiate the release of the Pueblo's crew and to extend an unconditional invitation to discuss all aspects of the Korean situation at the Council.

JUDITH ANDERSON'S real moments as the monarch torn between pride of realm and love of man was the viewer's intermittent reward last night in tuning in Maxwell Anderson's "Elizabeth the Queen." The play was seen on the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" over Channel 4.

NAURU, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- In a day-long celebration with fireworks, a choir singing hymns and a message from Queen Elizabeth II, this tiny Pacific island today hoisted a new flag and became the independent Republic of Nauru.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Union and company witnesses painted a gloomy picture today of prospects of settling the 6 1/2-month-old strike that has shut down most of the nation's copper industry.
You have just entered Hugger Month. Feel different? Never mind how you feel, do you understand?
The Brooklyn chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality charged yesterday that Negro and Puerto Rican students were being struck and beaten by teachers in the city's public schools.
The annual mass-media award of the national women's division of the American Jewish Congress was presented to The New York Times yesterday for "distinguished journalism in the public interest."

MRS. JUDY DE CASEMBROOT of Buxted, Sussex, England, a world-traveling judge of all breeds, heard a familiar tune when she attended a meeting of the English Cocker Spaniel Club of America during her recent visit here.

CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 31 -- Nearly 3,500 people have been arrested during three days of anti-Government agitation by the Communist - dominated United Front of Left Parties in the state of West Bengal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--The United States paid $24,000 for plain sea water after being told it was a product called Bioceane used to treat nausea and skin eruptions, a Senate investigations subcommittee was told today.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 31--A draft board member here who strongly disapproves of the war in Vietnam has aroused indignation among some residents of this affluent suburb.
Mayor John V. Lindsay will address the Bond Club of New York at its annual dinner on Wednesday, Feb. 7, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Arthur L. Wadsworth, president of the club, announced yesterday.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- Three Center and Right parties agreed today on the basis for Denmark's first non-Socialist Government since 1953.

The Queens Federation of Churches yesterday rejected a plan to establish a Council of Churches of the City of New York that would have embraced most of the Protestant, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox congregations in the five boroughs.
Because a Massachusetts insurance company wanted a piece of property for an urban redevelopment program in Springfield, a New York realty man ended up with some properties in Manhattan.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- The North Vietnamese news agency said today that the Vietcong had set up a revolutionary council in Saigon while its suicide squads attacked the United States Embassy and the Presidential Palace yesterday.
MANILA, Jan. 31 -- The Taal Volcano south of Manila started acting up again today, for the fourth time in a year. It belched smoke and spewed rock in periodic explosions.
SAIGON, Thursday, Feb. 1 (AP)--In three days the enemy has lost 4,949 dead, according to an allied tabulation reported today.

Intermediate School 201, the controversial East Harlem school that the Board of Education had promised to make a "showcase" for quality education, will start the new school term today tortured by troubles and facing an uncertain future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Labor Department and the Health, Education and Welfare Department have given to a House subcommittee their priorities in the 50-city job program that will pay employers part of the costs of training the hard-core unemployed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) --The Atomic Energy Commission described today the development of an injection "gun" technique for treating cancer with tiny radioactive projectiles.
ABA, Nigeria, Jan. 27--On a Saturday night in Nigeria's besieged secessionist area, formerly the Eastern Region, the hardships and tragedies of the civil war suddenly recede.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--A new method of preventing tooth decay has been found highly effective in animals and will be tested in man, scientists have reported in The Journal of the American Dental Association.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (Reuters)--The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia said today that in response to popular demand it would print more articles in 1968 attacking the United States and praising the joys of being a Soviet worker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--A Senate report issued today charged that evasiveness by Government space officials, compounded by "overconfidence and complacency," contributed to the Apollo spacecraft fire that took the lives of three United States astronaut a year ago.
CAGLIOSTRO: Scoundrel or Saint? By Francois Ribadeau Dumas. 308 pages. Orion Press/Grossman. $6.95.
Two small upstate banks have agreed to join the proposed bank holding company being formed by the Bank of New York and the County Trust Company. White Plains, the banks announced yesterday.

AS a man whose early life was like a Horatio Alger story, State Senator John H. Hughes finds that some of "these long-haired guys" in colleges today lack habits of hard work and discipline. He made the statement after his Joint Legislative Committee on Crime had heard testimony yesterday on the use of narcotics by an apparently large number of students at the State University's campus in Stony Brook. L. I.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31--Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall asked today that four states bordering Lake Michigan join the Federal Government in an effective program to combat pollution of the lake and save it from an "ugly, useless death."

DANANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 31--Of all the cities and villages attacked by the Vietcong in the last 48 hours, few have suffered so much or endured so long a period of sustained terror as tiny Apba, on the outskirts of Danang.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 31 (AP)--Teletypesetter tapes -- the kind used in newspaper offices to set type automatically--have been adapted for use in an inexpensive machine, "Spelltalk," that converts them to audible words for the blind. Carnegie-Mellon University said today that the machine was developed by one of its faculty members, Dr. Richard L. Longini, a professor of electrical engineering.
IT WAS another tumultuous day in the stock market for the shares of the Amphenol Corporation and Solitron Devices, Inc.
The United States Olympic Committee announced yesterday a squad of 113 for the Winter Games beginning next Tuesday in Grenoble, France.
Investors, restrained a bit by the shortened hours, slowed their over-all trading pace yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices were down in the process.

A basket by Ed Grant with three seconds left gave St. Francis a 69-68 victory over Siena last night at the Bishop Ford High School gymnasium in Brooklyn. John Conforti of St. Francis took scoring honors with 22 points.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., the world's largest producer of nylon yarn, gave notice to customers yesterday that, in effect, they were cutting the large discounts on certain continuous-filament yarns used in the weaving and knitting trades.

Balloons, streamers and masks will cover tile walls and ceilings of the libracy. Louis XVI and Versailles Suites of the St. RegisSheraton on Sunday night at a cocktail dance benefiting St. Basil's Academy in Garrison. N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--North Korea's seizure of the intelligence ship Pueblo is regarded by Government analysts here as the latest step in a campaign of violence begun 15 months ago when North Korean leaders with a military background began to strengthen their political control.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today that the companies that would ultimately use facilities built for them by local governments under industrial revenue bond financing be required to make full disclosure of their financial position, just as if the companies themselves were the issuers of the industrial revenue bonds.

Two Off Broadway openings were announced yesterday. Eugene Ionesco's "Amedee, or How to Get Rid of It," a comedy, will open March 6 at the Garrick Theater. It was done here previously in 1955. Rae Allen and Paul B. Price will be in the cast, directed by Harold Stone. On Feb. 28 Lynne Carter will open in a one-man satirical revue, "Fun City," at the Jan Hus Playhouse. Mr. Carter will impersonate feminine stars.
A program to encourage corporate support of the arts on a national basis has been formulated by the Business Committee for the Arts, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, warned yesterday that the onrush of speculative activity by institutions held "a serious potential danger to continued public confidence in the securities markets."

Prudence has prevailed over passion. To the disappointment of his more emotional admirers, but to the surprise of almost no one, Senator Robert F. Kennedy has reaffirmed his decision not to oppose President Johnson for renomination "under any foreseeable circumstances."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--A United States Navy propeller-driven Skyraider fighter from the carrier Ticonderoga inadvertently flew within seven miles of the Communist Chinese island of Hainan today, the Defense Department announced.
GENEVA, Jan. 31--The Swiss Government announced today that an East German spy ring centered in the town of Chur in northeastern Switzerland had been smashed with the arrest of its organizer.

The city's Air Pollution Control Commissioner yesterday proposed a new timetable for the application of Federal standards to heating fuels here, which he argued would mean cleaner air sooner. Federal officials immediately charged the proposal would set their program back a year or more.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt denounced Governor Rockefeller's South Mall complex of house state offices today as an "insatiable project" and called on the Legislature to make an immediate inquiry into the "deplorable" method of financing and "extravagant" design.
The trend toward lower interest rates that was so pronounced earlier this year has leveled off.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -The Treasury today offered to holders of securities maturing in February, August and November a new seven-year note bearing 5 3/4 per cent interest, to be offered at par.

A Criminal Court judge, an assistant district attorney and a Legal Aid Society lawyer joined yesterday in charging that the Legislature was "absolutely to blame" for a "disgraceful backlog" in the new narcotics commitment program.

The abuses disclosed in the operation of the system of unsalaried city marshals should at last spur the Legislature to abolish this anachronism. Attempts have been made sporadically--ever since Fiorello La Guardia was Mayor--to achieve this end, but Albany has never agreed to do away with this rich political mine.
THE ENGLISH. By David Frost and Antony Jay. 255 pages. Stein Day. $5.95.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 31 (AP)--A spokesman for former Gov. George C. Wallace said today he would not run in the Presidential primary in New Hampshire March 12.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Anyone visiting the headquarters of the Republican National Committee for the first time might well conclude that he had inadvertently stumbled into a modest but rather successful insurance agency.
BONN, Jan. 31--West Germany resumed diplomatic relations with the Communist Government of Yugoslavia today after a 10-year break.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 31--The desert sun can help your golf when you draw near to 40 years of age, said Bill Collins today after he and Bob Rosburg scored 67's to share the first-round lead in the $100,000 Bob Hope Classic.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 31 (UPI)--The St. Louis Blues scored five goals in the second period tonight and defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 9-4. The victory moved St. Louis into a tie with Los Angeles for third place in the West Division of the National Hockey League.

GRADY, Ark., Jan. 31--Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller, moving to forestall charges of a white-wash in the state's investigation at a nearby prison farm, indicated tonight that a police inquiry would continue.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 31 (AP)--John D. Rockefeller 4th will announce tomorrow his candidacy for Secretary of State of West Virginia, reliable sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--President Johnson will nominate Dr. Thomas O. Paine, a scientist in Santa Barbara, Calif., to be deputy administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the White House announced today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 (AP)--For the handful of Americans inside the white United States Embassy here, the fight that began at 2:54 A.M. today was one of survival.

HOUSTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--Billy Anderson, a reserve quarterback for the Houston Oilers last year, said today he had been notified by Commissioner Pete Rozelle that he would have to return to the Los Angeles Rams next season.

THE 40-year-old international grandmaster Jan H. Donner of the Netherlands, with the best performance of his career, won the recent Venice International Tournament by topping a 14-man field that included seven grandmasters.
IOWA CITY, Jan. 31--A white-haired English professor and his wife were found guilty today of disrupting a local church in a rare Presbyterian church trial.

TOULON, France, Jan. 31 (UPI)--French Navy authorities tonight declared the submarine Minerve lost at sea with all hands. It is presumed sunk in the western Mediterranean. [Israeli search crews kept up their hunt for the submarine Dakar, missing in the eastern Mediterranean with 69 aboard, but sources in Jerusalem said hope was all but gone.]

THE professional football player draft, the commodity futures market of sports, began in 1936 as a willy-nilly curb exchange. Franchise owners crowded into Bert Bell's hotel room, shucked their jackets and cleared sitting room on beds and bureaus. Bottles circulated, solemn oaths of league solidarity were taken, and the college stars were distributed.

The computer industry was extremely active yesterday with the introduction of new equipment, the addition of third-generation units to handle the overflow business on the stock exchanges and the sale of equipment to France.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 31--Dr. Homer Joe Stewart, a member of the team that launched the Explorer 1, recalled in an interview yesterday that "the booster rocket and upper stages were actually spares from a test launching in 1956 and Van Allen's equipment had also been worked out the year before."
A charge of homicide against Carlos Diaz, 36 years old, of 176 East 123d Street, was dismissed in Supreme Court yesterday by Justice Gerald P. Culkin after a grand jury had declined to indict him.

A threatened round-the-clock sit-in at Public School 67 in the Bronx was averted yesterday when parents, complaining of double sessions and overcrowding, received a promise of some relief from the Superintendent of Schools.
Indian Head, Inc., a diversified manufacturing company, announced here yesterday the election of Charles L. Schultze and Warren C. Hume as directors.

TEANECK, N. J., Jan. 31--The New Jersey Americans out-scored the Dallas Chaparrals, 16-1, in the last seven minutes of the final quarter and scored a 119-111 American Basketball Association victory at the Teaneck Armory tonight that snapped a four-game losing streak for the Americans.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP)--Jim Ryun's world records of 3 minutes 51.1 seconds for the mile and 3:31.1 for 1,500 meters have been ratified, the International Amateur Athletic Federation said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--The Federal Bureau of Investigation added today the name of Robert Leon McCain, a Texan sought in the death of a customer during a bank robbery, to its list of 10 most wanted criminals. The F.B.I said that McCain, 26 years old, was extremely dangerous and that he had been a member of an armed gang responsible for more than 200 holdups in the state since 1964.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (UPI)--A high school boy died yesterday after sniffing glue in the home of a friend, the police said. The victim was identified as Dale Pesavento, 15 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--An Illinois coroner testified today that diet pills were suspected as the cause of what he said was the sudden and unexpected death of 14 persons in his state, most of them young people.

DETROIT, Jan. 31--The General Motors Corporation's profits climbed 2 per cent in the fourth quarter from the level the year before. But G.M. profits for all 1967 were down 9 per cent from the 1966 total, and the company warned the squeeze on profits would continue or intensify this year.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Thursday, Feb. 1 (UPI)--Bus drivers of the Bee Line Bus Company went on strike today, halting service for 20,000 passengers who ride daily from Freeport, Hempstead and Valley Stream to the IND subway station in Jamaica, Queens.
New York magazine, the Sunday supplement of the defunct World Journal Tribune, will appear as an independent weekly on April 8, Clay Felker, its editor, announced yesterday.
THERE are harmonies in cooking not unlike those of architecture, Kenneth Tam remarked, decanting a red Burgundy into crystal.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 31 (AP) --A Rembrandt painting valued at $100,000 was stolen during the night from Eastman House, the police said here today.
TRENTON, Jan. 31 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes ruled out today any new or increased taxes in the budget he will submit to the Legislature on Feb. 13.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--Scientists on earth commanded Lunar Orbiter 5 to dive to its death on the moon today. It did.

Professional football's annual draft of senior college players concluded yesterday with the additional selection of 325 athletes, of whom fewer than 100 are likely to win jobs with their teams this summer.

A 10-man advisory panel of art experts was appointed yesterday by Commissioner Sheldon S. Cohen of the Internal Revenue Service to reduce abuses of income tax laws governing charitable donations of art works.

Jim Garrison, District Attorney of New Orleans, said last night that the late Jack Ruby, the slayer of Lee Harvey Oswald, was near the scene of the assassination of President Kennedy an hour before it occurred in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The United States is preparing to approach North Korea anew through the armistice commission in Panmunjom in an effort to negotiate the release of the intelligence ship Pueblo and her crew.
LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 1--A suspicion that Leonardo da Vinci picked up the idea for his armored vehicle from a contemporary was raised in The Burlington Magazine, published here today.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 31--With three hours to go before the deadline, the name of former Vice President Richard M. Nixon was formally entered today in the New Hampshire Presidential primary of March 12.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31--An observation of the sun made from deep inside a South Dakota gold mine has shown that there is "something fundamentally wrong" with present ideas concerning the sun's interior.

McGraw-Hill, Inc., Textron, Inc., the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company and the Meinhard-Commercial Corporation were among several companies to announce yesterday changes in their senior management.

The annual winter cocktail party benefiting the Brooklyn Association for Mental Health will be held on Sunday at the Albemarle Towers in Brooklyn. Proceeds will go to the association's programs in education, research, rehabilitation and prevention of mental illness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The National Association of Travel Organizations, though primarily interested in promoting travel in the United States, said today that it saw danger rather than advantage in penalizing Americans who want to travel overseas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--President Johnson is considering action, publicly unspecified, to meet the growing crisis in Asia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--The time has come for an overhaul of American government, Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, of Vermont, said today. "The economic and scientific world travels so fast that our political structure has difficulty even keeping in sight." Mr. Aiken told the Senate Subcommittee on Executive Reorganization. "The need for continuous study of our government structure was never more apparent," he said.

ALBANY, Jan. 31--Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia announced today he would introduce legislation to eliminate "costly special elections" by permitting the Assembly and Senate to fill vacancies in their ranks.

The New York Board of Rabbis, made up of 900 Orthodox, Conservative and Reform clergymen, sharply criticized the Bundy school-decentralization plan yesterday as a "potential breeder of local apartheid.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Julius Rudel, general director of the New York City Opera Company, and William McCormick Blair Jr. former Ambassador to the Philippines, have accepted leading posts here at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

ROME--Sir Laurence Olivier, in camelhair coat and muffler and clutching his hat against a strong wind, stood on a boarding ramp scanning the wintery sky over the Rome airport recently. He waved with his free hand to a plane that was carrying his wife, the actress Joan Plowright, and their three young children back to London.

BAMAKO, Mali, Jan. 22 -- Mali looks like John Wayne country, crossed with Beau Geste. Scrubb-dotted mesas roll away from the wide curves of the more fertile Niger River basin into the vast void of the Sahara. If a posse doesn't come thundering down one of the gullies, the American visitor half expects a squadron of the French Foreign Legion to ride over the hill to set everything right.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--A House judiciary subcommittee approved a bill today that would give alien widows of United States servicemen killed in Vietnam the same chance to become a citizen that they would have had if their husbands had lived.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -The nation's gold loss in December, disclosed in general terms a month ago, was $900-million, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It was the largest gold loss for any month on record.
GRENOBLE, France, Jan. 31 (AP)--Girls who are to compete in the Winter Olympics arrived in France today and immediately were asked to undergo a test to determine their sex for athletic purposes.
A poll of Bowery Mission residents shows that while 81.9 per cent of them believe President Johnson will be re-elected, only 54.2 per cent consider him the best choice.

Suffolk County Police Commissioner John J. Barry, testifying yesterday before the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime, accused the dean of students at the State University's Stony Brook campus of having tipped off youngsters at a "pot party" to a planned police raid last March.
The voice of the bear was heard again in the stock market yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 31--Yugoslavia has rebuffed West German efforts to get her to make a statement that would bolster Bonn's position toward East Germany.

WARSAW, Jan. 31 -- About 50 Warsaw University students were arrested last night after demonstrations against a Communist party decision ending the run of an anti-Russian play by the 19th century romantic poet Adam Mickiewcz.
NEW LONDON, Conn, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- The nuclear submarine Seawolf has been damaged in the Atlantic 150 miles southeast of Boston and is being escorted back to base, navy officials reported today.

CORONADO, Calif., Jan. 31--"The winds of change are blowing strong in tennis and something has got to give, but just how far the United States will go in backing Britain it is utterly impossible to say."

Sapphire Steamship Lines, Inc., has asked the United States District Court for the District of Columbia for a summary judgment against 15 shipping lines the Federal Maritime Commission said had "combined and conspired" successfully to drive the independent carrier out of business.
WHEN a band of beavers dams a stream, the resulting impoundment not only provides them a home-site, it also exerts a substantial effect on the wildlife of the area.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 31 (UPI)--Villanova said tonight that its track and field team would not participate in the New York Athletic Club meet at Madison Square Garden Feb. 16.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 (AP)--Earl Monroe scored 35 points and led the Baltimore Bullets to a 113-108 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight in an N.B.A. game.
OROVILLE, Calif., Jan. 31 (UPI) -- The Pacific Coast's worst snow storm of the winter ended today with at least seven persons still missing or stranded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--The Defense Department identified today 29 United States servicemen killed in action in Vietnam. Among them were two Army men, Sgt. Lawrence C. Bloom and Pfc. Angel O. Ruiz, both of Brooklyn. Also killed were Lance Cpl. Paul Christmas of Newark, Pfc. William E. Donohue of Buffalo, Pfc. Emmitt Galloway of Brooklyn and Pfc. Angel A. Garcia of the Bronx, all of the Marine Corps.

Members of the United Steelworkers of America who had threatened to strike against the American Can Company and the Continental Can Company won a pay increase of about 6.1 per cent in an agreement reached in New York just before the midnight deadline last night.
Futures prices of metals, which had been dropping in recent sessions, rebounded yesterday on the commodity exchanges. Soybeans and grains also showed gains.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP)--The yacht Phoenix bearing medical supplies arrived safely in Haiphong, North Vietnam on Monday, its sponsor, a Quaker group, announced today. George Lakey, co-chairman of the group, said the cargo consisted of $5,000 worth of surgical instruments and $2,000 worth of medicine.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- Democratic leaders announced today an unofficial 10-day Congressional recess beginning Feb. 9 to permit Republicans to return home for Lincoln Day speeches.

DR. ROBERT BERMAN of Valley Stream, L. I., Mrs. Marthe Charles and Dr. Emanuel Bernstein of Plainview, L. I., and Jack Van Gelder, Leonard Jefferson and Seymour Bibuld, all of New York, are undoubtedly the giant-killing team of the present season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--(AP)--The Senate Commerce Committee approved today the nomination of William H. Chartener, New York economist, to be Assistant Secretary of Commerce for economic affairs. The committee acted after a 10-minute hearing at which no opposition to Mr. Chartener's selection was voiced.

MONROE, N. C., Jan. 31 (UPI)--Friends of Robert Williams, a Negro militant, who now lives in Peking, said today he has been denied permission to enter Sweden. Word of the denial reached this small town, where Williams was once a leader of the local National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in a copy of a letter he had written protesting the government ruling.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 (AP)--Following is the text of a statement proclaiming martial law broadcast to the South Vietnamese people today by President Nguyen Van Thieu:

Income averaging can be a tax-saving boon to a person who suddenly received a substantial increase in income last year. One of the leastknown aspects of the tax regulations, the income averaging rules are complicated. Yet they can be helpful, even to small-income persons.

United States intelligence officers believe that the latest nationwide attacks in South Vietnam by Communist guerrillas and sabotage and terrorist units, as well as the impending battle around Khesanh, are focused squarely on public opinion in this country and in South Vietnam. The enemy hopes to foster war-weariness; to strengthen the opposition to the war in the United States and in South Vietnam, and to force the allies to enter negotiations at a disadvantage.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 31--Prime Minister Dudley Senayake announced a minor reshuffle of the Cabinet today. It followed the resignation yesterday of Harry Jayawardene, the Health Minister. Hugh Fernando becomes Minister of Trade and Commerce and E.L. Senanayake Minister of Health. Mr. Jayawardene has been appointed Minister of Scientific Research and Housing.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31--The citizen who finds weather forecasts undependable might as well resign himself to this for the next decade or so.

A final, smashing nine minutes, in which the Rangers narrowly missed connecting from distances of a foot to 20 yards, brought swells of roars that wound up as moans last night as the New Yorkers grudgingly dropped a 3-2 decision to the Chicago Black Hawks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--The Maritime Administration added four ships today to its blacklist of vessels that have called at Cuban ports since Jan. 1, 1963, raising the total to 206.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 31--Kenya and Somalia resumed diplomatic relations today in an effort to close the lid on a desert war that has continued fitfully on their frontier for four years.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 31--Fairleigh Dickinson's basketball team went over the 100-point mark tonight for the second time this season to gain a 101-93 victory over Hofstra, in a Metropolitan Conference game.
The Cunard Line yesterday announced the sale of two passenger liners to an Italian steamship company.
A new air pollution control bill that would give city landlords more time to improve or shut down their incinerators was approved yesterday by the City Council's Committee on Buildings.
The Port of Liverpool, which is midway in a $175-million port modernization program, has named a well-known New York shipping man to help develop Liverpool trade here.
ALGIERS, Jan. 31 -- The French completed their withdrawal today from the Mers-el-Kebir naval base in western Algeria. The withdrawal was completed 10 years ahead of schedule.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- President Johnson hailed breakthroughs in heart surgery and new triumphs in drug treatment today as he proclaimed February American Heart Month.

The citizens of New York State defeated a proposed new Constitution last November by more than two million votes. In the campaign, the proposal to drop the present constitutional ban on state aid to denominational schools was unquestionably the most hotly debated question. While many factors entered into the result, the church-state issue was certainly one of the more influential.

REEDLEY, Calif., Jan. 31 (Reuters)--A former inmate of the Arkansas State Prison, Pershing Mills, 49, said today that he had witnessed the killings of five prisoners by prison guards while he was confined.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 31--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin called today for "unconditional stoppage" of the United States bombing of North Vietnam in a communique issued at the end of the Soviet leader's six-day visit here.
A man described as a lieutenant in a $300-million-a-year narcotics operation with links to Cuba was convicted in Bronx Supreme Court last night of felonious possession of narcotics.

District 65 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Workers Union last night called a nationwide strike of 1,000 office and warehouse employes against four shoe-store chains. Frank Brown, vice president of the union, said picketing would start at 800 retail shoe outlets, about 400 of them in the metropolitan area. He identified the companies as Miles, Meldisco, A.S. Beck and National Shoes.
SAIGON, Jan. 31, (UPI) -- President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam said today in a broadcast over the Hanoi radio he was "very happy with the victories'' of the Vietcong in the past two days.
The annual ball of the Kosciuszko Foundation will be held on Feb. 9 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The District of Columbia apparently settled today a dispute over how to implement the controversial criminal arrest and interrogation provisions of a new local crime control law enacted by Congress over the city government's protest.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 96.2 on Tuesday from 96.1 on Monday.

The Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations has issued a timely and eloquent warning that the deterioration of living conditions in the great American population centers is threatening their total domination by the national Government.

Commissioner George Nicolau announced yesterday his resignation as head of the city's Community Development Agency and blamed Congressional "hostility" and "indifference" to the plight of the poor for his action.

ROME, Jan. 31 -- A vote on a Government move to prevent a parliamentary inquiry into an alleged rightist plot to overthrow the Government in July, 1964, was postponed tonight in the Chamber of Deputies until tomorrow.
BOSTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- Bailey Howell's 27 points led the Boston Celtics to a 118-109 victory over the Chicago Bulls in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31 (UPI)--About 32,000 union employes involving 90 per cent of the nation's glass and bottle production industry were ordered off their jobs early today in a contract dispute over wages.
HONG KONG, Jan. 31--Peking has speeded its program for establishing new provincial organs of power by giving key positions to tested military commanders and Communists.
The New York Yankees signed a pitcher, an outfielder and a controller yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- When the children are asleep, some London women are borrowing their new toy for a bounce around the bedroom to tone abdomen muscles. An Australian doctor likes the same toy for physical therapy. Gymnasts are also interested.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 31 (UPI)--A Trans World Airlines jet with 36 persons aboard, which may have struck a power line while attempting to land in Chicago, touched down safely tonight at Wier-Cook Airport here.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, Jan. 31--The Supreme Court today passed its first death sentence, condemning former Prince Hood Bin Abed al Fadhli after a one-day trial on charges of bribery, extortion, abuse of power and conspiracy with former British political officers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- William W. Sherrill was sworn in today to a full 14year term as a governor of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Sherrill was appointed to the board last year to fill an unexpired term and was named to a full term early this month by President Johnson.
Two airlines -- Pan American World Airways and Trans Caribbean Airways -- will introduce daily air service to San Juan from Newark Airport for the first time.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- Walter Ulbricht presented to the East German Parliament today the draft for a new constitution that establishes East Germany as a "socialist German state" and declares Berlin "the capital of the German Democratic Republic."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Dr. Wernher von Braun, who launched America's first satellite 10 years ago today, warned today that this country was "dismantling the high competence" of its space team.
A proposal by two mediators for settling the dispute over a new sanitation contract was rejected last night by both the city and the Uniformed Sanitationmens Association.

Eleazar De Carvalho, the Brazilian conductor of the St. Louis Symphony and the Brazilian Symphony Orchestra, has been appointed conductor and music director of the Pro Arte Symphony Orchestra of Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I.
SINGAPORE, Feb. 1 (Reuters)--A broadcast of the Vietcong's Liberation Radio urged officers and men of South Vietnam's armed forces today to turn their guns against the Americans in Vietnam.

WHEN you enter a theater on a first night and the usherette announces: "Only one Playbill per two people--we have run short," you tend to wonder what else they have run short of. The answers closely attended the raising of the curtain at the Booth Theater, where Samuel Taylor's comedy "Avanti!" opened last night.

Elvin Hayes and his Houston teammates, conquerors of Lew Alcindor and the University of California, Los Angeles, will display their skills at Madison Square Garden tonight against Marshall University of West Virginia in the opener of a college basketball double-header at 7 o'clock. New York University plays Army in the second game.
IF there is any magic left in the 18th-century, glittering glass globes hung in a corner of Henry Algan's French Renaissance kitchen, it was not operating last week.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 31 -- The American-owned International Railways of Central America was put under provisional government management today as Minister of Labor Carlos Hall Lloreda named a former railway accountant, Portillo Paiz, temporary head of the financially ailing enterprise.

Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that he could not "go out and shoot" people wanting him to be a Presidential candidate, but he insisted again that he favored the candidacy of Gov. George Romney of Michigan.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP)--A grand jury returned 11 bills of indictment today against Richard J. Noble, 20 years old, a University of Pennsylvania sophomore charged with setting a fraternity house fire that killed three persons Dec. 10. The bills charged voluntary manslaughter, involuntary manslaughter and arson.

The David McKay Company has bought all the stock of Ives Washburn, Inc., and in the process drawn attention to one independent book company that is still growing despite the trend toward acquisition of publishing companies by large corporations outside the industry.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 31 (Reuters)--Premier Kosygin arrived here today for an overnight stay.
The admission of Clinton Gilbert Jr. and Philip R. von Stade as general partners was announced here yesterday by Scudder, Stevens Clark, investment counselors.
LONDON, Jan. 31--Labor Members of Parliament today suspended 24 M.P.'s from party activities for a month. The vote at a party meeting was 123 to 66.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Federal Maritime Commission, for the first time in its regulatory history, described as illegal today certain rates for freight moving along a major ocean trade route.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 (UPI)--The Mainichi newspapers published today pictures of the nuclear-powered aircraft, carier Enterprise accompanied by a smaller flattop, indentified as the Yorktown. The two ships and escorting vessels were reported sailing in the Sea of Japan off the Korean coast. Japanese newsmen who flew over the carriers to take the photographs said a Soviet destroyer was trailing the task force.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 1 -- Vietcong forces stubbornly held pockets of resistance in Saigon and other areas today after their spectacular attacks on cities and American bases throughout South Vietnam.

Walter W. Heller, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that he is "not ready or willing to give up on the tax increase in spite of the inscrutability of the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee."
CINCINNATI, Jan. 31 (UPI)--Cazzie Russell's jump shot at the buzzer gave the New York Knicks a 128-126 overtime victory over the Cincinnati Royals in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 31--A suspended Maryknoll priest ordered home from Guatemala was reported yesterday to have married the nun who was ordered out of that country with him.

The Patent, Trademark and Copyright Research Institute of George Washington University has awarded the Charles F. Kettering Award for meritorious work in patent, trademark and copyright research and education to Dr. Stephen P. Ladas, it was announced yesterday.

The dominant concern of transportation executives currently is "intermodalism," for both passenger and cargo traffic, a series of speakers representing all forms of carriers indicated yesterday at the National Transportation Institute.

Zev Bufman, producer of two current shows, "Spofford" and "Your Own Thing," is planning to present a third, "Mike Downstairs." The author of the fantasy-comedy with autobiographical touches is George Panetta, an advertising writer, who has had four plays produced.

MADRID, Jan. 31 -- Actual long-term borrowing and borrowing commitments for Eurodollars by United States corporations in Western Europe have already exceeded in the first 10 days of January the loans totaling $527-million contracted during all of 1967.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) --Selma Munter Borchardt, a three-time president of the American Federation of Teachers, died at a convalescent home here Tuesday. She was 72 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, accused President Johnson today of avoiding any tough decisions on spending cuts.
Dow Jones Co., Inc., and The Associated Press announced yesterday that they would offer a new service for stockbrokers and others in Europe interested in United States investments.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Jan. 31 (AP)--Officials at Narragansett Park said today that racing has been canceled through Friday because of poor track conditions. The oval will be scraped and resurfaced, with racing to resume Saturday.

Flowers and delicate bouquets of choreography were Robert Rodham's gift to his dancers last night at City Center. The Pennsylvania Ballet gave the New York premiere of his "Gala Dix," which incorporated the traditional performance-end presentation of flowers into the cavalierly competitive fabric of this elegant ballet for five couples.

NAPLES, Jan. 31--An American admiral, retiring today from command of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, called the French boycott of the alliance "foolhardy" and a "fallacy.'' He said that France Sheltered behind the protection of allies meeting their treaty obligations.
Floyd D. Hall, chairman and chief executive officer of Eastern Airlines, proposed yesterday that tax credits be granted to business corporations that train the hard-core unemployed.

The new State Office Building for 125th Street, whose design was unveiled yesterday, promises to be exactly what was hoped for: a landmark and boost for the Harlem community. It also opens unlimited development possibilities for the city's investors and builders.
WHEN Dr. Bernard Bucove's father emigrated to Canada from his native Russia at the age of 20 around the turn of the century he joined a railroad gang that was pushing the tracks into the wilderness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Individuals who intend to buy stock with the proceeds of a loan that is secured by other stock will be subject to criminal prosecution if they fail to disclose that fact, under a new regulation issued today by the Federal Reserve Board.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 1 -- The Second United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, attended by delegates from 132 nations and designed to narrow the growing economic gap between the rich and poor countries of the world, opened here today.

A RECORD for time-span in regional championship success was probably established last week when Mr. and Mrs. Richard Frey of New York captured the Mixed Pair title in Bermuda. As long ago as 1936 they won the New England Team Championship, and it is most unlikely that any other partnership can claim more than this 32-year spread.

Mud in the Port Authority Trans Hudson tunnel near the construction site of the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan halted train service between the Hudson Terminal and Jersey City and Newark during the morning rush hour yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A difference between blood vessels of diabetics and persons free of the disease may help scientists to understand better this major health problem, a specialist said here today.
ROCKVILLE, Md., Feb. 1 -- Public school teachers in Montgomery County, a District of Columbia suburb, voted today to strike tomorrow to enforce salary demands.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 1 -- A strike by bus drivers and mechanics against two private Nassau County bus companies today forced 20,000 commuters to find alternate means of getting to and from work in New York City.
POTSDAM, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Seven students of the Clarkson College of Technology, including two girls, were arrested last night at an alleged marijuana party.
Arnold H. Vollmer, senior partner of Vollmer Associates, engineers, architects and landscape architects, has announced that Edward J. Moloney and Peter E. Shrope have joined the firm as partners.

Gang fighting with racial overtones broke out in the East New York and Park Slope sections of Brooklyn yesterday. In the East New York disturbances, as many as 500 teenagers roamed the streets in groups of 50 to 100, but the police quickly dispersed them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Sports Arbitration Board, appointed 27 months ago to settle the power struggle in American amateur sports, rendered its decision today. The Amateur Athletic Union seemed pleased. The National Collegiate Athletic Association and the United States Track and Field Federation did not.

THE youthful talent of Camille Pissarro, who became the patriarch of impressionism, is shown in a group of his early drawings and water-colors in an excellent exhibition, "Pissarro in Venezuela," that opened to the public yesterday at the Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Feb 1 (AP) -- California urged the Supreme Court today to outlaw racial discrimination by licensed housing developers throughout the country.
A MINOR stumbling block on the road to the merger of Occidental Petroleum and Signal Oil cropped up yesterday, when the chief executive of Signal said he hadn't been told about the proposed deal.
Directors of Burlington Industries, Inc., the nation's largest diversified textile company, realigned its top management yesterday, elevating a 48-year-old executive to the presidency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- According to two scientists, live fish may become infected with dangerous germs from man and thus become a public health problem.

GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- The Soviet Union suggested today that a pact outlawing flights beyond national boundaries by bombers carrying atomic warheads could follow the projected treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

A two-day strike by maintenance workers at New York University Medical Center ended last night after both sides agreed to submit a contract dispute to binding arbitration. The 93 workers are members of Local 810, International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Sympathy strikes of soft-coal miners spread through five states today, closing dozens of mines.

Picketing garage workers sought shelter from the chill dampness, weary motorists sought legal parking spaces, and union and management negotiators sought an end to the garage contract dispute yesterday -- all with little success.

Seiji Ozawa, the 32-year-old Japanese conductor, has been appointed music director of the San Francisco Symphony beginning with the 1970-71 season. He will succeed Josef Krips, who will be named conductor emeritus of the orchestra when he retires after seven years at the end of the 1969-70 season.
Merchants, bankers and economists who tend to look to January retail business to provide a barometer for the year are due for disappointment and frustration, at least as far as New York is concerned.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The American Telephone Telegraph Co. filed today a proposal for sharp increases in the rates charged the communications and other industries for some services.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Government is taking executive power to reinstate at its discretion the export rebates due for removal on March 31.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 1 -- Here in the Jack London Inn overlooking Jack London Square, a boxing historian remembered today that when Jack Johnson won the world heavyweight title six decades ago, Jack London commented that "it's up to you, Jeff, to save the white race."
The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday it would not defend individuals who refuse to register for military service as a protest against war or the draft.
Harlem's first professional theater in almost 20 years, the New Lafayette, whose quarters were destroyed by a five-alarm fire Wednesday night, is seeking a new home.

KONTUM, South Vietnam, Feb. 1 (Agence France-Presse) -- Civilians were evacuated today from this province capital in the Central Highlands while troops of the United States' Fourth Infantry Division battled to loosen the Vietcong grip on the city.

As a senior in high school I was amazed to read your account of the widespread, unconcealed and basically ignored sale of addictive drugs on the streets of New York City's slum areas. My amazement was compounded, however, by the grim memories of the recent pre-dawn raid on the Stony Brook campus of the State University, in which 198 policemen arrested 33 alleged marijuana sellers and users in a manner reminiscent of a carnival atmosphere.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Following are excerpts from Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara's annual report to Congress on the defense posture of the United States:
The bond market continued its probing action yesterday, seeking to find out if interest rates could be held below the levels reached in mid-January.
A 26-member Cultural Council, which will formulate "broad goals" for the city's cultural affairs and administer grants and bequests for cultural activities, was named yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 1 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan lost a key member of his Republican administration today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Organized labor made clear in advance that it would not go along with the degree of wage restraint suggested by President Johnson in his Economic Report to Congress today.

Three men were arraigned for grand larceny in Criminal Court in Brooklyn yesterday after the Waterfront Commission said its investigators caught them loading a truck on Port Authority Pier 11 at the foot of Hamilton Street with cloth and tin ingots from Thailand on Wednesday night.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- The United States Military Academy, for more than 165 years an impenetrable gray bastion of masculinity, has admitted a woman to its instructional ranks.

Harold Rome, known for his songs in "Pins and Needles," "Wish You Were Here," "Fanny" and other shows, has been commissioned to write the music and lyrics for a Japanese-language musical version of "Gone With the Wind."

HANS RICHTER has long been one of the most versatile and appealing figures on the international art scene. Born in Berlin in 1888, he became one of the founders of the Dada movement in Zurich in 1916.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Secretary General Thant gave a luncheon today honoring Mrs. John F. Kennedy. It could have been a "thank you" for a small and sentimental gesture.

The Houston Cougars played before 52,693 fans in the Houston Astrodome recently when they halted the University of California, Los Angeles. Last night the nation's No. 1 team played before 8,606 fans in Madison Square Garden.
HAMBURG, West Germany, Feb. 1 -- Tevya the milkman found himself in unusual circumstances tonight: The red-light district -- you should excuse the expression -- of a German city.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 1 (Agence France-Presse) -- North Vietnam is waging a peace offensive while the Vietcong press an extraordinary war offensive. The contradiction is only in appearances.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- A Madison newspaper reported today that a New Orleans hospital patient told of a Presidential assassination plot three days before President Kennedy was killed.
Starting tomorrow, New York City consumers can obtain information about the best buys in food by dialing 349-0949. The 24-hour-a-day recorded telephone-message service is scheduled to begin at 9 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Following is the text of President Johnson's Economic Report, photographically reproduced, which accompanied the report by the Council of Economic Advisers that was presented to Congress today:
James McCracken sang Don Alvaro in Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" for the first time with the Metropolitan Opera last night, and it became clear the company now has a stalwart, new man for the role.
SKIING conditions were generally good to excellent in most of the north country yesterday, but a weather report that temperatures were expected to rise by morning had ski operators a bit worried.

PARIS -- Harold Wilson would be deluding himself if he thought his new austerity program and the dropping of virtually all military commitments east of Suez will at last satisfy President de Gaulle that Britain is eligible for Common Market membership.
A task force of plainclothes men to provide protection for women who have to use the streets at night was set up yesterday by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 1 -- Premier Chung II Kwon declared today that South Korea "should immediately take punitive action" against North Korea for recent Communist thrusts if the Seoul Government "could obtain international cooperation" in such an effort.

National Steel Corporation announced yesterday a number of expansion projects that will cost more than $250-million over the next three years and add a million tons to the company's finished product capacity.

The National Dairy Products Corporation, the producer of processed packaged foods, achieved in 1967 the highest sales and earnings in its history, Gordon Edwards, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 1 -- Talks between Israeli officials and Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations peace envoy, indicated today that a stalemate had been reached over the question of clearing the Suez Canal.

Bernard B. Zients, executive head of the Gimbels New York division of Gimbels Brothers, Inc., has been named president of Gimbels-New York as a result of changes in the company's organizational setup.

What, you might ask, is a modern dancer like Ross Parkes doing in a ballet company? One good answer would be John Butler's "Villon," which the Pennsylvania Ballet performed last night at the City Center.

New York City's Air Pollution Control Commissioner called yesterday for a $1-billion state bond issue to pay for new clean-air facilities, including incinerators to burn refuse for heat and power.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Senate Democratic and Republican leaders said today that they hoped to offer a compromise next week for the Administration's civil rights protection bill.
GRADY, Ark., Feb. 1 -- James Wilson has spent much of his life in Arkansas prisons, and his sad, dulled eyes reflect the pain and terror that have rushed past him there.

From time to time The New York Times expresses editorial displeasure with the actions of Congress in curtailing our foreign-aid appropriations. It has variously charged irresponsibility on the part of Senators and Representatives who have not accepted unthinkingly executive proposals for foreign spending.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Federal minimum wage rose to $1.60 an hour today for 33 million workers and to $1.15 for 8.5 million others.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 1 -- Hilmar Baunsgaard, leader of the Radical Liberal party, was named Denmark's new Premier in a 17-ministry Cabinet announced tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Vice President Humphrey walked through the rain apst 500 students shouting "Hell no, we won't go," tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Widespread Vietcong attacks on cities throughout South Vietnam dealt this city a hard blow, too.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- ''Rain-making,'' once a gleam in the eye of the transient charlatans, has advanced into the realm of scientifically grounded facts, reports to the annual meeting of the American Meteorological Society attested today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- Directors of the newly merged Pennsylvania-New York Central Transportation Company held their first meeting here today. Saunders, chairman, and Alfred E. Perlman, president.

JOHN BARRYMORE'S "Hamlet," which many consider the greatest of this century, lives only in the memories of those who saw it. Richard Burton's "Hamlet," regardless of how it is ranked, will suffer no such fate. Future generations will know how it looked, what it sounded like and how it was put together.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 -- Strike pressure in the automobile industry began easing today. The General Motors Corporation recalled 27,900 workers who had been laid off earlier, following the end of strikes at General Motors foundries earlier in the week.

A last-minute change has added considerable spice to one race and taken a little from another for the 49th annual Knights of Columbus track meet tonight at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Soviet Union took a giant step toward closing the nuclear missile gap last year by more than doubling its force of intercontinental ballistic missiles, Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The Senate Aeronautical and Space Sciences Committee said today aviation safety shows no signs of improvement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Within the first year after the war in Vietnam ends, the American economy might have to absorb 400,000 returning servicemen looking for jobs. The Government believes that this "should not pose an insuperable problem."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 1 -- The Yemeni republican ambassador to the United Arab Republic, who accused Saudi Arabia yesterday of having sent a tank column into Yemen, flew to Damascus today and delivered a special message to President Nurredin al-Attassi of Syria from Premier Hassan al-Amri of Yemen.
The Federal Reserve kept a firm rein on the nation's credit policy in the week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The United States is attempting to learn, through another direct contact, whether the North Korean Government has softened its refusal to hand back the intelligence ship Pueblo and her American crew, the State Department said today.
ATHENS, Feb. 1 -- The Government dismissed four senior ambassadors tonight as the military regime extended its purge of the civil service to the diplomatic corps.

A near blackout about property price information in the state since the expiration of the Federal levy on deed transfers Dec. 31 may be remedied by a number of bills that have been introduced in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The possibility that members of the armed services might have to be held on duty past the normal expiration of their terms has been touched on vaguely in discussions between President Johnson and some members of Congress, a White House spokesman said today.

Governor Rockefeller and Negro leaders unveiled the model of a state office building planned for Harlem and predicted yesterday that the project would touch off a new and better era for the world's most famous Negro community.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Johnson Administration asserted today that there would be "no prospect" of slowing the pace of inflation this year unless negotiated union wage settlements were "appreciably lower" than the average 5.5 per cent increase last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb: 1 (AP) -- The House Banking Committee today approved a bill to remove the requirement for a 25 per cent gold cover on Federal Reserve notes. If passed, the bill would free about $10.7-billion in gold for use to hold the dollar at its present international-exchange value.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 2 -- Vicious street fighting continued today in many South Vietnamese towns and cities, and the Vietcong attacked three more province capitals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The House passed today a comprehensive "truth-in-lending" bill designed to give consumers full and clear information on how much they pay in interest and other finance charges on loans and credit purchases.

DAWES ISLAND, Nigeria Jan. 30 -- A cool breeze wafted up the channel from the ocean, and the soldiers from the breakaway Eastern Region who are on this swampy island lay on top of their concrete bunkers, sunning themselves.

The establishment of the Oral History Association, the first national organization of oral historians, was announced yesterday at Columbia University. Dr. Louis M. Starr, director of Columbia's Oral History Research Office since 1958, is president of the group.

For several years, Roswell Rudd, a trombonist in the jazz avant-garde, has usually been the most communicative and enlivening member of the various groups with which he has played. WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Ho Chi Minh has been saying for over twenty years that the secret weapon of his soldiers was that they were more willing to die than their opponents. The courage and bravado of his guerrillas in the last few days were obviously meant to illustrate his point, yet even for men whose religion teaches them that death is preferable to life, there must be a limit to the slaughter.

Federal agencies have won support from an influential New York organization of foreign freight forwarders in a running dispute with shipping interests over liability limits on ocean cargo.

Richard M. Nixon formally announced yesterday, as expected, that he was a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Feb. 1 -- Vincent Lombardi stepped down as coach of the Green Bay Packers tonight. SOUTH AFRICA'S starfish flower (Stapelia) is a milkweed and butterflyweed relative which has adapted itself to a cactuslike growth. Minute hairs covering the surface give it a velvety green appearance. The genus is rich in huge, complexly patterned purple, brown and white flowers.

To buyers of his record albums (a half million of them in 1967), Rod McKuen is the writer and husky-voiced singer of sweet songs that celebrate love, loneliness and the loyalty of animals.
