Steel mills in the United States churned out last week the highest weekly tonnage in the history of the industry, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
ATHENS, Feb. 5 -- Five generals and 14 other officers of the Greek Air Force were dismissed today for having supported King Constantine's attempted coup of Dec. 13 against the revolutionary regime.

I appreciate the acknowledgment in your Jan. 31 editorial "Nobody Believes Communists" of the true meaning of my persistently misquoted assertion that the U.S. Government has the right, indeed the duty, in times of grave national danger to put out statements designed to mislead the enemy.
SALEM, Ore., Feb. 5 -- Attorney General Robert Y. Thornton refused to rule today whether Gov. George Romney was eligible to appear on the ballot in the Oregon Presidential primary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Johnson Administration, in the light of the Pueblo incident, is taking a number of steps to try to minimize the likelihood that other intelligence ships will be seized.

Conrad J. Lynn, a Negro lawyer, refused yesterday to surrender his passport, as he had been ordered to do by the State Department. The order, in a letter dated Jan. 30, had been issued because Mr. Lynn traveled last March to North Vietnam -- a restricted area under department regulations.

Your Jan. 26 editorial "Copper Strike Improvisation," correctly notes the importance attached by both sides in the current copper strike to the unions' determination to reinforce, and where necessary, establish bargaining on a company-wide basis in place of the "localized bargaining system that now prevails in copper."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Following is the text of President Johnson's message to Congress today outlining his proposals on education:

RECIFE, Brazil, Feb. 5 -- To the rich sugar plantation owners of Brazil's Northeast, the Most Rev. Helder Pessoa Camara, Archbishop of Olinda and Recife, is a Communist agitator. But to many reform-minded Roman Catholics around the world he is almost a saint.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction after several weeks of decline, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

DOUBLING the opponents in a game contract that they are expecting to make a hazardous occupation. To do so on the basis of high-card strength is foolish, but a double may be indicated for lead-directing reasons, or because there are indications that the cards will lie badly for the declarer.

CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 5 -- George Romney is looking relaxed these days. He has slowed his speech somewhat, if not his pursuit of voters' hands to shake, and while his syntax still is less Presidential than his profile, he seems to be weighing his answers more judiciously.

James Reston's interpretation (Jan. 17) of the American reaction to the withdrawal of Britain from the Far East is less than reassuring. As he points out, the American verbal denials of filling the vacuum are accompanied by thoughts of redeployment from Europe and new visions of alliances.

BETHPAGE, L. I., Feb. 5 -- Older residents of Nassau County will get door-to-door bus service from their homes to clubs for the elderly under an experimental plan announced today by the Franchised Bus Service Council of Nassau County.
A City Council committee considered two problems concerning the city's sidewalks yesterday -- how to keep the newsstands from disappearing and how to encourage more sidewalk cafes.

A major new retail chain in both the women's specialty store and the discount-department store fields was in the making yesterday when it was announced that the Diana Stores Corporation and the Mangel Stores Corporation had agreed in principle to a merger. The total annual sales volume of the two concerns is close to $300-million.

CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 5 -- The long locks of 18 students at Bishop Brady High School were sheared today after the boys ignored a warning from the school administrator, the Rev. Norman Limoges, to get their hair cut.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 5 -- Israeli authorities announced today that only Israeli currency would be legal tender in the occupied Gaza Strip and northern Sinai Peninsula after Feb. 16.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Three Brooklyn men were indicted today on charges of conspiring to violate the New Jersey election laws in connection with the unsuccessful referendum for a new race track in Secaucus last November.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Congress is considering a new travel tax to cut the dollar flow to Europe, and the question, as always when Government thinks of something new to tax, is, who shall be excused from paying it?

TWO pigeons fluttered beneath the huge center dome and swooped saucily to rest on the other side of the new Madison Square Garden. It had no significance. One look at the awesome grandeur of the latest temple to muscle and a visitor knows for sure that the new Garden definitely is not for the birds.

A bitter dispute between the United States and Brazil has imperiled renewal of the International Coffee Agreement, which has been vital in supporting the economies of many developing countries. Both sides are at fault, but if the agreement collapses the United States, as the richest country on earth and the biggest coffee consumer, will get most of the blame.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 5 -- The classic picture of a school hockey game being played at a New England school would be one of a rink set in a snow-covered meadow and ringed by bundled youngsters filling a wintry late afternoon with cheers.
OTTAWA, Feb. 5 -- Premier Daniel Johnson of Frenchspeaking Quebec rejected as inadequate today the federal Government's "human rights" approach to revising Canada's Constitution.
New York's largest bank warned businessmen yesterday not to go on an inventory-buying spree in 1968 "that would inevitably bring its own correction in the form of a serious recession."
SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 5 -- Sung-Hi Han danced on South Korea's largest stage tonight, but through all the ovations she kept scanning the audience for someone who would take her away from here.
A Federal grand jury returned a 10-count indictment yesterday against Donald Mullany, a former employe of Shields Co., the brokerage house.
The international travel industry was shocked yesterday by the Johnson Administration's proposals to curtail American tourism abroad.
PRIDE, fear and injuries, the key factors to success or failure in the National Hockey League, manifested themselves yesterday on several fronts.
BONN, Feb. 5 -- A West German millionaire, Hannsheinz Porst, suspected of spying for East Germany, was a victim of rivalry between two East Berlin Intelligence services, it was disclosed today.
Stock prices continued to decline yesterday as trading activity fell to the lowest level in more than two months.

In a series of executive shifts, the Turner Construction Company has designated Howard S. Turner, the company's president, as chief executive officer, and has named Francis B. Warren, executive vice president, as vice chairman of the board.
The Singer Company attained record sales and earnings for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, it was reported yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that arms would be distributed to South Vietnam's loyal citizens by next week.

NONE of the ingredients in Gerald Green's new novel is terribly new. The time is the Depression years of the thirties; the place the tenement area of a large city gone to seed, in this case the Brownsville section in Brooklyn.

GEORGE SZELL conducted the Cleveland Orchestra in the Verdi Requiem last night in Carnegie Hall, and better performances do not come around. Not since Toscanini has there been equivalent power and passion, line and control, in this great piece of music.
A group of 200 winter vacationers will sail from New York Feb. 23 aboard a luxury liner for a benefit cruise to help keep afloat a different type of vessel, the hospital ship Hope.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Johnson Administration proposed to Congress today curbs on foreign travel that would include the nation's first travel "expenditure tax."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A Federal Judge upheld today an Army ruling denying the use of Arlington National Cemetery to an antiwar organization for a memorial service for the country's military dead in Vietnam.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 5 -- The Rabbinical Council of America today announced a program for training Latin-American Jews in American seminaries and recruiting American rabbis for a year's service in Latin America, to arrest "a potential breakdown in Jewish religious life" there.

Mayor Lindsay, angry and tight-lipped, yesterday ordered municipal hospital employes to drive sanitation trucks and perform all sanitation duties, under police protection, to dispose of garbage accumulations in 71 municipal and voluntary hospitals.

Chrysalis is the cocoon state that ambitious caterpillars assume on their way to graduation as full-fledged butterflies. "Chrysalis" is also the title selected by Valerie Deakin to characterize her taut but limited ballet of adolescence, given its premiere last night at Theater 80 St. Marks by the Manhattan Festival Ballet.
Trading and prices declined yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Out of uniform, Charles Hartwell Bonesteel 3d is not likely to convey the impression that he is a full general in command of the Eighth Army and the United Nations troops in South Korea.
It was auto travel as usual for most commuter motorists as 650 parking garages reopened in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday after the settlement of an eight-day strike by 3,500 workers.

WHEN the curtain goes up on the second (and last) act of "I Only Want an Answer," the new play that opened last night at the Stage 73, Hermione Baddeley, playing a garrulous London charwoman, is, as they say in the acting versions of such plays, "discovered" at stage left, striking a match.

Julius Rudel will take the New York City Opera back to Los Angeles next November for a 14-performance season of eight operas in the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. The troupe played a three-week, 20-performance season there last fall, in its first Los Angeles visit.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The British Government reversed itself today and decided to compensate from public funds 12 British soldiers for their sufferings in the Sachsenhausen concentration camp during World War II.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The State Department said today that the United States recognized only the federal government of Nigeria and had never supported the secession movement of the former Eastern Region, which declared its independence May 27 as the Republic of Biafra.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- In the view of the Johnson Administration, North Vietnam has, both by word and deed, rebuffed the United States' efforts this last month to try to arrange talks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, deplored today the summary execution of a Vietcong officer but suggested that it had occurred "more in a flash of outrage" than in cold blood.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- President de Gaulle, reported to be furious over conflicting reports about remarks made by Foreign Minister Brandt, today withdrew luncheon invitations to two West German Cabinet ministers and sereral other high officials.
ATHENS, Feb. 5 -- Greece and Turkey have resumed efforts, this time in secret, to solve the Cyprus problem.
In Wall Street, where centennials are almost common-place these days, there was a sesquicentennial observance yesterday
Cleon Jones, the wandering outfielder of the New York Mets, signed his contract yesterday amid signs that he might wander no more.

CAPETOWN, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Fluid has formed around Philip Blaiberg's transplanted heart, and doctors have tapped it several times with needles inserted into the sac surrounding the heart, a spokesman for Groote Schuur Hospital said today.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 5 -- The poor nations of the world can look forward to little in the way of increased aid, according to initial statements made at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, which began work here today.

Art Farmer, the jazz trumpeter whose group was scheduled to appear at McMillin Theater last night with the Roland Kirk Quartet, turned out by some mischance to be in England. So Howard McGhee brought his sextet as a replacement.

A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order yesterday preventing the mass seizure of the East Village Other, but he declined to block the arrest of those involved in distributing the weekly tabloid, which authorities contend is obscene.

CANTHO, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Vietcong forces attacked 11 of the Mekong Delta's 16 provincial capitals in their big offensive in the last week and about 1,250 civilians were killed, more than 3,000 were wounded and 80,000 to 120,000 were left homeless, according to estimates today.
" Well, I guess there had to be a scapegoat for the police riots of 1964, and I'm it."
FORT BELVOIR, Va., Feb. 5 (UPI) -- Three Army men were being held here today for disciplinary action after they reportedly set up a meeting with a Soviet diplomat in nearby Washington.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 5 -- Roses will rain from the sky, parachutists will jump into five rings and hundreds of flags will drift down on a wind out of the southern Alps when the 10th Winter Olympic Games are opened tomorrow by President deGaulle in this historic city.

On the dusty cement floor of the new Madison Square Garden, Nino Benvenuti, displaying a dedication to the proposition that seats are to be sat on, scanned the red, mauve, green and blue cushioned chairs that rose to the roof.

The stock certificate, a major culprit in the current paperwork jam on Wall Street, may eventually become obsolete as a result of a program announced yesterday by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb., 5 -- Abolition of the Westchester Board of Supervisors, which has guided the county government since 1683, and the setting up of a compact Board of Legislators to absorb its duties was proposed reluctantly today by the chairman of the Board of Supervisors.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Richard McCombs (lanky, blond and tall as a lighthouse) and William Forman (slight, dark and "cute," as a girl described him later) walked into the Sarah Lawrence College cafeteria this morning and turned not one of half a hundred feminine heads bent over breakfast.
Officers of a Parents Association at Bedford-Stuyvesant's Junior High School 258 yesterday accused a group of teachers of "the deliberate incitement of our children to demonstrate.''
One of five men charged in a Bronx bomb plot to blow up a pro-Communist meeting last June was sentenced yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court to two years in prison.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The State Department made public tonight details of three incidents in which it said Soviet electronic intelligence ships had intruded into the United States' three-mile limit and had been ordered to leave.
Running against the prevailing trend in the industry, the Dow Chemical Company yesterday reported new records in sales and earnings for the final quarter of 1967 and for the year as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- More than 15 years after the first deaths were attributed to it, doctors are still using the drug chloramphenicol in cases for which it is neither needed nor useful, three specialists said today.

PARIS -- If one could categorize the French calendar like the Chinese calendar, which represents each passing year by symbols, one might call 1966 de Gaulle's NATO year and 1967 his gold year, respectively indicated by the general's withdrawal from the alliance organization and by his attack on the pound and dollar.

A performance of Mozart's great C minor Mass by the Dessoff Choirs would not normally be extraordinary -- this was the fourth time they have sung it over the years -- but last night's presentation in Carnegie Hall was just that because it marked the official end of Paul Boepple's 32 years as the organization's conductor.

The nation's two top can manufacturers -- the American Can Company and the Continental Can Company -- achieved record sales in 1967, according to reports issued by the concerns yesterday. Continental outdistanced American, which suffered a sharp setback because of a non-recurring loss from the sales of its glass business.

OTTAWA, Feb. 6 -- Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the federal Minister of Justice, who is a French Canadian, said today that the special powers demanded for French-speaking Quebec by its Premier, Daniel Johnson, would undermine the province's position in the Canadian confederation and lead ultimately to secession.
" WOW," whispered a small boy, glancing up at an array of plastic, glass, chrome and paper furnishings. "That's what we're going to have in the really Modern Age."
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 6 -- Mayor Richard C. Lee tonight ordered "police patrols on a saturation basis" to prevent further outbreaks of racial violence in New Haven's public high schools.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Feb. 7 -- While South Korean youths demonstrated outside the United States Embassy yesterday, the National Assembly adopted a strongly worded resolution condemning the secret negotiations between the United States and North Korea over the Pueblo.
CRANSTON, R. I., Feb. 6 (AP) -- A husband and wife who are doctors were acquitted yesterday of charges that they ignored a police request to come to the aid of a sick woman last New Year's Eve.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary has ordered an investigation of the entire narcotics bureau of the Police Department based on charges by a captain formerly in the bureau who contends that it is "riddled with corruption."
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association said yesterday it would appeal a ruling by an impartial umpire who found it guilty of raiding the jurisdiction of another union.
The sanitation union agreed last night to resume garbage collections at hospitals, schools and other places designated by the city as suffering emergency conditions.
Mayor Lindsay directed Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin yesterday to suggest new legislation to the state to tighten fire safety for the city's buildings.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- An Assembly committee acted today to assure full-scale debate and a vote on a bill that would reform the state's 85-year-old abortion law.

GENEVA, Feb. 6 -- Rumania joined Italy and Brazil today in opposing an attempt by the United States and the Soviet Union to have the disarmament conference give its prompt endorsement to their proposal to prohibit the further spread of nuclear weapons.
I read with interest and dismay your Jan. 25 editorial concerning the taxi problem.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Sweden granted asylum today to six more American deserters, raising the number of those allowed to stay in the country to 13.

A cooperative that includes more than 50 meat processing companies has signed a 20-year lease with the city to develop 37 acres in the Hunts Point Food Processing and Distribution Center of the Bronx.

Even the pledge the sanitation union has finally given to start alleviating the worst of the pile-up is scant solace to this beleaguered community.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 6 -- The Belgian Government, fighting for its life in a renewed outbreak of the struggle between Walloons and Flemings, tonight defeated a Parliamentary motion of censure of its handling of the language war at the University of Louvain.

Norton W. Simon probably had decided as early as last October to relinquish his last connection with the Wheeling Steel Corporation, although he did not sell his remaining 100,000 shares in the troubled company until December.
BONN, Feb. 6 -- Despite increasingly elaborate and efficient security measures, border guards of the East German People's Army are continuing to defect to the West.
GRADY Ark., Feb. 6 -- At least 70 of the 254 deaths reported at the Arkansas State Penitentiary since 1936 resulted from violence, an inspection of the prison records showed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Charles J. Zwick, President Johnson's new budget director, got his baptism of fire today before a Congressional committee. He wound up defending not only Mr. Johnson's budget but also United States troop strength in Europe.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 6 -- After the bands had played and the roses had showered down on the stadium and the Olympic flame had been lit after nearly two hours of pomp and ceremony, most of the 60,000 spectators who had watched the opening of the Winter Olympics today agreed it had been spectacular.

Brig. Gen. Nguyen Ngoc Loan's act (Feb. 2 Times) was revolting. It is a sad day when our Government unquestioningly supports a regime which appears willing to countenance such criminality on the part of its high officials.
The horrifying picture on the front page of the Feb. 2 Times showing the police chief in Saigon killing a Vietcong prisoner should be enough to turn the stomach even of a sanctimonious hawk.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 6 -- J. Fagan Dickson, an Austin lawyer, has filed as a candidate in the Democratic primary for the 10th Congressional District, the area once represented by President Johnson. At the same time he issued a call to the President not to seek re-election as a means of promoting "new alternatives in Vietnam."

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 6 -- Wondrous it was. The sun obediently broke cloud cover after early morning rain and snow. The snowcapped Alps reared into view on cue. And the vast stadium came alive in a carnival of sight and sound. President de Gaulle had arrived to open the 19th Winter Olympic Games.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., reported yesterday record results for 1967, generally acknowledged as the most profitable year in Wall Street history.

Under court compulsion Westchester is reluctantly moving toward abolition of the antiquated Board of Supervisors that has been the county's governing body since 1683. Now a new fight is in prospect over the mechanism to be put in its place.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 7 -- The American command reported yesterday that new Vietcong forces were slipping into Saigon from the south, as the fighting in the city went into its second week.
Bob Seagren may not be alone in his quest for 17 feet in the pole vault at the Madison Square Garden invitation meet Friday night.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that it had received from the United States Department of Labor on the union's new service charge of up to $100 a year to its pensioners. It said it had not yet received replies from the New York State Banking Department and Insurance Department.

The Health Services Administrator of New York City is, potentially at least, the most prestigious and influential local public health official in the nation. One might have thought that news of a vacancy in this $37,500-a-year position would bring a rush of well-qualified applicants, and that Mayor Lindsay's problem would have been one of an embarrassment of good choices.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 6 -- The anti-American policies of President de Gaulle of France are steadily eroding the high regard Americans traditionally have held for France and her people, according to the latest Gallup Poll.
A Lindsay-appointed member of the city's Air Pollution Control Board said yesterday that he had "lost faith in the Mayor," declaring that he had fallen down on promises to speed pollution control.

Five blocks on the Lower East Side were closed by the police last night after residents -- spurred by a neighborhood action group -- dumped their rubbish into the streets to protest the Sanitation Department strike.
The long-standing plan of Eastern Air Lines to diversify out of the airlines business came to naught yesterday.

THE pageantry of the opening of the 10th Winter Olympic Games in Grenoble, France, was carried in live color yesterday morning over the network of the American Broadcasting Company. The satellite circuit spanning the Atlantic was not up to past technical standards; the picture was frequently plagued by a fuzzy overcast that caused soft and grainy color reproduction.

With Bill Bradley making the largest contribution of his brief but well-documented career, the New York Knickerbockers routed the St. Louis Hawks, 121-100, at Madison Square Garden last night and gave their followers all sorts of gratifications.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 6 -- A State Supreme Court justice today struck down three laws by which the five eastern towns of Suffolk County would have broken their ties to the county police department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The aircraft carrier Enterprise has been ordered to withdraw from a position off the North Korean coast.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- More than 80 of the 327 Labor Members of Parliament tonight urged Prime Minister Wilson to break with United States policy in Vietnam.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Two New York City Democrats introduced a bill in the Legislature today to revise auto insurance policies drastically and keep most accident cases out of the courts.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 -- At exactly 3:40 P.M. today Semon Emil (Bunkie) Knudsen permitted himself to be photographed in a Ford car for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- "Attack and counterattack widened across South Vietnam today," The Associated Press reported. "Large sections of Saigon and Hue lay in smoldering ruins, and columns of smoke rose as South Vietnamese divebombers, U.S. helicopter gunships, artillery and tanks blasted away at Communist troops in scattered sections."

What's in a price increase? Sometimes commodity futures respond, sometimes not. Yesterday palladium and platinum futures apparently gained strength following Monday's late afternoon anouncement of higher prices for palladium quoted by Engelhard Industries.

BAYONNE, N. J., Feb. 6 -- Eighteen gangs of longshoremen, 360 men in all, walked off their jobs this morning at the Military Ocean Terminal here in a dispute over penalties imposed by a stevedoring company because of absenteeism. Later it was announced that the men would return to work tomorrow.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The Ballet Rambert, which opened tonight at the Phoenix Theater, is offering a repertory mingling American-style modern dance with classic ballet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Bids totaling a record $602,204,284.26 for the privilege of drilling for oil on the Pacific Ocean bottom off the coast of California were opened today by the Department of the Interior.
HELENA, Mont., Feb. 6 -- Republican Gov. Tim M. Babcock announced his intention today to campaign for re-election.

RHODES, Greece, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- The United States destroyer Bache went aground on rocks here today, forcing most of her crew of about 240 to abandon ship.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 6 (UPI) -- Racing resumes tomorrow at Santa Anita race track.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman of Thailand declared today that the present Vietcong offensive had not altered his conviction, shared generally in his area, that the allies were winning the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Johnson, in a special message to Congress, proposed today an eight-point program "to protect the consumer -- and the honest businessman alike -- against fraud and indifference."

ANTONIO and his Ballets de Madrid returned to New York last night at the New York City Center. He had a number of new works, even though everything that was new was the mixture as before. If you like Antonio and his way with the Spanish dance, you will definitely like this program.

NEWARK, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- The Negro playwright LeRoi Jones, who faces two and one-half to three years in prison on conviction of carrying guns during the Newark riot last summer, has been heading an advisory group at the Robert Treat Elementary School.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 -- Semon E. Knudsen, who resigned last week as an executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, was named president of the Ford Motor Company today.

HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 -- United States marines recaptured the provincial capital building today and added 14 more blocks to their growing foothold in this historical city, once the center of Vietnam's imperial government.
Carter L. Burgess resigned yesterday as chairman, chief executive officer and a director of the American Machine and Foundry Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) -- One section of President Johnson's balance-of-payments program has been dropped and another will undergo readjustments, Administration sources confirmed today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 7 -- Nine Soviet-made tanks spearheaded a North Vietnamese assault early today against the Langvei Special Forces camp, six miles west of Khesanh, the isolated marine outpost near the Vietnamese demilitarized zone.

The stock market wobbled to a mixed close yesterday as trading activity continued to diminish.

National Educational Television and the City Center Joffrey Ballet are looking for $250,000 to present a new, full-length ballet on stage and television.

ORONO, Me., Feb. 6 -- Two University of Maine policemen barred about 30 students and faculty members today from entering Coburn Hall, where a Dow Chemical Company recruiter was interviewing student for prospective employment with the company.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 6 -- To see Mrs. George Romney in action is to watch an authentic, stand-up evangelist weave a spell.

FEW scenes are so dismal as an auto speedway after the race. The grandstands are vacated, concessions boarded up, garages deserted and untidy, pit popsies have departed and suddenly the gay advertising banners seem listless and tatty.

BONN, Feb. 6 (Reuters) -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger informed Christian Democratic Members of Parliament today that remarks by Foreign Minister Willy Brandt in a speech Saturday were not directed against President de Gaulle.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- First-born or only children are, in general, more fearful than are their younger siblings and do not perform under stress as well as they do, a psychologist says.
Interest rates on short-term securities and tax-exempt bonds -- two areas of the credit markets that declined in yield throughout January -- turned about and moved upward yesterday.

HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- An advance party of British engineers has arrived to begin construction of a $100-million fertilizer plant essential for Cuba's ambitious agricultural plans.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Despite the loss of Steve Hunt, Army's big pivot man, the cadets played another masterly ball-control game to beat Rutgers, 50-41. It was Army's 10th straight victory. This is the longest winning streak in 21 years for a cadet basketball team.

An aviation industry leader warned here yesterday against enactment of "any sweeping and precipitous" legislation to restrict general aviation's use of airports and airspaces. General aviation refers to all civilian flying except that by the airlines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Five employes of the Agency for International Development, including an assistant administrator, have resigned in the last month as a result of an agency investigation of alleged misconduct and possible malfeasance.

The Ramuz fables fit many occasions. His tales of yesterday become parables for our hysteric time. The scene of today's book is emblematically neu tral Switzerland.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- The measures proposed by the Johnson Administration to curb spending by American tourists abroad aroused alarm and indignation in Europe today, tempered only by the hope that Congress would not go along.

A spokesman for most of the state's private colleges and universities said yesterday that many of these institutions fear they are being unjustifiably overshadowed by the fast-growing State University.
There was a further slowdown in trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices retreated and advanced throughout the day and finished with little change in either direction.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 7 -- Peggy Fleming of the United States took a commanding lead in the figure skating and Franco Nones, an Italian customs officer, astounded the world of Nordic skiing today by humiliating all the great Scandinavian racers in winning the 30-kilometer cross-country race for the first gold medal of the Winter Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Orville L. Freeman, announced today sale of 8.75 billion board feet of timber in the Tongass National Forest in southeastern Alaska to United States Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc. Completion of the contracts was set for July 31.
OTTAWA, Feb. 7 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson won approval of all 10 provincial premiers today for a long-term program to give the French language equal status with English throughout Canada.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Johnson and Jean Rey, president of the European Common Market Commission, agreed today that both surplus and deficit countries must act "to achieve a better equilibrium in the international balance of payments."

BONN, Feb. 7 -- Willy Brandt, West Germany's Foreign Minister, told the Bundestag today that he would not go to Paris "wearing a hair shirt" because a German press agency had misquoted him when it reported he had said President de Gaulle was "power-obsessed."
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- Temple defeated St. John's tonight, 62-55, in a game that exhibited excellent team and individual defense before 3,696 fans at the Palestra.
The State Health Department has found conditions at Fordham Hospital "deplorable" and has demanded a response within 60 days to its item-by-item criticism of health and safety practices.

SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 7 (UPI) -- District Judge Joe Angel today ordered 11 persons to stand trial for the raid on the Rio Arriba County Courthouse last June 5, but dismissed charges against nine others.

Mayor Lindsay's ultimatum to the striking sanitationmen who have held the city in bondage since last Friday is precisely the action required to save the city from disaster. Not far from here, along one of the narrow roads that thread New Hampshire's hills, an old, white clapboard house has been restored and painted and a witty weekend resident has placed a sign out front that reads: "The Old Values."

DETROIT, Feb. 7 -- The American Motors Corporation reported net profits from operations of $4,483,000, or 23 cents a share, for its first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 against a loss of $8,460,000 a year ago.

At least not the pop, bad tasty, arrested pubescent humor that has overtaken the fashion world in what is probably the most boring spring season in a generation's memory. There wasn't a single camp joke in the collection that the 43-year-old, Los Angelesbased designer presented yesterday at the Plaza Hotel here.
The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, a leader in American Protestantism for half a century, died of a heart attack yesterday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 83 years old.

PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 9 -- Four or five armed men escaped with about $120,000 from the Riverside branch of the First National Bank of Passaic County shortly before noon today.
The only seagoing synagogue in the North Atlantic luxury-liner service in recent years has made a landfall in Brooklyn.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 9 (AP) --The South Vietnamese United Nations observer accused Senator Robert F. Kennedy today of making "unfair and unfounded criticism," against the people and Government of that country.

In nearly five years since his other New York recital, Thomas Schumacher has grown from a promising talent into a confident artist. At the Metropolitan Museum last night, he played with a round, pleasing tone, considerable dynamic flexibility and, as the evening progressed, real virtuosic flair.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 8 (AP) -- George Gallup, now in his fourth decade of surveying the moods of America, says the public today is confused, disillusioned and cynical and "wants desperately to find a way to resolve international problems without going to war."
EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Feb. 9 -- A white clergyman was charged today with committing criminal damage to property by allegedly painting "Black Power" and other slogans on buildings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Treasury bill rate rose again at today's auction from the levels of last Monday, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

TOKYO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Japanese Government may suspend a 10 per cent withholding tax on interest payments made to foreign investors who purchase foreign currency debentures issued by Japanese companies.

ORANGEBURG, S. C., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Gov. Robert E. McNair put this college town under a night time curfew today and said black power advocates had sparked the violence in which three Negro students were shot to death.

DALLAS, Feb. 9 (AP) -- John M. Bailey, the Democratic National Chairman, today denounced former Vice President Richard M. Nixon on foreign policy. He declared that Mr. Nixon had said a screen of ships and planes should have been provided for the Pueblo, the intelligence ship captured by the North Koreans.

LEONIA, N. J. -- Fresh-baked bread and jam make a favorite after-school snack for youngsters across the country, but for eight boys in this Bergen County community the repast had special significance because they baked the bread themselves.
L.T.V. Electr0systems, Inc.,! has announceki'fthe election of Oliver Kirby as a vice president. Mr. Kirby was formerly assistant director of the National Security Agency.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 9 -- Eighteenth-century furniture made in the American South is just being rediscovered. A finely carved chair has provided Colonial Williamsburg researchers with new evidence of the excellent craftsmen working there, now that it has been identified as a local product of the Revolutionary period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today htat a Federal judge should decide whether illegal eavesdropping led to the spy conspiracy conviction of an American scientist and a Soviet chauffeur.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The Defense Department lifted today a four-month-old freeze on $800-million in military construction in the United States and abroad.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission allocated 165 new radio channels today for business and public use, including 20 for the exclusive use of police departments.

For most of the audience that filled Philharmonic Hall last night, the concert given there was more than a musical occasion. It was the leave-taking of a former mentor, friend and symbol of remembered joys in music when they were young.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 9 -- Last Wednesday in practice, Princeton's basketball captain, Joe Heiser, suffered a slightly sprained ankle. He was unable to practice yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Some 500 leaders of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations will meet next month to plan how to swing the political weight of the 14-million-member labor federation behind President Johnson and liberal Congressional candidates in the November elections.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 10 -- American infantry troops were brought to Saigon yesterday to help clear the city of guerrillas who have held out here for 12 days.

PHOENIX, Ariz. Feb. 8 (AP) -- The parents of Linda Marie Ault were charged today with involuntary manslaughter in the death of their daughter, who killed herself rather than shoot her dog as punishment for spending the night with a man.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 9 -- The Secretary General of the British Commonwealth, Arnold Smith, an active figure in earlier attempts to bring Nigeria's civil war to a negotiated end, arrived today in Lagos and met with Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, head of the federal military Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Prime Minister Wilson of Britain today ended talks with President Johnson during which he concluded that the latest American and North Vietnamese positions on peace negotiations could still be reconciled.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 9 (AP) -- A state income tax and other revenue reforms were recommended today by Gov. John H. Chafee to finance a $219.1-million budget submitted to the General Assembly. Mr. Chafee is a Republican, and the Assembly is controlled by Democrats.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 9 -- The British decision to withdraw from the island of Bahrein in the Persian Gulf in 1971 has revived antagonism between Iran and the Arabs.

Florida citrus growers yesterday denied rumors that a frost injured orange groves, and down went orange juice futures by the 3 cents a pound limit. The previous day they had jumped the limit on rumors of the frost.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 9 -- In the normal course of events tomorrow night's $25,000 Early Bird Pacing Series final would monopolize attention at Roosevelt Raceway. But so much interest has been generated by an ordinary Class A-3 pace worth only $4,000 that this event will share the spotlight.

Bistate legislation to extend the Waterfront Commission's police powers to the major airports of the metropolitan area is the obvious answer to racketeer infiltration of the air freight industry. WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) --The United States and West Germany canceled today a joint project to develop a vertical take-off tactical fighter plane.

CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The New Hampshire Supreme Court ruled today that Eugene Daniell Jr. did not need Robert F. Kennedy's consent to conduct a write-in campaign for the New York Senator in the state's Democratic Presidential preference primary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Johnson sent Cyrus R. Vance, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, to Korea today as his special representative for discussions on the "grave threat" to South Korea.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 9 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy said tonight that the unplanned growth of government has harmed, instead of helped, New York State's efforts to meet the needs of the future.
SAIGON, Saturday Feb. 10 (AP) -- United States Navy jets attacked the Catboi air base, four miles southeast of Haiphong, yesterday, military headquarters reported today.

A special performance by leading artists of the Metropolitan Opera will be presented by the company at 8 P.M. on Saturday, March 16, during the 26th week of its season, as a benefit for its Benevolent Fund and Retirement Fund. The singers will perform arias and ensembles they have not sung previously at the Metropolitan.
The establishment of the Port of New York Coordinating Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Maritime Committee was announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Public relations personnel at Missouri Pacific said that normal operations were expected to be resumed sometime tomorrow morning.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9 -- The Republican party lost its four seats in the Louisiana Legislature in the state's general election this week, but Louisiana politicians do not interpret the Democratic sweep as a gain for the national Democratic party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- As never before in the bewildering warfare of Vietnam, the forces of the United States and North Vietnam are gathered for battle, and world attention is focused on one point -- Khesanh.

To the Editor: I am appalled by The Times's Feb. 1 news story regarding the cutoff of Social Security benefits to some 15,000 aliens resident abroad. It is indecent for the United States to treat people who have worked here and paid their Social Security taxes in such a cavalier manner.

To the Editor: The public has been helpless to defend itself against the abuses of power by unions supposedly serving the public. Transportation, sanitation, education and other services are shut off to enforce the demands of the members of these unions -- reasonable or unreasonable.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 9 -- Former Gov. George C. Wallace has enlisted more than a dozen top elected and appointded officials of Alabama, to support his Presidential campaign.

JERICHO, Jordan, Feb. 9 -- This historic area of the Israeli-held West Bank known as the site of Joshua's most famous battle, was the scene today of two contrasting incidents in another struggle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The White House and the Pentagon described as false and ridiculous today speculation that the military had sought nuclear weapons for use in Vietnam and was stockpiling them there.

Nervousness over the international situation sent prices tumbling again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Brokers said many investors appeared to be acting on the axiom: when in doubt sell.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A significant comeback in automobile sales in January contributed strongly to a general rebound in retail sales in January, after a disappointing December, Commerce Department figures showed today.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino criticized the Lindsay administration yesterday for the increasing gap between the large sums appropriated for city construction programs and the smaller sums actually spent.
Investors gave a good -- but not enthusiastic -- reception to the Treasury's $24.3-billion refunding offer earlier this week, figures released yesterday by the Government indicated.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 9 -- Harsh words for the rich and poor nations of the world were delivered today by George D. Woods, president of the World Bank.

The 91st annual banquet commemorating the birth of George Washington will be given by the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York on Feb. 22 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 9 -- Columbia's basketball team, which hopes to be the monarch of the Ivy League this season, was extended by unpretentious Dartmouth tonight. Columbia won, 76-70, in double overtime after trailing most of the way against a smaller team that had lost 12 of its 16 previous games.
ROME, Feb. 9 -- Pope Paul VI today, for the first time, named laymen and women as consultants to a congregation of the Roman Curia, the administrative body of the Roman Catholic Church.

The Kosciuszko Foundation held its 33d annual ball last night in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. LONDON -- New York may soon have an antiques supermarket. London already has three and Bennie Gray, who started two of them, plans to have his New York venture open "in time for the Christmas trade." The American Export Isbrandtsen Lines applied to the Maritime Administration yesterday for construction differential subsidy for the modernization of the company's two 20,269-ton passenger liners, the Independence and the Constitution, into single-class vessels.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 9 -- Jean-Claude Killy won downhill gold medal as the French placed one, two today in this classic Winter Olympic event. DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Cale Yarborough and Richard Petty won the pole positions today for the Daytona 500-mile stock car race on Feb. 25 with record-breaking qualifying speeds that bettered 189 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The American Institute of Architects has selected Marcel Breuer of New York to receive its 1968 gold medal. The medal is awarded annually "for most distinguished service to the profession of architecture or to the institute."
TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 8 -- The Libyan Parliament is expected to pass a foreign investment law soon which hopes to attract diversified industries to this desert country.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 11 -- An important Opposition leader was found dead early today on a railway track near Benares.
What promises to be New York's first major rock 'n' roll concert series is picking up tempo at the Anderson Theater, 66 Second Avenue.
Tom Paxton gave another of his folk concerts in which he pokes fun at all sorts of human foibles last night at Philharmonic Hall.
GRADY, Ark., Feb. 11 -- A county grand jury will begin an investigation tomorrow into the removal of three skeletons from mysterious graves at a nearby prison farm.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- Senator Gale McGee said today the Vietcong penetration of 28 of South Vietnam's 44 provincial capitals was no proof that the Communists were winning the war.

Ch. Hetherbull's Arrogance, a 3 1/2-year-old brindle-andwhite bulldog, was selected best of breed for the second successive year yesterday in the Bulldog Club of America specialty at the Hotel Edison. Beryl R. Gould of Frankfort, Ind., made the selection after he pared down the field of 94 entries.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Two California redwood lumber companies have notified Congress that they are resuming timber harvesting in the Redwood Creek drainage area.
The General Electric Company last week became the first major company this year to attempt something new in the way of controlling the length of stockholder meetings.

TORONTO, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press) -- David Kuehne and David Cady of Rochester were unofficially named winners today of the Canadian winter auto rally. They became the first Americans to win the event since 1959.

State Medical Society leaders urged doctors yesterday to abandon "the horse-and-buggy approach" to providing health care and to support Federal programs for medical services that many physicians have vehemently opposed.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Feb. 11 (UPI) -- The City Council of this beach community will decide this month whether to seek funds to install a police surveillance system that critics of the plan compare to George Orwell's book, "1984."

Madison Square Garden the Fourth opened last night with a main event that, if not quite the fight of the century, at least reeked of greatness. Bob Hope, boxing under the nom de glove of "Chicken Delight," squared off against Rocky Marciano, the retired unbeaten heavyweight champion.

Mayor Lindsay charged yesterday that the plan under which Governor Rockefeller ended the city's nine-day sanitation strike is "unsound" and "corrupts the fundamental rights of the people of New York City."
SOUTH PITTSBURGH, Tenn., Feb. 11 (UPI) -- The Mayor and police commissioner told townspeople today that a prominent citizen had been killed not by a policeman's bullet but by a heart attack.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Like a delayed time fuse, the current enemy offensive in Vietnam seems to be setting off within the Senate a critical political reaction against the validity as well as the credibility of the Administration's policy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 -- "There's nothing here but old ladies," Capt. Jeffrey I. Dalia radioed to his battalion headquarters this afternoon as his infantry company completed a search for Vietcong in a suburban hamlet.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The United States hockey team, shut out the last two periods by a reserve goalie, lost again tonight when Canada scored twice in the final period for a 3-2 Olympic victory.

Stella Marrs, a singer who is described by her pianist, Gene Harris, as "a groovy chick who's been scuffling and should be heard." gave a concert at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon that justified the comment.
A $38-million expansion of the New York Coliseum was proposed yesterday by its owner, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Vice President Humphrey, a founder of the liberal Americans for Democratic Action, quietly dropped out of the organization three years ago.

The top management of the Cities Service Company has been realigned following the resignation of John L. Burns as chairman, chief executive officer and director, the petroleum, natural gas and petrochemical concern announced yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Stalactites and stalagmites are growing under the Lincoln Memorial.

After more than 11 hours of judging the 441 entries in the 25th annual American Boxer Club specialty show at the 71st Regiment Armory yesterday. Ch. Salgray's Ambush was named best of breed for the second straight year.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -The Ice Capades arrived a day early at the Spectrum today with the pulsating triumph of Manuel Santana in the final of the Philadelphia indoor tennis championships.

PRATTVILLE, Ala., Feb. 11 (UPI) -- A gunman and his 16year-old girl friend were transferred to jail here today to face murder charges following a four-state chase that left two dead and four wounded.
The City Health Department received 200 telephone calls yesterday, mostly from worried residents, but many from out-of-towners who asked if it were safe to come to the city.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Donald Colby and Eddie Schissler of Lake Placid captured the New York State junior ski jumping championships today.

BONN, Feb. 11 -- Spurred by the rapidly growing European demand for electronic data processing equipment, West Germany's Siemens A.G. is about to join the exclusive ranks of companies with sales of more than $2-billion a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Union Station, with its mammoth Roman arches and empty, echoing waiting room, is like a grand but lonely old lady who has fallen on hard times. Last night, the station, a throwback to the pre-plane era, saw more action than it has in years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (UPI) -The Montreal Canadiens registered their 15th victory in their last 16 National Hockey League games today, routing the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-0, for their seventh shutout of the season.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 11 -The continuing chaos in Communist China has refurbished the Chinese Nationalists' dream of recovering the mainland, but there is a new hard-headed reality among this island's leaders about the dream's fulfillment.
Gary Towlen, a 25-year-old pianist who is already 13 years into his concert career, played at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 11 (AP) -- If the merged Penn Central Railroad can't make a good profit, "then transportation in this country won't go on as free enterprise," a Connecticut State official said today.

NEWPORT, N. H., Feb. 11 -A critic of American policy in Vietnam said today he had new evidence that American officials were actively interested in bringing Ngo Dinh Diem to power in Vietnam more than a year before the French suffered their decisive military defeat there in May, 1954.
The abrasive rattle of garbage cans was heard again yesterday on the sidewalks of New York.

Feelings of rejection and self-pity were apparently rife at the recent meeting of the American Physical Society in Chicago. Complaints were voiced of inadequate enrollment in physics courses, from the high school to graduate levels, as well as of declining financial support. One speaker referred to a "revulsion against science" throughout all American society.
" Brush up your Shakespeare," as a popular song advises, and you may be able to deduct it from your income tax. That is, if you are an English teacher.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers, sparked by Jerry West and Elgin Baylor, stormed to a 30-point half-time lead today and went on to hand the Boston Celtics their worst defeat of the National Basketball Association season, 141104, before a jeering crowd of 9,001 and a national television audience.

NEWARK, Feb. 11 -- City officials said today they were "shocked" that a special commission studying last summer's riots in New Jersey had "fudged the real issues" by urging a grand jury investigation of alleged corruption at City Hall.

HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (Agence France-Presse) -- A South Vietnamese soldier who was test-firing his rifle set off a blaze today that killed two North Vietnamese soldiers held in a Government compound here.

ATHENS, Feb. 11 -- The principal spokesman for the governing Greek Junta denounced as a "rehash" today the draft constitution drawn up last December by a group of jurists and indicated that a radically revised version would be prepared.
George Young is ready, Dave Patrick says he will be ready in five weeks and Billy Mills says he will be ready when it counts.
The abandoned Canadian freighter Charny sank yesterday approximately 520 miles off Cape Hatteras, N. C., the Coast Guard reported yesterday.

Nova Scotia and its two deepwater ports, Halifax and Canso, expect to be a factor in the "land-bridge" movement of containers between Europe and Asia, W.S.K. Jones, Nova Scotia's Minister of Trade and Industry said here last week.
Hundreds of angry pharmacists voted yesterday to stop filling Medicaid prescriptions here beginning this morning.

ELLEN STEWART lives in two worlds. At night she is impresario, angel and den mother of La Mama E.T.C. (Experimental Theater Club), an East Village group dedicated to exapnding the boundaries of the theater arts. Days, she works for Victor Bijou as a designer of sport dresses and beach wraps, which are dedicated to "helping a woman look beautiful."
Special to The New York Times BONN, Feb. 12 -- The police initiated today legal proceedings against four persons who wore swastikas and other Nazi emblems to a private costume ball in Nuremberg.
For Morris Bernstein, a Wall Street businessman for the last 52 years, it was a slow day. His business was down about two-thirds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Republican members of the House Banking Committee charged today that businessmen were refusing to speak up against elements of President Johnson's balance-of-payments program because they feared reprisals or hoped for favorable treatment.
John Mosler, former chairman of the Mosler Safe Company, now almost entirely owned by American Standard, Inc., has resigned from the American Standard board.

SAIGON, South Vietnam. Tuesday, Feb. 13 (Agence France - Presse) -- The South Vietnamese Government has decided to ban Air France flights over the country, the Saigon Daily News reported today. The English-language paper said the decision was made because Air France serves Cambodia and Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Gen. William C. Westmoreland was defended today by several Representatives against criticism of his performance as commander in Vietnam.

THE New England Regional Knockout Championship that was played in Hartford ended late Sunday night in a victory for Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., and Andy Bernstein, Peter Weichsel and Harold Feldheim, all of New York.

WESTOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Defense forces of the North American Air Defense Command will conduct joint training exercises over the Eastern United States early Friday, the Air Force announced today. Residents were warned that harmless, high altitude sonic booms might be heard over Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, New York, Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Jersey, Delaware and Pennsylvania.

DALLAS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Four-year-old Dianne Watts of Denison, Tex., whose playmates tied a rope around her neck and pushed her down a slide Thursday, died today in a Dallas hospital. She was fatally injured when the rope "snapped her back," a spokesman at Parkland Hospital said.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- This port was Japan's busiest last year, handling $4.7-billion in imports and exports, the Yokohama Customs House reported today. The total was a 17 per cent increase over the 1966 figure.

Special to The New York Times LONDON, Feb. 12 -- A startling diplomatic disclosure here over the weekend -- that Kemal Ataturk once offered a British ambassador the Presidency of Turkey -- turned out today to be an embarrassing practical joke.

SUNDAY afternoon in Seoul, in the basement of the secretariat building next to his presidential palace, President Chung Hee Park of South Korea spent a full hour in his shooting range to improve his skills with a pistol and rifle.
HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 -- Two companies of American marines moved into the northern section of Hue today, bringing American strength to a full battalion, or 800 to 1,000 men.

Special to The New York Times ORANGEBURG, S. C., Feb. 12 -- Doctors who examined the bodies of three Negro students who were killed Thursday night in racial violence said today that one of them had died of a wound in the back.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Pentagon said today that it had been studying new ways to destroy hostile space satellites but "no decision has been made to develop a new weapons system" against them.
A campuswide survey at a Roman Catholic college here indicates a large-scale rejection of traditional Catholic practices, moral rules and pastoral leadership.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- The Foreign Minister of Kuwait, Sheik Sabah el-Ahmed el-Sabah, arrived in Saudi Arabia today to discuss the Persian Gulf situation in view of Britain's announced intention to withdraw from the area by 1971, the Kuwaiti radio reported.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The Assembly, overriding Republican protests, voted today to require public schools in the state to hold memorial services each year on the birthday of John F. Kennedy, May 29.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The European A-300 airbus, manufactured by Britain, France and West Germany, should be in service by early 1973, the British Minister of State for Technology, John Stonehouse, said today.

British West Indian Airways has entered an interim 90-day management and technical assistance agreement with Trans World Airlines as a first step in the reorganization of the British carrier, the carriers announced ysterday.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs continued to crumble tonight as the Los Angeles Kings shut out the Stanley Cup champions, 2-0, before a Forum crowd of 12,307.

A 10-year-old white miniature poodle came out of four years of retirement last night for the start of the Westminster Kennel Club dog show and created a sensation by winning in the old Madison Square Garden.
Richie Dubin scored five goals as Queens College defeated City College, 8-1, last night in a Metropolitan Intercollegiate Hockey Association game played at the Riverdale Skating Rink in the Bronx.

Governor Rockefeller has been condemned in a large number of newspaper editorials around the state for his handling of the city sanitation emergency. A recurring crit cism yesterday was that the Governor, by yielding to union pay demands in his plan that returned the sanitationmen to their jobs under temporary state control, had struck a perhaps fatal blow to the state's Taylor Law, which bans strikes by public employes.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Senator Charles H. Percy said today that he could not "foresee any circumstances" under which he would be the Republican Presidential or Vice-Presidential candidate this year.
TOKYO, Feb. 12 -- The Japanese Foreign Ministry expressed concern to the United States today over the recent stationing of B-52 bombers in Okinawa.
The appointment of Thomas J. Smith as executive vice president of Farrell Lines has been announced by C. Carlton Lewis, president.
MARSEILLES, France, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- Sardine fishermen demanding higher prices for their catches mounted a blockade of French Mediterranean harbors today, halting all shipping here.

THE return of "Elektra" to the Metropolitan Opera also saw much the same cast that had officiated at the premiere of the new production in October, 1966. There were Birgit Nilsson in the title role, Leonie Rysanek as Chrysothemis and Regina Resnik as Klytaemnestra. Around these three women the Strauss opera revolves. Toward the end, Orest, sung again by William Dooley, enters to complete the quartet of principals.
HERSHEY, Pa., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Higher sales and a decline in net income were reported today by the Hershey Chocolate Corporation for 1967.

NEWARK, Feb. 12 -- Two predominantly Negro neighborhood groups that have led the resistance to building a large state medical college here have agreed to the reduced 57.9-acre site for the campus proposed by the college's board of trustees over the weekend. The original request was for 150 acres.

The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Company suffered a net loss of $16,676,757 in 1967 on operating revenues of $221,885,407. In the preceding year, the railroad had net income of $1,897,548, or 65 cents a share, on operating revenues of $230,365,603.

An agreement in principle was reached yesterday for Benguet Consolidated, Inc., to acquire about two-thirds of the outstanding shares of Grand Bahama Port Authority, Ltd., Nassau, Bahamas, for about $80-million in cash or common stock.
Barge commerce for 1967 showed an over-all increase of 5.5 per cent over 1966, the American Waterways Operators, Inc., reported yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 -- The garbage trucks rumbled along the streets of Saigon this morning but the commissioner was unhappy, the drivers were dissatisfied and the mayor was unreachable.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- The Pennsylvania Citizens for Kennedy announced today no petitions would be filed in behalf of Senator Robert F. Kennedy in the state's Presidential primary election.

PALERMO, Sicily, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A sharp earthquake, followed by light tremors, rocked Sicily tonight, sending hundreds from their homes into the streets. More than 100 aftershocks have shaken the island since the disastrous earthquake Jan. 15.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Johnson called on Americans today to obey the law, to respect the rights of others, to aid police officers and to uphold the judgments of the courts.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Boston University, backed by the brilliant goal-tending of Jim McCann, captured the Boston Beanpot hockey championship for the third straight year tonight by defeating Harvard, 4-1, before a crowd of 12,674 at the Garden.
The head of the transit policemen's union said yesterday that 1,500 more patrolmen should be added to the subway force because daytime passengers did not receive enough protection.

The report by Governor Hughes's commission to investigate last summer's Newark riot makes it plain that Newark is sick and New Jersey has been irresponsible. The report challenges the city to reform itself and the state to begin governing itself in accordance with its wealth and its grave responsibilities.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Full production resumed today at General Motors Corporation plants across the nation. However, Chevrolet division operations in the Flint, Mich., area, face a strike early tomorrow.
Special to The New York Times JERUSALEM, Feb. 12 -- Premier Levi Eshkol indicated tonight that continued Jordanian shelling along the Jordan River cease-fire line would bring Israeli retaliation.
Special to The New York Times DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 12 -- A new rolling status symbol, the Continental Mark III, was unveiled today by the Ford Motor Company.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (AP) -- His bed is a pile of newspapers under a bridge, his wardrobe is on his back, and he finds happiness in a bottle of wine.

ROME, Feb. 12 -- Pope Paul VI and the dean of the Vatican's marriage court uttered "a cry of alarm" today at the threat to the indissoluble sacramental nature of matrimony presented by a materialist secular society.

The appointment of the Rev. James J. Hennesey as superior of the Jesuit community at Fordham University was announced yesterday. He succeeds the late Rev. Joseph B. O'Connell. An associate professor in Fordham's theology department, Father Hennesey served as assistant provincial of the New York Province of the Society of Jesus from 1965 to 1967.
Price increases ranging from 3 to 5 cents a pound on textile rayon filament yarns were announced yesterday by the American Enka Corporation to take effect March 1.

Northrup Knox of Buffalo and Aiken, S. C., is in a commanding position to complete successfully the defense of his world open court tennis championship after again defeating George H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr. of Locust Valley, L. I., 3 sets to 1 in the second block of their challenge match at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday.
National political figures are becoming involved in the special election campaign for the House seat representing Brooklyn's 13th District. The contest will be decided Feb. 20.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The Legislature unexpectedly decided tonight to postpone action on Governor Rockefeller's emergency legislation for temporarily resolving the New York City sanitation strike.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Sweden and the Soviet Union today signed a protocol providing for the exchange of nuclear specialists. The accord called for exchanges of visits by experts in nuclear power reactors, plasma physics, radiation and solid state physics.
Mutual of New York (MONY) has elected Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, to its board of trustees, the insurance company announced yesterday.

Special to The New York Times PARRIS ISLAND, S. C. -- They cry when they get here. They cry when they leave. They also cry a lot during training, but they are encouraged to weep in the showers, so as not to upset the other members of their platoon.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Output per man-hour increased more in the final quarter of 1967 than in the third quarter but was still vastly outstripped by wage increases, thereby adding to business's unit costs, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- President Johnson announced today the promotion of Joseph primary contacts with Congress. M. Bowman Jr., a career specialist on tax legislation, to be Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- President Johnson, pressing for international acceptance of a treaty to curb the spread of nuclear weapons, promised today that the United States "will undertake with the utmost seriousness" negotiations aimed at atomic disarmament.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 -- The Sheraton Corporation today told two unions that are striking the Penn-Sheraton Hotel that if they did not accept management's offer or make a new proposal by Feb. 20, the hotel would be sold.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Senate met today in a token session that lasted five seconds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- President Johnson said tonight that despite the offensive in Vietnam, his San Antonio formula offer for peace talks still stood.
Radio station WNYC began its 29th annual festival of American Music yesterday afternoon with a live concert at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Dr. Benjamin Spock and the four men accused with him of violating the draft laws asked the Supreme Court today not to decide a key issue raised by their indictment when it rules on the constitutionality of the law against draft card burning.

The United Aircraft Corporation elected Olcott D. Smith, chairman of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, to its directorate yesterday. He succeeds Henry S. Beers, who resigned as a director after serving 10 years on the board.

TOKYO, Feb. 12 -- Comdr. Lloyd Bucher, captain of the intelligence ship Pueblo, was reported today to have said that North Korea has "all the data and documentary evidence" regarding the vessel's intelligence activities and intrusions in North Korean waters.

NEWARK, Feb. 12 -- A deputy police chief who told a state commission that bookmaking and numbers were "very large business" in the city was named by Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio to night to head a special anti-gambling squad.

ALPE D'HUEZ, France, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Warm weather again forced postponement today of training for the four-man Olympic bob-sled event, increasing the possibility the race might eventually have to be canceled.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 13 -- American riflemen fought Vietcong guerrillas twice yesterday in widely separated regions of South Vietnam.

Seven engineering groups have proposed that the city guarantee landlords that they will be allowed to operate apartment house incinerators for 10 years to allay their fears that incinerators may be banned.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- Clocks in Britain will be put forward an hour at 2 A.M., Greenwich mean time, next Sunday probably for the last time. Under the provisions of a bill now before Parliament, clocks will remain one hour ahead of Greenwich mean time throughout the year. The new time system is to be known as British standard time.

The Public Service Commission approved yesterday a Long Island Rail Road plan to install automatic flashing light warning signals and an electrically operated highway gate at the Port Jefferson branch grade crossing of East Gate Drive in Huntington, L. I. The cost of the installation, estimated at $22,000, will be shared equally by the state and railroad, the commission said.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 12 -- Jean-Claude Killy has done it again. The 24-year-old French customs officer with the movie-star profile won the giant slalom today and a second gold medal in his bid for the Winter Olympic triple crown of Alpine skiing, a feat accomplished only by Toni Sailer of Austria in 1956 at Cortina, Italy.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Art and museum officials were in an uproar today over the sale of a 15th-century Gothic brass lectern to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 12 -- Wide differences between Washington and Seoul on the basic concept of South Korea's defense posture are said to have been discussed today in a lengthy conference between President Chung Hee Park and Cyrus R. Vance, President Johnson's special envoy.

THE Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship playoffs, marred by student misconduct in two of the last three years, will get under way with city-wide eliminations next week. This year's event might best be described as a chaperoned affair. The 1965 championship game between Franklin and Boys High at Madison Square Garden was marred by a student riot and last year the tournament was halted by racial trouble involving students from Boys High and Lafayette.
