The city Health Department said yesterday that the threatened boycott by pharmacists of the Medicaid program appeared to be ineffective so far. far.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the Uris Buildings Corporation has agreed to build a second legitimate theater in the 51-story structure planned for the site of the Loew's Capitol Theater at 51st Street and Broadway.

AMHERST, Va., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Ernest G. Floyd, 60 years old, owner of two dogs in the pack that attacked and killed two children Dec. 17 at nearby Madison Heights, was indicted today on charges of involuntary manslaughter. But Circuit Judge C. G. Quesenbery, ordering a thorough search of Virginia statutes, declared "I have very serious doubts there is any criminal law on which to base these charges."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- President Johnson predicted today further turmoil in the cities and "several bad summers" before the nation's urban problems are resolved.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Diamond Head, the volcanic cone that symbolizes Hawaii, was approved today as a Registered Natural Landmark by the Secretary of the Interior, Stewart L. Udall.

Special to The New York Times DARIEN. Conn., Feb. 12 -- Forty pupils, teachers and maintenance men safely escaped from a fire last night that destroyed a four-story dormitory and dining building of the Cherry Lawn School on Brookside Road. The damage was estimated at $100.000. The cause of the fire was not determined.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad will become part of the Norfolk Western Railway system, probably on April 1, a top N. W. official said today.

SEOUL, Tuesday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Cyrus R. Vance held another round of talks with President Park today in which, informed sources said, the South Korean leader stressed the tough line that he wants the United States to adopt on North Korea.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Kentucky took over first place in the Southeastern Conference tonight by rallying to gain a 60-59 victory over Tennessee before 12,000 fans.

CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Hope Cooke, the New York society figure who became queen of the Himalayan kingdom of Sikkim, gave birth to a daughter tonight in a Calcutta nursing home. She and the King also have a son.

MYTHO, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 (AP) -- President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that more United States troops were needed if the Vietnam war was to be ended soon. He made the comment during a tour of four Mekong Delta cities that were recently attacked by the Vietcong.

More than 50 American manufacturing companies are under investigation by the Federal Government in connection with a possible tax evasion scheme in the use of secret trust accounts in the tiny Principality of Liechtenstein.

A 3-for-2 split of the common stock of the Kaiser Steel Corporation will be proposed to shareholders at the annual meeting March 25 in Oakland, Calif., the company announced yesterday. Directors increased the quarterly dividend on the existing common stock to 37 1/2 cents a share from 25 cents a share, payable March 29 to shareholders of record March 15.
Narcotics detectives and Federal agents arrested 22 persons last night in a raid on a Brooklyn basement apartment that they said was stocked like a drugstore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Johnson's oldest friends always insist that he is at his best when the going is roughest, and the record tends to support that judgment. Just over four years ago, for instance, he performed superbly in rallying the Government and the people in the weeks after John Kennedy's death.

Sales of existing single-family homes across the country continued at the end of last year to show gains over year-earlier levels; a survey by the National Association of Real Estate Boards has shown. The sales in December were 25 per cent above those in the last month of 1966.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- This is not a town to overlook a chance to make a speech, stage a ceremony or have a party. Hence, after 103 years of silence, the restored Ford's Theater has had three black-tie openings in less than a month -- a solemn dedication service on Jan. 21, a star-studded inaugural program 10 days later, and the opening of "John Brown's Body" by the National Repertory Company tonight.
Thirty men will take their first steps today on a new path from poverty toward productive work that the city has laid out to bypass problems that have stalled previous job-training programs.

Special to The New York Times MADRID, Feb. 12 -- In the nearest thing to a major political campaign that Spain has witnessed since her Civil War in 1936, Don Juan de Borbon y Battenberg, the 54-year-old Pretender who lives in exile, has acted for the last week like a candidate for office -- in this case that of king and chief of state to succeed Generalissimo Francisco Franco.
A top negotiator for the sanitationmen's union said yesterday that it was "up to City Hall" whether the continuing contract dispute became a "world war or a bush battle."

Special to The New York Times WARSAW, Feb. 12 -- A Warsaw court today rejected defense pleas and ordered a closed trial for the author of a satirical operetta whose targets are said to include prominent Poles, from Wladyslaw Gomulka, the party leader, to Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate.
Two last-minute free throws by Brooklyn College's Steve Maletz gave the Kingsmen a 79-78 victory over Kings Point last night at Roosevelt Hall in Brooklyn.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Rev. James E. Groppi, the white Roman Catholic priest who has guided Milwaukee open housing demonstrations since they began last August, was fined S500 and put on two years' probation today on a charge of resisting arrest.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen. former Governor of Minnesota, challenged today President Johnson and four candidates in Wisconsin's Presidential primary to a debate. He said he had reserved the Dane County Coliseum for the debate March 28. He said others invited were former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, Gov. George Romney of Michigan, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, all Republicans, and Senator Eugene R. McCarthy, Democrat, of Minnesota.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The rumor started with an anonymous phone call to a Congressional committee. Within a week the rumor had gone around the world and involved the President of the United States, the Prime Minister of Britain and leaders of Congress in a discussion over whether or not the United States was considering using tactical nuclear weapons in Vietnam.

The first test of sentiment within the Democratic State Committee on the war in Vietnam is expected tomorrow at a meeting in Buffalo in which action is scheduled on a resolution endorsing the Johnson Administration.

The appointment of William J. Shields and Milton J. Levitt as directors of Barber Steamship Lines, Inc., and American West African Line, Inc., has been announced by the lines. Mr. Shields is a vice president of both corporations and Mr. Levitt a partner in the law firm of Herman Goldman.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A United States trade mission, which will start on a tour of European capitals this week, will tell the Europeans that this Government has under consideration two possible actions to help the balance of payments, officials said today.

The city's antipovery program has overspent its budget by more than $4-million because of a huge drive to employ poor teen-agers last summer and Federal cutbacks of funds, according to estimates by city officials.

BANMETHUOT, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 -- Prisoners taken by the South Vietnamese Army in the fierce battle last week for Banmethuot said today that they were soldiers of the 33d Regiment of the North Vietnamese Army.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (12) -- The Civil Service Commission announced today that it was replacing the complicated three-page application form for Government jobs in use since 1942 with a 4 by 8 inch card.
MIAMI SPRINGS, Fla., Feb. 12 -- The threat of a boycott when the New York thoroughbred racing season opens at Aqueduct March 11 loomed today.
Forced by management to operate at half-throttle, the program-sellers at the National Boat Show continued to drag anchor yesterday.

John Shirley-Quirk, 36-year-old baritone, made his New York recital debut in Town Hall last night and proved to be another of the many gifted English artists to have come of musical age since the war. The singer's appearance here last season in concert performances of Handel operas were well received, but this solo program presented a much greater challenge, which he met with exceptional ability.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Pentagon today identified 139 servicemen killed in action in Vietnam, including the following men from the New York area:
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Charlie Scott, with 34 points, paced third-ranked North Carolina to a 96-84 victory over North Carolina State tonight. It was the Tar Heels' 16th straight victory.

Special to The New York Times ROME, Feb. 12 -- Giacomo Cardinal Lercaro, the consistently progressive and intermittently controversial Archbishop of Communist-ruled Bologna, was relieved today, at his own request, of direction of his archdiocese.

TEANECK, N. J., Feb. 12 -- The New Jersey Americans pulled into a tie for third place with the idle Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Division of the American Basketball Association by walloping the New Orleans Buccaneers, 118-109, at Teaneck Armory tonight. The victory was the Americans' third in a row.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- The United States military command in Vietnam today issued a 90-page booklet titled "1967 -- A Year of Progress."
Special to The New York Times BOISE, Idaho, Feb. 12 -- Representative George V. Hansen, a Republican, said today that he would seek the United States seat held by Senator Frank Church, a Democrat.

MALDEN, Mass., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Pledges have been signed for a slate of delegates favorable to Senator Eugene J. McCarthy in the Massachusetts primary April 30. The action came yesterday at a Citizens for McCarthy rally.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Jerry Sloan's two baskets in overtime led the Chicago Bulls to a 112-104 national basketball association victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight.

Al Capp, who created the great Sadie Hawkins Day chase as a boon for the unwed women of Dogpatch, will be the master of ceremonies on Feb. 29 at a Leap Year Cocktail Buffet Dansant to aid the Judson Health Center.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Colin Adair of Montreal rallied to defeat his fellow townsman, Peter Martin, today for the national squash racquets championship.

Special to The New York Times BONN, Feb. 12 -- A high-level United States delegation opened talks with West German leaders today on measures to help ease Washington's payments problem and to offset the costs of maintaining 220,000 American troops here.
The East New York Savings Bank announced yesterday the election of Arthur Levitt Jr. to its board of trustees.

Adams Dana Silverstein, the smallest, youngest and latest ad agency to go public, has just completed its 90-day period under the "cone of silence" required by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Now the agency can talk about itself and why it went public. So it did.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Soviet novelist Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn is reported to have defied again Communist bureaucrats who administer the party's controls over literature.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 12 -- Before the Winter Olympics began, a local cynic said of the French organizers: "They're all running around, trying to do everything but put de Gaulle in ski boots and stretch pants."
The New York Athletic Club said yesterday that 400 athletes were entered for its beleaguered track meet next Friday night at the new Madison Square Garden.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 12 -- Cardigan Bay was spared a life of boredom in his remaining years yesterday when his trainer, Stanley Dancer, announced that the 12-year-old gelding "looks good and feels good" and will race again.
The election of Howard W. Johnson, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, as a director of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company was announced yesterday.
The Public Broadcast Laboratory has dismissed Robert Hoyt, who had been its managing editor until six weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- An aide of Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, filed suit against the Supreme Court today, demanding that it literally clean up its own "backyard."
Before the largest empty house in their history, the Rangers had the honor last night of being the first team to perform in the new Madison Square Garden.

The master of the Canadian freighter Charny said yesterday that he ordered his crew to abandon the vessel in the Atlantic last Friday when he discovered the ship's pumps could no longer keep up with leakage on the port side.

Two senior creative supervisors at Ted Bates Co. -- Barry J. Ballister and William Maynard Jr. -- have been raised to senior vice presidents. Sort of senior seniors. At the same time, Marvin Goldman has been made vice president and art supervisor. Both seniors started with the agency as copywriters. Mr. Ballister, at 32, is the youngest senior vice president now at the agency.
DALLAS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Dallas Cowboys of the National Football League signed Tommy Lunceford of Auburn today. Lunceford, a punter, was the Cowboys' 15th draft choice.

Special to The New York Times STAR CITY, Ark., Feb. 12 -- A county grand jury was ordered today to determine if "any law violations" had occurred when state penitentiary officials removed three skeletons from an unmarked burial ground at a nearby prison.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The National Farmers Organization extended its month-old grain market boycott to meat today, demanding up to six cents a pound more on sales of cattle, hogs and sheep.
SAN DIEGO, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- John Kilroy's Kialoa II of the Newport Harbor Yacht Club recaptured the fleet lead today in the ninth biennial San Diego-to-Acapulco sail race.

Special to The New York Times HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 12 -- Dartmouth's basketball team defeated Cornell, 64-63, tonight in an Ivy League game that was rescheduled from Saturday night because a snowfall had delayed the arrival of the Big Red team.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- A Teamsters Union member said today that he had made six times his normal salary from The Detroit News through a prestrike deal with one of the interim newspapers that sprang up during Detroit's news blackout.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Communist terrorists killed six Thai Army troops and wounded 20 others in a series of ambushes during the past week, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn said today. He said most of the men were killed in the northern province of Nan.
GARY, Ind., Feb. 9 -- Mayor Richard G. Hatcher's first six weeks in office have been a period of both progress and setbacks.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Tonny Ferweda, a 24-year-old construction worker, set a one-hour speed-skating world record yesterday by covering 21.9 miles, the national news agency, AMP, said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that the Johnson Administration was still opposed to wiretapping except in cases affecting the nation's security.

The appointment of the General Steamship Corporation as general passenger reservation agents for the western part of the United States and for Hawaii has been announced by the Italian Line as part of the reorganization of its West Coast operations.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Nuritdin A. Mukhitdinov, a former Uzbek premier and party chief who was a member of the Soviet leadership from 1957 to 1961, has been appointed ambassador to Syria. He was a deputy chief of the State Committee for Foreign Cultural Relations, which has been abolished.

Will classification of motion pictures by municipal, state or Federal agencies, already practiced in Dallas, Chicago and several smaller communities, become the new way of censoring movies in this now virtually censor-free medium? This question is thought by knowledgeable lawyers to be hanging at the moment in the United States Supreme Court, where the constitutionality of classification, as it has been enforced in Dallas for the last two years, is being decided.
Steel production set a record last week for the second week in a row, rising 1.3 per cent above the output in the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

SENTIMENT can blur vision and the old Madison Square Garden really didn't seem so hopelessly inadequate during the misty-eyed farewell ceremonies on Sunday afternoon. But a few hours later the new Garden was formally opened with a show that reflected the lavishness of the surroundings.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- Abie Nathan, the Israeli "peace pilot," went on trial today on charges of breaking a long list of laws when he made two lone flights to Egypt in search of a Middle East peace.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The United States asserted today that "the threat posed by Soviet nuclear forces" makes necessary patrols by United States bombers armed with nuclear weapons.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Astronauts at Cornell University have mapped a third of the planet Venus with the world's largest radio-radar telescope and have pinpointed the location of rough areas that may be mountains.
RIO DE JANIERO, Feb. 12 -- Summer A. Long's ketch Ondine III broke a six-year record today in winning the eighth annual Buenos Aires-Rio de Janeiro yacht race.
Ship casualties during the second quarter of 1967 declined sharply from the previous quarter as well as from the comparable quarter in 1966, according to Lloyd's Register of Shipping.
Special to The New York Times MOSCOW, Feb. 12 -- Secretary General Thant of the United Nations wound up two days of talks with Soviet leaders today and left for London.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Largely because of the international financial tension affecting the British pound, the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee made no change in its monetary policy at its meeting last Nov. 14, it was disclosed today.
PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- The Surveyor 7 spacecraft was reactivated today after two weeks of silence on the surface of the moon.

Judges for the National Book Awards have chosen 31 books as "leading nominees" for the six $1,000 prizes. The winners will be named on March 6 at a gathering of the literary community in Lincoln Center's Philharmonic Hall.
Studebaker - Worthington, Inc., a company formed last Nov. 27 by a merger of Studebaker and Worthington Corporations, reported yesterday a 10 per cent rise in sales and earnings for 1967.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, 46 years old, a former heavyweight boxing champion, is undergoing treatment at Passavant Hospital for a nerve condition (lateral sclerosis) in his spine.
Bill Spivey made his National Basketball Association debut Sunday night in Baltimore. His team lost, 38-37, but Spivey, as usual, was top scorer with 12 points.

Special to The New York Times MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Nineteen persons, including an instructor at Orange County Community College here, were arrested Saturday night and Sunday morning in a series of narcotics raids.

Estimated net earnings of the Armstrong Cork Company in 1967 fell to $27.3-million, or $2.50 a share, from $32,299,000, or $2.97 a share, in 1966, it was reported yesterday. Sales rose to $460.2-million from $455,414,000.
The London stock market turned mixed yesterday in fairly brisk trading.
Previews, Inc., the international real estate clearing house, has named Alan L. Emlen executive vice president. The appointment was announced by John C. Tysen, chairman of the concern.
ANDROS, the Bahamas, Feb. 12 -- The beach was white under the moon when I wandered inland past giant coconut palms to the pine forest until I knew a chickcharney was watching me.

Vilas Hickey, members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the admission as general partners of Irving C. Meyersfield, John L. Farley and Thomas A. Ebner. Mr. Meyersfield is with the firm's bond trading department; Mr. Ebner will represent the firm on the floor of the Big Board; Mr. Farley will become operations manager.

Special to The New York Times JERSEY CITY, Feb. 12 -- The Jersey Journal announced today that it was increasing its daily price from 5 to 10 cents, effective next Monday. The newspaper cited rising labor and other costs for its first price increase in more than 20 years.
WASHINGTON -- An escalation of the war on the waistline seems to be concerning the political and social world here.
Special to The New York Times ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Following is the text of Governor Rockefeller's special message to the Legislature on the sanitation emergency in New York City:
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 -- According to an American expert on the Vietcong and North Vietnam, Defense Minister Vo Nguyen Giap of North Vietnam may be trying to win the war by spring.

The State Assembly has passed a bill that would provide more three-day weekends by providing that five legal holidays would always be observed on Monday, unless they happened to fall on Friday. While the objective of providing longer leisure periods is desirable, this is a matter more appropriately treated on the national level.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Garbage and refuse began piling up in most sections of Memphis today as all but a few of the city's sanitation workers struck for pay rises of 33 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Three labor union presidents resigned today from the board of Americans for Democratic Action in protest against the organization's endorsement of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for President.
Special to The New York Times PARIS, Feb. 12 -- Andreas Papandreou, the exiled Greek centrist leader, said today that he was considering a resumption of his American academic career.

Special to The New York Times LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The Bank of England announced today that the package of central banks' support for the pound, known as the Basel credits, had been extended for another year.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A tractor-trailer unit carrying high-octane gasoline burst into flames today after smashing into the rear of a truck carrying 17 tons of dynamite. The dynamite did not explode.

Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, whose name awaits White House action for appointment as a Federal judge, has just given an impressive demonstration of his obliviousness to the issue of trafficking with lawbreakers, an issue raised by Governor Rockefeller's formula for settling the garbage strike.

CHAMBROUSSE, France, Feb. 12 -- Toni Sailer, the Kitzbuehel kid, who set the ski world agog in 1956 at Cortina, Italy, by being the first athlete to sweep the three Olympic Alpine gold medals, was down at the base of the mountains today almost as soon as Jean-Claude Killy was.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A White House task force whose membership is drawn from outside the Government has been appointed to study the antitrust laws and make recommendations for their improvement.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- Rod Steiger was named best dramatic actor for his performance in "In the Heat of the Night" in the Hollywood Foreign Press Association's 25th annual Golden Globe awards here tonight.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- The West Indies fought back to avoid an innings defeat today after a riotous fourth day in the second cricket test against England. Needing 233 runs in their second innings to make England bat again, the West Indies was 258 for five wickets at the close.
Special to The New York Times PARIS, Feb. 12 -- Informed sources said that export licenses for the sale of half a million tons of surplus wheat to Communist China were granted to brokers here today.

Special to The New York Times LOS ANGELES, Feb 12 -- "Everything is going up -- our cost of merchandise, our Labor costs, everything. Our biggest problem this year is going to be convincing people that increased prices are mandatory."

Two gunmen held up eight employes of Sloan's Supermarket, 40 East End Avenue, near East 81st Street, prior to the store's opening yesterday and fled with $2,000 after fonting the manager to open a safe. The manager, Murray Sussman, told the police that the gunmen had ordered him and seven employes into the store's collar after taking the money.
Interest rates, which reversed direction last week and began to climb, are expected to continue moving up this week.

Uncollected refuse, blown by chill winds, still swirled around the city's streets yesterday, despite intensive efforts by the Sanitation Department to clean up the residue from the nine-day sanitationmen's strike.
DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Male seniors of Duluth high schools were advised by a Roman Catholic priest today to resist induction and not to fight in Vietnam.
OTTAWA, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press -- The Government has decided to go ahead July 1 with its medical-care-insurance program although only one or two provinces are expected to participate at the start.

The sharp divisions in Albany over Governor Rockefeller's proposal for a bogus state takeover of the New York City Sanitation Department indicate how gravely many legislators believe the integrity of the governmental process has been compromised by the formula the Governor evolved to end the illegal garbage strike.
The City College basketball team finally recorded its second victory of the season after six attempts last night, scoring an 87-71 triumph over Southern Connecticut State College at Wingate Gym.

Cleavon Little, who plays the Negro frogman in "Scuba Duba," will portray Hamlet in Joseph Papp's avant-garde version of the Shakespeare work. It will be performed for high school students, beginning March 4, in the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Mr. Papp's group, the New York Shakespeare Festival, will be the sponsor.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The United States hockey team recorded its first victory of the Olympic Games tonight, defeating West Germany, 8-1. The Americans had lost to Czechoslovakia, Sweden the Soviet Union and Canada.

Evergreen Review, which began as a quarterly in 1957 with a circulation of 7,500 copies, will become a monthly magazine with its March issue, on the newsstands Friday. The circulation is estimated at 150,000.
Support of the Vietnam war by the American people rose from 61 per cent in December to 74 per cent this month, according to a Harris Survey.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 -- A pair of helicopters with machine guns repeatedly raked the smoking ruins of a hamlet on the edge of Saigon this morning.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers Uni announced today that members of its locals had overwhlemingly ratified an agreement on a three-year contract at 14 International Harvester Company plants in eight states.
The election of Russell W. McFall as a director of the American Cancer Society was announced yesterday. Mr. McFall is president and chairman of the Western Union Telegraph Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Senate ethics committee has hired a certified public accountant to assist in its inquiry into misconduct charges against Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri.

Alfredo Stroessner had insured himself another term as President of Paraguay even before tossing his sombrero into the ring, but Sunday's elections were significant despite the inevitability of the result. They were far from free but they were freer than any other elections held during General Stroessner's fourteen years as Paraguay's dictator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The White House press secretary, George Christian, said today that the level of forces was always "under consideration." But he said he did not know of any discussion for increasing troop levels.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Bowie opened its winter race meeting today with a crowd of 11,869 in attendance to watch Kathy Kiely beat out Miss Keymar by a nose in the $6,000 Rail Splitter Purse.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The tires were flattened today on 42 of 48 buses operated by the suburban Fairport Central School, making 4,500 public and private school pupils an hour late to classes. Officials said vandals had deflated the right front tires of the 42 buses, which were parked in a lot outside the school building. The other six vehicles were in a garage.

Striking California grape workers have begun a series of lawsuits seeking court protection for their boycott against table grapes grown by the company that has refused to bargain with or recognize their union.

James M. Gavin, the retired lieutenant general who was Army Chief of Plans when the French withdrew from Vietnam in 1954, says that Pentagon leaders at the time "strongly favored landing a force in the Haiphong-Hanoi area, even at the risk of war with Red China."

Two armed holdup men made off with $1,100 from the Household Finance Company, 152 West 42d Street, shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday. The police said the manager, H. James Felelstroth, 47 years old, reported the thugs had forced nine employes to a rear room after taking the money.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Flames destroyed a lumber warehouse, several automobiles and a number of tractor trailers and for a while threatened the United States frigate Constellation tonight on Baltimore's waterfront. The frigate, launched in Baltimore in 1797, was not damaged. She is now a tourist attraction.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Biafran radio, still maintaining that it broadcasts from the fallen capital of Enugu, said today that secessionist troops have retaken Nsukka, more than 40 miles north of Enugu. A federal military spokesman denied it. Nsukka was captured by federal troops about 10 days after the civil war erupted last July 6.

HEIDELBERG, West Germany, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Maj. Gen. Benjamin F. Taylor, a native of Washington, Pa., has been named to take over as chief of staff of the United States Army in Europe and the Seventh Army, a spokesman said today. General Taylor, now chief of staff of the Central Army Group in Europe, replaces Gen. Charles H. Chase, who is retiring.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union arrived in Sofia today for talks with Foreign Minister Ivan Bashev of Bulgaria and other leaders.

Special to The New York Times DOVER. N. H., Feb. 12 -- Richard M. Nixon, returning to the campaign trail in New Hampshire, tonight described the United States commitment in Vietnam as "the cork in the bottle of Chinese expansion in Asia."
The Haarlem Philharmonic Society's midseason card party will be held Friday in the Waldorf-Astoria's Sert Room. Proceeds from the event will aid the group's Music Scholarship Fund.
Special to The New York Times PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- A proposed merger of the Provident National Bank and the Central-Penn National Bank was outlawed here today by a Federal judge.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Following is the text of the Militant's press conference:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Johnson placed a wreath at the Lincoln Memorial today and compared his ordeals to those of the Civil War leader.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that it would study a New York Central proposal to discontinue passenger trains 404 and 405 between Albany and Boston.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- An informed Congressional source said tonight that the envoy who went to Hanoi was an American, not a foreigner.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Macrae Sykes, a senior partner in Shields Co., had been elected chairman of its board of governors for a one-year term.
CASPER, Wyo., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Representative William Henry Harrison, Republican of Wyoming, announced at a news conference today that he would seek a sixth term as Wyoming's only member of the House.
There are no clear indications that widespread aerial spraying to strip Vietnames war zones of foliage will do long-term damage. However too little is known to assess the efforts with confidence.
The FMC Corporation, a diversified producer of fibers, films, machinery, chemicals and defense products, showed a 13 per cent decline in earnings in 1967 despite a 5 per cent rise in sales.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Peggy Fleming, the Winter Olympic gold medalist, is expected to appear in the Funorama on Ice at the South Mountain arena April 21 and 22, the event's sponsors announced today.

OFFICIALS of Eastern colleges that field major football teams can breathe more easily. The Lambert Trophy, stolen from the trophy case at Penn State Thursday, has been returned. It appears to be in better shape now than it was before the cup-napping. The person or persons who took the trophy polished it before giving it back to its lawful owner of the year. The guess is that the polishing was done to remove finger prints.
The president of Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., William S. Simpson, urged stockholders yesterday to turn down the Seeburg Corporation's tender offer of $80 a share.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- A University of Kansas mathematics professor asked three R.O.T.C. students today to leave his class because he did not want to teach them anything they could use to kill people, the student newspaper reported.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Representative Donald Rumsfeld, Republican of Illinois, said today that state Selective Service directors had been directed by Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey to disclose the names of draft board members to the public.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 12 (AP) -- A program begun three years ago to curb speeding violations by foreign diplomats on the New Jersey Turnpike has apparently paid off, William J. Flanagan, the authority's executive director, said today.

KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 -- The first shell burst caught the marines outside the bunkers filling sandbags. More exploding rockets sprayed showers of hot fragments. The Americans dived for cover.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 12 -- Mrs. Maxine Morrison, the wife of former Gov. Frank B. Morrison, announced today that she will seek the Democratic nomination for Congress from the second Congressional district.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Mike Estep of Dallas and Len Schloss of Baltimore scored upsets in the first round of the national indoor tennis championship tonight.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Bobby Dunlop of Australia captured the vacant light-heavyweight championship of the British Empire tonight when he stopped Young McCormack of Ireland in the seventh round.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The son of a socially prominent New Yorker plunged to his death yesterday after being caught for two hours in a traffic jam caused by the crash of a Navy plane into the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge.

ATHENS, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- Salvage workers removed all the fuel today from the American destroyer Bache, grounded outside Rhodes harbor since last Tuesday. A spokesman for the Sixth Fleet said there now was no danger of contaminating nearby beaches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A foreign emissary went to Hanoi last month at President Johnson's request to explore North Vietnam's terms for entering peace talks, and the United States suspended bombing around Hanoi to promote and protect his mission.

Red, white and blue bunting and ribbon rosettes decorated the Plaza's Grand Ballroom last night, where the New York Commandery of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion and the State Society of the Dames of the Loyal Legion held their eighth annual Lincoln's Birthday dinner dance.

Special to The New York Times MAGNA, Utah, Feb. 10 -- Vincent Zito sat in a blue and silver picket trailer parked near the silent Kennecott Copper Corporation refinery here the other day and talked solemnly about the long copper strike.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Eduardo Ritter Aislan of Panama withdrew today as candidate for the position of Secretary General of the Organization of American States.
An entire wing of the Metro politan Museum of Art is being ripped apart, but thousands of daily visitors are unaware of the rattle of the jackhammers and the crash of falling debris.
The Whitney Museum of American Art has joined the growing list of museums staying open at least one night a week.
Plans for a New York daily publication devoted to a cross section of national columnists and political cartoonists were announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- A priest allegedly banished from the Chicago Roman Catholic Archdiocese for seeking to discourage racial integration has been reassigned to a secondary school at Tulsa, Okla.

The troubled New York Athletic Club track meet won an endorsement from a top local official of the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday but lost the world's No. 1 hurdler, Earl McCullouch, and Georgetown University.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 13 -- The Pacific Area Travel Association predicted today that the Johnson Administration's proposals to tax American tourists would, if adopted, have serious adverse consequences without greatly improving the United States' balance-of-payments situation.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., Feb. 13 (UPI) -- A Chicago soldier turned away several other soldiers tonight from a chapel to which he had invited them for what he had called an "hour of meditation" in protest against the war in Vietnam.

GAFFNEY, S. C., Feb. 13 (UPI) -- A teen-age Negro girl, waiting for a school bus by the side of the road, was kidnapped by a white man today in the same area where the nude, garroted bodies of a woman and a girl were found last week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) -- Scientists reported today that weightless flight in space appeared to stimulate mutations, or heriditary changes and abnormalities, in certain living things.
PARIS, Feb. 13 -- The decision of a Government committee to dismiss the director of the Cinematheque Francaise is drawing a storm of indignant protests from all over the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Federal Government joined the automotive and petroleum industries today in announcing a three-year, $10-million research

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- One of the primary troubles with black power is white liberalism. Black power doctrine challenges and in some cases refutes every tenet of the faith in which most whites have fought the so-called "civil rights" or "integration" battles of the last fifteen years, and that is one of the major reasons why so many of these whites have muted or abandoned their efforts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said today the economy moved ahead briskly during the fourth quarter of last year but at a slightly lower pace than at first believed.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 13 -- The original woodblock for a print by Albrecht Durer, the German Renaissance master, has been given to the Art Museum of Princeton University.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI)--A petition is apparently being circulated in the Soviet Union calling on intellectuals to speak out in protest against Stalinism, which the document says is "slowly but surely" being restored.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Government ordered auto makers today to equip all new cars with frontseat head rests starting next Jan. 1. The aim is to cut whiplash injuries set off by some four milion rear-end collisions a year.
BANG, bang, bang. A major investor in American Enka apparently unloaded 225,000 shares of the producer of synthetic fibers in three massive block trades yesterday with explosive suddenness.
The city has opened discussions with Standard Poor's Corporation for a thorough reexamination of its downgraded credit rating -- for a fee.

MEMPHIS, Feb. 14 (UPI) -Mayor Henry Loeb broke off negotiations today with the union representatives of striking sanitation workers. He gave the strikers the choice of returning to work tomorrow or losing their jobs.

In a time when the Federal budget is under heavy pressure because of war spending, President Johnson has discovered that protective legislation for consumers is one front where he can push toward the Great Society at relatively little cost. His latest message tied together several unrelated proposals which would extend Government control over various shoddy commercial practices.

Your Feb. 10 editorial is confusing. You accuse Governor Rockefeller of "selling out" the people of New York City when he proposed a solution along the lines suggested by the emergency mediation panel. Your editorial then seems to suggest that any other course than that proposed by the Governor invited greater disaster -- therefore, protesting to the end, you accept the Governor's solution.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The effectiveness and administration of antipoverty programs in 17 states will be scrutinized in a study by the General Accounting Office ordered by Congress.

Gliding higher and higher last night on the eight escalators that rise to the blue seats under the orange-and-beige ceiling of the new Madison Square Garden, 35-year-old Edward Sabatel stared through the glass-walled tower overlooking Eighth Avenue.

State Supreme Court Justice Saul S. Streit denied yesterday a request of the sanitationmen's union that its jailed president, John J. DeLury, be released in the sheriff's custody to participate in contract talks with the city.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 14 -- Despite Governor Rockefeller's repeated insistence that he is not a candidate for President, the Nebraska Secretary of State entered his name today in the May 14 Republican primary.

Newark and Detroit still haunt the nation's conscience. They are two quite different cities, and yet each of them last summer collapsed into violence. Their disasters made it evident how fragile and how imperiled the social organization of a city is.
Edward N. Ney of Young Rubicam was in Milan yesterday and there's nothing unusual about that. The new president of the agency's new international division is traveling two-thirds of the time.
G. Michael Morris, in charge of the City Register, was found dead, apparently of accidental causes, at his home at 436 West 22d Street last night.
ANDROS, Bahamas, Feb. 14 -- The chickcharneys came through for a stranger, but the stranger gave credence to erroneous forecasts of strong winds and lost a chance at bonefishing.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- With Mayor Lindsay resuming control of efforts to resolve New York City's sanitation dispute, the Legislature, which had struggled futilely with the problem for two days, adjourned today for the week.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 -- Two nonunion printers who have been helping publish the struck Los Angeles Herald-Examiner were shot last night by an unidentified gunman as they walked into the downtown motel where they have been billeted.

State Senator John M. Hughes closed five days of a legislative hearing into the use of narcotics in colleges by saying that testimony had convinced him there was a serious problem at the Stony Brook campus of the State University.

AUTRANS, France, Feb. 14 -- In this enterprising era of faster-than-sound jets and theaters in the round -- such as the new one at nearby Grenoble, where even the audience goes around on a moving turntable -- it is not surprising to learn that cross-country ski racing is entering into the spirit of the age.

Fiasco would be too strong a word to apply to the first sports program in the new Madison Square Garden last night, but foul-up would not. Both games of a National Basketball Association doubleheader were delayed and marred by mechanical inadequacies in the $43-million structure.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The State Board of Regents called on local school boards today for "more determined, more powerful, more energetic" efforts to achieve integration.

John Mosler, a businessman and the president of the New York Urban League, has resigned from the New York Athletic Club because its officers have refused to answer charges of discrimination in the club's selection of social and athletic members.

The Manhattan District Attorney's office reluctantly dropped its case yesterday against Ralph Berger, who was convicted in 1964 of conspiring with the owners of Playboy Clubs International to give a $50,000 bribe to Martin C. Epstein, then chairman of the State Liquor Authority.
Two days after an East Side woman sent a $100 check to a charity in response to a solicitation letter, she found another copy of the same letter in her mailbox, and a week later yet another.

A MANHATTAN housewife, who looked as if she had a wild beast by the tail, left a fur coat auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries yesterday afternoon and paused to ask where she could pick up her purchase.
TWO sizable exhibitions devoted to the work of the American painter Adolph Gottlieb, one of the original members of the abstract expressionist group, opened yesterday.
The rise in the Government securities market that began Tuesday continued yesterday and spilled over to the corporate bond market.

GAFFNEY, S. C., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- A newsman who had received an earlier call from Gaffney's strangler disclosed today that the killer had phoned again just hours before a 15-year-old Negro girl was snatched from the side of the road and forced into a white man's car.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Bill and Cora Sue Gorth are different from most young couples nowadays. For one thing, they talk just the way people in television commercials talk. You know, no pronouns in front of their verbs and lots of imbecilic gushing about scouring powder and cuticle softener.
VIENNA, Feb. 14 -- Franz Novak, chief transport officer for Adolf Eichmann, is to be tried a third time on charges of having aided the mass murder of Jews during World War II.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 14 -- Eight Arab infiltrators and an Israeli soldier were killed north of the Dead Sea today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Representative Wright Patman accused the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board today of "malfeasance and nonfeasance in office" for refusing to buy large quantities of securities of the Federal Home Loan Banks and the Federal National Mortgage Association to help housing and the mortgage market.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 14 -- Two physicians were reprimanded and one placed on professional probation for a year by the California Board of Medical Examiners today because they had taken part in abortions of women who had been exposed to German measles.
Hunter College inaugurated Dr. Robert D. Cross, former chairman of the history department at Columbia University, yesterday as its eighth president.

ATHENS, Feb. 14 -- Greece has agreed to discuss with Turkey the latter's complaints about the treatment of the Turkish minority in the Greek-held part of Thrace, authoritative sources disclosed today.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 14 -- Gold continued to flow out of central bank reserves in January into the coffers of speculators and hoarders, figures just released by the central bank of Belgium showed today.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller's South Mall construction project continues to shake up Albany, literally and figuratively. Pile drivers rattle the Capitol, dust and mud coat the streets as well as pedestrians' ankles, and the $610-million job helps the local economy.
Stock prices rallied, fell, then rallied again yesterday as the market reacted to a rash of news items.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Defense Department said today that an unarmed United States Navy dive bomber with one man aboard had been shot down by a Chinese Communist MIG when it strayed into Chinese air space. It was the eighth United States plane lost over or near Chinese territory in three years.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., may move its home office from 70 Pine Street to a new skyscraper in the financial district reportedly planned as the New York headquarters of the United States Steel Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The United States announced today that it had decided to resume arms shipments to Jordan, which have been suspended since the six-day Israeli-Arab war last June.
CARDENAS, Mexico, Feb. 8 -- One of the biggest investment programs in Latin America is improving the life of thousands of peasants here and will soon contribute to Mexico's industrialization.

NEON, Ky., Feb. 14 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy criticized today the "unacceptable" failure of the Johnson Administration's welfare and antipoverty programs in the Appalachian Mountains and the nation's slums, as well as its policy in Vietnam.

The presidents of 16 European airlines have cabled President Johnson to express their "deepest concern" over tax measures proposed by the Administration to reduce travel abroad. The lines are members of the European Air Research Bureau, with headquarters in Brussels.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 15 -- United States warplanes yesterday mounted their biggest assault on North Vietnam in six weeks, bombing a bridge just outside Hanoi and two airfields in the region of the capital, a military spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, expressed confidence today that the Marine outpost at Khesanh in South Vietnam could be defended without the use of nuclear weapons.
Industrial issues lost ground yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. Recent favorites were neglected but some merger prospects provided a few highlights.
BUFFALO, Feb. 14 -- The New York State Democratic Committee voted overwhelmingly today an endorsement of President Johnson for re-election.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Seantor Russell B. Long of Louisiana, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that "1968 just does not seem to be the year" for any tax reform.

With George Szell conducting the Cleveland Orchestra in a Brahms program last night at Carnegie Hall, everything was predictable.

Made up of three one-act farces, the evening, after a slow start with the first, warms up with the second and ends with an all-stops-out, grandstand finish with the third.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Many public schools are misusing Federal funds designed for the education of disadvantaged children, according to a report submitted to President Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee will start hearings March 12 on legislation to authorize a comprehensive investigation of automobile insurance.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 14--Two committees of the American Trial Lawyers Association took issue here today with a report made public recently by the American Bar Association that called on lawyers, judges and police officials to restrict their comment on pending criminal cases.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- About 1,500 troops with 10 tanks occupied the National University here today after clashes in which a student was shot to death by the police.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 14 -- Shareholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation paved the way here this morning for their company to acquire the Cerro Corporation through an exchange of new stock.

ORANGEBURG, S. C., Feb. 14 -- An uneasy quiet settled in the city of Orangeburg today as units of the National Guard and the Highway Patrol continued to patrol streets near the campus of the South Carolina State College.

MODESTO, Calif., Feb. 13 (AP) -- No young men are being drafted in Stanislaus County because of a shortage of draft board members.

Shirley Clarke will be at the University of Rhode Island at Kingston today to lecture about underground films and to show her latest feature, "Portrait of Jason." Adolfas Mekas was at the University of Cincinnati last Saturday, lecturing and showing his new film, "Windflower." Net earnings of the International Paper Company declined by 15.6 per cent in 1967 to $88,785,909, or $2.03 a share, from $105,221,821, or $2.40 a share, in 1966, Edward B. Hinman, president, reported yesterday.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 14 -- A challenge of raw courage by the experienced Terry McDermott in speed skating and some suberb figure skating by young Tim Wood brought the United States back into the medal hunt as the favorites won their specialties today at the Winter Olympic Games.

The accord reached in Seoul today by Presidential emissary Cyrus Vance and President Park of South Korea is a step to correct a long-festering crisis in relations between the United States and its Korean ally. This crisis has come to a head as a result of Washington's unilateral negotiations with North Korea over the Pueblo incident.
KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 14 -- From foxholes just inside the wire that makes up Khesanh's vulnerable perimeter, it was easy today to spot an occasional North Vietnamese soldier within 150 yards.

TRENTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- More than 70 Bridgeton residents opposed to an integration plan imposed on their elementary schools staged a five-hour sit-in in the reception room of Gov. Richard J. Hughes's office today. But they did not get to see the Governor.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- The Consolidated Edison Company made an offer to New Rochelle today to buy an 80-acre island, containing the old Fort Slocum, for a nuclear-fueled generating plant.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 14 -- Former Gov. William Wallace Barron and five others, including three top state officials, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to "carry out bribery activities in state government."
MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- Treacherous of the Lazy F Ranch was the most diligent of the dozen contestants in the $32,450 Columbiana Handicap for fillies and mares today at Hialeah.

The Board of Estimate ordered the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority yesterday to allow elderly passengers to ride its buses for 10 cents during nonrush hours, holidays and weekends.
Northrup Knox of Buffalo and Aiken, S. C., successfully completed the defense of his world open court tennis championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. Feb. 14 (AP) -- Former Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland said today at a hearing on a bill to abolish capital punishment that he had allowed four prisoners to be executed during his term "because I didn't have the character to do what I should have done."
SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Feb. 15 -- The United States and South Korea agreed today on a joint program to counter aggressive moves by the Communist North Korean regime.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Jan Leschly of Denmark and seven Americans advanced to the quarter-finals with straight-set victories in the national indoor. tennis championship tonight.

ATLANTA, Feb. 14 -- George C. Wallace announced today that Marvin Griffin, a former Governor of Georgia, will at least temporarily be his Vice-Presidential running mate on third-party tickets across the country.

SOME new powder snow in New England has generally improved the skiing conditions for areas 150 miles or more from New York City. Closer areas in the Catskills and Berkshires remain in need and several are relying upon their snow making systems to keep operating.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- Secretary General Thant conferred for more than an hour here today with Mai Van Bo, Hanoi's chief representative in Europe. He then discussed Vietnam and the Middle East in separate meetings with President de Gaulle and Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Johnson's decision to rush 10,500 more Army and Marine infantrymen to South Vietnam will seriously deplete this country's already frayed force of active Strategic Reserve divisions.

A bull market for bright young lawyers is spreading through the city's large law firms in the wake of a decision by Cravath, Swaine Moore to raise its salaries for new law-school graduates to $15,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 14 -- The Justice Department, in a case that may break some new ground in antitrust law, filed suit today against the recent acquisition by the Gillette Company of a German manufacturer of electric razors and other products, Braun, A.G.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 14--On the evening of Jan. 29, a 22-year-old Vietcong recruit named Le was told that the National Liberation Front had overrun all the cities of South Vietnam except Saigon. The job of Le's unit was to take the capital.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 14 -- Former Gov. Orval E. Faubus removed himself from consideration today as an opponent this year of either Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller or Senator J. W. Fulbright.

THE Mickey Mouse watch is back and ticking -- and just in time for the little rodent's 40th birthday. Mickey returns after a 10-year absence on a $12.95 Timex watch that will be sold in drug and department stores throughout the country, including Macy's and Bloomingdale's.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- Representatives of North Vietnam met with Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani here 10 days ago and discussed prospects for a negotiated settlement of the war in Vietnam, it was disclosed today.
SO. ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 14 -- St. Bonaventure of Olean, N. Y., the nation's fourthranked college basketball team, battled to an 81-71 victory in overtime over a relentless Seton Hall team tonight.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed a $1.1-billion program today for the construction and rehabilitation of municipal and nonpublic hospitals, nursing homes and health centers.

Moviegoers have paid approximately $15-million thus far to see "Gone With the Wind" in its engagements in 82 theaters around the country since the new, wide-screen version of the Civil War spectacle began its revival run in Atlanta on Oct. 4.

Futures in pork bellies, one of the most successful commodity contracts started in recent years, continue to attract a large amount of trading. In a typical day, 4,000 to 5,000 contracts change hands, a very good showing for a non-grain or non-soybean contract.
Three major drug concerns failed yesterday to obtain an acquittal, or a new trial, after their conviction last Dec. 29 of conspiracy and monopolizing the market in "wonder drugs."
The Port of New York is scheduled in mid-April to join the ranks of major United States ports with bridge-to-bridge radio telephone communications for merchant vessels entering or leaving the harbor.

Consolidated net income of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., in 1967 fell 25 per cent to $52,952,000, or $2.14 a share, from $70,667,000, or $2.92 a share in 1966, despite record sales, the report disclosed yesterday.
The Government dropped stowaway charges yesterday against Michael Lucien Shway, 19 years old, who had himself nailed in a crate for shipment to Australia earlier this month.
The Kayser-Roth Corporation, the world's largest apparel producer, achieved the highest sales and earning for any half-year period in its history in the six months ended Dec. 31.

Three Cubans, two of whom the Government said were former members of the Cuban House of Representatives, were convicted yesterday in Federal Court of conspiring to print and distributing $1-million in counterfeit United States currency.

The wisdom of beginning renegotiations of labor contracts far in advance of contract expiration dates certainly is open to question after several recent fiascos in New York City alone.
The Superintendent of Schools' new plan for rezoning all 17 Queens academic high schools to improve racial balance was praised yesterday by leaders of the original effort to achieve such change.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- A constitutional amendment that provides for a national runoff election to avoid a three-way contest for the Presidency in the House of Representatives was proposed today by Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx.

Track and field makes its debut in the new Madison Square Garden tonight, accompanied by a Negro boycott, a picket line and, almost incidentally, the makings of an extraordinary meet.
Cass Canfield Jr. has been selected to succeed Evan W. Thomas 2d as head of the general book division of Harper Row, the 150-year-old publishing house.

Federal Judge Edward C. McLean issued an order yesterday asking the Securities and Exchange Commission to show cause Monday why it should not be cited for contempt of court for filing certain depositions obtained in the case involving Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Army is stockpiling riot control equipment in strategically located depots across the country, officials said today, and is ready to airlift it to any city if civil disorders break out next summer.

Angry Negro antipoverty workers confronted Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administrator, yesterday to demand the appointment of John Edmonds as the new commissioner of the Community Development Agency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Production declined in many different industries in January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 15 -- Nancy Greene has taken the giant slalom in the Winter Olympic Games for Canada, just as she was supposed to do. The blue-eyed beauty from British Columbia ripped and slashed down the 1,610-meter, 63-gate Chamrousse course in 1 minute 51.97 seconds to win by an incredible 2.64 seconds from Annie Famose as France had its entire quartet in the first seven.

NEWARK, Feb. 15 -- Henry Lewis today became the first Negro appointed music director of a symphony orchestra in the United States. The 36-year-old Mr. Lewis will head the New Jersey Symphony effective June 1.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The American Bar Association gave its active support today to a program to train Negroes and members of other minority groups to become lawyers. Tuition and expenses would be paid.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva shook up his Cabinet today in a new attempt to straighten out the tangled economic affairs of the country. He named new Treasury, Economy and Labor Ministers to draft a new economic plan for his remaining three years in office.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -- Jordan announced tonight that 13 civilians and five soldiers were killed during the fighting today.

THE Philharmonic program last night was composed of standard pieces, what with Mendelssohn's "Hebrides" Overture, Mozart's C minor Piano Concerto with Gina Bachauer as soloist, and Tchaikovsky's Sixth Symphony, the "Pathetique." But all of these tried and true works received exceptionally strong performances.

Macy's New York has named Frederick D. Wilkinson, a 47-year-old buyer of men's shirts, to the post of administrator and manager of its branch store in Jamaica, Queens, effective April 1.

The New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday urged changes in state law so that the courts could restrict the use of police undercover agents.

The Shell Oil Company plans one of the largest equity financings in corporate history. It could involve nearly $395-million. The company has not had an equity financing since the nineteen-twenties. Shell said yesterday that it would file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an offering of about 6,150,000 shares to its stockholders.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 15 -- Gov. George Romney said today the Vietnam war would be his major campaign issue in the New Hampshire Presidential primary and called former Vice President Richard M. Nixon "a me-too candidate on Vietnam."

ROME, Feb. 15 -- Violence flared again yesterday in central Sardinia, arousing fears of a new wave of banditry that could be even worse than last year's. The situation grew so desperate then that the Government in Rome was forced to send a small army to maintain order.

ANTHOLOGIES, at their best, are interesting gambits for attention, or conveniences, or sometimes both. Even at their best, however, they are suspect. Indictments against two Long Island lawyers accused of participating in a $15,000 shakedown plot were dismissed by a State Supreme Court justice yesterday because a 14-month delay in bringing them to trial had violated their constitutional rights.

On the eve of the greatest advance in the metropolitan transportation system in at least half a century the Board of Estimate has raised a minor diversion by decreeing that passengers over 65 should be allowed to ride on city-owned bus lines during nonrush hours for half fare. It would be wise to defer this politically appealing but administratively difficult proposal.

TRENTON, Feb. 15 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today that he was "strongly tempted" to go beyond the spending ceilings in his new budget to implement the urban reforms that his Select Commission on Civil Disorder had urgently recommended. Charging the New York Athletic Club with exploitation of black athletes, spokesmen for some groups planning to picket the club's track meet tonight at Madison Square Garden appealed yesterday for a boycott of the event by athletes and asked for support on picket lines.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 15 Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, the top-ranking player of the United States and winner of the title the last two years, overcame the blazing challenge of Martin Riessen of Evanston, Ill., in the quarter-finals of the national indoor tennis championship tonight and won 7-5-6-4.

Benjamin Oren, an Israeli pianist who has performed in New York several times since his debut here in 1958, returned to Town Hall last night to play Bach's Variations in the Italian Manner, Mozart's Rondo in D (K. 485), Schumann's "Kreisleriana," Ben-Haim's Music for the Piano and Chopin's Bolero and Ballade No. 4.

State Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Spiegel ruled yesterday that Adam Clayton Powell should be held accountable for any expenses incurred by an elderly Harlem widow in suing him for defamation of character.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The economic arguments for and against a tax increase are ending in a miserable stalemate, but the moral argument for raising taxes has scarcely been debated.

Fifty Notre Dame alumni urged their fellow alumni yesterday to resign from the New York Athletic Club unless the club explained its membership policies regarding non-whites and non-Christians.

FORT LEE, N. J., Feb. 15 -- A 24-year-old man who wrenched himself out of his father's arms and leaped 250 feet from the George Washington Bridge today swam 200 yards to shore and survived with only a cut on his thigh.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Four vice presidents and 15 board members of the Americans for Democratic Action who opposed A.D.A. endorsement of the Presidential candidacy of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy signaled their intention today of remaining in the organization.

DICK BUTTON, the former United States Olympic skating champion, appears in line for a gold medal in television sports reporting. One of Europe's leading central bankers warned yesterday that the United States "must" succeed in ending its balance of payments deficit, "or the dollar will be in very grave danger."

The New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday it had agreed to make two commercial mortgage loans in the Watts area of Los Angeles, scene of Negro rioting in 1965.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 15 (Agence France-Presse) -- Hospital Corpsman David Heriford of Springfield, Ill., goes out every night with a stethoscope and puts it to the ground at this base's airstrip and around the command bunker. He is listening for sounds of digging.

Earnings of Time Inc. fell sharply last year, despite a small increase in revenues, it was announced here yesterday. The publishing complex, which announced plans on Wednesday to buy The Newark Evening News, netted $30.4-million, or $4.36 a share, last year.

Former West German Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said here yesterday he believed that recent measures taken by the Johnson Administration would improve the United States balance of payments.

But, a lieutenant who offered this assessment yesterday of the new bureau chief, Thomas Caldwell Re naghan, said that the assistant chief inspector won obedience as much by gaining his men's respect as by be ing tough.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- Two brothers with a habit of falling clown and injuring themselves were sentenced yesterday to two years in jail for their pains.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 16 -- The three American fliers released from imprisonment in North Vietnam flew here tonight and immediately became the center of controversy over how they should proceed to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -The Johnson Administration abolished today most graduate deferments from the draft. Exceptions were granted for medical and dental students, students in allied fields and those who will have completed two or more years of their studies by June.

There was a superb debut of sorts at the Metropolitan Museum last night: the first joint recital in New York, after many highly acclaimed individual appearances here, by Peter Pears and Julian Bream. Anticipation ran high for this meeting between the celebrated English tenor and his countryman, the master lutenist-guitarist; the hall was sold out two weeks ago, and some 60 standees were ranged across the back of the auditorium by concert time.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 16 -- Remember when a ski race could be held by merely having a group of schussboomers sweep down a slope together, with the first man to reach the bottom the winner? Or when the champion of an ice hockey tournament was determined the easy way -- by the most games won?

MARLBOROUGH-GERSON, that outpost of New Bond Street at 41 East 57th, brings us another report from the British art front this week via four London artists -- Joe Tilson, Colin Lanceley, Richard Lin and Gordon House.

Wooden horses used by the police for crowd control started going into place outside the Coliseum yesterday as the National Boat Show prepared for the final leg of what could be record run.
NEWARK, Feb. 16 A (AP) -- The State Board of Higher Education called today for new or increased taxes to support public higher education in New Jersey.

MIAMI, Feb. 16 -- John Bass, the retired sugar executive, and his wife, who donated their controversial collection of paintings and art objects to the city of Miami Beach four years ago, today offered to reimburse the city for the money it spent in housing the collection if the city, in turn, would give the collection to another museum of their choice.
MOSCOW, Feb. 16 -- Leonid I. Brezhenv, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, lashed out against the United States today, charging that its foreign policy was one of "worldwide brigandage."
JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 -- The normal flow of refugees, truckers, visitors and officials resumed across the Allenby Bridge today in the wake of the battle between Israelis and Jordanians yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Betty Lou Raskin, a Baltimore chemist and psychologist, will receive a patent later this month for foamed plastic smoke.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Johnson said today that no recommendation had been made to him for the possible use of nuclear weapons in the Vietnam war and in dicated that no such step was being considered by the Administration.
The Temple of Dendur, now in pieces on an island in the Nile, is in the final stages of being packed for shipment to Manhattan.
A five-member panel of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has voted unanimously to reverse a key ruling in the 1965 murder trial of Richard Robles.

The top three commanders of the Police Department's Narcotics Bureau, which is under investigation by four different agencies, were relieved of their posts yesterday and assigned to less important duties.
THAT blockbuster trade in American Motors that blasted the tape yesterday on a dip raised eyebrows and fluttered pulses in the highest circles of institutional trading yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 -- Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service from 1936 to 1948 and a founder of the World Health Organization, died last night in Presbyterian-University Hospital. He was 75 years old.

ROME, Feb. 16 -- Opponents of the plan to create 14 region governments in Italy by 1970, approved this week after a marathon parliamentary struggle, promised today to continue the battle in the next legislature.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Richard L. Kiley, president of the 700-member Cincinnati Teachers Union, was sentenced to five days in jail and was fined $500 for contempt of court today for leading a four-day teachers strike last month.

THE Helsinki Philharmonic Orchestra has come to the United States, bearing Finnish music. It is the first visit of the orchestra to these shores, and last night the group made its New York debut with a Carnegie Hall concert.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- The American Bar Association's board of governors tentatively endorsed today a controversial report that proposes stringent restrictions on pretrial dissemination of information in criminal cases.

SOCIAL CIRCLE, Ga., Feb. 16 (UPI) -- State troopers escorted school buses to an all-Negro elementary school by a back route today, slipping by demonstrators who had planned to throw themselves in front of the vehicles.

Twentieth Century-Fox has announced plans for a film sequel to "Valley of the Dolls" under the tentative title of "Return to Valley of the Dolls." Jacqueline Susann, who wrote the original best-selling novel, is writing the outline for the sequel and her husband, Irving Mansfield, will produce it.
MIAMI, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The third wife of John Jacob Astor 3d was granted a divorce today on the ground of mental cruelty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Senate prepared today for a showdown next week on choking off a month-long debate over civil rights.

IN a lucid and beautifully written introduction, Elizabeth Seeger states her purpose: to tell a story. This was surely a Herculean task.
