SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 19--The Vietcong struck sprawling Tansonnhut Airport here again this morning after having bombarded cities, provincial towns and American military compounds yesterday.

The award of a $25,000 contract to a Manhattan consulting engineering company for a location and feasibility study of a bus terminal in central Flushing, Queens, was announced yesterday by Arthur E. Palmer Jr., City Transportation Administrator. The contract was let to Frederic R. Harris, Inc., of 300 East 42d Street by the Department of Highways. The concern has four months to complete the study.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 18 (UPI)--Premier Emir Abbas Hoveida presented today a record $3.6-billion budget to Parliament. The budget included plans to equip Iran's armed forces with advanced weapons.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 18 (UPI) --The Cincinnati Royals, led by Oscar Robertson's 30 points and Jerry Lucas's 23 rebounds, scored their fourth victory in four days, beating Boston, 107-100, today and ending the Celtics' four-game winning streak.
AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 18 (AP) --Akron's Goodyears led all the way to score a 100-67 basketball victory today over Wichita, Kan. At half-time, the Goodyears led, 42-31.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Britain joined Europe early this morning--in time, that is.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 18--All New York Yankee pitchers and catchers are expected to check in tomorrow for the start of the club's 66th spring training season, which will begin with less impact than any Yankee camp since 1920.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 18 (UPI) -- Jordanian security forces today seized guns and ammunition hidden by Arab commandos for raids against Israel.
A 177-automobile reduction in the size of the city's motor pool was ordered yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
Fred H. Merrill, chairman of the board and president of The Fund America Companies, has been named to the board of Middle South Utilities, Inc., according to an announcement from the latter.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The Federal Maritime Commission approved Friday the basic agreement setting up the Inter -American Freight Conference.

FRANKLIN, Ind., Feb. 18 (UPI)--Two men were killed today when their single-engine planes collided above the Franklin flying field and crashed to the ground. They were William Maurice Emmert, 25 years old, of Beech Grove, Ind., and Clifford Query of Greenwood, Ind.
The Metropolitan Duane Methodist Church is one of those bustling downtown churches with something for everyone in the neighborhood, including theater buffs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Solid evidence now in the hands of top Administration officials indicates that the Soviet Union is close to pulling even with the United States in land-based strategic missiles.

The first bids for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship and the National Invitation Tournament will be extended to colleges tomorrow. The N.C.A.A. will have a one-hour head start on the N.I.T. to bid for the at-large teams

TOKYO, Feb. 18 (AP)--Japanese and American interests are going ahead with negotiations to build an aluminum reduction plant at Astoria, Ore., at the mouth of the Columbia River, industry sources said here over the weekend.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 18--Chile's Government Copper Corporation denied this weekend that there was any definite plan to modify copper sales policy abroad based on the adopter of a cash payments formula in the London market.
The Common Carrier Conference of Domestic Water Carriers has changed its name to the Water Transport Association and moved its headquarters from Washington to New York.
Opposition by one maritime union to the sale of two American-flag cargo ships to a shipping company affiliated with a rival union has prompted the seller to hold up the transaction.
MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (AP)--President Nikolai V. Podgorny marked his 65th birthday today.
What has happened to the investment climate in Greece since the military take-over last April?

TULSA, Okla., Feb. 18 (AP)-Senator Robert F. Kennedy brought his investigation of Indian education to Oklahoma tonight and was greeted by some 400 persons, many carrying "Kennedy for President" signs. The New York Democrat will have breakfast tomorrow with students at the Seneca Indian School at Wyandotte, near Hiami, Okla.
Employing various neckcraning techniques, the first capacity crowd at the new Madison Square Garden welcomed the Rangers to the arena atop Penn Station last night.
WASHINGTON, Monday, Feb. 19 (UPI)--The President landed at Andrews Air Force Base at 1:10 A.M. today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 (UPI) -- Helmeted policemen used tear gas tonight to disperse hundreds of young people who spilled onto streets of the Haight-Ashbury hippie district and blocked traffic.
A total of $1.1-million has been given to Harvard University by John L. Loeb, senior partner of Loeb, Rhoades Co., the investment banking concern.

The double bill of "The Trials of Brother Jero" and "The Strong Breed," which had been announced to close last night, will continue at the Greenwich Mews Theater. Wole Soyinka is the author of both plays.

SEA BRIGHT, N. J., Feb. 18--Charles and Tom Jones of the Racquet and Tennis Club of New York won the Sea Bright squash racquets invitation doubles today for the third consecutive year. They defeated George Doetsch of Baltimore and Hastings Griffin of Philadelphia, 18-15, 11-15, 15-12, 15-7.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Jim Clark of Scotland drove his Lotus 49 to a record for the race today in winning the 101-mile Warwick Farm event in 1 hour eight minutes 17.2 seconds. He led all the way.

Andrew B. Murray has been appointed director of labor relations for Loew's Hotels. Mr. Murray was formerly with the Pierre Management Corporation and is a former officer of the American Hotel and Motel Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--If formal courtesies are a hallmark of diplomacy, then the Secretary of State and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have come close to breaking diplomatic relations in recent weeks.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18-(UPI)--Charlie Williams, held scoreless in the first quarter scored 38 points in the final three periods tonight and paced the Pitsburgh Pipers to a 103-92 American Basketball Association victory over the Denver Rockets.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to start developing machines this year that will enable astronauts to drive or hop about on the surface of the moon.

RYE, N. Y., Feb. 18--Thomas Poor of Philadelphia, the defending champion who headed the draw, won the 26th annual Apawamis Club squash racquets invitation tournament today by defeating Anil Nayar of Harvard, 17-14, 11-15, 15-13, 10-15, 15-7.

The Uris Buildings Corporation has appointed Christopher N. Carson and Edward G. Flather Jr. as vice presidents. Mr. Carson will supervise building management, and Mr. Flather will be in charge of the company's hotel operations.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 18 -- The Arkansas legislature appears to be ready to enact some kind of prison reform legislation this week.
TOKYO, Feb. 18 -- Japan's fast-growing economic stake in South Korea has made this onetime Japanese colonial territory a magnet of major importance for Japanese trade and investment.
To add to the pain of April 15, taxpayers should not forget that New York State income tax returns must be filed the same day.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 18--In the headquarters of the Florida Education Association, a half block or so from Florida's capitol, staff members of the association spent most of today answering the telephone.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 18 (AP) --Six men scored in double figures today as the New Orleans Buccaneers toppled the Oakland Oaks. 132-111, in an American Basketball Association game.

GENEVA, Feb. 18--The campaign to grant Swiss women the vote made another advance today when men voters in the mostly German-speaking Canton of Berne authorized individual municipalities to allow women to vote in minicipal elections.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Ellsworth Bunker, the United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, has declared in Saigon that the allies are stronger than they were before the enemy's Lunar New Year offensive.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (UPI)-Kenny Wharram and Stan Mikita scored three goals each today and sparked the Chicago Black Hawks to a 7-1 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League's nationally televised game.
HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 (AP)--The field team of the International Control Commission has pulled out of Hue.
The League for Parent Education, 1705 Cortelyou Road, Brooklyn, will benefit from a bazaar to be held tomorrow from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. at the Flatbush Terrace, 1475 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 18--John Cashman Jr., the race secretary of Roosevelt Raceway, welcomed Cardigan Bay back to the pacing wars today. But the welcome, meant in high respect, took the form of a penalty for the brilliant 12-year-old.
SAN DIEGO, Feb. 18 (UPI)-The underdog San Diego Rockets scored their first victory over the Philadelphia 76ers, 111-106, tonight and snapped a 17-game losing streak. The victors led most of the way.
MIAMI, Feb. 18--Ralph Conrad of Brazil won the North American Finn Class sailboat championship today and the right to represent his country at the Summer Olympics at Acapulco, Mexico.
The corporate bond market is approaching March--customarily a time when financing activity picks up markedly -- with a relatively light schedule of sales in prospect.

Just how many potholes lie in wait for motorists on New York City's streets this year is an urban unknown. But there were more than a million of them in 1967--or about 165 holes for each mile of pavement --and the 1968 crop is likely to be even larger.

The appointment of Orlando Jose Irizarry and Mrs. Maria Magdalena Ortiz as human rights specialists on the staff of the City Commission on Human Rights was announced yesterday by Commissioner William H. Booth. Both appointees were born in Puerto Rico.
A change in the law to free employers from having to deal with a union whose members turn down a collective bargaining agreement without a secret vote was urged last night by Theodore W. Kheel.

F. William Free, president and chief executive of the Marschalk Company, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has quit to set up his own shop. He is being replaced as president by Richard W. Bowman, an executive director at McCann-Erickson, another of the Group.

The public school system has made an agreement with the Police Department to install equipment in every school to permit an instantaneous signal to the local station house "when uncontrollable violence takes place in the school."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)--Vice President Humphrey has joined a country club that last fall became the first in this area to admit a Negro to membership. The club, Indian Spring, in nearby Glenmont, Md., approved last November the membership application of the columnist Carl T. Rowan; United States District Court Judge Aubrey E. Robinson Jr., and Dr. Charles Ireland. All three are Negroes.
On the fourth floor of the Coliseum last night, the $29.95 Guzzler Bilge Pump churned the water in its demonstration tank with one last gurgle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -When Walter E. Washington became Commissioner, or Mayor, of the District of Columbia last fall, no less an authority on municipal melancholy than his friend, Mayor Lindsay of New York, told him his new job was bound to be a "no win" proposition.
FREEPORT, L. I.--There is ice on their lines, a freezing wind in their faces and a grueling five-hour sail ahead, but the cod fishermen are happy.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 18 (AP) --Police said today that a widow who did not believe in hotel safes reported the theft of jewelry valued at $114,000 from her room in a hotel in the French Quarter. The widow, Mrs. Margaret B. Bowdle, 40 years old of Wichita Falls, Tex., told the police she left the jewels in her room when she went to dinner last night, and returned before midnight to find them gone.
Harper's Magazine and The Atlantic Monthly are each devoting almost their entire March issue to single articles on America's mood in the face of the disruptive debate over the Vietnam War.
Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced over the weekend an important breakthrough in his protracted efforts to pay off the depositors of the New York branch of Intra Bank.

The romantic -- and, at its best, necromantic--art of giving lieder recitals has no more eloquent exponent than Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, even when she happens to be momentarily out of voice. When, as happened yesterday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall, the voice is at its current best, the soprano can turn a song program into a cheering contest.

A $5-million lease for office space in the 41-story addition to the Bankers Trust Company Building at 280 Park Avenue has been signed by the General Signal Corporation, a diversified industrial concern.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 18--The Israeli Cabinet met twice today and it seemed apparent that the new Jordanian attitude was discussed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:
MOSCOW, Feb. 18--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin has called on Soviet industry to overcome the gap in consumer goods with the United States.
BASEL, Switzerland -- The son of a Lutheran minister has become the first American to set up a private bank in Switzerland.
ROME, Feb. 18--Pope Paul VI today welcomed the prelates who will take part in the Italian Bishops' conference that opens in Rome tomorrow.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 18 -- President Johnson and some of his leading aides told former President Dwight D. Eisenhower here today that they believed the enemy had been hurt badly in recent weeks of fighting in Vietnam and that the South Vietnamese Army and Government might well emerge stronger than ever before.

THE television viewer was told last night that "The Legend of Robin Hood" had been brought to him by his gas company; never was an advertising announcement so warmly accurate. The musical special on the National Broadcasting Company network succeeded only in suggesting that Sherwood Forest must have been the scene of the first revival of "Blossom Time." It wasn't a bad musi cal: it was genuinely awful.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 (UPI)--Glen Sather took a pass from Ed Westfall with only 1 minute 14 seconds left and rammed home a 15-foot shot to give the Boston Bruins a 6-5 National Hockey League victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight.

VADUZ, Liechtenstein -- Prosperous Liechtenstein, a postage-stamp principality between Switzerland and Austria, is worried about her reputation as a haven for tax dodgers, gun-runners and shady financiers.

Larry Arrick, who staged 40 Off-Broadway plays and one on Broadway, has been named artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater, an adjunct of the Yale Drama School. He has been signed until July, 1969, and will be Yale's first artistic director. The appointment was made by Robert Brustein, dean of the Yale Drama School.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 18 (UPI) --The North Vietnamese Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Nguyen Tho Canh, will arrive this week in what is apparently a campaign by North Vietnam to present Hanoi's view to Western Governments, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI)--Senator Hugh Scott described former Alabama Gov. George C. Wallace today as a "menace." He said that it was "surely not impossible" that his third-party candidacy would leave selection of a President this year to the House of Representatives.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 18 (AP)-Running as a unit for only the second time this year, Villanova's two-mile relay team broke its own world indoor record in the eighth Mason-Dixon Games last night with a time of 7 minutes 23.8 seconds.

HOUSTON, Feb. 18 (AP)--A three-judge Federal court is to hear arguments tomorrow on Cassius Clay's appeal of a fiveyear prison sentence received upon conviction for refusal to enter the armed services.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 18 (AP)--John F. Bolton Jr., Director of Insurance for the State of Illinois, announced today that several of the nation's largest automobile insurance companies would test a new method of paying auto accident victims beginning March 1.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 (UPI)--The United Automobile Workers local at an Ohio plant tentatively accepted a new contract from the General Motors Corporation tonight, paving the way for an end to a three-day strike.

ALLEGANY, N.Y., Feb. 18 (UPI)--Gregg Hendryx, 10 years old, of Bradford, Pa., one of seven persons injured yesterday in a chair-lift accident died today at Children's Hospital in Buffalo. The boy suffered a fractured skull in the accident at the Grosstal Ski Resort when chairs on a lift sped down the hill out of control.

Mayor Lindsay has exempted the Department of Hospitals from the need to obtain prior approval of the Budget Bureau for expenditures up to $10,000. All other city agencies require prior approval for outlays of more than $5,000.
The American Jewish Congress, a human rights agency, called on the Administration yesterday to declare a "national domestic emergency" to deal with the crisis in the cities.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18--A bomb threat was phoned today to the Pittsburgh-Hilton Hotel, where Mr. Wallace will speak tomorrow night. The switchboard received a call from an unidentified man who said, "I'm planning to blow up the hotel when Wallace is there."
MARATHON, Fla., Feb. 18 (UPI) -- A professor's son apparently hired a private plane yesterday, then pulled a gun on the pilot and ordered him to fly to Cuba.

When Lionel Hampton's octet struck up "Greasy Greens" at the end of a concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, Mr. Hampton asked for volunteer dancers from the audience. One of those who leaped onto the stage was Sid Davidoff, an assistant to Mayor Lindsay, who writhed through a remarkably undulant boogaloo to uproarious applause.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP)--Andy Hampton drove at a steady pace today and triumphed in the 300-mile Automobile Racing Club of America winter championship race in a 1967 Dodge Charger.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 18 (UPI)--Pakistan's oil and gas development corporation has discovered "oil in quantity" at Tut, 75 miles west of Rawalpindi, it was announced over the weekend. Testing at the site is being carried out with the aid of Soviet technical experts.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 (AP)--More than 200 South Vietnamese politicians, many of them strongly opposed to the present Government, met today to form an anti-Communist front.

From the $7 red seats in the loge to the $2.50 blue seats high in the last row of the mezzanine, spectators were on the edges of their cushions last night during the first hockey game at the new Madison Square Garden.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 18 -- A group of white children will be transported to an Integrated, inner city school on Feb. 26 for the first time despite strong objections from the white parents who have complained about increased tensions in Negro schools here.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 18 (AP)--The bodies of a young man and a young woman from Nassau County, L. I., were found today in a motel room that the police said was littered with barbiturate capsules and hippie trappings.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP)--The National Safety Council reported today that fatalities from firearms and poisonings in homes increased in 1967 despite the lowest yearly home-accident death rate ever recorded.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A special commission has recommended that the International Association of Fire Fighters modify its constitutional ban on strikes.

Enrico Macias is a guitarstrumming French singing star who is unknown here, a fact that is difficult to reconcile with the tumultuous reception he received on his American debut Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city's agreement to settle its dispute with the sanitation union by binding arbitration was "a major breakthrough in labor relations," but some municipal labor leaders took a skeptical view of the idea.
The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation will not give any funds to fellows selected this year because of a cutback in Ford Foundation support.
Richard J. Bartlett, chairman of the state's new Crime Control Council, said yesterday that the police should make greater use of nonlethal weapons such as Chemical Mace and tranquilizer-dart guns.

BERLIN, Feb. 18--More than 10,000 people, including 4,000 students from West Germany and other European countries, staged a march and rally today to protest the American involvement in Southeast Asia. It appeared to be the biggest anti-American demonstration yet staged in the city.
Production of man-made fiber in this country achieved an alltime record of 4,030,600,000 pounds in 1967, topping the 1966 level by 3 per cent, the Textile Economics Bureau reported over the weekend.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $118,652,787,964. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

MANALAPAN TOWNSHIP, N. J., Feb. 18--An out-of-control car with a 9-year-old boy at the wheel struck and killed a woman passerby here yesterday. The victim was Mrs. Rose Threatt, a 57-year-old worker at a fruit farm owned by John Guinco, where the accident took place.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP)--Premier Piet de Jong of the Netherlands arrived here today for talks with Prime Minister Wilson on ways of improving Britain's relations with the European Economic Community despite France's veto of the British application for membership.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18 (AP)--The Pittsburgh Federation of Teachers authorized today a strike of Pittsburgh's public school system Feb. 29. The federation has been trying for some time to hold a bargaining election sanctioned by the Pittsburgh Board of Education. The board has balked, reportedly because it believes the federation's demands would be too stiff. The federation claims the support of 1,000 of the city's 3,000 teachers.
Two American pacifists, a professor and a priest, accused the United States Government yesterday of having endangered future prisoner releases by the North Vietnamese.
The State Education Department will begin a campaign today to help alleviate the teacher shortage by bringing into teaching, or bringing back into education, persons not now working in the field.

Sy Grubel, the fourth-seeded player, was upset by Al Goldstein, 5-7, 10-8, 6-4, in the second round of the Brooklyn indoor clay-court tennis championship for men 35 years and older yesterday at the Hi-Way Club in Flatbush.
PARIS, Feb. 18 (Reuters)-The former Supreme Commander of the Soviet armed forces said today that defeat for the United States in Vietnam was inevitable unless the Americans used nuclear arms.

The United States has evidently decided to give its blessing to the military dictatorship in Greece and to be seen giving it. There is no other way to explain the visit of the carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt to Piraeus and the convivial entertainment offered to junta leaders on board by Ambassador Phillips Talbot.
The report of the President's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders "will make all America uncomfortable." Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, Feb. 19 (AP)--The United States conceded today that two of its planes had violated North Korea's airspace. A United States spokesman expressed regret for the incident.

High state and legislative officials predicted yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's role in the sanitation dispute and his worsening personal relationship with Governor Rockefeller would damage the Lindsay administration's chances of getting what it wants from Albany --at least temporarily.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 18--President Johnson brought his impromptu weekend tour of military installations today to the golf course winter home of the most famous soldier of them all--former President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
Two teen-aged brothers were shot, one fatally, and a bystander was critically wounded yesterday afternoon in a fight that started with an argument over a stickball game in a Brooklyn street.

They used to call vocalists of such rare talent as Janis Joplin "a great jazz singer." Because the music has changed and the scene has shifted, the 25-year-old dynamo from Port Arthur, Tex., is what one would call nowadays a great rock singer.

Donizetti's "Don Pasquale" might seem an easy opera to perform, on the face of it: just five characters, and an unchanging setting. There are many lovely tunes and no profundities to explore. What makes "Don Pasquale," like others of its opera-buffa genre, difficult to bring off successfully is the need for a sense of style and for a cast intensively drilled in ensemble singing and acting.
Negotiators representing the New York Newspaper Guild and The New York Post tried yesterday to avert a strike set for 5 A.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)--A mock trial of world communism is to begin a three-day run here tomorrow. The primary sponsors are Young Americans for Freedom, a conservatively oriented college-age group, and Twin Circle, a company that specializes in publishing material of appeal to conservative Roman Catholics. Richard Harold Slemmer, lawyer from Columbus, Ohio, is to be the presiding judge.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 18 (Agence France-Presse)-The Communist party newspaper Nhan Dan said today that the Vietnamese people "resolutely reject" President Johnson's San Antonio formula for opening negotiations.
The National Association of Securities Dealers announced yesterday details of its longawaited plan to develop an automated quotations system for the huge over-the-counter securities market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Daniel F. Fitzpatrick of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service has been assigned to New York City as assistant director of Region 1 effective March 4. The region consists of New York State, the New England states and northern New Jersey. Mr. Fitzpatrick will continue to serve as national maritime coordinator for the service.

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., Feb. 18--Bill Mazeroski, second baseman of the Pittsburgh Pirates, made another clutch play today. He sank a four-foot putt for a net birdie that helped him and Paul Krause, his partner, a safetyman for the Washington Redskins, to win their second straight American Airlines Astrojet Golf Classic.

IT is said that the popularity of Americans in France is at its lowest ebb in history. After the Gauls read "The Cooking of Provincial France" by Time-Life Books, things are very likely to get worse. They might even start a small war in Normandy, Alsace or Provence, and I might very well join them.

Robert Moses, in his last report as chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, admonished his successor yesterday not "to undermine, destroy or tarnish" the agency's methods of operation.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18--The steel market was scheduled to move into a new phase last week.

FLANDERS, L. I., Feb. 18--A 2-year-old boy was burned to death here this morning when fire destroyed a small apartment on Flanders Road. Mrs. Dorothy Langhorne, the mother of the victim, and her four other small children escaped without injury. The police and Flanders volunteer firemen found the body of the boy. Ricky Langhorne, at about 8:15 A.M.
LISBON, Feb. 18 (Reuters)--Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, who has performed two heart transplants, arrived here today from Johannesburg on his way to South America and the United States.

TORONTO, Feb. 18 -- Western Canada's "independent" oil companies, which are largely American-owned, have been lobbying hard in Washington for a $100-million industrywide exemption from the new restrictions on investment abroad.

George C. Scott will stage the first revival here of Eugene O'Neill's 1923 drama, "All God's Chillun Got Wings," in April. The co-star of "Plaza Suite" will work the new production into his performance schedule. The play will be presented by Theodore Mann at an Off Broadway house not booked yet, with James Earl Jones heading the cast.
A test of public sentiment on the war in Vietnam is expected in tomorrow's special election for the House of Representatives in Brooklyn's 13th Congressional District.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 18 -The nation's school superintendents have been asked to approve a policy urging integration where it is feasible but recognizing that it is not "the main goal" of urban schools.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 18 (AP)--A 50-year-old New Jersey woman died today in a fire in a two-family house. The victim was identified as Mrs. Alice Lee of Westfield. She was here to settle an estate, of which the house was part, the police said.

Dennis A. Meehan has been named assistant to Donald G. Aldridge, the American Export Isbrandtsen Lines vice president for freight traffic. For the last two years Mr. Meehan has been a vice president with West Coast Line. Earlier he was a port manager for Grace Line, Inc.
CAIRO, Feb. 18--The United Arab Republic's efforts to curb its precipitous population growth, one of the country's principal economic handicaps, have slackened since the June war with Israel.

New York City's financial status will get a much more thorough and searching examination than ever before as a result of the negotiations between Finance Administrator Roy M. Goodman and Standard Poor's.
MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., Feb. 18--Harry deLeyer, the owner, piloted the winners of both the open jumper and working hunter championships today at the Middle Island Horse Show.

The most important heritage of New York's garbage strike is the proof it has provided that embattled public opinion can be a controlling factor in the outcome of a strike in which the community is being used as a door mat.

RYE, N. Y., Feb. 18--Thornton Gerrish Jr. of Apawamis and Mrs. Graham Knox of the Field Club of Greenwich, Conn., seeded No. 1, defeated David Florence of Apawamis and Mrs. Peter Aldrich of Manursing Island Club, Rye, seeded second, 2-6, 10-8, 7-6, today in the final round of The Apawamis Club invitation mixed-doubles platform tennis tournament.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 18 (Agence France-Presse)--North Vietnamese antiaircraft gunners shot down a pilotless American plane today over Hanoi, the North Vietnamese press agency reported.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP)-The British Film Academy today nominated "Bonnie and Clyde" and its stars, Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway, for its 1967 awards.

ROME, Feb. 18 -- The police repulsed a march on the United States Embassy today by several hundred demonstrators who oppose the war in Vietnam. The demonstrators later smashed the office windows of an American airline office and of a shipping company office.
A new pressure group with two high city officials among its leaders made its public debut yesterday with a call on Congress to finance 600,000 housing units a year--six times the present pace.
Shamai Rosenblum, an Israeli actor-impressionist, will appear in a Yiddish show on March 3 at the Town Hall. The program will consist of folklore humor and sketches from plays.

LONGMIRE, Wash., Feb. 18 (AP)--A young Seattle woman died of shock and exposure today after she, her husband and a hiking companion were caught in a storm on Mount Rainier and huddled all night in a dug-in snow cave. Mrs. Edith Anderson, 22 years old, died at a ranger station near here. Her husband, Charles, 24, and their companion. David Mischke, 26, were reported in fair condition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The United States warned North Korea today against "deliberate aggravation of an already serious situation" by any move to punish the 82 surviving crewmen of the intelligence ship Pueblo.
PARIS, Feb. 18 -- A bomb exploded in the basement of the Yugoslav Embassy residence here tonight, killing one person and injuring 19.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (UPI)-Cook County Republicans announced today the candidacy of a South Side teacher believed to be the first Negro woman Congressional candidate in Illinois backed by either party.
The Blau Mortgage Company has elected Edward L. Blau president. He succeeds his father, Leslie L. Blau, who becomes chairman of the board of the New Jersey organization.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has circulated among advertising agencies a program schedule for the next season, containing the smallest number of changes by the network in some years.

The Allegheny Beverage Corporation announced over the weekend that it had extended its exchange offers for certain securities of Allegheny Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company and Consolidated Bottling Company to the close of business Feb. 29.
A long-missing letter to General George Washington that accompanied the evidence of Benedict Arnold's treason has been found in a cache of Revolutionary War letters.

Eight choreographers collaborated to produce seven dances yesterday in Choreoconcerts' third Sunday afternoon of dance at St. Luke's Chapel, 487 Hudson Street. Remy Charlip, the eighth one, transformed himself into a hesitant voiced musician with a sweetly horrid little song advocating elimination of the old, as accompanyment to Viola Farber's intense and lonely solo "Time Out."

SALISBURY, Conn., Feb. 18 --Scott Berry, a Class A jumper representing the Dartmouth Outing Club, overcame treacherous 30-mile-an-hour winds today to capture the 43d annual United States Eastern amateur ski-jumping championship on John Satre Memorial Hill.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, Feb. 18 -- Distance lends a certain magic to many things. Here among the flowering bougainvilleas and wavering palms that tired old war horse, the benefit ball, is kicking up its heels and acting like a frisky colt.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 18 (AP)--Dr. Norman M. Yoder, suspended State Commissioner for the Blind, will be removed from his $20,629-a-year post after he uses up 89 days of accumulated sick pay, a spokesman for Gov. Raymond P. Shafer says.

HOLLAND, Pa., Feb. 18 (UPI) --A sporting goods dealer pushed one of his five children through a window to safety today, then died with three other members of his family in a fire that leveled their $32,000 home.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18--The allied command was sharply divided today over the aims of the enemy's new rocket-and-mortar offensive, in which dozens of cities, towns and military outposts came under shellfire.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 17-North Vietnamese forces in Laos are poised to assault the provincial capital of Saravane. Their new aggressiveness is being linked here to Hanoi's plans against the United States Marine outpost at Khesanh, near the Laotian border.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 18--Cliff Richey attained another peak in his tennis career today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) --Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that instead of the eight days he intended to campaign in New Hampshire, he will spend 14 of the 15 days between next Friday and March 11 there.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 (UPI)--The Detroit Pistons, forced to play without Dave Bing, the National Basketball Association scoring leader, repulsed a third-period San Francisco rally today and snapped a five-game losing streak with a 123-104 victory over the Warriors.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 18 --The Olympic flame was snuffed out today in a spangled spectacle of booming cannons and parachuted roses, but the controversy over the outstanding performance of the Winter Games increased in intensity.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 (UPI)--James Woodburn, 27 years old, a striking pressman at The Los Angeles HeraldExaminer, was shot and wounded today by patrolmen investigating the burning of one of the newspaper's delivery trucks, the police reported.
THE DOUBLE HELIX: A Personal Account of the Discovery of the Structure of DNA. By James D. Watson. Illustrated, 235 pages. Atheneum. $5.95.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 -- Dave Maggard of Mount View, Calif., a shot-putter, and John Mason of Fort Hays State in Kansas and Martin McGrady of San Jose State, both runners, set records for Moscow's Palace of Sports today on the last day of an indoor international track meet.
AYER, Mass., Feb. 18 (AP)-A number of families were evacuated from their homes near where 32 cars of a Boston Maine freight train derailed today. No one was reported hurt in the derailment.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 18 -- Pierre Cardin is sorry about the sari, but he doesn't think it has much of a future.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 18--Black-haired Vladimir Beloussov won the 90-meter ski jump for the Soviet Union today in the final event of the 10th Winter Olympic Games. The 21-year-old locksmith roared down the chute, hung suspended briefly in space and landed with hands raised high over his head.
Stern Brothers, New York department store, will find itself in the unusual role this morning of being a supplier to the Smithsonian Institution.

The title of La Monte Young and Marian Zazeela's (she is Mrs. Young) sound-plus-light show, heard and seen at the Barbizon Plaza Theater last night is (hold your breath) -"Map of 49's Dream the Two Systems of Eleven Sets of Galactic Intervals Ornamental Lightyears Tracery (1966-present):"
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 18--Fair Lark, who has competed in at least four divisions, won the regular working hunter championship at the Secor Farms Horse Show today.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 18 (Agence France-Presse)-Two medical professors from Paris left here yesterday at the end of a weeklong visit during which they studied means of developing medical cooperation between France and North Vietnam.
A sedan skidded out of control last night and crashed into a Bronx storefront, killing two young sisters and a taxi company dispatcher.

Berislav Klobucar will conduct Wednesday's performance of Wagner's "Die Walkure" at the Metropolitan Opera. He will replace Herbert von Karajan, who was to arrive today. Mr. von Karajan is hospitalized in Munich with influenza.
SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 18--An 84-man highway patrol will be established this spring to police the Seoul-Pusan and Seoul-Inchon superhighways, the national police announced last week.
Eastern Airlines has opened a $1.5-million automated cargodistribution center in Atlanta.
GENEVA, Feb. 18--An international effort to restore order to world trade in poultry is to be undertaken by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade at the request of the United States.
The American Cyanamid Company is branching out into a new field--the sale of a computer system that will help other companies put their fleets of railroad cars to better use.
Furman University of Greenville, S. C., defeated Georgetown University of Washington on the National Broadcasting Company's "G.E. College Bowl" yesterday. The score was 225 to 190.
Channel 13 will present an hour-long special starring Peter Ustinov, "Ustinov on the Ustinovs," on Wednesday at 9 P.M. Mr. Usinov will offer a series of impersonations from his family tree.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- The American Bar Association will make a major study next year of a proposal to abolish damage suits in automobile accident cases in favor of an insurance plan that would compensate all auto accident victims, regardless of which driver was at fault.

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Feb. 19 (Reuters)--Jose Torres, the former world light-heavyweight champion, has accepted an offer to fight Bobby Dunlop, the British Empire and Australian champion, here on March 25, the manager of Sydney Stadium said today.

On Nov. 19, 1963, three days before his assassination, President Kennedy spoke of his intention of getting rid of Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson as his running mate in 1964 and the possibility of replacing him with Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina, according to Mrs. Evelyn Lincoln, who was Mr. Kennedy's secretary.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 18 (AP)--The Hyster Company, which manufactures equipment for the logging industry, has acquired the assets of the Lewis-Shepard Company of Watertown, Mass., it was announced during the weekend.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 (AP)--His leg shattered. Ngo Van Tranh crouched in the wreckage of a wooden hut on the edge of Saigon.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 18 (AP)-The Chicago Bulls plugged the St. Louis Hawks' defense with keen outside shooting today and posted a 113-107 victory.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 18 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy is expected to make his most intensive campaign and his strongest showing in the Wisconsin Democratic primary just six weeks away.

The pledge of the building trades unions to work with civil rights groups in all parts of the country to let in more Negroes represents the most far-reaching commitment these organizations of skilled construction craftsmen have made to eliminate racial bias.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--A majority sentiment has emerged within the Administration in favor of doing nothing at all in the field of tariff and trade legislation to improve the balance of payments, but there is an almost desperate hope that the European Common Market nations can make some kind of gesture to help head off measures by the United States.
The Propeller Club of the United States has invited the nation's high school students to enter a 1,000-word essay contest on the theme: "The American Merchant Marine-Key to Defense and Trade."

KEITH IRVINE represents the antithesis of the dictator-decorator. He has never sparked a decorating trend nor designed a light bulb. He denies allegiance to a single style of decorating and is embarrassed if a pattern of furnishing recurs so frequently in his schemes that it becomes labeled as his taste.
Directors of American Book-Stratford Press, an integrated book manufacturer, have elected Craig T. Senft as president and chief executive officer of the newly formed Education Systems Corporation.
The American Stock Exchange is toughening its policies for continued listing of companies and is adopting a set of revised guidelines to cover its 1,200 stocks.
The election of George J. Charmoy as a vice president has been announced by Continental Copper and Steel Industries, Inc.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, Feb. 19 -- Troops of Yemen and Southern Yemen joined to attack dissident forces in royalist-held territory near their common border, according to broadcasts by the official radio stations in Aden and Sana.

As fighting intensified in Vietnam, support increased for Richard M. Nixon and decreased for Governor Rockefeller in separate national tests against President Johnson, according to the latest Harris Survey.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 19 -- The board of trustees of South Carolina State College named as legal counsel to that troubled institution today a lawyer who is representing Cleveland L. Sellers Jr., black power advocate.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Idaho N., the 4-5 favorite took command at the three-quarter-mile pole tonight and breezed to a 2 1/4-length victory over Barkley Square in the featured $4,000 pace at Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Pentagon identified today the following servicemen killed in Vietnam:

The ways that the underworld's infiltrators move in on legitimate business were described yesterday to 175 industrial and commercial executives here at the first of a series of briefings to be given in cities across the nation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 19 -- The executive director of the National Education Association estimated today that there would be more than 250 teacher strikes next year, triple the number of stoppages since September.
UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 19 (UPI) -- A gasoline station operator routed a robber today by shooting a three-foot barbed shaft from his skin diver's spear gun into the man's side.

The Johnson Administration has put forward a reasonable proposal for compromising the stubborn basic issue in the seven-month-old copper strike. Neither the 26 striking unions nor the industry's Big Four companies will be wholly satisfied with the plan, but it offers the only real prospect for a settlement that will meet the needs of both sides and heal a bleeding wound in the national economy.

The people of New York State face the gradual dismantling of the Medicaid program which only two years ago was hailed as the means of bringing adequate health care to the poor of this state. Governor Rockefeller's budget calls for a reduction of Medicaid eligibility and services which may disqualify over 10 per cent of the presently eligible 5.7 million residents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- With the aid of a Harvard history professor, Senator J. W. Fulbright, a former university president, began a "seminar" course for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today on the "Nature of Revolution."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The head of the foreign aid program said today that it was just "rubbish" to suggest that his agency had tried to "pigeonhole" an investigative report on alleged misconduct that led to the resignations of four employes, including the assistant administrator.
American Airlines placed a $400-million order yesterday for 25 huge new DC-10 jetliners designed to serve the heavily traveled medium-distance routes in the nineteen-seventies.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19 -- The Arab guerrilla organization Al Fatah defied Jordan and announced today that it would not allow "anyone or any regime" to prevent it from undertaking operations against Israel.

The New York Athletic Club, whose indoor track meet at Madison Square Garden was boycotted by many Negro and some white athletes last Friday night, almost called a boycott of its own yesterday. Instead, it decided to send a "token entry" to the Amateur Athletic Union national indoor championships at Oakland, Calif., next Friday and Saturday nights.
One week old, but already sadder and wiser, the new Madison Square held its first wrestling show last night while executives and architects grappled with more serious undertakings.

The New Lafayette Theater, the first professional company in Harlem in almost 20 years, has recived a grant of $15,000 from the New York Foundation, one of the country's oldest charitable organizations.

MIAMI, Feb. 19 -- Iron Ruler of the October House Farm exhibited a tendency to relax after getting to the lead in a six-furlong sprint today. In so doing the son of Never Bend threw a scare into the many fans in the crowd of 21,082 at Hialeah who had bet him a 3-10 favorite against four others. Nevertheless, he managed to win.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Following are excerpts from a statement released later today by J. Edward Murray, editor of The Arizona Republic and chairman of the Freedom of Information Committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors:
DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 19 (Reuters) -- Syria announced today it would withdraw from the Mexico City Olympic Games next October because of the readmission of South Africa to the games.

Neither rain, nor nonoperative scoreboards nor a faulty public-address system has prevented the New York Knickerbockers from winning their first two National Basketball Association games at the New Madison Square Garden.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Svetlana Alliluyeva expressed skepticism today of a report that her brother, the eldest son of Stalin, virtually ordered German guards to execute him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Johnson Administration was reported today to have blocked Congressional testimony by Dr. James L. Goddard, Food and Drug Commissioner, because he is opposed to part of the President's proposed drive against the drug LSD.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- "The thermonuclear bomb was increasing the power of nuclear weapons by a factor of something like a thousand. Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., announced yesterday that it was making a tender offer to purchase for cash 100,000 shares of the common stock of the J. M. McDonald Company, which operates a chain of department stores in the Midwest.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Vice President Humphrey said here today that the recent attacks on major South Vietnamese cities had had a temporary psychological impact and had "stopped the pacification program, but that they had failed to achieve their objectives."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 -- A major voluntary agency supported here by the United States Government is cutting most of its field work and reducing the bulk of its staff because of "security conditions" in the countryside.

DIBAI, Persian Gulf, Feb. 19 (Reuters) -- Two Persian Gulf states, Dibai and Abu Dhabi, announced today that they would federate under one flag, sharing a joint foreign policy, defense and citizenship.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Treasury bill rate fell at today's auction from the levels of the preceding sale, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
A patrolman was found guilty at a departmental trial yesterday of accepting Christmas gratuities from an executive of Reichhold Chemicals, Inc.
Richard M. Nixon's income for the period from 1963 to 1966 was disclosed yesterday in an article by Fletcher Knebel in the current issue of Look magazine.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- A new note of sympathy is becoming evident in British feelings about the American position in Vietnam.

One of Broadway's oldest ticket brokers, the Broadway-Piccadilly Theater Ticket Service, 227 West 45th Street, went out of business on Saturday because it couldn't get enough tickets to make a profit. A sign on its door said: "Closed. For information call 246-0300."
The city has ordered the Human Resources Administration to put its employes under the Civil Service.

With quiet persistence, pork bellies have managed to set quite a record in commodity futures trading. In January the bellies, from which bacon is produced, became the nation's most actively traded commodity futures. That is quite an achievement for a relatively new contract, introduced in 1961 by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which had searched desperately for a contract to help keep it in business.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 19 -- Premier Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub won yesterday a nine-day respite in efforts to bring down his Government.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 19 -- About 40 per cent of Florida's 60,000 public school teachers did not show up for work today in a dispute over pay, closing many schools.

" THE TWO OF US," which opened last night at the Beekman Theater, is a lovely, sentimental reminiscence of childhood in wartime. The child is an 8-year-old Jewish boy in Paris in 1944; and one of the unstated themes of the movie is the degree to which even the most catastrophic political developments can leave personal lives, particularly the private lives of children, virtually untouched -- or touched in quite mysterious ways.
The Board of Education is planning to hire about 700 men to help protect teachers and pupils from intruders.

Robberies and assaults against cab drivers here have dropped 40 per cent since last August, when policemen began to moonlight as taxi drivers under a new state law permitting them to hold outside jobs.
The New York Mets will open their spring training camp in St. Petersburg, Fla., tomorrow with everyone on the roster, signed except Al Jackson.

Embittered by his differences with the Johnson Administration over Vietnam and other aspects of foreign policy, Senator J. William Fulbright has described as "most depressing and shocking" a report issued to Congress by the Inspector General of Foreign Assistance which listed examples of waste and inefficiency in the foreign-aid program.
The Board of Health ended yesterday a 12-day health emergency caused by the sanitation men's strike.

BILL PUTNAM, a stately, very commanding figure, looked at Emile Francis yesterday and said, definitely not tongue-in-cheek, "I wouldn't trade my goalies and defensemen -- my apologies, Emile -- for any others in the National Hockey League."

ATLANTA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Gov. John B. Connally Jr. of Texas said today that the position of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, on Vietnam had damaged the whole conduct of foreign affairs by the United States.
OTTAWA, Feb. 19 -- The minority Liberal Government suffered a defeat tonight in the House of Commons on a bill to increase income taxes.
A 31-year-old Brooklyn butcher surrendered to the police yesterday in the fatal shooting of a 14-year-old boy and the wounding of two others during an argument over a stickball game.

SALEM, Mass., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King captured the New England women's indoor tennis championship on her third attempt by defeating Mary Ann Eisel of St. Louis, 6-3, 6-4, at the North Shore Tennis and Squash Club tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 19 -- India told the Security Council today that she was ready to throw her full weight behind any resolution calling for sanctions against South Africa.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Unbeaten Gypsy Joe Harris easily outpointed Dick DiVeronica of Canastota, N. Y., in 10 rounds tonight for his 24th victory.
Kirk Kerkorian, chairman of the Trans Internatio0al Airlines Cqrporation, plans to sell 780,000 shares of Transamerica Corporation stock valued at $36,855,000, it was announced yesterday.

Phelps Barnum and Son, architectural concern, has reorganized under the name of William Milo Barnum Associates. The principal administrative officer of the new company will be William Milo Barnum. His father, Phelps Barnum, will continue as partner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Government sought today to refute charges that it had mishandled the return of three captured American airmen freed by North Vietnam and that it had thereby endangered prospects for further prisoner releases.
An appeal to other nations to join this country in attacking its balance-of-payments problem was made yesterday by William M. Roth, President Johnson's special representative for trade negotiations.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The London Metal Exchange opened a rival market in silver today, threatening the business of London's three traditional silver bullion dealers.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 19 (Reuters) -- The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, which began here Feb. 1, adjourned its final plenary session today after quarrels between Arabs and Israelis and over the participation of South Africa. The session will be adjourned until a date and time to be announced later, but conference business was expected to continue in committees.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller of New York removed himself today from Nebraska's Presidential preference primary ballot for May 14.

EXPERTS rarely appear in regular club duplicate games because they get little satisfaction out of defeating less experienced performers, but they will usually seize an opportunity to compete with their equals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Though it was largely lost in the flow of news, Robert S. McNamara chose the other day to assess the high and low points of his performance as Defense Secretary in revealing terms.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Although the New York Yankees announced the receipt of seven signed contracts today, two pitchers were on the verge of being officially classified as holdouts: Al Downing and Dooley Womack.
For a month the Senate has been engaged in a desultory debate on the civil rights bill. The daily round of speeches has had a make-believe quality because the underlying facts are clear to all.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Feb. 19 -- Allegations of attempts to open the Korea war anew were exchanged here today by the United States and North Korea at a heated meeting of the Military Armistice Commission.

GENEVA, Feb. 19 -- A three-man arbitration commission today awarded Pakistan about 300 square miles in the Rann of Cutch, a desolate uninhabited salt marsh, now administered by India, over which the two nations almost went to war in 1965.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 20 -- An enemy force of more than 300 seized a village within easy mortar range of Tansonnhut air base and Gen. William C. Westmoreland's headquarters yesterday and held it for eight hours before being driven back.
GREENSBORO, N.C., Feb. 19 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal court ruled today that North Carolina's Speaker Ban Law was unconstitutional because it was vague.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A team of Republican Governors will stage a flying, five-day tour across the nation early in May to hold hearings on their party's Presidential platform.

For anyone who views the drum solo as one of the more tiresome traditions of jazz, Elvin Jones can be an astounding experience. When Mr. Jones, a huge, muscular man, starts swarming over his drums, using both arms and both feet to create an astonishing variety of rhythmic rolls, rumbles and shotgun reports, he creates massive solos that have structure, continuity and a boiling sense of excitement.
The First National City Bank is negotiating to sell its controlling interest in the Carte Blanche credit card to the Avco Corporation, the two companies announced yesterday.
Light trading continued yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but prices edged ahead.

While the domestic steel industry believes it finally will be given the quota on imports it has been seeking, existing support for the measure in Congress would not be enough to win if a vote were called immediately, an industry spokesman indicated here yesterday.
A seat in the House of Representatives from Brooklyn and three seats in the Legislature -- two from Queens and one from Manhattan -- are at stake in special elections here today.
Enthusiasm for the dance avant-garde is no substitute for the real thing as the kaffee-klatch choreography of Merle Marsicano, Sally Gross and Eugene Lion proved last night at the Judson Church.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 19 -- Gov. George Romney, on his fourth brief campaign trip to Wisconsin where the Presidential primary will be held on April 2, continued his attack today on the Administration's handling of the Vietnam war.
Israel has initiated an international campaign to rehabilitate the ancient walls and other ruins of Jerusalem's Old City, ravaged by centuries of wars and neglect.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Jose Fiolo, Brazil's Pan-American Games champion, broke the world record for the 100-meter breast-stroke swim by three-tenths of a second tonight with a time of 1 minute 6.4 seconds.
Canada Dry yesterday proudly announced its latest entry into the $3.4-billion soft-drink market. It's called Sport-Cola and the company's big pitch will be that it's 99 per cent caffeine free.
The 24-year-old grandson of General of the Armies John J. Pershing was killed in action in Vietnam, his parents reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A sweeping bill designed to give new force to the nation's internal security laws was proposed today.

George Szell has conducted the Cleveland Orchestra for 22 seasons and has brought it to New York many times, yet he had not led the ensemble here in a work by Tchaikovsky until last night, when in Carnegie Hall he put the orchestra through the heady paces of the Fourth Symphony. MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- Nationalism in the Ukraine was condemned at a Communist conference last week by the chief of the party in that Soviet republic.

ONE of the by-products inspired by last year's Westminster Kennel Club Show was a Yorkshire terrier made of Dynel and introduced by Saks Fifth Avenue. The store reports that little old ladies loved it, teen-agers flipped over it and parents whose offspring's canine cravings gave them no peace bought it as a substitute for the real thing.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 19 -- The Indian Cabinet met tonight to decide how to deal with a storm of angry protests building up over the international tribunal's award of 10 per cent of the disputed territory in the Rann of Cutch to Pakistan.

AS a paean to pectoral development and the idea that there is no point in knocking sex, "Good Morning and Goodbye!," which was exposed at the 55th Street Playhouse yesterday, is probably as significant as any of the manufactured teases to hit 42d Street or Eighth Avenue in recent years.
Everything went as planned at Madison Square Garden last night. Exhibition wrestling, led by Bruno Sammartino, made its debut in the new arena before a crowd of 12,989.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The sad truth of Vietnam has seldom been clearer than it is in the decision by the American military command to "use all the firepower needed" to root Communist forces out of Hue and other Vietnamese cities.

Members of the International Longshoremen's Association's Local 1814 were told yesterday that they may call on the services of Myles J. Ambrose, a former executive director of the Waterfront Commission, in any personal legal battles with the bistate agency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- President Johnson will nominate Leonard Sutton of Denver, Colo., to be a member and chairman of the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission, the White House announced today.

Charges against 33 students of Brooklyn College accused of participating in a riotous anti-recruiting demonstration last Oct. 19 were dropped yesterday after the prosecution said that conviction might jeopardize their future.

RON SEQUOIO'S new ballet "Coruscare," given by Manhattan Festival Ballet at Theater 80 St. Marks Place last night, has style and spirit. It is Mr. Sequoio's best ballet to date, and should be a most useful acquisition to the company's permanent repertory.

The Times Square blockfront containing the Criterion, a first-run motion picture theater, and one of the world's largest men's wear stores, is being sold to a builder who plans eventually to add another skyscraper to changing Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The scientist whose supposed trip to South Vietnam set off rumors about the deployment of nuclear weapons never made it to South Vietnam, the Defense Department acknowledged tonight.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 19 (Agence France Presse) -- The top leadership of the political organization of the Vietcong called today for unity of the Vietnamese population to bring about "victory and reunification of the fatherland."

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Feb. 19 -- President Ayub Khan appeared in newspaper photographs yesterday for the first time in several weeks. The pictures on the front pages of Pakistan newspapers followed concern about his health.

THE recent retrenchment from the stock market by some wary mutual-fund managers is matched by growing piles of cash in many fund tills.

The conviction of the late Lenny Bruce for giving obscene monologues in a Greenwich Village coffeehouse was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Term of the State Supreme Court.

Fifty laymen, priests, nuns and brothers from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn have called upon church authorities to begin holding public hearings on important church decisions -- including the selection of bishops.

New York State sold $80-million of tax-exempt bonds yesterday at a cost well below a similar sale on Jan. 3, but investors were less eager to buy the newer, lower-yielding securities.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday asked Raymond May Associates, an urban-design firm, to move ahead swiftly with final development plans "to create a model community in the Annadale-Huguenot section of Staten Island."

The National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System have scheduled special programs on the report of President Johnson's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders. The programs will be offered Sunday, March 3, the day the report is scheduled to be issued.
