CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Chicago and North Western and the Chicago Great Western railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to adopt recommendations made by its examiner with respect to the Soo Line Railroad.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 19 -- Two medium-budget American movies dominated the nominations for the 1967 Academy Awards, announced here today. And Americans for the first time in several years all but shut out English competition for the Oscars.

The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in earnings for the 12 months ended Jan. 31 and for the month of January. Donald C. Cook, president, placed net income for the 12 months at the new high of $94,740,000, equal to $2.01 a share.
The reorganization of the city's Community Planning Boards has become the focal point of a dispute among Mayor Lindsay, the City Council and the Borough Presidents.
Prices edged lower yesterday on the London Stock Exchange under the pressure of steady selling.
About 1,000 guests are expected to fill the Grand Ballroom, Crystal and Baroque Rooms of the Plaza on Friday night for the 16th annual Piarist Ball.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 -The first game of the threeman playoff matches to break a sixth-place tie for the world chess championship challenger's competition ended in a draw last night between Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., a six-time United States champion, and Leonid Stein, threetime champion of the Soviet Union.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that he had not been consulted about the hiring of a campaign strategist, F. Clifton White, to make political soundings for California's Republican delegation.
THE German-made motion picture of the life of Hitler, produced by Paul Rotha and edited in Hamburg, was shown last night over National Educational Television (Channel 13.)

Rudolf Serkin and Beethoven, William Steinberg and the New York Philharmonic, these are no strangers to each other. And so Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto, which Mr. Serkin played and Mr. Steinberg conducted at the Philharmonic concert at Philharmonic Hall last night, was like a meeting of friendly forces.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 17 -- President Abdel Rahman Arif of Iraq said here today that his country was ready to re-establish diplomatic relations with Britain if the Labor Government in London proposed resumption. He also made it clear that he was not ready to resume diplomatic relations with the United States.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 -- George Meany said today that voluntary arbitration should be considered as an equitable means for resolving major labor disputes involving public employes.

ONE historical handicap of every set of Winter Olympic Games has been the unpredictable behavior of that slightly daffy tactical joker, Old Man Winter. He started playing pranks on the chilblain devotees at the first show in 1924 and would seem to have taken a ghoulish delight ever since in slipping his refrigerated whammy into the proceeding.
The stock market made a modest advance yesterday as volume slumped to its lowest level since Aug. 30.

The trustees of Brandeis University plan to offer the school's presidency to Morris B. Abram, president of the American Jewish Committee and senior adviser to the United States Mission at the United Nations.
NEWARK, Feb. 19 -- Seventeen persons were arrested today after a brief but violent encounter between pickets and policemen at the St. Michael Medical Center here.

PIRAEUS, Greece, Feb. 19 -- Ten Greeks -- shipowners, seamen and merchant navy officers -- appeared in court here today to face charges arising from the loss of 241 lives in the sinking of the Iraklion, an 8,922-ton car-ferry, in the Aegean on Dec. 8, 1966.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The United States and Brazil settled their differences over the troublesome instant-coffee market tonight, paving the way for the renewal of the International Coffee Agreement, which expires on Sept. 30.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- The American Bar Association approved today new rules of conduct for lawyers and new procedures for judges designed to restrict the release of crime news to the press.
In a realignment of executive and management functions at Carl A. Morse, Inc., building contractors and construction consultants, four officers have been elevated to new positions.
Federal agents thwarted early yesterday morning an alleged plot by two men, described as right-wing extremists, to blow up a Union Square bookstore that specializes in left-wing literature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- A South Korean diplomat took the witness stand at a mock trial of international Communism today and predicted that war would break out in Thailand if America concluded a cease-fire in Vietnam.

Roy M. Cohn, the Manhattan lawyer, became an additional defendant yesterday in the lawsuit of the Securities and Exchange Commission against Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and three other individual defendants.

Longshoremen looking for jobs along the waterfront yesterday were not required to get traditional "show-up" cards as proof to the New York State Division of Employment that they had tried to find work.
Alfred E. Buehler, the Liechtenstein lawyer sought for questioning in a Federal tax inquiry failed to appear here yesterday to testify and automatically incurred a $5,000 fine for contempt of court.

David Dubinsky has said he will remain a member of Americans for Democratic Action despite his disagreement with the organization's endorsement of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for President because he wants to continue to have a voice in the organization's policies.

While we have reservations concerning some aspects of the regulations governing graduate student deferments announced on Feb. 16, we believe it important to recognize that these regulations did incorporate several major recommendations of the academic community.

OSSINING, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- The Hudson River Expressway proposal was defended by state officials and assailed by some residents and conservationists here tonight at the first public hearing on the controversial project.
Retired members of the National Maritime Union who are now required to pay a pension service fee to the union received at least a partial reprieve yesterday.
HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 -- United States marines were stalled today in their efforts to complete the liberation of Hue, South Vietnam's second most important city.

In an unusual move, the New York Stock Exchange has put members of its staff to work in the offices of Pickard Co., Inc., a member corporation of the exchange, to help clear up a pile of paperwork that has impeded operations of the small brokerage house.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- President Johnson, back from a highly secret major domestic trip, said today that much of his traveling in this election year would likely be done without much advance notice.
RUTHERFORD, N. J., Feb. 19 -- United States Representative Henry Helstoski was arrested here last night, charged with punching his second wife, Victoria, in the eye and knocking her down.

DENNIS ENGEL of Syracuse has been making a habit of being a two-time winner. The senior from Buffalo is a gymnast and diver for the Orange swim team. However, his specialty is gymnastics. He has recorded seven first-place finishes and one third in floor exercises in gymnas tic meets this season.

DENNIS ENGEL of Syracuse has been making a habit of being a two-time winner. The senior from Buffalo is a gymnast and diver for the Orange swim team. However, his specialty is gymnastics. He has recorded seven first-place finishes and one third in floor exercises in gymnas tic meets this season.
IF Peter Max has anything to say about it, the furnishings industry will be a Peter Max world by the end of this year.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Sixty-two deformed "thalidomide babies" will receive "very substantial damages" under an agreement announced today with the company that made and sold the drug in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- With the radical change in draft policy decreed last week by President Johnson, the United States will soon have an army composed of college men. The prospect must make the generals as well as the drill sergeants wake trembling in the night.

The Getty Oil Company, in its 1967 report issued yesterday from Los Angeles, showed estimated consolidated earnings from operations of $114,989,000, equal to $5.56 a share. This was up 17 per cent more than the 1966 of $98,038,000, or $4.42 a share.

WARSAW, Feb. 19 (UPI) -- Janusz Szpotanski, 35 years old, was sentenced to three years in prison today for writing a satiric operetta that a court ruled could damage "the prestige of state authorities" in Poland.
A spirit of restlessness and turmoil is sweeping through the convents of the United States as nuns debate and design the most radical changes in their history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Johnson and Manlio Brosio, secretary general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, agreed today to revive proposals for an East-West agreement on mutual reduction of forces in central Europe.
Two employes are retained by the Lerner Stores Corporation to do nothing but travel to the concern's retail outlets to adjust wigs on the mannequins.

OTTAWA, Feb. 20--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson will ask the House of Commons tomorrow for a vote of confidence to keep his Liberal party Government in power after a narrow defeat last night on a crucial tax-increase bill. The Prime Minister, who plans to retire in any event in April, said tonight that the 84-to-82 vote against his Government was a "hazard" of governing as the Liberals do, with a minority. The Liberals have 130
NEXT Tuesday evening, Frances Fitz Gerald will speak at the New School in a forum entitled "The Writer in an Age of Violence." The 27-year-old free-lance writer is finishing a book on Vietnam.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 20 (AP)-Nguyen Tho Chanh, North Vietnam's ambassador to the Soviet Union, arrived here today for talks with Foreign Minister Torsten Nilsson and other officials. The Vietnamese said he intended to present Hanoi's views on the war.
Prices moved down again yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- James H. Rowe Jr., a Washington lawyer, who has been a friend of several Presidents, will serve as the chief political adviser to President Johnson in this year's election campaign, according to Democratic party leaders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --The Johnson Administration reluctantly agreed today to let Dr. James L. Goddard, Food and Drug Administrator, testify before Congress on penalties for possession of LSD, an issue on which he and the President differ.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --President Johnson asked Congress today for $5.7-million to hire more F.B.I. agents, Federal prosecutors and investigators of illicit traffic in narcotics.

Fireman Francis Griffin rescued 4-year-old Anesto Colon and Caridad Tores, 3, from a smoky fire in a six-story tenement at 754 East 151st Street, the Bronx, at 10:15 A.M. yesterday. The children had been left by their parents with a neighbor on the fourth floor. The children, who wandered away, were found hiding uninjured in the bedroom of a fifth-floor apartment.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (Reuters)--Pilots of British United Airways agreed tonight to halt a strike that started Saturday and had threatened to close Britain's largest private airline. The airline agreed to restore recognition of the pilots, union, withdrawn in a dispute over wages.
Special to The New York Times SCHENECTADY, Feb. 20 -The mayors of 12 upstate cities met here today with Mayor Lindsay and went away endorsing his new plan for sharing state aid.

ORANGEBURG, S. C., Feb. 20 (AP)--Gov. Robert McNair announced plans today to resume classes Monday at South Carolina State College, closed Feb. 9 when three Negro students were shot to death in a clash with officers.
Recovering from lengthy strikes during midyear, the B. F. Goodrich Company posted modest gains in sales and earnings in the fourth quarter last year, Ward Keener, chairman, reported yesterday.
Special to The New York Times ATHENS, Feb. 20 -- Nineteen persons were killed and 18 injured when a powerful earthquake ripped across the Aegean Sea early today.

WHEN Alexander (The Great) Wojciechowicz matriculated at Fordham in the Seven Blocks of Granite era, he was sorely tempted to truncate his surname to the more pronounceable and spellable nickname of Wojie. He sought the counsel of his wise coach, Sleepy Jim Crowley.

Special to The New York Times BOSTON, Feb. 20--James E. Dowd, administrator of the Boston office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that an investigation of possible manipulation of Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway stock last August extended to two other companies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 (AP)--The number of reporters covering the Vietnam war has reached a high of 600, representing newspapers, radio stations and television networks from around the world. The number of newsmen averaged 300 to 400 last year and at the start of the current year it increased to 500.
Volume and prices expanded a bit yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

The number of business failures in the country fell to 220 in the week ended Feb. 15 from 286 in the corresponding 1967 week, but rose from 206 in the previous 1968 week. Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
Austin T. Cushman, retired chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., has been elected a director of the Bekins Van Storage Company.
It is no longer against the law in New York State to conspire to obstruct justice by influencing a judge or a prosecutor.

Special to The New York Times LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20-Merger plans of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Signal Oil and Gas Company were terminated today by their respective boards of directors.

NEW YORK is always a mite more lively a town when the City Center Joffrey Ballet is in residence, and it was a pleasure last night to welcome it back to the City Center for a month's season. Appropriately the season is dedicated to the late Morton Baum, who not only established the company in its present home but even gave it its present name.
Special to The New York Times KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 20 --A report of 500 smallpox deaths in Karachi in four months was "highly exaggerated," a Karachi municipal spokesman said today.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 20 (AP)--A power failure left most of the city's downtown district in blackness for more than eight hours ttoday. Officials of the New Bedford Gas and Edison Light Company attributed the breakdown to insulator failure at its local generating plant.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20 (UPI) --A suspect was arrested today, several hours after two downtown banks had been robbed of about $5,000. The Federal Bureau of Investigation identified him as Kenneth Hetrick, 28 years old, who was seized at his home in nearby North Braddock.
Philadelphia--Gypsy Joe Harris, 155 pounds, Philadelphia, outpointed Dick Diveronica, 153 1/2 pounds, Canastota, N. Y., I0 rounds.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews presented national awards for "courageous leadership in intercreedal relations" last night to four clergymen in the New York area at the organization's 40th anniversary dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia in a decision of far-reaching significance has ordered a halt to all planning and construction of $182-million worth of bridge and highway construction in the nation's capital.

IT is always the second time around that is more revealing than the first. The Negro Ensemble Company, now resident at the St. Marks Playhouse, had a great success with its first production, Peter Weiss's "The Song of the Lusitanian Bogey." But that sprawling chronicle play with its staging was not a complete test of the new troupe's capabilities.

Special to The New York Times LONDON, Feb. 20--Wood furniture and wood veneers will be used in the new liner Queen Elizabeth II to avoid what the owners, the Cunard Steam-Ship Company, see as "a hard metallic" look in other postwar passenger ships.

Special to The New York Times RICE LAKE, Wis., Feb. 20 -- Gov. George Romney called today for a revision of the draft laws to provide greater uniformity in the ages of those drafted and in the standards used for granting deferments.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 20 (AP) --Three Scandinavian leaders criticized today the International Olympic Committee's decision on South Africa.

Special to The New York Times HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 --Military and civilian activities have often been found surprisingly close together during the three weeks of conflict in this former capital of the Annamite Empire.

Special to The New York Times LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20--The second game of the three-man playoff to break the sixth-place tie for the world chess championship challenger's competition between Grandmaster Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia and Leonid Stein, the current and three-time Soviet champion, was adjourned for a second time last night after some seven and one-half hour's play. At adjournment, Hort was a pawn plus, but with scant winning chances.

One of the first recommendations of the Litton International Corporation to the Greek Government for the economic development of the island of Crete was to abandon five large and costly proposed dams and to substitute a ground water-storage system.
Army turned down a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament yesterday and shortly afterward accepted one to the 31st annual National Invitation Tournament.

Paul Brown is back in professional football. Now 59 years old, the former coach of the Cleveland Browns has made himself vice president, general manager and coach of the Cincinnati Bengals, the newest team that will play in the American Lague next season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)--The Defense Department reported today that 19 servicemen previously listed as missing in action in Vietnam were now listed as dead.
Victor G. Bloede, newly elected president of Benton Bowles, announced yesterday the election of John S. Bowen, 41 years old, to executive vice president and director of account management.

Special to The New York Times HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 20-Former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama suddenly canceled tonight a scheduled campaign trip to Philadelphia at the request of Philadelphia's Police Commissioner, Frank Rizzo, who said that he feared "difficulties."

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a membership for $475,000, or $5,000 higher than the price of a transfer on Monday. This represents the highest price since May 8, 1930, when a seat sold for $479,000. Following the latest sale. Big Board seats were quoted at $440,000 bid and $500,000 asked.
A State Supreme Court justice yesterday reserved decision on a move to force the Westinghouse Air Brake Company of Pittsburgh to turn over a list of stockholders to a company seeking a merger.

GENEVA, Feb. 20 (Reuters) Authoritative Swiss newspapers reported today that France warned the United States before Jan. 29 that the Vietcong were preparing a move to strengthen their negotiating position.
About 1,000 homes in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn were without power for an hour and a half last night when an underground cable in Consolidated Edison's substation on Fifth Avenue failed.

It was good political fun for opposition forces to seize an unexpected opportunity to defeat the Canadian Government in the House of Commons, but it would be irresponsible to carry the joke any further. A serious attempt to bring down Prime Minister Pearson at this time could plunge the country into political chaos and imperil a Canadian dollar just beginning to recover from sustained heavy pressures.

The Book-of-The-Month Club, Inc., in cooperation with Recording for the Blind, Inc., has set up a new monthly service to provide books on long-playing records for blind, partly blind and other handicapped persons. The service, called the Recorded Book Society, will operate much on the order of a book club, with members being offered a single new selection plus a number of "alternates" each month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The poultry industry generally endorsed today the extension of Federal inspection standards to all poultry products. Small operators appealed, however, for continued exemption from inspection.
New state regulations that provide for notice and a hearing for any relief recipient before his welfare grant may be cut off were called inadequate in Federal Court here yesterday.
The New York Board of Trade announced here yesterday the election of Holmes Brown as president. He was formerly a vice president of American Airlines, Inc.

Special to The New York Times GENEVA, Feb. 20--Italy offered today an amendment to the proposed treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons that would make it clear that any nation could obtain nuclear materials for peaceful purposes.

Special to The New York Times CHICAGO, Feb. 20--Daniel Escobedo, whose conviction for murder was reversed in 1964 by the United States Supreme Court, was sentenced today to consecutive prison terms of 15 and seven years for narcotics law violations.

A quarterly magazine discussing American involvement in Vietnam made its initial appearance yesterday at Yeshiva College. The magazine, Dissent, is published by an official student club formed last year of students opposed to the war in Vietnam. Bruce Horiwitz, editor, said that articles of professors and students would be printed "to give students a chance to re-evaluate their own consciences."

HONG KONG, Feb. 20 (Reuters) --North Vietnam accused Premier Souvanna Phouma of Laos today of making false allegations to justify the dispatch of United States and right-wing Laotian troops to Communistheld areas in Laos.

Special to The New York Times NEW DELHI, Feb. 20 -The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ended a year of political turbulence in West Bengal today by dissolving the state's assembly and assuming responsibility for its administration.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday asked the Transit Authority to hold public hearings in Brooklyn and Queens on the "high rate" of complaints of poor subway service since the November route changes. The authority, which had no comment on the request, recently hired a consulting concern to analyze the complaints and make recommendations.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a portion of President Johnson's tax program. At the same time it announced that it had not necessarily closed the door to consideration of the major element in the program--the 10 per cent tax surcharge on individuals and corporations.

Tom Lockhart, the 75-yearold president of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States, received the Lester Patrick Memorial Tropny last night at the annual dinner at Toots Shor's given by the Rangers and National Hockey League.

Jonathan Logan, Inc., a leading women's apparel manufacturer, yesterday announced record results for the fiscal year ended Dec. 31, 1967, with an 8 per cent gain in sales and a 10 per cent gain in net income.

The election of M. B. Thompson, 58 years old, as president of Geo. A. Hormel Co., Austin, Minn., was announced yesterday. He replaces R. F. Gray, 62, who resigned the post of president but continues as chairman.

Special to The New York Times TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 20 --Hundreds of Florida students refused to be taught by substitute teachers today as school officials tried to break a teachers' walkout by hiring volunteer teachers to go into the classrooms.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP) -The press agency Tass said today that Soviet diplomats in Peking had been refused permission to lay wreaths on the graves of Soviet soldiers in four Manchurian cities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --The American Automobile Association today pinned an "antisafety" label on legislation to permit heavier and wider trucks and buses on the interstate highway system.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, Feb. 20--Governor Rockefeller announced today that large numbers of state troopers would move into metropolitan areas, especially New York City, in a major drive against illegal narcotics traffic.
Bertram L. Podell is an organization man, and the organization that has held his allegiance for nearly two decades is Stanley Steingut's Brooklyn Democratic machine.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 [AP] --Following the roll-call vote by which the Senate refused today to invoke closure on the civil rights bill, a step requiring a two-thirds majority:
THE BLACKFRIARS GUILD bills itself as "New York's oldest Off Broadway theater." It might be more accurately described as New York's-and probably the nation's-oldest Little Theater.

Consolidated net income of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financing arm of the giant auto maker, rose to $51,638,540 last year from $45,478,534 in 1966, the company reported yesterday. The figures included net earnings of Motors Insurance Corporation, a G.M.A.C. subsidiary, which were $1,557,527 in 1967, and $8,969,766 the year before.

SAIGON, Feb. 20 (Agence France-Presse)--Premier Ngu yen Van Loc said today that the second phase of the Vietcong's general offensive would be more powerful than the series of raids staged Sunday morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara asked Congress today for $2.88-billion in order to pay for new military construction around the world, including United States antimissile facilities.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -Farm spokesmen and Vice President Humphrey urged the American housewife today to accept a significant increase in the cost of filling her market basket or learn to do without much of the quality food to which she has become accustomed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --The first of the 1968 money bills, a $1.2-billion supplemental measure, was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate. It was debated less than an hour and passed by voice vote. The total included $1.134-billion for public assistance grants to states, $50.9-million for payment of claims and judgments against the Government, and $28.8-million for unemployment compensation payments to Federal employes and ex-servicemen.
ALBANY, Feb. 20 (AP) -Additional judges will not improve the image of the Family Court, a legislative committee said today. It urged more and better paid probation workers.

Special to The New York Times LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20--A superb exhibition of painting by the late Chaim Soutine (1893-1943) opened today at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Organized by the museum's curator of modern art, Maurice Tuchman, the exhibition consists of 90 paintings, making it the largest show of Soutine's work ever mounted in this country.

CAPETOWN, Feb. 20 (Reuters) -- Defense Minister Pieter W. Botha today warned Britain she could no longer depend on the use of South African air and naval bases for long-range defense, except when it suited South Africa.
The Tishman Realty Construction Company, Inc., has taken control of the last piece of property standing between it and the office building it wants to put up on Third Avenue.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 20 (UPI) --Mr. Wallace in effect bowed out of the Nebraska Democratic primary today by announcing that he would organize a third party for the balloting May 14.
United States Lines yesterday announced the appointment of Robert B. Murphy as assistant European general manager.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) --Representative L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, declared today that it was time the United States called up more reserves, turned the war over to its generals and admirals and went all out for a military victory in Vietnam.
There are two Irwin Coreys, at least two for research purposes: the on-stage senior madman of ego-shattering comics and the off-stage well-read sometimes despairing man of strong opinions.
In the kitchens of three of the city's most elegant French restaurants, a man with a badge has appeared in recent weeks and confiscated some oysters.

Special to The New York Times BAL HARBOUR Fla., Feb. 20--The Johnson Administration's plan for breaking the impasse in the seven-monthlong copper strike was flatly rejected today by the striking unions

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --The United States Court of Appeals rejected today a request by attorneys for Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for "equal time" on three television networks to reply to statements by President Johnson last year.

A chronic shortage of longshoremen on the Newark and Elizabeth waterfronts is causing a diversion of traffic from New York Harbor, Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, said yesterday.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange declined by 662,713 shares in the month ended Feb. 15 from the total reported a month ago, the exchange announced yesterday.
Mark Cross, Ltd., the New York leather goods specialty store, announced yesterday that it would give a 20 per cent reduction on all purchases by Europeans for delivery to foreign destinations.
Special to The New York Times ROME, Feb. 20 -- Italian bishops today heard a protest against what was called a "continuous process of de-Christianization" of the laity.
One year ago, college students questioned Jimmy Caras's credentials as a fourtime world pocket billiards champion. Yesterday, Caras was named billiards man of the year for his fifth world title.
Special to The New York Times NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20-Nineteen men were indicted today in the theft and blackmarket sale of $500,000 worth of cosmetics from the Clairol plant in Stamford.

The hardships inflicted on New York City by the garbage strike have now brought two significant developments toward improved community protection against further disruptions of essential public services.
If there is a mainstream of American music, the works by William Mayer that were played last night at the Guggenheim Museum probably can be located in a bright little stream running modestly nearby.
The annual dinner dance for the benefit of Childville will be held on March 2 in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom.

School Superintendent Bernard E. Donovan decided yesterday to allow a memorial program at Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem this morning in honor of Malcolm X, the black nationalist who was slain three years ago today.
The Iowa Electric Light and Power Company announced yesterday plans for the state's first nuclear power plant, about eight miles northwest of Cedar Rapids in Linn County.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.0 on Monday from a revised level of 96.5 on Friday.

Special to The New York Times ADEN, Feb. 20 -- Chinese Communist experts are surveying land in Bagel, 100 miles southwest of Sana, for construction of another textile factory in Yemen, the Sana radio said today.

The election of Robert T. Scott as vice president for tax and legal activities was announced here yesterday by the Foreign Trade Council. Mr. Scott was formerly director of the tax and legal division.

Special to The New York Times LONDON, Feb. 20--A British company distributing the wines of Communist China is getting much to think about these days --the thoughts of Chairman Mao-Tse-tung appear at the top of every business letter.

Special to The New York Times CHICAGO, Feb. 20--The American Bar Association authorized today creation of the nation's first experiment in prepaid legal insurance patterned after the Blue Cross and Blue Shield medical plans.
MIAMI, Feb. 20 (AP)--Donald W. Doran, a charter pilot who was forced to fly a passenger to Cuba at gunpoint Saturday, landed here today but would say little about his adventure.
Twelve persons were arrested yesterday after they tried to block construction workers clearing a two-acre site in Morningside Park for a new Columbia University gymnasium.

HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 20--The South Vietnamese military leader of war-devastated Hue today ordered that looters be shot on sight and announced that there would be public executions within two days of some Communist agents arrested recently.

Special to The New York Times SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 21 -- Enemy forces tried to slip several antiaircraft guns into the outskirts of Saigon but were foiled by alert air observers, the South Vietnamese military command announced yesterday.
The United Aircraft Corporation attained the highest sales and earnings in its history in 1967.

Is the title of the new Tennessee Williams play, now in preparation for a March 20 opening at the Barrymore Theater, "Kingdom of Earth," favored by the playwright, or "The Seven Descents of Myrtle," as announced by David Merrick, the producer, and favored by Warner Brothers-Seven Arts?
Bache Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of Edward I. O'Brien as a first vice president.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 20 (AP)--Additional police units were ordered into a racially mixed area in east Chattanooga today as a preventative measure after the shooting of a white teen-ager by a Negro youth behind a Salvation Army recreation center.
A Bellevue psychiatrist who was stabbed by a patient outside the psychiatric unit's unguarded admitting office on Dec. 27 began a $1-million lawsuit against the city yesterday.

Special to The New York Times ABOARD U. S. S. RANGER, in the Sea of Japan, Feb. 20-As this great gray carrier churned through white-flecked seas after refueling from a tanker this morning, the "William Tell" Overture crackled through her loudspeakers.

Assemblyman Bertram L. Podell, a proclaimed "100 per cent" supporter of President Johnson, defeated Melvin Dubin, an avowed peace candidate, in the special election for Congress yesterday in Brooklyn's 13th District.

The men of Les Ballets Africains must be the only human beings who can throw themselves three feet into the air, prone, and live to tell the tale. The women possess a rocking, pulsating energy that makes tired blood set track records. The combination brought a half-frozen audience to an emotional boil last night at the Mark Hellinger Theater as the company opened its Broadway season.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -New orders for durable goods fell back in January after their sharp increase in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

Theodore Sambol has been named executive vice president and a director of Aileen, Inc., women's apparel manufacturer. Mr. Sambol has been with Aileen for nine years, serving most recently as manager of manufacturing operations in Virginia.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (UPI)-The Soviet Union launched two unmanned satellites today. Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said the two satellites. Cosmos 202 and Cosmos 203, were "functioning normally."

Special to The New York Times MIAMI, Feb. 20--Vitriolic, Ogden Phipps's 3-year-old who seems to have his age group opposition spreadeagled at this early stage of the season, will compete in the Everglades Stakes tomorrow. A strong field, including Elmendorf's Verbatim and the Carolawn Farm's Subpet will oppose Vitriolic in the mile-and-an-eighth race, the first stakes of the year at the extended distance for the class.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 20 --The National Council of Churches disclosed today plans for an "expose in depth" of the suppression of religious freedom in the Soviet Union.

Special to The New York Times CAIRO, Feb. 20--The commander of the Egyptian air force during the June war with Israel was pronounced guilty by a military tribunal today and sentenced to 15 years in prison on charges arising from the air force's poor performance and swift destruction by Israel.

Special to The New York Times QUINHON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20--A month ago the villages and hamlets near this coastal capital were considered relatively secure and were the focus of a massive American and South Vietnamese effort to "pacify" the vital province of Binhdinh.
AND now, a "dog department store."
Yuriko and her dance company will appear in a series of three Saturday night performances at the Kaufmann Concert Hall of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association on March 9, 16 and 23.

Special to The New York Times BRUSSELS, Feb. 20 -- The elder statesmen asked by King Baudoin to try to resolve the 13-day-old government crisis reported failure today. A new parliamentary election is expected as a result.

A musical version of "The Goldbergs," based on Gertrude Berg's long-running radio and television series, has been announced for Broadway production next season by David Black. The plot will cover one week in 1933 in the life of a Bronx family struggling to overcome the effects of the Depression.

Special to The New York Times WALLINGFORD, Conn., Feb. 20--John Alsop of Avon, whose brothers are Stewart and Joseph, the writers, was elected tonight as the new Republican national committeeman from Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) --Representative Thaddeus J. Dulski upstate Democrat has introduced a bill to make it a Federal offense to assault or murder postmen.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP)--Honeywell Controls, Ltd., the British subsidiary of Honeywell, Inc., Minneapolis. Minn., had a before-tax profit equal $8.16-million in 1967, up 127 per cent from 1966. Sales last year were a record $6.8-million, 35 per cent more than in 1966.
Prices of copper futures continued their reluctant course upward yesterday, pushed ahead not by any news developments in this market but by higher London prices.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The State Department said tonight that it had no verification for a press report that American military advisers in Hue had approved in any way of Vietnamese plans to hold a public execution of captured Vietcong.

ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 20 (Reuters)--Ghana announced today that she plans to send 16 Soviet-trained Ghanian doctors back to medical school for a year or more because they are unqualified, according to a government statement.

Special to The New York Times GENEVA, Feb. 20--Six Swiss experts in business administration, who were detained for questioning last week at Lubumbashi, capital of the Congo's Katanga Province, are now free to leave the country, a Swiss Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --Federal Power Commissioner Charles R. Ross said today he would probably resign toward the end of this year to return to Vermont "for family reasons." His four-year term, his second, is not due to end until June, 1969.

Special to The New York Times LONDON, Feb. 20--The British Broadcasting Corporation carried a report tonight that North Vietnam would order its troops in South Vietnam to cease fire in return for an end to American bombing and a beginning of negotiations.
A retrospective concert devoted to the music of Stefan Wolpe was given last night at the McMillin Theater at Columbia University.
The appointment of Gordon J. Crook as a vice president in the corporate planning and research group of the Chase Manhattan Bank was announced here yesterday.

Special to The New York Times ALBANY, Feb. 20--The Republican-controlled Senate disregarded the angrily shouted protests of Democrats today and approved a measure designed to cut back the state's Medicaid program by about $300-million a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, told the Senate today that Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman was organizing an 11-day trip to the Far East for members of Congress and others.

Other African governments will make a serious mistake if they boycott the summer Olympic Games in Mexico because South Africa is allowed to participate. Fourteen countries thus far have announced their intention to stay away.

Special to The New York Times NEW DELHI, Feb. 20--Confronted with bitter outcries over an international tribunal's verdict on the Rann of Cutch dispute, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi postponed today any reaffirmation of India's commitment to abide by the decision.

The first benefit for the Culinary Institute of America, to be held on Monday at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof, will be a gastronomic tribute to Joseph Castaybert, who retired last July as the hotel's executive chef.
"It's nice to play in this big room. It's so warm here." 10-year-old Roslyn Felder said yesterday.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Dr. Jude P. Dougherty has been named dean of the School of Philosophy of the Catholic University of America. He is the first layman to hold the post. Dr. Dougherty joined the faculty in 1966.
MOGADISCIO, Somalia, Feb. 20 AP)--The Government today announced the appointment of Yousuf Omar Azhari as the new Ambassador to the United States.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Following are excerpts from a statement on the Gulf of Tonkin incidents presented today by Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara at a closed session of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and released later by the Pentagon:

Special to The New York Times KUWAIT, Feb. 18--Kuwait is a tiny sheikdom sitting on a huge puddle of oil. Not content with nature's gifts, it will soon be using some of the world's most advanced petroleum technology and techniques.

Special to The New York Times WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 20--A dozen teams will take part in the Eastern Schools for the Deaf basketball tournament that begins Thursday. The three-day tourney, for which the New York School for the Deaf here is the host, will be played at the Woodlands High School on Hartsdale Road in Hartsdale.

Special to The New York Times CLEVELAND, Feb. 20--Richard R. Green, 38 yeras old, of Cambridge, Mass., was named today director of Cleveland's Department of Community Development, which has responsibility for the urban renewal program here.

Sales and earnings of Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., in 1967 reached record levels for the twelfth consecutive year, the company reported yesterday. The international manufacturer of cosmetics, toiletries and hospital products said that earnings totaled $14,783,000, equal to $1.42 a share. In 1966, earnings were $12,551,000 and $1.21.
HONOLULU, Feb. 20 (AP)-Stanford University surgeons report they have successfully replaced defective human aortic heart valves with transplants in 35 of 40 patients.

Special to The New York Times DETROIT, Feb. 20--An automobile head lamp that promises to reduce sharply the hazard of "one-eyed" cars on the highway was disclosed here today by Wagner Electric Corporation. Wagner said it would begin selling the new headlights in the replacement market next month.

DETROIT, Feb. 20 (AP)-Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was recalling 91 Dodge trucks in an effort to locate one that might have a steering gear shaft that does not meet the company's specifications.
FLINT, Mich., Feb. 20 (AP)--An open-housing ordinance, backed by the Negro Mayor of this Michigan automotive center of 200,000, was narrowly rejected today in a referendum.

Special to The New York Times UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 20--The Commission on the Status of Women, which ended its 21st session here yesterday, has appointed a special investigator to study birth control programs throughout the world.

Special to The New York Times SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 -Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky submitted his resignation quietly today as chairman of the powerful Emergency Recovery Committee, usually reliable sources said.

"HE talks the language of teachers. They can hear their feelings vibrate when he speaks," a close associate of Dr. Henry Philip Constans Jr., the leader of the Florida teachers' walkout, said yesterday.

Francis S. Fox was named president yesterday of the Raytheon Education Company, a subsidiary of the Raytheon Company. Mr. Fox was formerly president of the Silver Burdett Company, a division of the General Learning Corporation.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The State Department declined to comment on Olivier Todd's report. Privately Administration sources said they had heard nothing about the reported North Vietnamese proposal.
The tug-of-war in the topquality utility bond market grew more taut yesterday.

Special to The New York Times JERUSALEM, Feb. 20--Mrs. Charlotte Jacobson of New York, the president of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization, was injured last night when a truck struck a bus in which she was riding near Herzliya, north of Tel Aviv.

Special to The New York Times PARIS, Feb. 20--The 110year-old London couture house of Worth has been sold to a British furrier and property holder, Sidney Massin, who has hired a team of six designers to create new clothes.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 20-Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that "by any measuring stick, rural youths are not getting the education they need and deserve."

Despite record sales of $1.1-billion last year by Celanese Corporation, net income fell 11 per cent to $59.3-million, or $4.12 a common share, from $66.7-million, or $4.67 a share, in 1966, the report disclosed yesterday. Sales rose 9 per cent from the 1966 volume of $1.-billion.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara disclosed today that the Administration had "highly classified and unimpeachable" intelligence information establishing that two American destroyers had come under North Vietnamese attack in the Gulf of Tonkin in August, 1964.
The Andrew Jergens Company, a producer of soap, toiletries and cosmetics, announced yesterday in Cincinnati the election of John F. Walrath to the new post of financial vice president and treasurer.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--The leaders of the Legislature have agreed to support a compromise that would go a long way toward restoring the right of policemen to shoot any fleeing felon, even if the felon does not use or threaten force.
The Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League title may be decided Saturday at Princeton, N. J., in the meet between Yale and Princeton. Each is unbeaten in six meets.

Special to The New York Times PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 20-Richard M. Nixon has widened his already commanding lead over seven other leading G.O.P. contenders as the top choice of Republican voters for the 1968 Presidential nomination.
The Haryou-Act antipoverty program defended its efforts yesterday after charges by one of its three original key planners that it had achieved no impact in Central Harlem.

The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company announced yesterday a reorganization that will include a two-for-one common stock split. Milton E. Harrington, president, said the split would be part of a proposed merger into a wholly owned Delaware subsidiary. Shareholders will vote on the plan at the annual meeting April 30, he added.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., had a net income in 1967 of $141,752,000, the second highest total in its history. The figure exceeded the $118,170,000 earned in 1966, Henry S. Wingate, chairman and chief executive officer reported from Toronto yesterday.

Special to The New York Times GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 20 --Fairleigh Dickinson University reached the .500 mark (9-9) for the first time since the opening game of the season tonight by scoring a 73-55 victory over Adelphi University in a non-league game.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --Richard M. Nixon's Presidential campaign was turned full force on the women's vote today.
H. Rap Brown, the militant black power leader, was arrested here yesterday on charges of violating the conditions of his bail in New Orleans by making a trip to California last weekend.
A complex of about 20 office buildings above a West Side transit line will be a necessary addition to the Manhattan of the year 2000, according to the Regional Plan Association.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 20--As Al Downing and Dooley Womack, who loom large in his plans, remained unsatisfied with the terms offered them. Manager Ralph Houk sent his New York Yankees through their first workout today and then settled back and discussed his prospects.
Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Administration has decided to slow further its program to develop a supersonic airliner.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Feb. 20 (AP)--Clever Union rallied today to win by a length over the even-money favorite, Hello Daddy, in the feature race at Narragansett Park. Clever Union raced the 5 1/2 furlongs in 1:07 2-5, paying $14.20, $5.20 and $3.80 for $2 across the board.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation announced yesterday sales of $174,185,000 and earnings of $8,224,000, equal to 81 cents a share, for the third fiscal quarter, the period ended Jan. 31. The figures compare with sales of $174,336,000 and earnings of $10,743,000, or $1.06 a share, for the quarter a year earlier.

The National Broadcasting Company's fall program schedule, now making the rounds of the advertising agencies, includes six new programs as replacements for the seven being canceled. Sponsor suggestions in the next few weeks could produce some changes in days and times.
Two Westchester men were accused yesterday of illegally paying off investors in 18 slum apartment buildings in the Bronx with restricted funds, including tenants' rent-security deposits.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it had awarded grants totaling more than $3-million to help strengthen predominantly Negro colleges.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The boycott of the Summer Olympics starting Oct. 12 in Mexico City picked up momentum today, as Kenya, Sudan and Iraq announced their withdrawal in protest of the International Olympic Committee's decision to re-admit South Africa.
Special to The New York Times BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 18 -- Many people in Baghdad criticize and many deplore the regime of President Abdel Rahman Arif, but few foresee any early change.

"Final Solutions," a musical drama about oppression of Jews in the Soviet Union, will be presented March 11 and 12 in the Felt Forum at the new Madison Square Garden by the American League for Soviet Jewry. The play, by Jan Hartman, runs an hour without intermission. The music is by Jacques Belasco. Gene Lasko is the director and Valerie Bettis, the choreographer. The producer is Zvi Kolitz, with Amnon Kabatchnik as associate.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Don't try to prod the Internal Revenue Service into speeding up your tax refund check. You'll only force some human being to pull your return out of the computer--delaying things even more.

Special to The New York Times NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20--St. John's outscored the defending champion, Manhattan, by 1 point today in the field events to take the lead in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP)--A North Korean diplomat said today of the Pueblo incident that spies "will have to be punished" under the laws of the country they spy against.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP) --Earl Monroe scored 35 points and Ray Scott pulled down 25 rebounds tonight to pace the Baltimore Bullets to a 127-115 victory over the St. Louis Hawks in a National Basketball Association game at the Spectrum.
Increased purses in overnight events stimulated the thoroughbred sport in the state in 1967, the New York Racing Commission said yesterday in its 73d annual report.

Billy Casper's victory in the Los Angeles open golf tournament and other fine performances during the month earned the golfer the January award yesterday in the S. Rae Hickok Pro Athlete of the Year poll. Casper, with 19 first-place votes and 104 points, beat another golfer, Johnny Pott. Pott, winner of the Bing Crosby tournament, got 15 first place votes and 67 points.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (UPI)--A British electronics group has bought an American aircraft accessories company in an unusual $8.88-million deal announced today.

Special to The New York Times CAMBRIDGE, Md., Feb. 20-A 33-year-old state hospital aide, found guilty of assaulting a Cambridge city policeman, was sentenced today to even years in prison for the offense.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP)--The United States said today it might ask for independent arbitration on its charge that Brazil was exporting cut-price instant coffee to the United States.

Since the role of Chrysothemis in Strauss's "Elektra" requires the soprano to outshout the orchestra, it is not a fair test for a newcomer. Ina Delcampo, a Viennese-trained artist, made her Metropolitan Opera debut in the part last night.

The magnificently joyful noise that free-form jazz musicians can produce in the full flush of their freedom burst forth from Stephen Reid and the Aquarian Jazz Ensemble on a couple of occasions last night at the Countee Cullen Branch Library, 104 West 136th Street.

"The Dream of Gerontius" may not be Edward Elgar's masterpiece, as it is sometimes called, but it is a major oratorio and a work deserving more performances in this country than it gets nowadays. Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society orchestra and chorus presented it at Philharmonic Hall last night, and all who heard it must surely be grateful for the experience.
James S. Schoff Jr. has been appointed a merchandise vice president for home furnishings at Bloomingdale's.
WHAT does it take for a resort fashion to cease being simply a shirt, dress or pair of pants and become a proper noun, taking the name of its creator?
BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP)-Bailey Howell hit steadily in a 25-point performance today as the Celtics romped to a 126110 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals.

THE most confusing area in card-play theory for the student is no doubt "restricted choice." For practical purposes the declarer can follow this rule: If the fall of an opposing honor card makes a finesse possible, take the finesse.
DORR-OLIVER, which offers the promise of fresh water at a price at a time of growing concern over pollution of the nation's rivers and streams, has drawn the interest of a take-over operator.
PARIS, Feb. 20 (UPI)--Brokers here voted today to close the Paris Stock Exchange until "further notice" because of a strike by clerks.

Special to The New York Times MOSCOW, Feb. 20--A band of legal "vigilantes" that terrorized a Ukrainian mining town was unmasked today by the national newspaper of the Komsomol, the Young Communist League.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) -- Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz told Congress today that in the nation's major cities Negro unemployment was four times as high as that of whites.
The stock market scored its second straight advance yesterday. Glamour issues were the biggest gainers.

A record $18,000 was paid last night for a 30-cent United States 1867 stamp, one of five known. It was sold at an auction conducted by Herman Herst Jr., of Shrub Oak, N. Y., at the Americana Hotel, 52nd Street and Seventh Avenue. Ezra Cole of Nyack, N. Y., bought the stamp, which was from the collection of G. M. deVerymont of Paris.

The New York Stock Exchange may resort to levying fines or other penalties against its member firms in an effort to reduce the backlog of paper work that has been clogging brokerage offices for months.
Special to The New York Times AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 20-Jim Smyth's 30-foot shot with one second left gave St. John's a 55-53 basketball victory over Massachusetts tonight.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 20 (Reuters)--Sources in the International Control Commission said today that the group was unable to investigate an alleged North Vietnamese threat to the southern Laotian provincial capital of Saravane because Poland had refused to take part.
Edward Bleier, vice president in charge of public relations and planning for the American Broadcasting Company Television Network, resigned yesterday.

The consolidated net earnings of ACF Industries, Inc., for the three months ended Jan. 31, totaled $5,449,000, equal to 96 cents a share, the diversified industrial concern reported yesterday. The earnings compared with $7,475,000 and $1.29 in the year-ago quarter.
Special to The New York Times WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 20--Stanley Dancer and his "great old horse" will be back in pursuit of $1-million tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.

The National Hockey League continued yesterday to give the sport a nation-wide image, as well as upgrade the expansion teams, by deciding to stage the annual all-star game as a contest between the established teams and the expansion clubs.

The case for basic scientific research has rarely been stated as persuasively as it is in the current Science by Nobel Laureate Charles H. Townes. Since budgetary pressures now strongly tempt the President and Congress to sacrifice such studies, Professor Townes's argument is timely.
Grim-looking off-duty detectives and policemen voluntarily helped search hospitals and investigate other possible leads yesterday in a vast manhunt for the killer of a 31-year-old patrolman.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)--The Internal Revenue Service said today a service charge paid to a union by a nonmember as a condition to hold his job can be deducted for income tax purposes.

SEATTLE, Feb. 20 (AP)-The Chief Justice of the Washington State Supreme Court predicted today that the bench, bar, press and law enforcement officers in Washington "will have no part of the Reardon program," which would limit what the public will be told about pending criminal trials and arrests.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) --John H. Noble, an American who was held in Soviet captivity for 10 years after World War II, charged at a mock trial of international Communism today that the Soviet Union was still holding a number of United States citizens in prisons and labor camps.

NICE, France, Feb. 20 (Reuters)--One member of a gang of young Yugoslav brothers was shot dead and two others were arrested today when the police raided their suburban home after they had robbed a bank in this resort. The dead man, identified as Misko Raguz, 26 years old, was said to have wounded a policeman.

Abraham Pokrassa has been appointed director of publicity and Thomas E. Rodgers has been named director of advertising for the Radio City Music Hall. They succeed the late Edward Serlin, who served as vice president in charge of advertising and public relations for the theater.
When Andy Williams brings his "Spring Special" to N.B.C. on April 28 he's going to bring along with it two advertisers who are going the network television route for the first time.

Emlyn Williams will present his one-man show, "Dylan Thomas Growing Up," at the Charles Golden Center of Queens College in Flushing on March 9. The actor's appearance is being sponsored by the school's Alumni Association with the proceeds going to the college.

Paperboard production rose 14.9 per cent with 481,900 tons in the week ended Feb. 17, from 459,000 in the corresponding 1967 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
BONN, Feb. 20 (AP)--The Ministry of the Interior said today that the West German Government would send $1.25 million worth of food, clothing and drugs to South Vietnam.
Special to The New York Times BONN, Feb. 20--Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger decried today what he described as a "certain climate of anti-Americanism" that is growing in West Germany.

Special to The New York Times UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 20 -- Charges of "mass error" and torture were made today against the Greek Government by Platon D. Morozov of the Soviet Union, speaking in the Commission on Human Rights.
The American book rights to an authorized biography of the Beatles have been purchased for $150,000.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (Reuters) --The assignment of London policemen to keep watch on Elizabeth Taylor's dogs produced a complaint in the House of Commons today.

The Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) showed its first profit in the final three months of 1967. The company reported yesterday fourth quarter earnings of $1.74-million, or 17 cents a share, including income from interest and investments. It did not break down its operating income for the period but stated that operations had been profitable.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 20 (UPI)--James Bay, a Canadian-bred son of Nearctic owned by G. R. Gardiner, went to the front nearing the start of the stretch at Bowie today and went on to win the $5,200 WIBC purse by a length.

The Slick Corporation, a diversified manufacturing and operating company, announced here yesterday plans to elect Robert Van Tuyle as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds David A. Edwards, who has resigned for health reasons. Mr. VanTuyle is currently president of the Drew Chemical Corporation, which Slick has announced plans to acquire.

Spread out on the elliptical slopes of the new Madison Square Garden, the largest crowd in the 22-season history of the National Basketball Association-19,500--cheered the New York Knickerbockers to a 115-112 overtime victory last night over the San Francisco Warriors.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20--A Federal transportation official chided the automobile industry here today for what he called concentration on new style changes in cars rather than on improved safety measures.

Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., has appointed Edward D. Brown Jr., 42 years old, a vice president. The Clairol account supervisor, he joined Doyle Dane in March, 1965. He formerly was managing director and co-founder of an ad agency in Madrid, and was at Ted Bates for 10 years.
Three elder statesmen of the municipal bond fraternity --close to retirement age-are planning to open a new municipal bond house.

Special to The New York Times SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 20 --President Chung Hee Park's Government announced plans today to organize the country's veterans, reservists and ordinary villagers into a national militia and counterintelligence network to cope with an expected increase in hostile incursions from North Korea.

Special to The New York Times ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20--The New York Mets opened their seventh spring training season today with a new president, new general manager, new manager, three new coaches and a covey of new baseball players.

Karl E. Oelke was named president yesterday of Calmar, Inc., a plastic products subsidiary of the Diamond International Corporation. Mr. Oakes was formerly vice president of the Packaging Products division of Diamond International.

Democratic State Chairman John J. Burns said last night that Assemblyman Bertram L. Podell's victory in yesterday's special election in Brooklyn's 13th Congressional District showed President Johnson could carry the state in November.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --The Federal Railroad Administration announced today approval of an extensive reorganization for its Bureau of Railroad Safety to increase its investigation of rail accidents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) -- President Johnson today signed a bill toughening Federal control over commodity markets. The Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman, said the law was necessary to stop those who would "prey on the farmer."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--A court decision here has apparently opened the way for individual rent strikes against the owners of dwellings with pre-lease violations.
Murray Drabkin, the planner behind the city's income and commuter taxes, resigned yesterday as head of the city's Washington office to return to the private practice of law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --The State Department confirmed today that there had been another United StatesNorth Korean meeting about the Pueblo, and it warned against any punishment of the ship's crewmen.

Last year's operations resulted in a loss of $3,434,000 for Cowles Communications, Inc., the publishing and broadcasting company reported yesterday. The loss compared with restated earnings of $3,786,000 in 1966.

Special to The New York Times UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 20--Qualified sources in the Secretariat reported today that Secretary General Thant, meeting President Johnson tomorrow, would report assurances from Hanoi and Moscow that if the United States unconditionally halted bombing of North Vietnam, peace talks would begin about three weeks afterward.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The Senate refused today to cut off its month-long debate over civil rights. The move to invoke closure--that is, shut off debate--failed on a vote of 55 to 37. This was seven votes short of the necessary two-thirds of those voting.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 20 -- Israeli leaders believe that indirect bargaining with Cairo over procedural matters leading to possible peace talks has been virtually exhausted.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The House opened debate today on a proposal to remove the 25 per cent gold cover behind the nation's currency, with the threat of heavy Republican opposition when the voting comes tomorrow.

Major league baseball and its players reached their first basic labor agreement yesterday. Among the provisions of the two-year contract are improvements in minimum salaries, meal money and training camp expenses.
The Rev. Harry J. Sutcliffe ran his fingertips lightly over the page and intoned in his reedy tenor, "Da-VID ha-YAH MEL-ech kha-KHAM."

No stocks changed hands on the Bourse yesterday as 800 of its employes picketed outside. Stockbrokers voted Tuesday to close the Paris exchange until further notice. This was in reaction to a third strike in two weeks by the Bourse's 4,000 clerks.

The Federal Aviation Administration is accepting applicants for the job of air traffic controller "whose qualifications don't amount to a hill of beans," F. Lee Bailey, the Boston criminal lawyer, charged here yesterday.

The Secretary of the Treasury warned the nation yesterday that the Administration's program to reduce the balance-ofpayments deficit "cannot be effective" without a tax increase and tight control of Government spending.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- The Security Council met today to call for South African clemency to prisoners from South-West Africa who were sentenced on Feb. 9 to long prison terms on charges of terrorism.
MIAMI, Feb. 21 -- A man wearing a white cowboy hat hijacked an $8.5-million Delta Airline jet at gunpoint this afternoon and forced the pilot to fly him and 101 other passengers to Havana.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A bomb explosion tore into a ground-floor office of the Soviet Embassy before dawn today in what the United States called a "senseless act."
A plan for modifying the stock transfer tax is soon to be introduced in the Legislature with the support of the Lindsay administration and the governors of the New York Stock Exchange.

The main scenes are Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Egypt and Israel. The time is October 1966 to January 1967 -- a few months before the June war. A great scene and a great time have produced no great shakes of a book.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 21 -- Fresh American troops must be thrown into the 23-day battle for Hue, the commander of United States Marines in Vietnam said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The savings and loan industry suffered the largest January decline on record for savings deposits last month but the drop was far less than had been feared, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

Three years ago India and Pakistan came to blows over the Rann of Cutch, an expanse of wasteland on their western borders. A major conflict was averted when monsoon seas flooded the disputed area, impelling both sides to seek refuge in statesmanship. They agreed to submit this border question to international arbitration.

GRANDMASTER Pal Benko of New York captured first place in the finals of the recent 177-man New York City Open Championship, scoring 4 1/2-1/2 in the six-man round robin at the Brooklyn Chess Club. Edgar McCormick of Elizabeth, N. J., was second with 3-2. Marc Yoffie, Harald Hohenberger, Paul Brandts and Roy Mallett, all of New York, trailed.

After a complaint last season by the New York Jets, drastic penalties for the use of electronic equipment, notably video tape, during games were set yesterday by American Football League club owners meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Prices and volume increased again on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The exchange index closed 11 cents higher at $23.53, after moving between the high for the day of $23.82 and the low of $23.19. Volume rose to 3,780,040 shares from 3,548,400 on Tuesday.

IN YESTERDAY'S appointment of the Most Rev. John Joseph Carberry as Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Louis, the archdiocese gets not only a new administrator but a violin and harmonica player as well.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- The French Government decided today to shave the percentage of the oil and gasoline market held by United States and British companies, and to award the difference to West German and Italian concerns.
A rare type of mule, born to a Shetland pony and a burro, is thriving at the Children's Zoo in Central Park.
AMHERST, N.H., Feb. 21 -Gov. George Romney accused the Johnson Administration today of "spinning a web of delusion over the events in Vietnam" to "distract us from the truth."
FLINT, Mich., Feb. 21 -- An open-housing ordinance was approved here yesterday by 43 votes.

President Johnson's rejection of a statement by Morris B. Abram advocating a softer line on Vietnam led to the New York lawyer's decision yesterday not to enter the United States Senate race here this year.
