MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- Political prisoners in two labor camps and one prison were reported today to have begun a hunger strike last week in support of their demands for better conditions.

The scene is a restaurant in mid-Manhattan. The time is around 2 P.M. Hank and Dan, two businessmen, are deep in conversation as the check arrives. Dan picks it up, looks it over and hands it back to the waitress with his credit card.
Representatives of community groups demanded yesterday that they be given a major role in health planning, including decisions on the size and location of hospitals, nursing homes and clinics.
TRENTON, Feb. 21 -- An insurance industry request for a 20 per cent increase in New Jersey automobile liability rates was rejected today by the State Department of Banking and Insurance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- In Washington, where everyone is so engrossed in the great issues these days that the possibility of murder lurks in every social encounter, a little sanity can be retained by spending one day a week pondering the tiny little issues.

Georg Jensen Inc., the silversmith and specialty concern, will shift its corporate headquarters and warehouse facilities to Hawthorne in Westchester County later this month to provide more selling space in the store on Fifth Avenue and 53d Street.
Stock prices advanced yesterday for the third consecutive session although profit taking trimmed some of the earlier gains and erased others.

Bernard Kalisky, who had refused on Tuesday to tell a grand jury anything, not even his name, was taken yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Charles Marks, who found him in contempt of both the jury and the court.
A police sergeant and two patrolmen admitted yesterday that they had accepted Christmas gratuities from two East Side concerns.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 22 -- United States Marine jet bombers hit enemy positions outside the south Citadel wall in Hue yesterday with rockets, bombs and napalm. The attacks followed a five-day pause in air strikes because of weather.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 21 -The City Council today rejected a motion to order an investigation into the authenticity of paintings in the city's controversial Bass Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Regulations regarding savings and loan association holding companies were released today by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. They give companies until Aug. 12 to register statements of financial worth and stock holdings.

John Bach, Fordham's basketball coach for the last 18 seasons, was hired as the Penn State coach yesterday. The 43year-old Bach, who has also served as the Rams' director of athletics for 10 years, will assume his new duties at University Park, Pa., in June.

Warner Brothers-Seven Arts has acquired screen rights to "Scuba Duba," the comedy by Bruce Jay Friedman, now at the Off Broadway New Theater. The 37-year-old novelist will receive $150,000 down, plus 5 per cent of the film's gross after it has recouped 2.7 times the cost of the negative. "Scuba Duba" is his first play.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -South Vietnam's Ambassador to the United States said today that the key objective of the recent Vietcong offensive was to weaken the American and South Vietnamese will to fight and that in this country the enemy has "made some headway."

FRAGMENTARY ratings available for the Public Broadcast Laboratory, the television experiment financed by a multimillion-dollar grant from the Ford Foundation, suggest in New York at least that the informational and cultural venture is encountering one of the more deadly forms of viewer response: ennui.

Arctic air swept down on the metropolitan area and most of the nation east of the Rockies yesterday, plummeting temperatures to a numbing 5 degrees at 6:45 A.M. This was only one degree above the record for the date -- 4 degrees, set Feb. 21, 1896.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. said today that he would try to use moral persuasion to get Florida's public school teachers to call off their "strike." Then he flew to Miami for his first confrontation with the teachers.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 21 -- Ordinarily, the outside post position in a harness race is pure poison, especially for a 12year-old horse who wears poultice bandages on his legs and hasn't started in six months.

" Hogan's Goat" will be converted into a musical for Broadway next season. Mitch Leigh, composer of "Man of La Mancha," plans to produce it as well as to furnish the score. The book is to be provided by William Alfred, professor of English at Harvard University, who wrote the play.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today approval of a modified plan for consolidation of the Pennzoil Company, a Houston holding company, with the United Gas Corporation, its Shreveport, La., subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- In order to prevent "indiscriminate shooting" in crowded civilian areas, American troops in some parts of South Vietnam do not sleep with their rifles by their bunks, Pentagon officials said today.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed legislation today to stop insurance companies from denying coverage to owners of slum properties.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 21 -- The sudden arrests of three key anti-Government figures in this tense capital have surprised and annoyed the United States Embassy here.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand -- People in 15 countries are now eating the high protein whole milk biscuit New Zealand wants all dairy countries to distribute as a weapon against hunger. New Zealand has developed the biscuit as a method of using dairy surpluses in foreign aid.
A former hod-carrier from Wales is currently carrying American music back to Americans of all ages at the Copacabana.
The American Viscose division of the FMC Corporation announced yesterday it would increase prices for acetate yarns on April 1.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., and Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia drew in 44 moves today in the third in a series of chess matches to determine a possible world championship challenger.

YONKERS, Feb. 21 -- A 10year-old Brooklyn boy in a blue Cub Scout uniform methodically ate popcorn while lottery winners were chosen today, then broke into a big grin when the drawing brought him $100,000.
Mrs. John F. Kennedy flew suddenly to Montreal yesterday with her children, John and Caroline.
MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 21 -- A campaign against the "widespread" use of marijuana by teen-agers in this community and neighboring South Orange was announced today by Mayor Edmund T. Hume here.

SUCCESS breeds success, they say, and it is therefore small wonder that Adolfo is a very successful man. In an era of scarves and bare heads, he has made women who belong to the restless society feel almost naked without his Panama hats and towering fur toques.

The overwhelming vote by which the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association adopted the Reardon report on "fair trial and free press" reflects the deep concern of the nation's lawyers that the reporting of crime news sometimes interferes with the execution of justice -- and something has to be done about it.

SAN DIEGO, Feb. 21 -- The National Council of Churches called upon the United States Government today to make farreaching changes in its foreign policy to pave the way for world peace based on justice.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

The open-housing amendment is the heart of the civil rights bill now pending in the Senate. On Tuesday sixty Senators voted or had themselves paired in favor of bringing the bill to an early vote. Yesterday approximately the same number rejected a motion to cut the housing amendment out of the bill.

Tile Marine Midland Corporation, New York's only statewide bank holding company, announced yesterday that its subsidiary in Nyack, N. Y., had proposed a merger with the $15-million Lafayette Bank and Trust Company of Suffern, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -The United States has privately urged Israel to relax her demands for direct negotiations with the Arab states to arrange a settlement of the Middle East war, reliable sources said today.
" OPPORTUNITIES for Women in New York State Government" is the title of a bulletin just published by the New York State Woman's Program.
BAR HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 21 -- George Meany said today that the first four years of the Johnson Administration had been better for organized labor than Franklin D. Roosevelt's initial term.
ATHENS, Feb. 21 -- The Government ordered the expulsion today of a resident British news correspondent and laid down rules for reporting by foreign journalists in Greece.
LORMAN, Miss., Feb. 21 (UPI) -- The police used tear gas and gunfire today to put down an outbreak at the predominantly Negro Alcorn A. and M. College.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A move by the Democratic and Republican leadership to kill open housing legislation was firmly rejected by the Senate today.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 (AP) -About 50 students, calling the use of napalm "treason to the human race," staged a sit-in at the State University unit here today. They were seeking to prevent interviews conducted by a representative of Dow Chemical Company, the major manufacturer of napalm for use in Vietnam.

Editorials in many United States newspapers have denounced the action of the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association in approving new rules of conduct for lawyers and new procedures for judges designed to restrict the release of crime news to news media.
GENEVA, Feb. 21 -- Switzerland opened an official channel of communication with Hanoi today in a move that could facilitate a Swiss attempt to help end the war in Vietnam.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 21 (AP) -Lawmakers here moved today to outlaw strikes by Tennessee public employes, as a walkout by 1,300 garbage collectors passed its 10th day with no end in sight.

MARACAY, Venezuela, Feb. 21 -- The Organization of American States completed work today on a reorganization of assistance to the neglected sectors of education and scientific development in Latin America.
COLUMBIA S. C., Feb. 21 -Two soldiers at Fort Jackson, the Army training center, are facing court-martial after publicly expressing their doubts about the war in Vietnam.
Taxi riders here are hailing fewer cabs since the 25 per cent fare increase went into effect, the taxi fleets reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -The head of the foreign aid program told a Congressional watchdog group today that he assumed full responsibility for the scandal that recently led to the resignations of four officials of the Agency for International Development, including an assistant administrator.

The head of the Federation of German Industries said here yesterday that talks with numerous Government and Congressional leaders in Washington had convinced him that there would be no import restrictions for the time being.
MOST foreigners, Manola Drozdoski said, have too many misconceptions about the food of Spain, her native land, and she would just as leave have the record straight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Youthful antiwar demonstrators twice interrupted a mock trial of world Communism today with protests against bombing of North Vietnamese cities and destruction of South Vietnamese villages.

Columbia's unbeaten fencers trounced New York University 16-11, last night in the loser's gymnasium at Washington Square. The Lions led throughout in handing the Violets their first loss of the season, after seven victories. It was the seventh triumph for Columbia.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP) -- In a demonstration of unity in the Detroit newspaper shutdown, at least eight unions picketed the city's two dailies today and two of them indicated that they had joined the teamsters in a strike at The Detroit News.
The United States Commissioner of Education called yesterday for a reorganization of the New York City school system as quickly as possible.
REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Feb. 21 (AP) -- A mother of 15 has won a divorce here on the grounds of incompatibility and extreme cruelty.
SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 21 -- Choe Chae Sin went to the Hwimun High School here last week to check on the results of the entrance examination taken by his son, U Sang.
James O. Wright resigned unexpectedly yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the Federal-Mogul Corporation "to devote more time to his personal interests."
KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 (AP) -- A fragment from a North Vietnamese mortar round hit a marine corporal in the head one foggy morning recently on Hill 881 South near here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) A House Investigating subcommittee said today that the United States could not "win" the war in Vietnam until it allowed its military leaders to fight it.
George Wallace of Alabama has announced his candidacy for the Presidency, promising that, if elected, he would make the streets of Washington safe "if it took 30,000 troops with two-foot bayonets."
MIAMI, Feb. 21 -- Most of greater Havana's 1.7 million population will go without milk for the next several months, the Cuban radio announced today.
WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King swept through her opening match in 21 minutes at the national women's indoor tennis championship today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -The House approved today legislation removing the last gold cover for the nation's currency.

About 600 Negroes, attending a memorial program for Malcolm X held at Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem, were urged yesterday to obtain weapons for "self-defense" against whites and to practice using them so that when the "hunting season" came they would be ready.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Republican Congressional leaders said today that they opposed taxes on overseas travel proposed by President Johnson.
The Police Department is exploring ways with the Ford Foundation to get more Negro and Puerto Rican patrolmen by recruiting newly returned servicemen from Vietnam.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yesterday it was offering a $1,000 reward for information leading to the capture of the men involved in the killing of Patrolman Anthony Graffia on Monday night.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 21 -- When the United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) was ordered into the northern part of South Vietnam last month, there was widespread speculation that its troops would reinforce the Marine base at Khesanh if it was attacked.
If the residents of Chinatown have ever staged a mass protest about anything before, the community's elders cannot remember when.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Two of the three American pilots freed by Hanoi last Friday have said they were threatened and beaten by North Vietnamese peasants after their planes were shot down in raids over North Vietnam.
The American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., showed a sharp decline in earnings last year from 1966 despite record revenues, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, reported yesterday.

Consolidated net income of the National Cash Register Company last year increased 9.5 per cent to $35,320,000 from $32,262,000 in 1966, Robert S. Oelman, chairman, reported yesterday.

THE First Company Governor's Foot Guard Athletic Association, the only military organization in the country that conducts dog shows, is bent on making its annual event in Hartford better next year through more stringent entry requirements.

About 1,900 listeners turned out at Philharmonic Hall last night for a program by the Lovin' Spoonful. They heard some of the saner and more joyful sounds and lyrics currently being made in the rock, folk and country scene.

In your Feb. 17 editorial you argued for an end to strategic bombing of North Vietnam and a continuation of tactical bombing in the immediate area of Khesanh. I believe this action would seriously endanger our troops in that area.
PANAMA, Feb. 21 (UPI) -The opposition called today for the impeachment of President Marco A. Robles for allegedly having tampered with the National Electoral Tribunal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A study prepared by the staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee asserts that the destroyer Maddox was under orders in 1964 to take provocative action in order to induce the Chinese Communists and North Vietnamese to turn on their radio and radar so the destroyer could monitor them.

A portion of the rich legacy left by Johann Gutenberg will be on view today at the Grolier Club, in an exhibition commemorating the 500th anniversary of the death of the Western world's inventor of movable type.

Democratic National Chairman John M. Bailey declared yesterday that the election of Bertram L. Podell as Representative from Brooklyn's 13th Congressional District was "a clear mandate for the policies of President Johnson."

Waterfront employers and labor leaders warned the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor at a hearing yesterday that a reopening of the work list to admit new men as longshoremen could disrupt the port and might prove disastrous.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 21 -- A Marine lieutenant inspected his sandbag-and-steel bunker at Khesanh one morning recently and shook his head. "I wish I could say it'll take a direct mortar hit," he said. "But it won't. Not enough steel, no wooden beams."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions at today's auction from last month's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- London's newest attraction is a 120-foot yacht sitting in the Thames near the Tower of London. It has been chartered by Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor, at an amount reported as $2,400 a week, to keep their four dogs from British quarantine.

The Northern Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries topped $1-billion in gross plant investment in 1967 as its earnings, revenues and sales hit new highs, according to the annual report released yesterday.
The P. Lorillard Co. announced yesterday terms for conversion of its 7 per cent preferred stock into subordinated debentures to be issued by the Lorillard Corporation.

You are to be commended for the basic spirit of your Feb. 18 editorial entitled "Subverting the Jarring Mission." No question about it. If we really want peace in the Middle East, and if we would support the efforts of the United Nations to achieve this end, then Gunnar Jarring should not be subverted by the mounting of an arms race.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 21 -- A search through the beach area of this seashore resort, which began when a mother said that two men had kidnapped her infant daughter, ended today when the child was found dead in the family apartment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Kosher poultry processors disagreed today over rabbinical opinion on Hebrew dietary law and "New York dressed poultry."

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- A crowd of more than 150,000 West Berliners rallied today on the John F. Kennedy Square in front of the City Hall in a show of solidarity with the United States at a time of turmoil over the Vietnam war.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Federal marshals arrested H. Rap rown today and charged the black power advocate with threatening an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and his family.

OTTAWA, Feb. 21 -- Opposition forces united in the House of Commons today to deny Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson's request for an immediate vote of confidence. As a result, the question of whether the minority Liberal Government will fall hangs in the balance until Friday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 21 -The United States Naval Academy disclosed tonight that 13 midshipmen had admitted smoking marijuana in their rooms in Bancroft Hall, the academy dormitory, within the last two weeks.
The Board of Education last night approved the hiring of men security "aides" or guards for schools and the installation of a direct telephone line from each school to the nearest police station.
GRUMMAN AIRCRAFT, a stock that has been buffeted by the winds of uncertainty, took off yesterday and climbed to a 1 5/8 gain at 34 3/8 on a 21,400-share turnover.
The next decade will see not only a tripling in air passenger traffic but an eightfold increase for air cargo, according to William P. Gwinn, president of United Aircraft Corporation.

The Finlandia Foundation's Sibelius Scholarship Fund, for the exchange of music students between the United States and Finland, will receive the proceds of the annual award dinner dance of the foundation's metropolitan chapter, Saturday, in the Waldorf-Astoria's Sert Room.

WINDHAM, N. Y., Feb. 21 -A sortie was made into the Catskills today to test the skiing prior to the long holiday weekend. It was a successful venture; plenty of skiing is available for the days ahead.
The General Electric Company reported yesterday gains of 8 per cent in sales and 7 per cent in net earnings for 1967.

Officials of the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn had a look yesterday at what their institution will be like in the future as a result of a planned construction and renovation program expected to cost between $20-million and $25-million.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Richard M. Nixon said today that the Soviet Union had more than doubled its land-based strategic missile force in the last year, and was now approaching equality with the United States in these weapons.

John J. DeLury, the 63-yearold president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, was released from the Civil Jail yesterday and was greeted by a phalanx of cheering and shivering sanitation workers.

Copper futures jumped the 2cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday in five nearby deliveries. The move was spurred by tightening supplies and the rejection by the union of a compromise bargaining formula to help end the seven-month strike.

Four of the seven pieces that Zadel Skolovsky played last night at Carnegie Hall were works that the pianist had included in his debut program at Town Hall 28 years ago. Sales of high-quality utility bonds picked up speed yesterday, and investment bankers became more optimistic that they could sell the major issues they have won this month.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- There may not seem to be much connection between the nearly disastrous garbagemen's strike just ended in New York City, the growing unrest in the black ghettos and the dangerous clash of armies in South Vietnam, but Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York sees at least one common thread.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Two cheers went up in the New York Mets baseball camp today as 24 jobseekers opened spring training and inaugurated the administration of Gil Hodges.

A certified public accountant who cashed almost $10-million a year in checks for gamblers and tax-evading businessmen for a fee was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison. Federal Judge Irving Ben Cooper also fined him $30,000 for incometax evasion.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Dooley Womack, Steve Whitaker and Roy White signed their New York Yankee contracts today, but the man who really had an experience in joining the fold was Bobby Cox.

The First Boston Corporation, Wall Street's largest underwriting firm and one of the few publicly held securities firms, reported higher earnings for 1967 and also disclosed plans to split its shares threefor-two.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 21 -Mr. Howe today recommended a program to help turn "the disruption and doubt" of social revolution "into a sense of purpose and progress."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, accused Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today of deceiving the American public by presenting a one-sided story of the Gulf of Tonkin incidents.
Directors of the Anaconda Company voted here yesterday to reduce the quarterly dividend to 37 1/2 cents a common share from 62 1/2 cents in previous quarters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -President Johnson and Secretary General Thant exchanged views here today on the prospects for ending the war in Vietnam, which both of them apparently rate as rather faint at the moment.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 19 -The Iraqi Government has broken a 40-year old grip held by the Western-owned Iraq Petroleum Company on this country's oil deposits but has paid a high price to do so, according to critics of a new deal with a French oil company.

MIAMI, Feb. 21 -- Forward Pass hit the mark with dramatic precision in the $30,250 Everglades Stakes today. The Calumet Farm's representative thrilled the crowd of 20,857 by taking the 1 1/8-mile race for 3year-olds by a head over Isidor Bieber's Wise Exchange.
MIAMI, Feb. 21 -- The Flamingo Ball will be held at Hialeah Park here on March 1, the eve of the $100,000 Flamingo Stakes for 3-yearolds ending the Hialeah season.
MADRID, Feb. 21 -- Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today the committee had not been notified of any withdrawals from the Summer Games in Mexico City.
MEDFORD, Ore., Feb. 21 -A 19-year-old youth whose two older brothers were killed in Vietnam was granted today a one-year draft deferment by the Jackson County Selective Service board.
Students from Australia and New Zealand who made a recent tour of Communist China ran into a series of incidents. This account is by John Pattison, a 19-year-old student at Melbourne University.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) Senate-House conferees reached agreement today on a bill increasing the ExportImport Bank's lending authority, but barring transactions with Communist countries.

AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 21 -More than 65,000 Arab refugees have fled from camps on the east bank of the Jordan River in the last week following Israeli shelling in the area, according to statistics compiled by United Nations Relief and Works Agency officials here.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 21 (AP) -King Baudouin agreed today to dissolution of the Belgian Parliament and new elections in an attempt to end the latest government crisis caused by the perennial Fleming-Walloon language dispute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -Pope Paul VI named the Most Rev. John J. Carberry to succeed the late Joseph Cardinal Ritter as Archbishop of St. Louis.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 -- The Chrysler Corporation sees "no need for new investment capital through 1969," for its United States and Canadian operations, Lynn A. Townsend, chairman, told the Boston Financial Analysts Society today.

THE George Washington Birthday sectional tournament, under the auspices of the Greater New York Bridge Association, begins this afternoon at the New York Hilton. The most important event will be a Knockout Team Championship, in which two rounds will be played today at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 21 -- St. John's turned back a hard-driving second-half attack by Providence tonight to beat the Friars, 58-56, before a crowd of 3,300.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 21 -- The Arkansas Legislature adjourned today after giving Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller two bills that he said he needed to revamp the state's penal system.
GENEVA, Feb. 21 -- United Nations economists see a twoway flow of investment capital across the Atlantic with the United States serving as a sort of turntable that keeps it moving.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that American troops were dying in Vietnam because of President Johnson's war policies, not because of dissent over the conflict.

St. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of investigation tonight charged Lawrence M. Rhodes Jr., a West Virginian, with hijacking a Delta Air Lines DC-8 jet and kidnapping its 108 occupants on a forced flight to Cuba.

Regine Crespin is getting around in Wagner's "Die Walkure." In December she made two unscheduled appearances as Sieglinde in the Metropolitan Opera production when Gundula Janowitz was ill, and on Wednesday night she took over the part of Brunnhilde, which was to have been her only Metropolitan "Walkure" assignment this season.

Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, proposed in a special report yesterday that public-employe unions be allowed the right to strike, except where the public health and safety could be endangered.

LONDON -- In a recent Commons debate one Labor M.P. observed that Malta is "under pressure to make itself available to the Soviet fleet in the Mediterranean." This is no mere emotional parliamentary nightmare. On the contrary, it is a subject of growing concern to Britain's Defense Ministry and armed services.

New car sales continued to spurt in the second 10-day period of February, with dealers selling about 193,000 American-made automobiles, up 18.5 per cent from the nearly 163,000 automobiles sold in the corresponding period last year.

The Board of Education, expressing "shock" over an anti-white memorial program to Malcolm X held at Intermediate School 201, directed the Superintendent of Schools yesterday to "establish clear control" over the East Harlem school, pending its ultimate transfer to community control.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 22 (AP) -- At least nine more persons have been arrested in the South Vietnamese Government's political crackdown, informed sources said today. This would bring the number seized since Tuesday to at least 12.

Henry Lewis is a proud as a young father, and eager to talk all about it. The head of the 21-nation European Travel Commission is going home to Ireland "distinctly encouraged" by the "tremendous public feeling" he sensed in Washington against travel restrictions as a solution to the balance-of-payment deficit.

The memorial program for Malcolm X at Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem was not just a nauseating racist exercise; it was also an inexcusable breach of public and educational policy for which Board of Education headquarters must take major blame. Board President Giardino has rightly, but belatedly, ordered a ban on any more such incidents in the schools.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 22 -- The National Council of Churches issued a warning today against what it called the increasing "Americanization" of the Vietnam war and the uncertain loyalty of the South Vietnamese people to the Saigon Government.

A strike against the upper school or the Barnard School for Boys in the Bronx was called yesterday by 14 teachers who are seeking official recognition of the United Federation of Teachers as their bargaining agent.

Peter Arno, who peopled a satirical world with lecherous aristocrats, dismayed dowagers, and choleric clubmen in hundreds of cartoons for The New Yorker and other publications, died yesterday of emphysema complicated by lung cancer at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y.
The Middle South Utilities System reported yesterday gains of 6.9 per cent in total operating revenues and 4.8 per cent in net income for the 12 months ended Jan. 31.
THE $450 Motorboard, a brash young newcomer that doesn't mind rocking the boat, appears ready to start making waves.
The president of the American Bankers Association yesterday attacked a bill sponsored by the Johnson Administration that would create a new system of Federally chartered savings institutions.

MARATHON, Fla., Feb. 22 -- "I'd like to wait until dark before bringing in this catch," said Skipper John Caperonis as we headed back to Marathon in the Florida Keys after a day's angling for king mackerel.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 22 -The South Carolina Task Force for Community Uplift appealed today for every municipality in the state to form biracial groups immediately to deal with the causes of "possible racial upheaval in their midst."
PARIS, Feb. 22 -- Fifty years after the death of Augaste Rodin, "original" bronzes of Rodin masterpieces are still being cast and sold, mostly for the American market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Republican national chairman, Ray C. Bliss, indicated tonight that the request of his party's Governors for an equal role in drafting this year's platform would be rejected.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 22 -- President Johnson, reflecting the national concern with decaying cities, outlined today a broad public-private plan for rebuilding the residential hearts of the nation's urban centers.
The Paris Stock Exchange was back in business yesterday following settlement Wednesday night of a strike of exchange clerks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Administration confirmed today that it would further slow development of the super sonic airliner.
An unusual consensus is developing in support of binding arbitration as the best insurance against more civil service strikes of the kind that covered New York City with garbage early this month.

Secretary of Commerce Alexander B. Trowbridge has turned down a bid by Lykes Bros. Steamship Company, Inc., of New Orleans to overrule a decision by the Maritime Subsidy Board on the company's diversification plans.

RISHIKESH, India, Feb. 22 -All four Beatles are now settled in a retreat here by the Ganges that their globe-trotting guru, Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, maintains for those who follow him in pursuit of "absolute bliss consciousness."
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 22 -Princeton University won the 30th annual Polar Bear track meet tonight at Lawrenceville Field House, scoring 75 points to Pennsylvania's 57 and Columbia's 5.
A new book, sure to draw raves from some motorists, lists 60,000 of the worst traffic violators here.
In move to combat crime, a bill to pay the city's 2,000 auxiliary policemen was filed yesterday for early introduction in the City Council.

SAIGON, South Vietnam Friday, Feb. 23 -- The United States command announced yesterday that the death toll of American troops for the week that ended last Saturday was 543, by far the highest of the war.
HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 22 -- The little gray spotter plane skimmed under the clouds covering Vietnam's embattled old imperial capital today, twisting and skidding away from intense enemy gunfire.

TOKYO, Feb. 22 -- While other Asian countries struggle to cope with the problems of excessive, fast-rising populations, Japanese demographers are worrying over harmful consequences becoming apparent as a result of their country's low population growth.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Kremlin's effort to reassert its ideological supremacy in international communism has achieved instead an even greater fragmentation of national Communist parties.
The nation's leading chain stores began 1968 much as they ended 1967 -- with a strong increase in sales.

GENEVA, Feb. 22 -- Although the Swiss Government has opened a direct channel of communications to Hanoi, it does not believe that present circumtances justify the use of its good offices in helping to end the war in Vietnam.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The Labor Government gave way to heavy political pressure today and moved to curb colored immigration into Britain.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 22 -- Harry Golden announced today the death of The Carolina Israelite, the humorous, urbane and liberal tabloid he has written and published by himself since 1941.
Not even two soloists, one of them appearing in two works, could make the New York Philharmonic concert last night at Philharmonic Hall seem like anything but a miscellany.
With unusual speed for a new-product introduction, Lestoil will bring out an all-purpose spray cleaner on April 15 that was only an idea and formula on Dec. 15.

Karl and Till Engel, a father-and-son piano team, made their New York debut at Carnegie Hall last night playing the Double Concerto in E-flat major (K. 365) in a Mozart concert given by the Orchestra da Camera.

THE George Washington Birthday tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association continues today at the New York Hilton. The principal events will be the Men's and Women's Pairs at 2 P.M. and the Mixed Pairs at 8 P.M.
The General Public Utilities Corporation believes it has found a simple and economical way to raise the huge capital it needs for growth and also to keep most of its stockholders happy.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Feb 22 (UPI) -- A teachers' strike closed Albuquerque's 108 public schools today and threatened to spread across the state unless Gov. David F. Cargo called a special session of the New Mexico Legislature on school financing.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 22 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican of Kentucky, said here tonight that it was "a very good assumption" that he would not seek re-election this year.

More than 300 people -- many of them African government officials wearing their native costumes -- dined on African delicacies, danced to African music and heard Vice President Humphrey speak on his recent visit to Africa at a party last night in the Manhattan home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Krim.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The State Department disclosed today that security precautions around the Soviet Embassy had been increased recently as a result of an anonymous threats against Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin and other Soviet diplomats.
SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 22 -- Four hundred and thirty couples were married here today in what was billed as the biggest wedding in history.

Three of the top schoolboy milers in the metropolitan area -- John Brady of St. Helena, Bill McLoughlin of Sacred Heart and Marcel Philippe of Mater Christi -- moved down to the 1,000-yard run yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Unless a new stadium is promised to the Boston Patriots in the next 12 months, the American Football League franchise will be obliged to consider shifting to another city, probably Seattle, the Patriots' president, Billy Sullivan, disclosed yesterday.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company expressed strong opposition yesterday to any increase in the present $35-anounce price of gold. A higher gold price, the bank said in its monthly survey, would neither reduce the United States balance of payments deficit, nor head off the trend toward direct controls over international transactions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 -- Dr. John Summerskill announced today his resignation as president of San Francisco State College. He charged that California higher education was "being eroded by political interference and financial starvation."

BRUSSELS, Feb. 22 -- A malaise has spread through the ranks of bureaucrats in the Commission of the European Common Market -- the men who are supposed to supply the main motive force for European integration.

WHEN a big country takes over a little country by force, one righteous way of denouncing the action is to compare it with a rape. It was not a figure of speech that seemed, at this distance, particularly appropriate when India took (or took back) the tiny coastal enclave of Goa from Portugal in 1961.
Morris B. Abram, New York lawyer and senior adviser to the United States mission at the United Nations, yesterday was chosen president of Brandeis University, the second in its 20-year history.
To the Editor: There is a disquieting implication in the Government's draft deferment statement of Feb. 16.
Earnings of the National Gypsum Company last year slipped slightly from the 1966 level, the company reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 -Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., a six-time United States chess champion, and Leonid Stein, the current and three-time champion of the Soviet Union, drew an 18-move King's Indian Defense in their second meeting at the Herman Steiner Chess Club here last night.

The new 11,000-ton Danish cargo ship Cornelia Maersk, whose cargo installations represent a "go slow" approach to the current cargo-handling revolution, brought about by containerization, sails today on her maiden voyage to the Far East.

A PLAY about teen-age values, "Let's Get Basic," put on this week to stimulate a parental discussion of sex, turned instead into a pot parley. Marijuana, hallucinogens and the confusions of the current world situation as reflected by their young were of more pressing concern to the 150 parents than sex, premarital or otherwise.
Governor Rockefeller assorted yesterday this country could not solve its problems at home or abroad by pulling a gun or calling out the troops or dropping a bomb.

Louis Heren, Washington correspondent for The Times of London, has been named the first winner of the John F. Kennedy Memorial award by Harper Row, Inc., for his book, "The New American Commonwealth."
AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 22 -- Following are excerpts front President Johnson's message to Congress today on "The Crisis of the Cities":

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The long wrangle over the price the British Government will pay international oil companies for natural gas from the North Sea appears to be approaching an end. A compromise price near 3 cents a therm is expected to be announced soon.

MONTREAL, Feb. 22 -- Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy, accompanied by her children, Caroline and John, and guarded by what one report said were four Secret Service agents, ignored rumors of an impending marriage to Lord Harlech today and went skiing in uncertain fashion.

AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 22 -- High officials in Jordan and the United Arab Republic have added their voices to the chorus of gloomy predictions about the prospects for a peaceful Middle East settlement that has been welling in recent weeks from the Arab side.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 22 -- Carl B. Stokes, the first Negro mayor of a major American city, ended the first 100 days of his administration on the upswing this week after a slow start plagued by disorganization, inexperience and minor blunders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -The Joint Chiefs of Staff have drawn up a mobilization proposal involving a call-up of 40,000 to 50,000 National Guardsmen and Marine Corps reservists and special alert orders to about 130,000 additional reservists.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Jerry McGee, admittedly "a little speechless," fired a seven-under-par 65 today and took a two-stroke lead over Deane Beman in the first round of the $100,000 Tucson open golf tournament.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Striking mechanics in San Francisco and Honolulu have voted to end their strike, started last Dec. 18 against Qantus Air Lines, and accept a new contract mediated in Washington, a union official reported today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 22 -- Eddie Cobb didn't like the way Ruy Blas IV was acting tonight before the richest trot of the Roosevelt Raceway winter meeting. And Bernard Grignola, who came over from France with the 7-year-old horse to help train him, was worried about the time.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 -- Dr. Max Rafferty, California's outspokenly conservative Superintendent of Public Instruction, announced tonight he would oppose Senator Thomas H. Kuchel, the minority whip, for the Republican Senate nomination.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 (UPI) -- An Air Force sled roared down the Mount Hoevenberg ice chute under cloudy skies today to capture the North American four-man bobsled championship.

HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 22 -- United States marines ran crouching up a stone staircase and reached the south wall of the Hue Citadel today to close an important phase of the battle to control South Vietnam's second most important city.
In the last few months, 81 manufacturing concerns, most seeking to enlarge their plants here, have asked the city's Department of Commerce and Industrial Development to help them find space.

It really isn't, however, even though the tumultous happenings of the world today have blurred its image and held it up to scorn. Yet the anti-Vietnam demonstrations to some degree and the civil rights demonstrations to a far greater degree are motivated by the loftier principles of idealism.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 22 -- The alarming casualties that turn up every year in spring training struck the New York Yankee camp today from two unexpected directions. Whitey Ford gagged on the juice of the chewing tobacco he was trying for the third, and last, time in his life, and an arm was broken -the arm on the cover of the large electric tureen that makes the noontime soup.

With the kind of gesture that belongs only to the New York City Opera Company, that group opened its 47th New York season last night at the State Theater with a double bill of Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex" and Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana."

PRAGUE, Feb. 22 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party began celebrating today its 20th anniversary in power amid indications that some members were uneasy about the presence of their most prestigious foreign guest, Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 -- The International Longshoremen's Association said today that it would refuse to handle copper exports and imports in the United States and Canada.
Legislative leaders have agreed on a Congressional reapportionment bill that virtually assures the election of Brooklyn's first Negro member of the House of Representatives.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The state's highest court upheld today the contempt conviction of Dr. Timothy Leary's wife for having refused, before their marriage, to testify about what went on at his headquarters in Millbrook, N. Y.

RICHMOND, Feb. 22 (UPI) -Handcuffed and vowing to fast until dead or free, H. Rap Brown was flown from New Orleans to Washington tonight and then taken by car to jail in Richmond.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 23 -- Asians in Kenya have started a panic rush to get to Britain before new British immigration curbs are enacted.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Laotian military sources said that Communist guerrillas attacked the key Laotian town of Saravane today and were repulsed by Government forces. However, they overran a regimental headquarters at Lao Ngam, 25 miles away. The outpost fell under an attack in battalion strength, the sources reported.
Mayor Lindsay's criticism Thursday of President Johnson's policies on the Vietnam war was sharply attacked yesterday by two City Hall Democrats.

THE glitter and sparkle of gold and silver of the 17th and 18th centuries in the "Art Treasures of Turkey" exhibition, currently at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is impressive, although it may seem shockingly gaudy to Western eyes.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia -- Ali Ibrahim Naimi received his 20-year pin last week from the Arabian American Oil Company. Normally, such a presentation is not a notable event. This case, however, is different. Mr. Naimi is only 31 years old.
TWO young New York stars, Peter Sager and Richard Miller, captured the Open Pairs Championship played Thursday in the George Washington Birthday tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association.
THE season's first shipment of Israel's sweet but tangy Jaffa oranges has arrived in local markets.

Reflecting the effects of a two-month strike last fall, the Ford Motor Company incurred a net loss of $109.1-million in the fourth quarter. As a result, earnings for the entire year fell sharply below 1966 levels.

It is true, as former Congressman Hamilton Fish points out in his letter [Times, Feb. 12] that President Johnson, by encouraging trade with the Communist-bloc countries, and favoring additional consulates with the Communists -- while sending young Americans to Southeast Asia to resist aggression there -- has confused the issues of the Vietnam war.

The Administration's bill to remove the 25 per cent gold cover on the domestic money supply squeaked through the House by a dismayingly narrow margin. It deserves stronger support in the Senate, even though the White House delayed much too long in calling for the cover's elimination. That delay is no excuse for lengthy haggling on Capitol Hill.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 -- A basic disagreement has developed between the American and South Vietnamese commands over the enemy objectives in the current offensive.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 23 -- Princeton's basketball team was back on its home court tonight for its final series in the Ivy League race. Returning from a successful road trip, the Tigers nevertheless seemed comfortably at home in beating Harvard, 84-72, to remain in a tie with Columbia for first place in the standing.

Fannie Hurst, the American short-story writer and novelist whose romances captivated millions, died yesterday after a brief illness in her apartment at the Hotel des Artistes, 1 West 67th Street. She was 78 years old.

KINGS POINT, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Hofstra University placed seven men in the semi-final round of the 10th annual Metropolitan intercollegiate wrestling tournament tonight and took the lead in the tournament that will end tomorrow night.

A new British nuclear submarine slips out of the Firth of Clyde, encountering a sailboat-borne peace demonstration and moving on to less peaceful demonstrations off the coast of Korea, on special watch missions with the American forces. This novel is as timely as the Pueblo headlines, what with the submarine engaging "enemy forces" and her skipper being torn between duty and friendships.
Prices of silver futures continued their upward move yesterday. Renewed speculative interest reflected world uncertainties and technical factors.
GENEVA, Feb. 23 -- Mrs. Charlotte Browne-Mayers of New York City has been appointed associate general secretary of the World Council of Churches. She will be the first woman to held the post.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 23 -- A Congress of Racial Equality project supported experimentally by the Ford Foundation is being denounced by some Cleveland leaders and applauded by others.

RONNIE HALL, a 27-year-old singer-actor, sat in a barber chair the other day while a woman in a black smock tugged at tufts of his hair for about 10 minutes. Pop! Pop! Pop! Each tug produced a sound as if a kernel of popcorn had exploded on his head.

TALK to cigar-waving economic consultant Pierre Rinfret and he'll tell you practically everybody has the wrong notion regarding how much the nation's businesses will spend on new plant and equipment this year.
The Taylor Law, which forbids strikes by public employes, was criticized before a legislative committee yesterday because the law had failed to prevent the teachers' and sanitation strikes.
THE comfortable, four-story brick house West 145th Street, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Harry B. Fitzgerald, is scarcely imposing architecture and looks a bit in need of the coat of paint it is soon to get.

The determination of a top administrative officer of the Presbyterian Church to track down his missing suitcase at Kennedy International Airport led the police yesterday to some $50,000 worth of marijuana and the arrest of a self-styled musician.
The Maritime Administration completed yesterday its new ship construction program for the current fiscal year by giving final approval for the building of 12 new merchant ships.
NAIROBI, Feb. 23 -- Rumors that all charter plane flights to Britain had been canceled today increased the ticket stampede until it was discovered that the rumors were misleading.
BEND, Ore., Feb. 23 -- Mayor Lindsay began a short skiing weekend today at Bachelor Butte near here by answering a question he has heard at least 100 times in Oregon: "How's the garbage, Mr. Mayor?"

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Lockheed engineers have concluded that the most efficient way to launch a rocket from a gun is to encase it in a plastic sheath containing a liquid. Once the gun is fired, the sheath falls away, the propellant ignites and the rocket continues under its own power.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Bill Ogden and Dale Douglass carded nine-under-par 135's today after two rounds to share the lead in the $100,000 Tucson open golf tournament.
Fourteen striking teachers were discharged yesterday by the Barnard School for Boys, in Riverdale, for breach of contract.

Joseph Cornell, the 64-year-old sculptor best known for his shadow boxes and collages, will receive this year's Award of Merit of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, the academy's president, George F. Kennan, announced yesterday.

A former tax collector for the Internal Revenue Service was indicted yesterday on charges of filing fraudulent documents that resulted in the Government writing off $657,000 as uncollectable taxes owed by nine persons.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The Board of Regents approved today the proposed sale of Long Island University's Brooklyn Center to the City University for the establishment of the Bernard M. Baruch College.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Robert Martin Jr. today enjoined the operators of a segregated bowling alley in racially troubled Orangeburg from operating the establishment in a discriminatory manner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The commander of the two United States destroyers in the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin incident said tonight that his ships were definitely attacked by the North Vietnamese and he denied that the attacks were provoked.

IF YOU build a better pinafore, Ceil Ainsworth has discovered, mothers who believe little girls should look ruffly and sweet will beat a path to your door. The door, in her case, is at the top of a narrow flight of stairs at 987 Lexington Avenue (near 71st Street) and bears the name, "Poupees and Pinafores."

By making public only selective portions of classified material to support its version of the Gulf of Tonkin incidents, the Pentagon has stirred justifiable anger among members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who have access to more complete information. The American Paper Institute reported yesterday that projected capacity of the industry for all types of paper and board was continuing to climb, despite warnings of overproduction and consequent weakening of prices.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 -- The New York Mets own three catchers who wear World Series rings, but none of them will be behind the bat on opening day, April 9.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- The pound slumped to its lowest level since the start of this year on the foreign exchange market today when a burst of selling from New York in the afternoon reversed an early improvement.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 23 -- After a delay of five days, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi publicly confirmed today India's intention to abide by the decision of an international tribunal on the Rann of Cutch.
ALBANY, Feb 23 -- The State Board of Regents today elected Joseph W McGovern, a New York City lawyer, as its 29th chancellor.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The American Friends Service Committee said today that it had temporarily suspended its programs in Vietnam because of the danger.

The dance series at Barnard Colleges Minor Latham Playhouse called "Dance Uptown" fills a definite need in the university community and Barnard is to be congratulated for its generous support. Increasing numbers of students are being exposed to dance as a regular part of their theatergoing, and the programs retire the belief that anything avant-garde has to take place in a drafty loft below 14th Street.

A battered, garbage-stuffed white Simca, festooned with animal entrails and designated a "work of art," was yesterday ordered removed from Riverside Park by the Department of Parks, which called it a health hazard.

An anguished Irving Mitchell Felt, close to tears and often pounding a table when recounting his troubles, admitted yesterday that his new $43-million Madison Square Garden did not offer a perfect view for many fans at hockey games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Department of Defense announced today that 48,000 men would be drafted for military service in April. This will be the highest monthly total in 18 months. In October, 1966, a total of 49,200 were inducted -- the highest monthly draft call during the Vietnam war.
Prolonged, excessive use of antacids of the kind often taken by ulcer patients can lead to serious depletion of the body's phosphorus reserves, a new study has shown.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace's doctors said today they were hopeful that surgery had cleared up all traces of cancer and that she would be able to go back to work in a month or so.
WEST END, Bahamas, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The 53-foot sloop Inferno ran hard-aground on shoals at the entrance to West End's Harbor tonight and was reported being broken to pieces by eight-foot waves.

The International Longshoremen's Association began yesterday a dockers' boycott of copper imports in support of the copper industry strike, but rescinded the boycott order a few hours later with the explanation that it had been sent out in error.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Judge William B. Jones, in United States District Court, ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation today to release data obtained by electronic surveillance bearing on Fred B. Black Jr., former associate of Robert G. Baker, once secretary to the Senate democratic majority.
Residents of the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn staged a sit-in at the area's antipoverty office yesterday to protest what they charged was political control of the antipoverty program.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 -- The nation's labor federation made it more difficult today for affiliated Unions to win exemptions from paying dues.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 23 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican of Kentucky, said today he would not seek reelection this year.

IN her recent neon structures at the Pace Gallery, 9 West 57th Street, Chryssa continues along the lines she has previously explored, but also takes off in a new direction to produce fresh, dramatic pieces that rank among the best of her work.
HONG KONG, Feb. 23 -- New unrest in Kwangtung Province has marred celebrations marking Communist China's establishment of a revolutionary committee to govern the region.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk is the Administration official who told a group of newsmen that criticism of the handling of the war in Vietnam sometimes gets to the point "when the question is, whose side are you on?"

WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King won her 20th straight match in powering her way into the semi-finals tonight in a bid for a third straight United States women's indoor championship.
MIAMI, Feb. 23 -- With United States Olympic observers on hand, Bill Roberts of Palm Beach, Fla., won both races today as the Flying Dutchman class midwinter regatta got under way.

SARITA, Tex., Feb. 23 -- For the last 10 years of her life, Mrs. Sarita Kenedy East, one of the nation's richest women and a granddaughter of an original Texas land baron, sought advice and religious solace from Brother Leo, a Trappist monk.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A one-year delay in imposing an annual ceiling of 120,000 persons on Western Hemisphere immigration to the United States was recommended today by a commission appointed by President Johnson and Congress.
Government securities prices declined slightly yesterday even though the Federal Reserve System purchased Treasury bills and some short-term coupon-bearing issues.

SANTIAGO, Chile. Feb. 23 (AP) -- The five surviving members of Ernesto Che Guevara's guerrilla band in Boliva appeared at a news conference here today and acknowledged that their attempt at insurrection had failed and that there was no immediate hope to revive it.
THE socially disturbing case of Kitty Genovese, who in March, 1964, was killed on a New York street while neighbors ignored her cry for help, was the subject of another dramatization last night.

With characteristic disregard for public opinion the legislative leaders have placed on the calendar for action early next week a bipartisan measure to redraw the lines of the state's 41 Congressional districts. SAIGON, Saturday, Feb. 24 (AP) -- South Vietnamese troops stormed a main enemy stronghold inside Hue's walled Citadel this morning and raised their colors in place of a Vietcong flag that had flown over the old Imperial Palace since Jan. 31, the United States command reported.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The House of Commons decided in principle today to end the censorship that has guarded the English stage for nearly 400 years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The hostess who falls apart if the bartender is a little late could take a lesson from the Russians, who threw a party tonight at their embassy despite a few problems.

In the century since the Civil War New York State has had five Constitutional Conventions. Only the convention of 1894 succeeded in getting the voters to adopt its product -- and that document represented few, if any, substantial changes from the charter it sought to revise.
WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 23 -- Daily double players with the right combination cashed in on a $475.60 mutuel tonight, the largest payoff of the winter harness session at Roosevelt Raceway.

An office building will soon rise from the mass of rubble that once was the Astor Hotel, covering the memories of many New Yorkers who knew the Astor as the center of Broadway, or even as the center of their youth.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Mayor Joseph Alioto announced a tentative settlement today of the 51-day-old strike on San Francisco's two newspapers, the longest in the city's history.
FREEPORT, L. I., Feb. 23 -- A "phenomenal" flock of 14 exotic looking harlequin ducks, rarely seen south of Massachusetts, was spotted today in the surf at Point Lookout, off Jones Beach Inlet.
BUFFALO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Three members of Dr. Leslie A. Fiedler's family and a teenager pleaded guilty today charges of possessing marijuana or barbiturates.
Another high official of Harper Row has resigned in the company's executive shake-up. He is Richard B. McAdoo, vice president and general manager of the publishing house's general books division.

President Johnson's special task force on travel has come up with a proposal everyone can applaud for closing the "tourist gap" and easing the balance of payments problem it creates. The plan's goal is to encourage more foreigners to visit the United States. The President has helped out by his request to Congress to relax visa requirements for certain friendly countries.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 24 -- North Vietnamese forces clashed with South Vietnamese rangers last night at Khesanh after the United States Marine outpost there was raked with its heaviest bombardment so far.

RICHMOND, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. ruled in a heavily guarded courtroom today that H. Rap Brown, the black power leader, had violated the conditions of his $10,000 bond and ordered him to pay the bond "forthwith."
AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 23 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to do away with visa requirements for tourists and businessmen from certain nations who wished to travel in the United States.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, the Soviet Defense Minister, declared today that the Soviet Union had deployed an "enormous" force of intercontinental nuclear missiles.
Last year, the St. John's track team talked about the Metropolitan intercollegiate track meet for two months and finished second to Manhattan.

TORONTO, Feb. 23 -- The Mercantile Bank of Canada, the First National City Bank of New York's subsidiary, which is thinking small these days, has just reported a $205,000 operating profit in 1967, said to be the bank's first such profit since it was established in 1953 by Dutch interests.

Of the interpretations and reinterpretations of "Hamlet" there is no end. Joseph Papp and his New York Shakespeare Festival have been setting the town and especially some of the city's educators on their cars by offering a drastically revised and truncated version of the tragedy, which is part rock 'n' roll, part hippie and almost all contemporary theater of the absurd.
Spokesmen for New York's thoroughbred horsemen, strongly opposed to legislative plans to increase the pari-mutuel tax, failed yesterday to get the state's ear.
Residents of Chinatown won a round yesterday in their fight to preserve the old Fifth Precinct police station on Elizabeth Street.

The Prague Quartet, a string ensemble of quality that has remained virtually unknown to New Yorker's despite two previous tours in the United States appeared in Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum last night to play a choice program, expertly and attractively.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- A brilliant performance by Wilt Chamberlain sparked the Philadelphia 76ers to a 138-117 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight in a National Basketball Association game at the Spectrum.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Government ordered an immediate and complete freeze today on sales of refined copper to anyone except military contractors.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A march by 1,000 striking garbage workers erupted in violence today, but the police moved in with night sticks and gas guns and quickly quelled the distrubance.

I should like to comment on the adverse and wide publicity given in your paper recently to the proposed abolition by the Mayor of the city marshals and say a word in their defense. At the same time I suggest that our Mayor look into the facts a little further.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Richard M. Nixon predicted today that the Soviet Union would achieve strategic power equal to that of the United States within two years unless the present Administration changed its policy or the country got new leadership.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 23 -- The young men in Army uniforms come into the city looking for excitement in the beer lounges or movie theaters along Main Street much as they have since nearby Fort Jackson opened as a training camp more than 50 years ago.
The Parke-Bernet Galleries has filed a suit for damages of $14,771 against a man who successfully bid $445,500 for 10 paintings but who has not paid for them.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 23 -- Columbia's sixth-ranked basketball team solved Brown's zone defense in the second half and breezed to a 73-45 Ivy League, victory tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 -- The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, which has been operating for two months despite a strike, filled its second page today with a list of what it called 150 cases of violence against the paper and its nonunion substitute workers.
Several streams of contemporary music flowed together last night at Carnegie Recital Hall in the course of a concert by the Gary Burton Quartet.
A rate reduction on coffee shipments from Brazil to United States Gulf ports is being watched with interest here by lines active in this trade.
Charges that two patrolmen had accepted Christmas gratuities were dismissed yesterday after the security manager of a Fifth Avenue department store denied he had given them money.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -- The full day of rain that reared its ugly head throughout Florida today disrupted a carefully wrought program of auto racing at Daytona International Speedway.
A British builder who plans to put a second $100-million skyscraper on top of Grand Central Terminal has appointed the noted architect Marcel Breuer to design the project.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 23 -- A Superior Court judge said today that he was "flabbergasted" to learn that a contested sum of $168,000 on deposit in the Hudson County National Bank here was not drawing interest.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Billy Gaines, a 19-year-old high school sprinter, won the national 60-yard championship tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union indoor games and then was ordered home with a 102-degree fever.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- The Brae Burn Curling Club No. 2 rink of West Newton, Mass., skipped by Frank McDonough, defeated St. Andrew's C.C. No. 1, skipped by W. Lincoln Seibert, the 1967 winner, 12-10, in an extra-end match today in the 13th annual St. Andrew's invitation mixed bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club.
ARLINGTON, Va., Feb. 23 (Reuters) -- John Patler, convicted of killing George Lincoln Rockwell, leader of the American Nazi party, was sentenced today to 20 years in prison.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 23 -- The back country of North Vietnam is prepared for a long war. It offers a secure refuge from the bombing for the administrative, industrial, cultural, scholastic and health organizations of the Red River delta and the southern provinces.

MARCEL BREUER did not make up his mind right away about whether he wanted to design a new tower to rise over Grand Central Terminal. THESE 16 essays, presented by a group of scholars to honor a member of their guild at the University of Southern California, have a great deal of charm, are wonderfully relaxing, and are entertaining in the best sense. Sales and earnings of the Union Carbide Corporation fell sharply last year from levels attained in 1966, it was announced here yesterday.
