SANTA FE, N.M., Feb. 26 -- Gov. David F. Cargo refused today to accede to a teacher demand that he call the State Legislature into a special session to revise school financing. The Governor said, however, that he was optimistic that a statewidc strike of teachers would be avoided.
FROM Massachusetts to Maryland a growing population of mute swans is bringing pleasure to some people and displeasure to others.

The American Electric Power Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for approval of its proposed acquisition of the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company through an exchange of stock valued at about $272-million.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) -- The Selective Service director Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, told local draft boards today that they could grant deferments to students at two-year colleges and vocational schools.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 -- A nationwide organization of prominent businessmen is about to step up its pressure on the Administration for a shift to a policy of de-escalation and disengagement in Vietnam.
A Detroit television station cut the last stanza of an anti-war song performed by Pete Seeger Sunday night on "The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour" on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

The University of Houston, looking more spectacular on the basketball court than at the ballot box, was named the No. 1 major college team for the sixth straight week yesterday, but the unbeaten Cougars had their lead trimmed by the University of California, Los Angeles.

GARY, Ind., Feb. 26 -- Mayor Richard G. Hatcher called on the private sector here today to furnish $300,000 in matching funds to help promote new and small businesses in slum areas. He said the money would be used along with $600,000 in Federal funds, as part of a program for small business.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26 -- A 21-year-old tourist arrested in December has written a bitter open letter from his prison cell dnouncing the NTS, an emigre subversive organization, and expressing scorn of dissident intellectuals convicted in Moscow last month of anti-Soviet activities.

The inhabitants of New York City are undoubtedly the most tolerant citizens of the Western world. If there is any physical discomfort, human inconvenience or affront to the dignity of man that they will refuse to put up with, it has yet to be devised.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The nation's unfavorable balance-of-payments situation would be even more serious were it not for the money earned by the United States merchant marine, according to a statistical study made public today by the Committee of American Steamship Lines.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 26 -- Iraq's four highest-ranking army officers were removed today from their military posts and appointed to civilian positions under decrees issued by President Abdel Rahman Arif and broadcast by Baghdad.
The city, after two years of opposition, agreed yesterday to put into contract form what more than 100,000 city employes have come to expect every summer -- a shorter work day from June to September.

READER response has long indicated that sports fans are fascinated by any election to any hall of fame. Because emotionalism was involved in the naming by the baseball writers of Joe Medwick in his last go-around, his recent choice cornered most of the attention. But the old-timers' committee met a few days later and voted two other outfielders, Goose Goslin and Kiki Cuyler, into Cooperstown.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Department of State disputed today two lines of criticism by Senator J. W. Fulbright in his continuing battle with the Administration over the Gulf of Tonkin incidents in 1964.
Both sides in Nigeria have their backs up again with the result that "this sad and senseless war," as the Archbishop of West Africa aptly calls it, seems farther than ever from the peace table.
DETROIT, Feb. 26 -- The Ford Motor Company recalled 41,000 of its 1968 Falcon, Fairlane, Montego cars and Ranchero station wagon for correction of a possible safety defect.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 27 -- North Vietnamese troops mauled a United States Marine patrol and blocked a rescue platoon 800 yards outside the combat base at Khesanh yesterday.

SAIGON, Feb. 27 -- A United States Special Forces patrol ambushed an enemy battalion spearheaded by three armored vehicles yesterday near them Cambodian border about 45 miles northwest of Saigon, a spokesman for the American command announced today.

When a group named the New York Baroque Ensemble plays a program of seven works, all written since 1954 and including Varese's "Density 21.5," that group must be awarded points for industry and its willingness to dabble in the post-Telemann era.

Herbert Blau, -who served as co-director with Jules Irving of the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater from 1965 to 1967, has signed a five-year contract for the positions of academic vice president of the California Institute of the Arts and dean of its School of the Theater.
PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Feb. 26 -- Yes, there really are "new Nixons" in 1968 -- but only one of them can vote.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The Government indicated today that it would not give way to protests against its proposal for new restrictions on colored immigraton.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 26 -- More of Florida's striking public school teachers returned to their classrooms today, but the Florida Education Association contended that the statewide walkout was holding its own as it went into its second week.

The Real Great Society, Inc., a self-help group started by reformed leaders of Puerto Rican fighting gangs four years ago, gave out the good word yesterday -- a $258,447 grant from the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity.

ROME, Feb. 26 -- France and Germany were in disagreement today as Common Market finance ministers sought a united position on border taxes, an issue that has threatened to set off new trade hostilities between the United States and Europe.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Proclaiming good health "a fundamental human right," Governor Rockefeller outlined tonight a program of compulsory health insurance that he will present to the Legislature next week.

HUE, South Vietnam -- The war in Vietnam usually evokes a picture of combat in steaming heat. The United States Marines who fought the battle of Hue, however, shivered for three weeks in wet, penetrating cold.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) -- Legislation to protect the nation's environment and natural resources was introduced in the Senate today.

The Department of Commerce said yesterday that its order to copper refiners reserving all production for defense use would remain in effect "indefinitely" even though the International Longshoremen's Association had resumed handling of imported shipments.

IT BECOMES increasingly clear that one of the most crucial things Negroes have been systematically denied in this country is a usable past. By that I mean a sense of history that acts to confirm a self-respecting identity, to verify participation in the shaping of history and to provide the requisite psychological base for effective political action.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Senate debated today the aesthetics of architecture, and narrowly passed a measure that would "encourage excellence of architectural design" in public housing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -Grover Loening, an aviation pioneer, challenged today the emphasis on speed that produces supersonic airliners but no swift intercity air transportation.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 26 -- The Johnson Administration today enlisted organized labor in its program to provide jobs in private industry for the hard-core unemployed.

WARSAW, Feb. 26 (AP) -Eva Klobukovska said today that her boy friend laughs at suggestions that she may not be completely female and the Polish Track and Field Federation said it would protest the decision to withdraw ratification of her world records and medals.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Senator Mike Mansfield urged the Administration today to give preference to "escalating our peace efforts" over expected military requests for more American troops in Vietnam.

Apartheid, in origin a Dutch word meaning separateness, is a political policy that the Government of South Africa has followed since 1948. As a policy it is defined officially as "separate racial development." As a practice it means separation of the races.
CAIRO..Feb. 26 (UPI)--The Government announced today that it was closing five universities and other, institUtlons of 'higher learning in the wake of severe student demonstrations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 -- South Vietnamese military sources said today that Lieut. Gen. Vinh Loc, commander of the II Corps area, had been removed from his post. He is the second of the four powerful corps commanders in the country to be ousted in the last few days.
Consumers really are converters because they produce "raw materials" when they empty tin cans and throw the containers into the garbage can. The trash heaps of America could be mined for metals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee took a cautious move toward a tighter monetary policy, with one member, Sherman J. Maisel, dissenting, at its meeting of Dec. 12, it was disclosed today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 26 -The Nassau County Board of Supervisors abandoned plans today for the proposed $74-million John F. Kennedy Education, Civic and Cultural Center at the former Mitchel air force base.
The candidacy of former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama currently threatens to take more votes away from any Republican than from President Johnson, according to the latest Harris Survey.
A MAINBOCHER dress is like a security blanket. An expensive one, of course, but to the women who can afford the four-figure price tag, the peace of mind is worth every penny.
Stock market prices fell sharply yesterday as the list made a broad decline in slower trading.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 26 (AP) -- For the first time in modern Alabama history, two Negro candidates became the party's delegates to the Democratic National Convention and neither had opposition, Robert Vance, the state chairman, said today.
A carton containing 4,000 signed city payroll checks has been stolen from the City Controller's office, authorities disclosed yesterday.

When Red Holzman replaced Dick McGuire as the coach of the New York Knickerbockers on Dec. 27, the Madison Square Garden Corporation hoped the team would make the Eastern Division playoffs in the National Basketball Association and help fill some dates at the new $43-million Garden to pay some of the bills.

In the face of increasing evidence that noise levels here are too high for comfort or health, the City Council's Committee on Buildings held hearings yesterday that may result in the first limits being set here on the sound level of construction equipment.

American Standard, Inc., is expanding into the home-building business through the purchase of the William and Leon Lyon enterprise in Los Angeles for stock valued at about $12-million, it was disclosed yesterday.
PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Hawthorne Circle, a major confluence of roads in Westchester notorious for its molasses-like traffic flow, will undergo a $22.1-million, three-year modernization.
HYDERABAD, India, Feb. 26 -- A legal battle is under way for what remains of the wealth of the late Nizam of Hyderabad, once thought to be the richest man in the world.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 -- The Vietcong radio has indicated that Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, North Vietnam's Defense Minister, is commanding the offensive in South Vietnam from Hanoi.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A top Treasury official challenged today virtually every argument that the American travel industry has made against the travel tax proposed by the Administration -- including one that he said was based on an error in "simple arithmetic."
Prices declined yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in moderate trading. The session was marked by selective trading that left the day's most active list mixed.

ORANGEBURG, S.C., Feb. 26 -- Some 1,500 Negro students, their arms filled with books and their eyes warry of passing whites, eturned this morning to college. The college closed 19 days ago after the students clashed with the police.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Legislature today perfunctorily approved a bipartisan plan that reshapes New York's Congressional districts for the national election next fall.
A sniper in the Bushwick Highland housing project in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday wounded a man standing near a liquor store after firing two shots into the store.

Timothy J. Cooney, an assistant administrator of Housing and Development Administration, resigned yesterday, saying that "I no longer have any faith that hard work within the government is going to make much difference in improving slums."

The Taylor Law, designed to prevent civil service strikes and to secure fairness to the public and public employes, has failed to accomplish both aims. It has not prevented strikes of civil service workers and has not assured fairness or impartiality to the New York State employes who are members of the Civil Service Employes Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A Federal Court jury has awarded $960,000 to the Kellogg Corporation of Battle Creek, Mich., for the loss of an executive jet plane that crashed off Freeport, Bahamas, last Nov. 21.
The General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains of 7 1/2 per cent in 1967 gross revenues, with sales running 7 per cent higher and net income up 6 1/2 per cent.
The Police Department has agreed to expunge from its records the arrest of 87 high school and college students who had been charged with assembling to use narcotics.
Benny Goodman will stage and perform in a benefit concert at Philharmonic Hall March 17 to aid the New York University Medical Center.
Indicated fourth-quarter earnings of the Boeing Company climbed to $1.08 a share from 79 cents in the 1966 period, according to the aircraft maker's year-end report, released yesterday.
Albany County postponed yesterday a $70-million bond sale scheduled for this morning to help finance the South Mall expansion of New York State's Capitol.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The tangled gray locks of Everett McKinley Dirksen have been washed once again in the sort of sudsy soft-soap that only the Senate of the United States can lather up. Louis Schein, a Bronx real estate man, has refused to tell a grand jury if he was either threatened with death or beaten up by a reputed Mafia leader who had allegedly lent him $5,000.

A decline in demand for color television sets was primarily responsible for the $3,770,061 net loss in 1967 reported yesterday by the Admiral Corporation, a Chicago television and appliance manufacturer. In 1966 the company had a net profit of $10,016,963 or $1.96 a share.

The sanitationmen's union, citing sharply increased productivity, injury hazards and the "strenuosity" of the job, said yesterday that sanitation workers deserved a raise of $3,486.16 a year.
The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday its television schedule for next season. It included several changes from the one sent out last week to advertising agencies.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 27 -- There were growing indications today that the mission to Korea by the Swedish Ambassador to Pakistan, Lieut. Gen. Lennart Finnmark, is more than routine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -Wire services and syndicates impose "unconscionable restrictions" that have made it almost impossible to start a new daily newspaper in competition with existing papers, O. Roy Chalk, the publisher, told a Senate subcommittee today.

Jacob K. Javits begins his campaign for a third term in the United States Senate from an almost invulnerable position. He has repeatedly demonstrated in past elections that he can hold normal Republican voters and also draw heavily from among the Democrats and independents. There are no signs that either his personal popularity or his prowess as a campaigner has diminished.

A VERY sad and very sick self - styled "comedy" called "Carry Me Back to Morningside Heights" arrived at the John Golden Theater last night. Morningside Heights might indeed have been one thing; West 45th Street proved quite another.
United Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that it had record earnings last year and that it became the first air carrier to pass the $1-billion mark in yearly revenues.

BEN ZUCKERMAN is "taking a rest" until May in Palm Beach. Leon Frechtel is planning a trip around the world, after which he may go into teaching or legal work.

The Radio Corporation of America confirmed yesterday its year-end prediction that sales in 1967 would top the $3-billion level for the first time, while profits would be "slightly higher'' than in 1966.

ROME, Feb. 27 -- An Italian parliamentary committee voted today, in effect, in favor of taxing the dividends on the shares held by the Vatican. The issue could imperil the center-left coalition led by the Christian Democrats.
DALLAS, Feb. 27 -- President Johnson said here today that the Vietnam war stood at a turning point and that Americans at home, like those fighting the war, must not retreat.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 27 -The 1,280-member National Association of Harness Drivers warned today of a statewide boycott of trotting tracks if Governor Rockefeller's bill dealing with the disposition of pari-mutuel takeout money became law.

ORANGEBURG, S. C., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Officials at South Carolina State College said today that conditions had apparently returned to normal at the predominantly Negro school after a two-week disruption caused by racial violence.

GENEVA, Feb. 27 -- Emmerich Danzer, the titleholder, took a slight lead today over Tim Wood, a 19-year-old pre-law student from Bloomfield Hills, Mich., at the start of the world figure skating championships.
A Harlem elementary school teacher was dismissed yesterday for having taken his class to the antiwhite program in memory of Malcolm X held at Intermediate School 201.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -Garbage workers and civil-rights leaders marched on City Hall today, seeking once more to have the City Council intervene in the 16-day-old sanitation strike.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- The Illinois Democratic organization headed by Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago passed over Adlai E. Stevenson 3d and Sargent Shriver today as candi dates for Senator or Governor.
FOUR players who organized a team at the last possible moment captured the Knockout Team Championship in the George Washington Birthday tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association.

MIAMI, Feb. 28 -- The Black Helen Handicap, the richest race for fillies and mares on the Florida thoroughbred racing calendar, will have its 26th running tomorrow. The race, at a mile and an eighth, has attracted a field of 10, including the Rokeby Stables entry of Green Glade and Prides Profile.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A House Interior subcommittee approved today a change in water guarantees to California that appeared likely to break the deadlock over the controversial multibillion-dollar Central Arizona Project.

Governor Rockefeller's $1.1-billion construction program for hospitals, both public and private, and for nursing homes and other health centers corrects an earlier legislative drafting oversight and looks boldly toward meeting the desperate need for additional health facilities.
SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Reies Lopez Tijerina was convicted today of criminal contempt of Federal court and sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $500.
Today is Ash Wednesday, the first day of Lent, the 40 days of prayer and meditation in churches that precede Easter.
The story carried on Feb. 18 by John H. Fenton under a Boston dateline correctly quoted The Boston Globe's listing of the Richmond Times-Dispatch as "dovish" on Vietnam, but The Globe was in error.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The House of Commons approved in principle tonight the Government's bill to reduce Asian immigration. The vote was 372 to 62.
Bernard B. Zients, president of Gimbels New York and suburban stores, has been named co-chairman of the 1968 General Campaign of the American Cancer Society's New York City Division.
The news that large law firms on Wall Street and around the country will pay beginning lawyers about $15,000 starting salary a year is bad news for the legal profession.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara confirmed today that a psychiatiric examination had been given to a Navy officer who had discussed the Gulf of Tonkin incidents of 1964 with Senator J. W. Fulbright.

All four works that the Clarion Concerts Orchestra played last night at Town Hall were first New York performances. One composer, Benjamin Lees, turned up in the audience to take bows after his "Concertante Breve," but the others could not make it; Heinrich Ignaz Franz von Biber (1644-1704), Francesco Geminiani (1687-1762) and Pietro Nardini (1722-1793).
The stock market made a narrow recovery in light trading yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The United States today underscored its serious concern about the increasing pace of North Vietnamese and pro-Communist Pathet Lao offensives in the panhandle of Laos adjacent to the Central Highlands of South Vietnam.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 -The Los Angeles County Assessment Appeals Board ruled today that Gov. Ronald Reagan had been getting an unwarranted tax discount of more than 80 per cent on his Malibu mountain ranch property.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Nino Benvenuti of Italy, who contends a cracked rib led to his defeat by Emile Griffith last September, said today he was perfectly fit for his third middleweight title fight next Monday night in Madison Square Garden.

In Wagner's "Lohengrin" given by the Metropolitan Opera last night, three principal roles were taken by singers who had not appeared in them here previously this season: Leonie Rysanek, who was Elsa, Christa Ludwig, the Ortrud, and William Dooley, Telramund.
PARIS, Feb. 27 -- At this time of year, a dry wind known as the harmattan sweeps down from the Sahara and shrouds West Africa in a haze of fine dust.

The New York Knickerbockers staged one of their typical rallies last night, but it fell short and they bowed to the St. Louis Hawks, 108-102, in a National Basketball Association game before 14,009 fans at Madison Square Garden.

James Reston's Jan. 24 column discussing the controversy among Harvard "action-intellectuals" over Robert Kennedy's proper role in the coming Presidential campaign reflects the degeneration of liberalism as a viable political philosophy in contemporary America.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The first thing Sargent Shriver is reported to have said to an employe early this morning was: "Well, I've got to learn French."
On cold days the kindergarten children at P.S. 178 in the Ocean Hill Brownsville section of Brooklyn have to wear sweaters and coats in class.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 27 -- Mrs. Lucy G. Moses, New York philanthropist, has given $750,000 to Yale University for a chair in music. It will bear the name of Mrs. Moses and her late husband, Henry L. Moses, Yale '00.

THE table settings that go on view today on Tiffany's second and third floors are not the usual luncheon and dinner place settings the store presents periodically. The eight displays are concerned with the arrangement of objects on table tops and shelves. Using crystal, china and silver from the store, with a few new pieces tucked in by way of introduction, the imaginative settings range from a bathroom to a bar.
JACKSON, Miss., Wednesday, Feb. 28 -- Charles Evers, the Negro civil rights leader, ran ahead of six white segregationist opponents yesterday in his race for the Third District Congressional seat.
A drop of 4 per cent in manufacturers' capital appropriations from the third to the fourth quarter in 1967 has created a doubt about the status of industrial expansion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -The United States balance of international payments improved markedly in January and European countries lost $1-billion of their reserves of gold and dollars, it was reliably disclosed today.

When Pharoah Sanders, a jazz saxophonist, has appeared as a sideman with groups led by John Coltrane, Archie Shepp and others, he has usually presented himself as an exponent of sheer noise as an element of music. other, more traditional side to his playing.
Two weeks ago the International Olympic Committee, comprising representatives of all nations participating in the Olympics, voted to allow South Africa to compete in the Summer Games at Mexico City.

DURING his long television career Red Skelton has displayed remarkable intuitive gifts for pantomime. But always lurking beneath the surface has been his relish for slapstick comedy. Last night, in a taped performance of an appearance before delegates to the United Nations, the extremes of expression, collided, and his program, seen over the Columbia Broadcasting System, failed to qualify winningly on either count.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Feb. 27 -- Preliminary results of a new vaccine against influenza indicate that it causes fewer side effects than previous antiflu agents, scientists said today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Embassy staff in Washington observed "strange activities of unknown persons" near the embassy on the eve of the recent bomb explosion there, Pravda reported today.

Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, the runner-up for the United States grass-court championship at Forest Hills last September and also for the national indoor title at Salisbury, Md., this month, has replaced Arthur Ashe in the Long Island indoor tennis tournament.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A move to call a special meeting of the International Olympic Committee to discuss the 32-nation boycott caused by South Africa's readmission to the games is building up, Olympic officals said today.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller today proposed a "revolutionary" multibilliondollar plan to create a special corporation with "drastic" powers to override cities' regulations when necessary, to rebuild slums.

Once again the metals held center stage in futures trading yesterday. Platinum and palladium caught attention with significant increases, and a reason was that the Soviet Union stood in the wings, apparently once again a reluctant seller hoping to force prices still higher.

William Filler, chairman and president of Terminal-Hudson Electronics, Inc., said in a statement yesterday that neither the company nor any of its officers or directors was in any way involved in the manipulative practices alleged in a Federal indictment returned Monday.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 -- A rugged young Australian aboriginal named Lionel Rose, hitherto little known outside the boxing rings of his native land, became the bantamweight champion of the world tonight by defeating Masahiko (Fighting) Harada of Japan by a unanimous decision in 15 rounds.
TORONTO, Feb. 27 -- By flexing its monetary muscles publicly, the Government of Canada is trying to restore international confidence in the Canadian dollar.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 -- A dozen Soviet intellectuals, defying warnings from the state security police, have appealed to Communists of the world "to consider the peril caused by the trampling on man in our country."
GENEVA, Feb. 27 -- India denounced as inadequate today a draft proposed by the United States and the Soviet Union for a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

Woodstock College, a Jesuit seminary in Maryland, announced plans yesterday to move to Morningside Heights and to share facilities with Union Theological Seminary, Jewish Theological Seminary and various secular institutions, including Columbia University.
Editorial employes of The New York Post voted, 89 to 67, last night to strike the paper at 5 A.M. Friday unless a dispute over some elements of a new contract were resolved by then.

New Yorkers need a comprehensive state health program that will provide good care, both in and out of hospitals, for all. The existing pattern of public and private plans -- including Medicaid, Medicare and programs set up through collective bargaining -- is a hodge-podge that provides excellent care for many citizens but leaves many others gravely underprotected.
BUDAPEST, Feb. 27 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that a conference of Communist parties of the world take place next November or December, and Moscow was suggested as its site.
SOPHIE is a designer who frequently walks alone. Occasionally, she joins her colleagues in fashion on their new and sometimes strange roads, but she is happier going her own way.
THE SHARES of Gillette grabbed the Big Board spotlight yesterday and in doing so accounted for the third largest dollar trade in exchange history.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--President Johnson laid before Congress today a broad program designed to give more Federal protection to farmers and more social and economic opportunities to rural America.
Jack Nicklaus recommended yesterday more variety in golf competition so that a greater audience could be obtained.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The copper strike has given the Administration a tough, three-dimensional problem.
A portrait of Washington by Gilbert Stuart was taken last Sunday night or early Monday morning from a university building at Clarkson College of Technology in Potsdam, N. Y.

The regional home loan banks, which provide reserve credit to the savings and loan industry, are moving to increase their lending rates. In addition to the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago, which raised its lending rate to 5 3/4 from 5 1/2 per cent late last year, banks in Cincinnati, Indianapolis and New York have also moved up to 5 3/4 from 5 1/2 per cent.

GIOACCHINO ROSSINI'S life was marked by enormous successes, great rewards, international fame, veneration and adulation. It is a pleasure to read about all of them. There was no Sturm und Drang in Rossini's musical life. He was a star composer by his mid 20's; he was adored in Italy, Austria, England and France.

TO those who love fine Italian food, the word "marinara" conjures odoriferous joys: garlic, tomatoes, olive oil, oregano, and such. Literally translated, marinara means in the style of the mariner, probably a reference to the dishes that sailors make quickly aboard ship or at the wharf, with the limited ingredients on hand.
HAVANA, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Cuban ship involved in an incident off the Virginia coast today is part of Cuba's national fishing fleet, the Foreign Ministry said.

The lucrative smell of money fills the cramped storefront offices of the Terminal Trading Company at 70 West 23d Street here, where a modern version of the ancient art of exchanging "new lamps for old" takes place each day.

PARIS -- The reason we are now in such a mess in Vietnam is that we haven't yet recognized the kind of war we are fighting and therefore haven't yet adjusted our strategy to the enemy's. The United States is engaged in a military campaign aided by various kinds of new devices and tactics.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The British Government plans to underwrite production of the Concorde, the British-French supersonic airliner, with a loan of $180-million to $240-million for working capital. A similar French loan appears likely.
The City Council passed a law yesterday to forbid "deceptive advertising practices" in newspapers, magazines, pamphlets and handbills. It was the second time that it had passed such legislation.
PARIS, Feb. 27 -- The prosecution today demanded terms of one to five years for 19 young Guadeloupe intellectuals for advocating independence for the West Indian island.
Mental health insurance, which has been abandoned by many carriers as too costly, will be offered this year to the 750,000 subscribers of the Health Insurance plan of Greater New York.
Two men using forged documents yesterday took $508,351 in palladium that had been shipped here to KLM Royal Dutch Airlines at Kennedy International Airport.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Feb. 27 -- Three Cubans seeking political asylum seized a 292-foot Cuban ship today but were thwarted in an attempt to bring her into Norfolk because they could not get the anchor up, United States Coast Guard crewmen related.
The trading pace slowed markedly yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as prices edged to higher ground.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27 -- In a bare-walled, well-lighted press room adjacent to the dressing quarters of the New York Yankees in Fort Lauderdale Stadium today, Mickey Mantle posed for pictures and offered good advice to the photographers as he signed a Yankee contract for the 18th time.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 27 -- Still another search is on for a workable compromise on the language question, the most dangerous and inflammatory issue in Indian political life.

Roy Gussow, a well-established sculptor whose work is much in demand, has been awarded a commission by the Xerox Corporation for a monumental stainless steel sculpture to be erected in Xerox Square, Rochester, N.Y., at the entrance of the company's new headquarters.
A State Supreme Court justice barred reporters and the public from a pretrial hearing of a criminal case yesterday in accord with news restrictions recently adopted by the American Bar Assciation.
DETROIT, Feb. 27 (UPI) -The United Auto Workers went on strike at a General Motors Corporation assembly plant today for the first time this year.

CAIRO, Feb. 27 -- Egyptian policemen and dissident students were at an apparent standoff today after a wave of student demonstrations. The students were protesting the Government's relatively lenient treatment of air force officers who are widely considered to blame for the Egyptian defeat in the war against Israel.

As a story, the news article by Nan Robertson, "Marines Salute Their Women," Feb. 13, is excellent. What it reveals about the mentality of the Marine Corps officers administering "boot training" for women at Parris Island is disturbing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Communist China's trade with non-Communist countries increased considerably in 1966, Secretary of State Dean Rusk reported to Congress today.
Dick Gregory, the comedian who is active in the civil rights and anti-war movements, will begin a 40-day fast here today in protest against the United States involvement in the war in Vietnam.
BOB BEATTIE, the personable head coach of the Olympic Alpine ski team, has no excuses for the failure of his charges to win a medal at the Winter Games at Grenoble, France.

The unions involved in the marathon copper strike seem bent on compelling President Johnson to do the thing they profess to want least: obtain an eighty-day injunction under the national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Three major pharmaceutical companies -- the American Cyanamid Company, the Bristol-Myers Company and Chas. Pfizer Co. -- were each fined $150,000 yesterday for conspiring to control the manufacture, sale and distribution of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
Here are highlights of the two-phase transportation program recommended to Governor Rockefeller by the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Agency.
R. W. Pressprich Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, will change from a partnership to a corporation tomorrow.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 28 -- The Government has asked the National Assembly to raise the reward for information leading to the arrest of Communist agents from 200,000 won to a million won or $3,700, each.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Lew Alcindor and two of his basketball teammates at the University of California, Los Angeles, emphasized today that academic problems had prompted their rejection of an invitation to try out for the Olympic team.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Two further indications of continuing strong inflationary pressures in the economy were reported by the Census Bureau today in its monthly publication, Business Cycle Developments.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- Soviet intellectuals were chided today by a Moscow newspaper for having sent it letters criticizing the trial last month of four Soviet dissident intellectuals.
The Campbell Soup Company had record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended Jan. 28, it was reported from Camden, N. J., yesterday by W. B. Murphy, president.
At most airline terminals, pretty girls or unpretty machines sell trip insurance -- just in case.
AT 74 Wooster Street, a dingy seven-story building barely distinguishable in the somber crush of warehouses and small factories, burials and exhumations are held regularly.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 28 -- Earl (the Pearl) Monroe put on a one-man show tonight in the Civic Center. The fabulous rookie from Winston-Salem College scored 40 points against the New York Knicks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- The problem of noisy airplanes and sonic booms will get worse before it improves, Donald F. Hornig, Presidential science adviser, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A panel of United States judges has proposed rules for press coverage of Federal cases that would be less restrictive than those approved last week by the American Bar Association.

BY now, Joao Carlos Martins must feel that he owns the Piano Concerto by Alberto Ginastera. The young Brazilian pianist, now 27 years old, played the world premiere of the work in 1961. Then he introduced it to New York the following year. Then he played it once again in New York in 1966. And last night he did it again, in Philharmonic Hall with the Boston Symphony conducted by Erich Leinsdorf.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 28 -- The governing Institutional Revolutionary party has named a new leader as part of a shake-up that has followed important electoral defeats.
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 28 -- King Faisal said today that Saudi Arabia would resume aid to the royalists in Yemen.

Three civil antitrust suits seeking triple damages were filed yesterday in Federal Court by seven public utilities against six manufacturers of brass tubing and pipes, charging a conspiracy to fix prices in restraint of trade between 1958 and 1960.
MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 28 -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon was caught by surprise today when Gov. George Romney of Michigan suddenly removed himself from the Republican Presidential race.
GENEVA, Feb. 28 -- The husband and wife team of Oleg Protopopov and Ludmilla Belousova won the world pairs figure skating championship for the fourth consecutive time tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Mayor Lindsay appealed today to a Senate committee to appropriate extra money to provide summer jobs for New York City's "500,000 teenagers who are released to the streets in summer after school closes."
John W. Brooks, 50 years old, was named yesterday chief executive officer of Celanese Corporation, a leading chemical manufacturer.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1967.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Wayne Morse charged today that Navy messages prior to the incident in the Gulf of Tonkin on Aug. 4, 1964, demonstrated that the Navy was intent on "bloodying the nose" of North Vietnam.
Columbia University yesterday surrendered all rights to the Strickman cigarette filter to a charitable foundation organized to advance medical research and education.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- For more than 14 years Mohammed Khan worked in the Ministry of Public Works in Kenya.

The ultimate $2.9-billion cost of the projected comprehensive transportation plan announced yesterday would be financed by bond issue funds, private investments, public authority contributions and Federal aid.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Six plumbing concerns pleaded no contest yesterday to charges of price-fixing and were fined a total of $150,000 by a Federal judge.
The Board of Education has invited the governing board for the Intermediate School 201 demonstration project to meet with it tomorrow.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Bob Cremins sank five free throws in the final 45 seconds tonight to give South Carolina an 87-86 upset victory over third-ranked North Carolina.

If the Port of New York Authority were not developing multimillion-dollar ocean cargo facilities at Newark and Elizabeth, shipping commerce would be moving from this port to such rival gateway cities as Baltimore, Norfolk, Boston and Philadelphia, Austin J. Tobin declared yesterday.
Seven religious organizations filed a brief with a Federal Court yesterday supporting the Federal Communications Commission's new rules to strengthen its "fairness doctrine."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 -Grand Master Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., a six-time United States chess champion, and the Czechoslovak star, Vlastimil Hort, drew their games last night at the Herman Steiner Chess Club.
A major policy dispute between the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the Federal Reserve Board in Washington was disclosd in the bank's annual report yesterday.

Tests conducted by Columbia University on Robert L. Strickman's cigarette filter indicate that the material used in it is somewhat better than cellulose acetate, the most widely used commercial filter material, in removing tars and nicotine from cigarette smoke.

R. Heath Larry, executive vice president and assistant to the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, and Edgar B. Speer, executive vice president for production, have been nominated as directors.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Britain's organized labor movement split almost down the middle today on the issue of voluntary wage restraint. The Trades Union Congress, at a conference of 163 unions on wage policy, won only slim approval for its voluntary program.

The increasing clouds of dirt rising from the demolation of buildings has led the city to consider a requirement that such buildings be enclosed in a plastic cocoon connected to a giant vacuum cleaner that would gather the airborne debris.
Governor Rockefeller's $6billion plan for rebuilding city slums drew mixed reactions yesterday, most of them focused on the sweeping authority he had proposed to override local obstacles.

A sweeping $2.9-billion blueprint for expanding the city's subway system and overhauling other mass-transit in the area was made public yesterday by Governor Rockefeller and his chief transportation adviser, Dr. William J. Ronan.
COOPER INDUSTRIES, which was thwarted by the Justice Department when it attempted to take over Waukesha Motor Company, is still in the market for acquisitions.

MIAMI, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- A Roman Catholic priest and five other leaders of an abortive plot to overthrow the Haitian dictator, Francois Duvalier, were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from 60 days to four years.

RENO, Feb. 28 -- Lady Spencer-Churchill won an uncontested divorce yesterday in the Washoe County District Court from Lord Charles Spencer Churchill. The divorce was granted by District Judge Thomas O. Craven during a closed-door hearing. LadySpencer-Churchill charged extreme mental cruelty in the action filed on Dec. 15.

The average price of new office space rented in Manhattan was $1.10 per square foot more in 1967 than it had been five years before. And in the next 15 months, prospective office tenants can expect an additional rise of 65 to 75 cents a square foot.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- The Federal Government relaxed restrictions today on imports of home heating oil to alleviate a shortage in the New York and New England area.

WHEN Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Levy of Mansfield Center, Conn., were on their wedding trip in England in 1962 they decided they wanted an Old English sheepdog. Neither had owned a dog before and they had no clear idea of what an Old English sheepdog looked like.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 28 -- A world conference of Communist parties in Moscow late this year became virtually certain today as a steamroller of Soviet origin took charge of the consultative parley of 67 parties.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 29 -- North Vietnamese machine-gunners shot down a Marine transport helicopter 11 miles northeast of Khesanh yesterday, the United States command reported this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, proposed legislation today that would effect a comprehensive reform of the draft, including suspension of deferments for college undergraduates during certain wartime conditions.

On the screen in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art tonight, a man who looks a good deal like Theodore Roosevelt will be seen stalking big game through a New Jersey forest. Accompanying him will be two men wearing placards, one reading "My Press Agent" and the other "My Photographer."
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- A representative of Mayor Lindsay said today that the city's school system was fanning the flames of racial hatred.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Many Americans will be disappointed if there is no apocalypse this year. It has been forecast, promised and talked about for so long that the nation seems to have developed a need for it, the way in February it used to need a new baseball season.
Since last month, Myron McDonald has been chairman and chief executive of Jack Tinker Partners, a medium-sized agency with a very big creative reputation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- President Johnson gave the Medal of Freedom today to his departing Secretary of Defense, Robert S. McNamara, and praised him as a "brilliant and good man."
SEATTLE, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A Japanese freighter and a Liberian tanker collided in heavy fog 340 miles west of the mouth of the Columbia River tonight. The Coast Guard said both ships were afire.
Robert Moses officiated yesterday at the final dedication ceremony of his long career as master builder and controversial figure with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

The action of the American Bar Association in restricting the availability of pretrial news in criminal cases seems as irrational as the action of appellate courts regarding the infringement of constitutional rights of accused persons.

NOEL COWARD'S comedy, "Present Laughter," has not survived too well the 25 years since its first production, but an overriding requisite is that the central part of the flamboyantly romantic, derisive and sardonic actor be played in the highest of styles.

Copper futures prices moved uneasily yesterday pending some additional news about the strike. The nearby March contract managed to end the day with a slight gain, closing at 72.50 cents a pound, up from 72.25. However, the more distant contracts weakened, possibly under some profit taking by nervous longs.
Birgit Nilsson was ill last night, so Milka Stojanovic a newcomer to the Metropolitan Opera this season, replaced her in the title role of "Aida," singing it for the first time with the company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A top Federal shipping official told Congress today "there must be some action to upgrade the merchant marine, or it is going down the drain, to put it bluntly."
BIG PINE KEY, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Here on one of the outermost Florida keys lives a big man who has protected America's smallest deer since 1946.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Administration appears to be reluctantly settling for the prospect of long negotiations with North Korea in the effort to liberate the intelligence ship Pueblo and her crew of 82.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Walter P. Reuther, the labor leader who helped found the Americans for Democratic Action, told newsmen today that the group had made a serious mistake in endorsing Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, for President.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Two publishers of weekly and suburban newspapers in the Chicago area said today that enterprises like theirs would be destroyed if the big dailies were granted exemptions from antitrust laws.

Casita Maria will benefit from a fashion show and tea party to be held on March 10 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre. Children, most of them girls, will model Joseph Love's young world clothes at the event, called "A Family Fashion Happening." Fathers and brothers will be special guests, with mothers assisting as hostesses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Criminal defendants in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York are waiting months longer for their day in court than in any other Federal district in the nation, a government report has shown.

IN his office at the Pentagon, Gen. Earle Gilmore Wheeler has one of those photographs that important men are obliged to pose for from time to time. It shows him holding a Vietnamese tiger by its very large jowls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The head of the foreign aid program acknowledged to Congress today that the recent Vietcong offensive against the cities of South Vietnam had thrown "the other war" in that country "all out of kilter."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The United States has suspended all nuclear-armed airborne alert flights by B-52's following the crash near Thule, Greenland, of one of the bombers carrying four hydrogen bombs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today that the United States suspend gold payments to foreign countries, at least as a temporary measure, to conserve the nation's remaining $11.9-billion gold stock.

The Unitarian Universalist District of Metropolitan New York presented its Thomas Jefferson Award for Religious Libertly last night to John B. Oakes, editor of the editorial page of The New York Times.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 28 -- Robert Lee Davis Jr. has received permission from a doctor to return to college despite a bullet lodged in his back.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Mayor Jerome Cavanagh, stepping into the Detroit newspaper blackout for the first time since it began 105 days ago, asked today for a meeting with the publishers and the Teamsters union.
The stock market declined yesterday in moderate trading. Quotations closed at the lows of the day after the morning's upward trend had been reversed.

Overseas and domestic air travelers would be whisked from midtown Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport on Jamaica Bay in 20 minutes by a $100-million high speed rail line to be built under the air transport section of the new metropolitan region transportation program.

The rejection of Adlai Stevenson III by Illinois's boss-ridden Democrats is the latest suggestion that President Johnson is going into the 1968 election as the candidate of a dangerously weakened coalition of state and local parties.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Gov. George Romney shocked the political world today by pulling out of the Republican Presidential competition less than two weeks before the New Hampshire primary.

DURHAM, N. H., Feb. 28 -- Prof. John A. Beckett of the University of New Hampshire called on members of the Romney organization today to rally behind Governor Rockefeller in the Presidential primary here on March 12.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The United States Court of Appeals declined today to interfere with the refusal of the House of Representatives to seat Adam Clayton Powell, Manhattan Democrat, a year ago.

Gov. George Romney's withdrawal from the Presidential race radically alters the outlook for the Republican party. By deciding to cut his losses now, Mr. Romney has moved friendly and decisively to anticipate events. Since all signs pointed to his defeat in the New Hampshire primary -- a setback that would, in turn, adversely have affected his prospects in Wisconsin -- he has robbed those events of their significance by abandoning the contest.
SAN DIEGO, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- The research submarine Deep Quest dived today to a record 8,150 feet, bettering by more than 1,500 feet the mark she set in January.

Tickets for "Dear World," starring Angela Lansbury, will be offered at record prices for a Broadway show. When the musical opens Dec. 26 at the Mark Hellinger, seats will cost up to $12.50 on Friday and Saturday nights, compared with the present nightly top of $12 for "Cabaret."

American Indians performing in Dublin, a jazz band belting it out in Vienna, Hawaiian hula dancers delighting crowds in Amsterdam, high-fashion models from Seventh Avenue parading on a runway in Melbourne. Such outposts of the Americans' socio - economic - cultural life have stimulated foreign sales of United States consumer goods in 13 countries in recent years.

TRENTON, Feb. 28 -- Classes were dismissed at Trenton High School again today after a series of fist fights between Negro and white students. Seventeen students were injured and at least six were arrested, most of them Negroes.

OTTAWA, Feb. 28 -- The minority Government of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson won a vote of confidence today that keeps it in power after a critical nine-day challenge in the House of Commons. The vote was 138 to 119.

Interest rates on new issues of triple-A utility bonds moved up to 6.40 per cent from 6.30 per cent yesterday as three investment banking syndicates underwriting $235-million of securities disbanded with an estimated $145-million still unsold.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- In contrast to the acrimony that marked President de Gaulle's ouster of the North Atlantic Treaty organization from France, American officials have been pleasantly surprised at French willingness to buy surplus material left behind by the United States.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Lieut. Arthur Ashe, the No. 2 ranking player in the United States, captured the Concord Hotel's international indoor tennis trophy for the second straight year today.

Archbishop Makarios has swamped his only opponent even more decisively than expected in winning a new term as President of Cyprus. He has thus received the renewed mandate he had asked of the Greek-Cypriote majority, and with it the opportunity for a fresh start in ethnic reconciliation and nation-building.

AN aged Queen writes her last words in her journal as the shadows close, punctuating a reign. The words are plain-heart simple: "I have tried with all my heart to do what you would have wished, and I hope you will be pleased."
The possibility of a statewide walkout by 27,000 Oklahoma public school teachers persisted yesterday while officials in Florida sought ways to break an impasse in a strike by 22,000 teachers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The House of Representatives passed today by voice vote a controversial measure limiting standardization of containers.
THE American Indian is demanding Red Power. He is having a tough fight with a short stick. But reports that he is vanishing have been grossly exaggerated.

ALL the world's a stage and at least half of the world is a circus -- the metaphor at the heart of Gerald Arpino's new ballet, "The Clowns," given by the City Center Joffrey Ballet at the City Center last night late in the program, is not especially original. Yet its familiarity is an advantage, for Arpino uses it to provide a deceptively soothing element in a parable of destruction and survival.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Both the Senate and the House took steps today toward enactment of the Administration's bill to continue automobile and telephone excise taxes at their present rates and to speed the collection of corporate taxes.
Julius F. Klein, whose prison and arrest record in Suffolk County had led to the transfer of his latest trial to Manhattan, declined yesterday to take the stand in State Supreme Court.

The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Roman Catholic Bishop of Rochester, gave parish property worth $680,000 to the Federal Government yesterday. The only string attached to the Ash Wednesday gift, he said, was that it be utilized to house the poor.
CAMP CARROLL, South Vietnam, Feb. 25 -- Like the United States marines at Khesanh, the troops at this artillery base eight miles south of the demilitarized zone are awaiting a major attack.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Judges and lawyers are rallying to the side of newsmen in their stand against proposed limits on crime news, an Associated Press survey shows.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A far-reaching civil rights compromise that would ban discrimination in about two-thirds of the nation's housing reached the Senate floor today. Prospects for Senate passage next week were bright.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring arrived in New York today to report to Secretary General Thant on his three-month effort to find a peace settlement between Israel and her Arab neighbors.
Maritime unions invited the 60,000 striking copper workers yesterday to set up picket lines on Atlantic and Gulf Coast piers to stop the current monthly flow of 80,000 tons of imported copper.
BONN, Feb. 28 -- President Heinrich Lubke of West Germany told the Cabinet today he would publicly defend himself against charges that he helped build concentration camps during World War II.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller today commuted the death sentences of four convicted murderers to life imprisonment.

CAIRO, Feb. 28 -- The United Arab Republic appeared to have halted the most extensive wave of student protest demonstrations here in more than a decade through conciliatory gestures and firm intervention by the police.
WIG wearers can apparently relax. Neither government officials nor safety experts seem to think that such women are in any special danger of having their hairdos go up in flames.

PETER LEVENTRITT of New York, one of America's greatest players, arrived in Johannesburg, South Africa, last night to begin a threemonth stint coaching South African teams for the 1968 world championship in Deauville, France, next June.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- The State Department announced today that all restrictions had been lifted on American's traveling to countries in the Middle East.

After the chaos caused by the garbage strike, the master agreement the city has just signed with the biggest of the unions representing municipal employes is a welcome reminder that rational relationships can bring solid benefits to both the community and those who work for it.
WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 28 -Ben Webster late today won at least a two-night reprieve from the resumption and completion of an original 15-night suspension from driving harness horses.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- August A. Busch Jr. owns six breweries, two yachts, one wildlife preserve, a monorail and the St. Louis Cardinals. Joan W. Payson owns a racing stable, mansions on Long Island and Hobe Sound, a priceless art collection and the New York Mets.

Louis Schein, a Bronx realty man who refused last Monday to tell a grand jury if he had been threatened with death or beaten up by a reputed Mafia leader, was directed in State Supreme Court yesterday to testify or be held in contempt.

As campaign manager for Mel Dubin I read with a feeling of outrage the statements of John Bailey, chairman of the National Democratic party, concerning the outcome of the special election in the Thirteenth Congressional District.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP) -- The contempt of court trial for Cesar Chavez was delayed yesterday until the head of the National Farm Workers Organizing Committee breaks his fast.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 -- The American College of Cardiology called a conference of medical, surgical, legal and theological leaders to grapple with the problems arising from the development of techniques for heart transplantations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Two physicians and a newspaper publisher told Senate investigators today of the "nightmare" deaths of their children, saying they were caused by the use of an antibiotic, chloranphenicol.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Administration sent to Congress today new legislation asking for $296-million for arms sales to less developed countries under Government credits or Government credit guarantees.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 28 -- Wisconsin officials sought late today to determine if Governor Rockefeller of New York could be returned to Wisconsin's Presidential primary ballot on April 2.
LANSING, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Michigan, Republican leaders insisted today that Mr. Romney would have made a great President.
TORONTO, Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Bob Schmautz, a rookie, scored his first National Hockey League goal tonight, giving the Chicago Black Hawks a 1-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
ATHENS, Feb. 28 -- A treasure of fine ancient sculptures, dug up by chance in an Athens suburb last weekend, raised hopes that the site of a fourth century B.C. sanctuary had now been identified.

Cecil L. Wright, 59 years old, executive vice president of the J. C. Penney Company, yesterday was elected president and chief administrative officer of Penney's, one of the country's largest merchandising and catalogue chains. He succeeds Ray H. Jordan, who will retire April 1 but will remain on the Penney board.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 28 -- Republican party leaders in Michigan and Gov. George Romney's administrative staff received word of the Governor's withdrawal from the Presidential race today with shock and near disbelief.

The Canadian dollar was steady in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The confidence vote for Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson in the Canadian Parliament had no effect on dealings.

Hitler's legions of horror marched across the screen last night at a preview of the television film made from William L. Shirer's book, "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich." Then the New York chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences put on a discussion -- "Can It Happen Again?"

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Feb. 28 -- The new $6.75-million Garden State Arts Center will open June 15 with a concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy and Van Cliburn as guest soloist.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Mrs. George Romney said tonight that she felt "greatly relieved" as a wife that her husband had withdrawn from the Presidential race but that as a "citizen"' it was "unfortunate.''

Councilman Theodore S. Weiss announced yesterday that he would try again this year to take the Democratic nomination away from Representative Leonard Farbstein in Manhattan's 19th Congressional District. Mr. Weiss narrowly railed in what amounted to two attempts in 1966.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Feb. 28 -- To the naked eye, there wasn't much difference between today's New York Yankee workout and the traditional ones: batting practice, with various pitchers taking a five-minute turn, and the hitters divided into three groups, with two working in the field while the third group was at bat.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 28 -- The first signs of a crack have appeared in the facade of unity in the governing party in Rhodesia, the Rhodesian Front. In well-informed circles it is believed that a right-wing revolt may be imminent in the party, which is led by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller could open a full-scale Presidential primary campaign "within two weeks" if he wished, sources close to the Governor and his staff said today. The New Hampshire primary, the nation's first, will be held March 12.

The Washington portrait by Gilbert Stuart that disappeared Sunday evening from the Clarkson College of Technology in Potsdam, N. Y., was found yesterday in a Buffalo church, 300 miles away. It is now back at the college, apparently intact except for a slight chip in its gilded frame.

Luxury restaurants that favor "Continental-style" waiters over Americans drew protests yesterday from the State Commission for Human Rights and the Hotel and Restaurant Employes Union. Both supported a study of hiring patterns to detect possible racial discrimination or anti-American bias.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The House voted, 300 to 92, today to send three members to Madrid, despite a protest against such trips by Congressmen while ordinary citizens face a possible tax on their European travel.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 28 (UPI) -- Former Gov. W. W. Barron and five other men charged in a Federal indictment with taking part in a scheme to profit from state business were granted a six-week continuance today to make pleas.
Prices declined on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in one of the slowest sessions in nine months.

A SPECIAL committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association will meet Monday and Tuesday at Palm Springs, Calif., to study the feasibility of establishing a playoff or tournament of some form to determine a major-college football champion.

The Pennsylvania New York Central Transportation Company announced yesterday the election of John T. Dorrance Jr. as a director. He succeeds James M. Symes, retired chairman of the former Pennsylvania Railroad.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 28 -- St. Peter's College snapped Long Island University's 20-game unbeaten record with a 70-59 victory tonight after the two quintets had dramatically accepted bids to the National Invitation Tournament.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 28 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan of California refused to budge from his noncandidacy stance today in the face of Gov. George Romney's withdrawal from the Republican Presidential race.

An airline can be a tough advertising agency client because it is difficult to find a "hook" to set it apart from the competition -- same airplanes, same pretty girls -- but you know all that. You want to know what's new.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- High Government officials said today that the Johnson Administration was making a reappraisal of American military strategy in Vietnam. The reports came amid indications that Gen. William C. Westmoreland was seeking 100,000 to 200,000 more troops for the war effort.

A brighter day for metropolitan transportation is dawning. The comprehensive plan submitted yesterday to Governor Rockefeller by the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority gives real promise of bringing great improvements to subway riders and to commuters alike within the next ten years.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America said yesterday in Newark that it planned to market "by the end of this year" an equity-based contract for individuals.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 28 -- Charles Evers, the Negro civil rights leader who won the first heat in the Third District Congressional race yesterday, faces overwhelming odds in the runoff March 12.

RHINEBECK, N. Y., Feb. 28 -In the small red, white and blue home where Buster Mathis meditates, the shiny kitchen table was set for dinner. Every so often Eddie Stubenvowl, the slim 57-year-old cook, glanced at two sirloin steaks sizzling in the broiler.

Nothing in George Romney's Presidential campaign became him more than the way he left it. Smiling and good-humored, as if at ease after an ordeal, Mr. Romney withdrew bravely and with dignity at his news conference in Washington late yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- John Havlicek scored 41 points, including a team-record 30 in the first half, as the Boston Celtics defeated the crippled San Francisco Warriors, 135-110, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
The expression of "shock" by the New York City Board of Education at the antiwhite memorial program at Intermediate School 201 is difficult to accept and understand.
A joint $850,000 loan venture by the Puerto Rican Forum, the Ford Foundation and two banks was announced yesterday in a new move to stimulate Puerto Rican businesses here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The Chicago Board of Education apparently killed today the proposal by school Supt. James F. Redmond to begin busing 1,035 Negro elementary school pupils from the inner-city to predominantly white schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Former Assemblyman Bertram L. Podell was sworn in today as Representative of the 13th Congressional District in Brooklyn.

The Richards Woodwind Quintet, an ensemble that is in residence at Michigan State University, made its New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night playing Ingolf Dahl's Allegro and Arioso and quintets by Peter Muller, Hans Werner Henze and Jean Francaix. Muller was a very minor German composer who lived from 1791 to 1877. The others are all alive and working today.
" COME along, Abdullah," the dark-haired mother was saying, "and leave those pistachios alone."

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- The languishing state lottery got a transfusion today. The Legislature overwhelmingly approved Governor Rockefeller's bill to expand the sweepstakes by increasing ticket outlets and allowing the prize drawings, now held monthly, to be run as often as once a week.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- The French Government declared today that it had "specific information" confirming the statement by Secretary General Thant that a cessation of American bombing of North Vietnam would be a "necessary and sufficient" condition for the opening of negotiations on the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Government officials say there are indications of a decline in use of LSD and express hope it means young people are heeding scientific reports on the danger in taking the hallucinogenic drug.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 29 -- The Government made a major concession late last night on its immigration bill, agreeing to exceed the planned quota on the entry of Asians with British passports on humanitarian grounds.

Thirteen persons, including 12 Columbia University students and a Harlem minister, were arrested yesterday in the course of two-hour demonstration by 150 persons protesting the construction of a new Columbia gymnasium in Morningside Park.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- As Parliament prepared to make a radical change in the nature of British citizenship, someone with a historical turn of mind recalled today an episode indicating what that citizenship once signified.

Ground between the upper millstone of England's forthcoming "color bar" and the nether millstone of Kenya's anti-Asian laws, 160,000 people of Indian and Pakistani origin must enlist the sympathy of all liberal and generous hearts everywhere.

MIAMI, Feb. 28 -Angel Cordero enjoyed the most successful day of any jockey in the 41-year history of the Hialeah race course by winning six races today. The 26-year-old rider from San Juan, P. R., far ahead in the jockeys' standing, sent his victory total to 59 on the 36th day of the 39-day meeting.
Sales and earnings of Revlon, Inc., for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31 were the highest in its 35-year history.

The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday operating revenues of $721,881,413 for the 12 months ended Jan. 31 against $686,160,725 a year earlier. Net income rose to $131,520,413, or $2.99 a share, from $125,480,257, or a $2.84 a share on fewer shares, in the 1967 period. Net income for January edged ahead to $12,640,913 from $12,128,257 a year earlier.
CHARLESTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 29 (AP)--Tonight's ninerace program at Charles Town Race Course was canceled because of snow.
THE ANSWER. By Jeremy Larner. 216 pages. Macmillan. $4.95.
The chancellor of the State University urged legislators yesterday not to enact laws that would interfere with academic freedom and institutional autonomy.

NEWARK, Feb. 29--George F. Kennan bitterly condemned President Johnson's Vietnam policy here tonight, characterizing it as a "massive miscalculation and error of policy, an error for which it is hard to find any parallels in our history."
BERLIN, Feb. 29--Sovietmade jet fighters twice this month approached Viscount airliners of British European Airways in the air corridors between Berlin and West Germany, British officials said today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29--Sheriff Joseph I. Woods's plan to form a special riot-control unit of 1,000 unpaid volunteers was ruled illegal today in Cook County Circuit Court by Judge Donald J. O'Brien, who said he would enjoin the Sheriff from establishing it.
The New York City Opera gave Puccini's "La Boheme" at the New York State Theater last night, and the performance was not very good.

The office products division of the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to move its administrative office from 590 Madison Avenue to Franklin Lakes, N. J., early in 1970.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI)--Representative L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, said today that the United States should authorize the use of tactical nuclear weapons at Khesanh or withdraw from the besieged garrison. Mr. Rivers is chairman of the House Armed Service Committee.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 29 (Reuters)--Saudi Arabia has decided to boycott the Olympic Games. A statement issued by the Saudi Olympic Committee said today's step was taken in solidarity with other African and Arab countries.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 29--Friends of Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that strategy dictated against his becoming an announced candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination now.

OTTAWA, Feb. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Paul Martin, Minister of External Affairs, gave a pessimistic appraisal today in the House of Commons of the chances of quick peace talks even if the United States halted the bombing of North Vietnam.

George Balanchine returned from a visit to Scotland in 1952 with the true spirit of the country for his masterly work "Scotch Symphony." Last night at the City Center Joffrey Ballet, buolant Sally Brayley danced the role of the beautiful and mysterious Highland sylph for the first time.

A British member of Parliament charged here yesterday that the state's proposed abortion reform was similar to Nazi laws that legalized execution of the physically and mentally handicapped and those otherwise unwanted by the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29--The National Labor Relations Board authorized its general counsel today to file an injunction action against striking copper unions.
The Western Electric Corporation filed charges of unfair labor practices yesterday against six maritime unions that threaten to stop completely the flow of imported copper.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -Manuel Diaz, president of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, said today inadequate Government support of shipbuilding in the 1969 fiscal year threatened the orderly fleet replacement program of his company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -Higher food and medical costs led a rise of three-tenths of 1 per cent in consumer prices last month and sharp wholesale increases indicated more budget problems were ahead for Americans.

MADRID, Feb. 29--A message from President Nasser was delivered tonight to Generalissimo Francisco Franco by Foreign Minister Mahmoud Riad of the United Arab Republic amid reports here that Cairo was launching a new diplomatic effort in the Middle East.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Feb. 29--Ranging through downtown business districts and housing developments, more than 120 Suffolk County policemen conducted an early-morning narcotics roundup today and arrested 22 persons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -Revenue freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Feb. 24, which included the Washington's Birthday holiday was more than in the comparable week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the corresponding period registered a decrease.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) --The Defense Department today identified 88 United States Servicemen killed in Vietnam.
LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The pound and the dollar came under pressure in the London foreign exchange and gold markets today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 (AP) -Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, and three Olympic officials from Mexico City met behind closed doors tonight to discuss the boycott threat to the summer Olympiad.
MOSCOW, Friday, March 1 (Reuters)--The Soviet Union is in the middle of a pancake gorge this week called the festival of Maslenita.

CAPE KENNEDY, Feb. 29 (UPI)--Recurring rocket trouble forced a second postponement today in the launching of an orbiting geophysical observatory to investigate earth's space environment. The 1,347-pound satellite had been set for launching at 8:06 A.M. tomorrow, but the latest trouble forced a delay until next Monday at the earliest.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Feb. 29--The Panama Canal, seeking to clean up a backlog stemming from last Sunday's 18-hour blockage by a ship accident, was well on its way-late today toward a record transit of oceangoing craft during a 24hour period.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29-G. H. (Pete) Bostwick of New York advanced to the semifinal round today in defense of his United States court tennis championship by defeating John M. Mirkil of Philadelphia, 6-0, 6-5, 6-1, after 1 hour 20 minutes of play at the Racquet Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29--The Soviet Union said today that new "provocations" had taken place at the Soviet Embassy. A spokesman for the Embassy described explosions heard nearby during the night, an attempt to enter the building by two unidentified men, and a smoldering fragment of an "incendiary rocket" found near the Embassy.
Capitol Industries, Inc., a phonograph record manufacturer, announced here yesterday the election of Glenn E. Wallichs as chairman and chief executive officer.
Prices closed on a firm note yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -Dr. James L. Goddard, Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said today he would question seriously any physician who prescribed the controversial antibiotic chloramphenicol for his children.
A young Bronx secretary-model who broke her engagement with a medical student has been ordered to return her $2,500 diamond engagement ring.
LONDON, Feb. 29--Britain has decided on the designation "p" for the new penny when the decimal currency system goes into effect Feb. 15, 1971.

The last tour of 40 patrolmen turned out of the West 47th Street station house in a chill rain late yesterday afternoon, never to return to the 106-year-old building that once echoed with names of famous cops and robbers like Lieut. Charles Becker, Jack (Legs) Diamond and Detective John J. (Boff 'Em Johnny) Broderick.

LONDON, Feb. 29 (AP) -The British Ombudsman, Parliament's watchdog on Government bureaucracy, reported today there was "some maladministration" in 10 per cent of the cases he investigated. Sir Edmund Compton said he investigated 188 complaints submitted to him in the last year by Members of Parliament, mostly on behalf of their constituents. Maladministration was found in 19.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 29 (AP)--Mayor Henry Loeb says 317 workers -- the largest number since the city's sanitation strike began 18 days ago--are now picking up garbage.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -Governor Rockefeller visited the White House today but still declined to say that he wanted to be a candidate to live there.
Trans World Airlines will resume its service from New York to Cairo on Monday. Flights have been suspended since the outbreak in June of the war between Israel and the United Arab Republic.
The Rockefeller administration's mass-transit blueprint drew mixed reactions yesterday with comment generally more favorable than not.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 29 (Reuters) -- David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, who is a member of the executive committee of Near East Emergency Donations, today presented a check for $1-million to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees. The donation organization, a United States group, has contributed $4.5-million since last September.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., Feb. 29 (AP)--Andrew Bender, 4 years old, died today in a fire that destroyed his parents' home at 571 Windsor Street here. His mother, Barbara Bender, 37, and a sleep-in maid, Janice Wright, 24, suffered smoke inhalation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29-President Johnson pledged his leadership today in a crusade for law enforcement and asked the nation's Governors to do the same in their states.
