Alexander Brown, a former stockbroker, pleaded guilty in Federal court here yesterday to two counts of a 23-count indictment that charged him and five other persons with manipulating the price of shares of the Pentron Electronics Corporation on the American Stock Exchange.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 29 (Agence France-Presse)--Hanoi's newspapers have not yet informed their readers of the recapture of Hue by American and South Vietnamese forces, but everyone knows about it. The name of the city, which was in headlines daily during the battle, has simply disappeared from the press.

Militant black groups promised yesterday to picket and demonstrate at Madison Square Garden next Monday night when Buster Mathis and Joe Frazier battle for the New York-Massachusetts-Illinois version of the world heavyweight boxing championship.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 29 (AP)-All but two crewmen aboard the 328-foot freighter Azar were evacuated to Cuban soil today after the Liberian-registered ship burned one mile off Cuba, the captain of a rescue vessel reported.

HOWARD HANSON likes to tell the story about the time Toscanini conducted his "Romantic" Symphony. Hanson came to New York and attended a rehearsal. Toscanini asked him what he thought. Hanson said it was perfect, a composer's dream.

The Liberal party will ask the three-man Federal court that ordered Congressional redistricting in New York State for the 1968 election to redraw lines where, the Liberals contend, districts are still gerrymandered.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 29 (AP) --The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today it would hold its annual stockholders meeting April 3 at the Statler Hilton Hotel in Boston. It will be the first time the company has held its meeting in New England, where Westinghouse has more than 15,000 stockholders.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city would resist Governor Rockefeller's new wide-ranging urban programs -- such as the $6-billion Urban Development Corporation -if those programs diminished the city's right of home rule.
DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 29 (Reuters) -- President Leopold Sedar Senghor of Senegal was sworn in today for a third four-year term following his unopposed re-election Sunday.

Columbia College approved yesterday a student request for weekday visiting hours and the extension of an experimental "unproctored sign-in system" for female guests in Columbia's five undergraduate dormitories. Columbia is the last of the eight Ivy League colleges to grant weekday women visiting privileges.

PARIS, Feb. 29--A Court of Appeal has ruled that royalties on the music of Maurice Ravel must be paid to a former barber who was no relative and apparently, never met the composer. Barring a final appeal, the barber, Alexandre Taverne of Hendaye, will collect $4million.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) --Ronald Eugene Stork, 27 years old, one of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 most wanted men, was arrested today aboard his 30-foot boat at a Honolulu Yacht Club, the F.B.I. announced. Mr. Stork, a native of Quakertown, Pa., was sought for interstate flight to avoid prosecution for murder.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 29 (UPI)--The police reported today that 89 people had been killed--17 murdered and 25 run down--during Rio's four-day Lenten carnival. One man was lynched after he struck a child.
Burt Kleiner, the California investment banker, is considering starting a proxy contest for control of the AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29 -The A.P.A. Repertory Company will not return to the Huntington Hartford Thester here this summer and will instead do at least three plays at the Stanford University Summer Festival in Northern California.

An organization called Action on Smoking and Health (ASH) was formed yesterday to file formal complaints against broadcasting stations that do not offer antismoking messages to counterbalance cigarette smoking.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 29--Rumania walked out of the meeting of 67 Communist parties here tonight. Paul NiculescuMizil, the Rumanian delegate, announced his party's decision to leave the conference at 9:45 P.M. after a lastminute effort to avert the walkout had collapsed. The delegation itself was still in Budapest late tonight.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 29 (Reuters)--President Rene Barrientos Ortuno today decreed a 120-day national emergency and introduced stringent tax measures to finance reconstruction in the wake of the disastrous floods of last week.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor proposed yesterday that a Federal-state urban "homestead" program be established to subsidize the purchase of homes and apartments by the poor.

The conferences of General Wheeler with General Westmoreland in Vietnam and his return to Washington with pacification chief Robert Komer have brought President Johnson the action proposals of his military and civil proconsuls in Saigon. One such proposal clearly is the dispatch of more American troops. What is less clear is the purpose to be served by the troop reinforcement and other measures recommended.
The National Biscuit Company is getting out of the bread business.
THE world team championship in Deauville, France, is now only three months away, and the United States team is emerging from its winter hibernation to begin a period of serious practice.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 29 (Reuters) -- India will withdraw if South Africa competes in the Olympic Games, the Indian Olympic Association president, Raja Bhalindra Singh, said today.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday condemned an antiwhite program recently given at East Harlem's Intermediate School 201.

Fricka would be many a woman's dream role: All she must do is come on the scene in the second act of "Die Walkure" and nag her husband for half an hour. Unfortunately for mezzo-sopranos of less than a factory whistle's staying-power, Fricka also must sing at full blast throughout one of the most taxing dialogues in opera.

The city's Council Against Poverty was reported last night to be seeking a time extension on a Federal deadline for submitting a plan to assure "adequate representation" of ethnic and other groups in local antipoverty boards.
Tom Killefer, financial vice president of the Chrysler Corporation, was named yesterday to the additional post of general counsel.
ERIC DE JUAN, custom dress designer at Bergdorf Goodman, skirted the mini-midi issue yesterday and also offered a bit of advice on just who should wear the calf-length fashions.
LONDON, Feb. 29 (AP)-Toneye Manning, an actor, went to jail today rather than give up Arthur, a cat loved by millions.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 29 (UPI) -- Harry Edwards, outspoken Negro leader of the proposed boycott of the 1968 Olympics, said today he would quit his job as associate professor of sociology at San Jose State College.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) --The House sent to President Johnson today a bill to clear the way for converting Washington's Union Station into a national visitor center.

The Otis Elevator Company earned $20,022,000, equivalent to $2.47 a share, last year, it was announced here yesterday. This compares with a restated $25,183,000, equal to $3.11 a share, in 1966. No reason for the decline in profits was given.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29--Representative Wilbur D. Mills, the House's chief architect for tax policy, said today that "substantial acceleration" of the war in Vietnam "could force" Congress to enact a general tax increase.

MIAMI, Feb. 29--The Cuban Government acknowledged today that its freighter, the 550ton 26 of July, rammed a small boat off the Virginia coast Tuesday to recapture three would-be defectors who were members of the crew.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino announced yesterday that he had submitted a bill to the Legislature to extend the stock-transfer tax at its present level for another year.
BEAUTY BEAST. By MacKinlay Kantor. 382 pages. Putnam. $6.95.
The No. 2 man of Publicis, France's largest privately held ad agency, is in the states for a four-day visit.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) --The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Joseph M. Bowman Jr. as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.
CHICAGO, Feb. 29 (UPI)-The Illinois State Athletic Board has voted to recognize the winner of the bout between Joe Frazier and Buster Mathis as world champion.
Stocks that fell on the American Stock Exchange yesterday outnumbered those that rose, 637 to 146.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 29 --Richard M. Nixon, in effect, told Governor Rockefeller today that if he wanted the Republican Presidential nomination he would have to fight for it in some state primaries.

Earnings of M.S.L. Industries, Inc., declined to $3,606,000, equal to $2.24 a share, last year, from $6,370,000, or $4.01 a share, in 1966, it was announced yesterday. Sales of the manufacturer of industrial and aerospace products fell to $108,451,000 from $115,666,000 in the preceding year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) --The number of airports in the United States rose to 9,276 last year, a rise of almost 400 over 1966, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) --Farm product prices increased one per cent during the month ended Feb. 15.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 29 (AP)--The Ohio Senate gave unanimous approval tonight to a bill proposing to help control rioting in the state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29--Administration officials said today the United States had received no indication that the Dutch Government wished to modify the 1961 secrecy agreement controlling information about centrifuge technology.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 29--All secondary schools will be closed here tomorrow as a result of a teachers' strike that began today.

YONKERS, Feb. 29--Mutuel clerks who work at Yonkers Raceway received telegrams today from Local 32E, Building Service Employes, to attend a meeting Saturday afternoon at Trinch's Steve Phillips Restaurant here to take a strike vote. The union is seeking a $10-aday raise for the clerks, who now make an average of $29 each night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29--The President's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders gave this warning to Americans tonight: "Our nation is moving toward two societies, one black, one white--separate and unequal."

Marlon Brando will star as Eddie Anderson, the writerhero of Elia Kazan's novel, "The Arrangement," which Mr. Kazan will produce and direct for Warner Brothers-Seven Arts. Richard Boone has also been signed to portray Mr. Brando's immigrant father.

MIAMI, Feb. 29--The groom led Vitriolic out of the stall and into the center of the walking ring alongside the Phipps family stable row at Hialeah. Eddie Neloy had his hands jammed into the slit pockets of his blue windbreaker as slight protection from the early morning chill when he made careful inspection of the big bay 3-year-old.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 29 -President Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro announced Cabinet changes today.
The 5th Dimension's "Up, Up and Away" won the Grammy Award last night as record of the year for 1967 in multiple presentations at the New York Hilton Hotel and in Los Angeles, Chicago and Nashville.
Columbia Pictures Corporation achieved the highest quarterly and half-year earnings in its 45-year history in the three and six months ended Dec. 30, Abraham Schneider, chairman, reported yesterday.

NEWARK, Feb. 29 (AP)-Pasquale Esposito, 53 years old, was fatally injured on Broad Street early today, the apparent victim of a hit-run motorist, the police said. He died 35 minutes later in City Hospital. Mr. Esposito lived at 9 Pennington Street, in Newark.
MOSCOW, Feb. 29--The Soviet Union's top-ranking academy of sciences acted today to quash a recent flurry of interest here in flying saucers.

PARIS--It is possible to argue the greatest American weakness in Vietnam is the fact that the U.S.A. has never lost a war. Neither American political maturity nor American diplomacy has been tested by adversity as has the resilience of every other world power.

License Commissioner Joel J. Tyler said yesterday that only a "relatively small percentage" of the 17,000 seats at the new Madison Square Garden had obstructed views and that he was satisfied with the efforts being made to correct the sightline problem.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29--Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., a six-time United States champion, drew his game with Leonid Stein, the current and three-time Soviet champion, last night at the Herman Steiner Chess Club here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29-The National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders released the summary of its report two days ahead of schedule because The Washington Post told the panel it was planning to publish the document in Friday editions.
SEVEN tribes of American Indians have agreed to send craftsmen, dancers and singers to this year's International Sport and Camping Show at the New York Coliseum.

Peralta Shipping Corporation has announced three executive appointments. F. J. Lipari was named director of sales, H. de Peralta general traffic manager and Samuel B. Wade assistant director of sales. The company is general agent for Torm Lines and operates the Peralta (Atlantic) Line with monthly sailings from Gulf and South Atlantic ports to British and continental European ports.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29--Following is the text of the summary of the report issued today by the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders:
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 29 (Reuters) -- South Africa set up its first multiracial sporting committee today to help choose the boxing team for the Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) --Edward Schwartz, the president of the National Student Association, outlined a program today in which all students reclassified 1-A could appeal Selective Service decisions and thus disrupt its operations.
The nation's stock exchanges and the over-the-counter market will resume normal trading hours next Monday after six weeks of shorter sessions aimed at easing paperwork problems in brokerage offices.
They are still fooling around with the Felt Forum of the new Madison Square Garden Center, trying to make a viable concert hall out of it.

BOSTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -Marcus Raskin, 33 years old, of Washington, and William Sloan Coffin Jr., chaplain of Yale University, asked United States District Court Judge Francis J. W. Ford today to grant them separate trials.

Without mincing words, Columbia University has totally severed its relationship with the Strickman cigarette filter. Just as the original linking of a smoking device to the university's good name--and especially to its medical school--evoked criticism, so now the frankness of the university's admission that it made "a well-intentioned mistake" deserves praise.
Matthew B. Rosenhaus, chairman and president of the J. B. Williams Company, has been elected to the board of the Columbia Pictures Corporation.
A 24-year-old theological student who is president of his class was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on draft-evasion charges.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 29 (UPI)--Charles Evers, the Negro civil rights leader, said today that he had asked the Justice Department to investigate a 1954 state law requiring a runoff election to fill a vacancy if no candidate won a majority in the first race.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 29--Bob Reilly, a senior who had not been on a horse in three weeks, scored 11 goals today to lead Georgetown University to a 13-10 victory over Valley Forge Junior College in a quarterfinal match of the national intercollegiate polo championship.
The Action Committee on American-Arab Relations urged in a telegram to the White House yesterday that President Johnson oppose Israeli "plans to annex the West Bank of the Jordan."

Fordham University's National Invitation Tournamentbound basketball team saw its 13-point lead in the second half melt to 2 points in the closing minutes before the Rams finally outlasted New York University, 79-73, last night at Madison Square Garden.
PARIS, Feb. 29--The Guide Michelin, the high court of no appeal for French restaurants, has dropped two of its three-star restaurants to twostar rank.

Rothman's Pall Mall of Canada, Ltd., the second-largest cigarette company in that country, contracted yesterday with the Strickman Foundation to pay a penny a pack royalty for use of the filter invented by Robert L. Strickman.

The New York Philharmonic will present a concert performance of "Oklahoma!" on March 26 at Philharmonic Hall for the benefit of the orchestra's pension fund. The performance is celebrating the 25th anniversary of the musical composed and written by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d. It will be the first time the work has been given in a concert version.
At least four patients who were among the early recipients of kidney transplants developed cancer in the transplanted organ because it had been taken from a cancer victim.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 29 (AP)--An aide said today that Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace had developed "a superficial infection" in a portion of the abdominal incision where she was operated on for cancer. But he said it was not considered serious. A hospital bulletin said the 41-year-old Mrs. Wallace had completed one week of hospitalization "without further evidence of serious complications."
School was cool for 250 fifth and sixth graders at Public School 6 yesterday morning.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 29 (AP)--A bus ran over a Vietcong mine in the Mekong Delta, killing nine civilians and wounding two, South Vietnamese officials said today.

HUNTER, N. Y., Feb. 29-Hias Leitner, a silver-medal winner in the 1960 Winter Olympics, added to his overall slead in the Professional Ski Racing Association - Bailantine competition today by winning the giant slalom from 36 rivals with ease.

The arbitration award handed down yesterday by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, ends the wage fight that led to last month's illegal sanitation strike. Mr. McDonnell has executed with agility the complicated footwork required to come out with a decision that would meet the demands of equity and still avoid reopening the political and economic wounds caused by the strike.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 29--The Government sent a letter to members of Parliament today informing them, it is understood, that the Netherlands has developed a potentially cheap method of making uranium 235, the vital material of atomic power.
The Boston Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Erich Leinsdorf, presented an allBeethoven program in Carnegie Hall last night.
PORTSMOUTH, Va., Feb. 29 (UPI)--The Canadian shop Sillery reported today she was sinking with 13 men aboard about 75 miles of Oregon Inlet, N. C.
New Yorkers planning to move today may not receive much help from the major moving van companies here.
LIVERPOOL, England, Feb. 29 (UPI) -- Peruvian heavyweight Roberto Davila stopped Brian London on cuts in the sixth round of their scheduled 10-round fight at Liverpool Stadium tonight.
GREENWOOD, S. C., Feb. 29 (UPI)--Roger Zane Dedmond was freed from jail today after serving for nine months over the slaying of his wife, a crime now believed to have been committed by another man.
George Champion, chairman of the board of the Chase Manhattan Bank, has been reappointed national chairman of the United Negro College Fund's annual campaign.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 29--Informed sources reported today that the United States command would be reshuffled for the expected battle of Khesanh.
Dr. Benjamin Spock predicted yesterday that President Johnson would seek a declaration of war if United States military forces were defeated at Khesanh.

Yesterday President Johnson proclaimed March Red Cross Month across the na tion. This is the time that Red Cross seeks to raise the funds needed to carry on its vital services in the community, the nation and the world. This year, the President noted, the demands on the Red Cross--and its financial needs--will be exceptionally heavy. To meet these, he announced that the Red Cross will conduct a special SOS-Support Our Servicemen-campaign.

LONDON, Feb. 29 (UPI)-Measures by the United States to improve her balance of payments, coupled with the expected massive improvements in Britain's foreign payments situation, will throw a heavy burden on European Common Market countries, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research said today.

Prime Minister Pearson's Liberal Government has survived a vote of confidence and has emerged from Canada's political crisis in less disarray than its Progressive-Conservative opposition. The chances are now good that the Liberals can proceed on schedule to choose a successor to Mr. Pearson in April and give the new Prime Minister time to make an impact on the country before calling a general election.
Bearish economic and Vietnam news sent the stock market down yesterday as trading slowed.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- Secretary General Thant and Ambassador Jarring discussed the prospects for a long-term settlement in Middle East in a talk this morning.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 29 (AP)--Thousands of public school children returned to classes here today for the first time in a week as teachers ended a walkout on the promise of attempts to seek more state money for schools.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 29 (AP)--The Georgia-Pacific Corporation and the Detroit Steel Corporation have called off plans for a merger.

SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 29 (UPI) -- A Japanese freighter that collided with a Liberian tanker in dense fog 300 miles off the Oregon coast yesterday was abandoned today and the search continued for eight missing men.
The following reports were provided yesterday by operators of ski areas (messages were filed at the times indicated in parentheses):

AMES, Iowa, Feb. 29 (AP)-Scientists from three nations asked their governments today for increased financial support of research aiming to wipe out Dutch elm disease, which is killing trees in the United States, Canada and Europe.
LONDON, Feb. 29 (Reuters) --Capital expenditure of British industry fell 7 per cent to a level of 553-million ($1.4-billion) during the fourth quarter of last year, the Board of Trade said today.
A state vocational rehabilitation counselor has been nominated by a community board as chief administrator of the Intermediate School 201 model school complex in East Harlem.

The city will submit to the Legislature a bill that would enable the state and local governments to subsidize private agencies that want to sponsor new housing, health facilities, schools, industry and other elements of community development.

Bond prices rose yesterday after Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, a major stumbling block in the way of the Administration's tax increase, appeared to be softening his opposition.

TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 29 --Imam Mohammed al-Badr of Yemen declared today he was confident that the decision by King Faisal of Saudi Arabia to resume full-scale aid to Yemen Royalists would enable them to take Sana, the capital, and regain control of the entire country. The Imam, who was overthrown in 1962, has been living in this country since the summer of 1966 for medical treatment.
The election of Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, to the presidency of the board of trustees of the Lycee Francais de New York was announced yesterday.
HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 29 --Death grips this shattered city of marble temples and tombs.
The Federal Reserve continued to implement a policy of tighter credit in the week ended Wednesday, according to banking statistics released yesterday.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 29 (Agence France-Presse) -Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Chief of State, said yesterday that he would retire if the Communists did not cease their spreading guerrilla activities or unless he could check them in the next few months.

ROME, Feb. 29--The internationalized and rejuvenated central administration of the Roman Catholic Church received new regulations on organization and working conditions, including a 33-hour week, from Pope Paul VI today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29-Today's White House fashion show -- the first in history--was as patriotic as the Fourth of July, as wholesome as apple pie and as promotional as a TV commercial.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29-The brief saga of Gov. George Romney's decision to withdraw from the Presidential race began Monday when his campaign managers concluded--on the basis of highly sophisticated polls--that he would absorb a defeat in New Hampshire from which he could not recover in future primaries.

KEARNY, N. J., Feb. 29 (AP) --The Hudson County chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union condemned today as "shocking and unconscionable" the alleged fingerprinting of students in shop classes at Kearny High School. After a fire at the school last weekend, the chapter said, Police Chief Paul Mulligan ordered all the students in several printing classes to be fingerprinted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits charged today that the Johnson Administration contributed to the outbreak of the ArabIsraeli war last June by neglecting the region in the months preceding the war. He warned of similar dangers now.

Record sales and earnings for 1967 were reported yesterday by Pepsico, Inc. Net income rose to $39,249,114, or $1.88 a share, from $38,040,288, or $1.83 a share, in 1966. Sales rose 10 per cent to $665,345,280 from $604,665,701.

Twenty years ago--shortly after he was discharged from a tuberculosis sanatorium -Benjamin Greene borrowed some money from his brother and opened a tiny jewelry store on Lexington Avenue between 81st and 82d Streets.
A 23-year-old man arrested in the armed robbery of a Harlem supermarket last October was arrested again yesterday in a holdup at the same supermarket.

Ralph Gigliello, 70 years old, a Brooklyn candy store owner, was arrested yesterday for possession of a dangerous weapon after he shot a man who he said had broken into his store at 593 Washington Avenue, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section. The suspect, Donald Payton, 24, of 1296 Pacific Street, was admitted to Brooklyn Jewish Hospital in fair condition.
CAMPECHE, Mexico, Feb. 22 -- Campeche has one of the most modern state government buildings in Mexico and one of the country's most backward agricultural systems.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 29 --A secret agreement to settle Florida's 13-day-old teachers' strike fell through today after Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. ordered other members of the State Board of Education to stop negotiating with striking teachers.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 1 (AP)--A young Buddhist burned himself to death last night, police sources said today.
Directors of The New York Times Company voted yesterday a quarterly dividend of 35 cents a share on the Class A and Class B common stock, payable March 26 to holders of record March 15.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 29-America's heart specialists were told today of an imposing array of devices that should enable them to look inside their patients painlessly, assessing blood flow at any point and scanning blood vessels for signs of the country's chief killer, circulatory disease.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) --The report on urban rioting sounds an urgent note and "calls for national commitment and action," Senator Edward W. Brooke said today.

NAIROBI, Feb. 29--A team of British immigration officials is due to begin work here to morrow to decide who should receive the 1,500 "vouchers" that the British Government says will be issued yearly under the new immigration laws. This would represent the annual quota for Asian holders of British passports.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., Feb. 29 (UPI)--Los Angeles took advantage of cold shooting by the Chicago Bulls tonight and scored a 117-107 victory in a National Basketball game.

The Bowery Savings Bank at 110 East 42d Street, across the street from Grand Central, was temporarily short of $4,860 yesterday. The shortage was rectified when a holdup man was caught by Transit Authority detectives a few floors below bank level on the southbound platform of the Lexington Avenue subway.
A 53-year-old man accused of the hit-run killing of three infants in the Bronx last Oct. 1 was found guilty yesterday of second - degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide.

The United States Navigation Company announced yesterday that four steamship lines had changed their New York berths and will now use Pier 12, Port Authority, at the foot of Wolcott Street in Brooklyn. The four lines are Mamenic Lines, Scindia Steam Navigation Company, Ltd. and United Philippine Lines.

DETROIT, Feb. 29 -- Thanks to leap year, the Rangers finished their best month since the nineteen-fifties with a 4-2 victory over the Red Wings tonight, and again crept to within a point of second place in the National Hockey League's East Division.

FORT WORTH, Feb. 29 (UPI) --An Air Force B-52 bomber, carrying eight crewmen, was missing and presumed crashed today on a routine flight from Carswell Air Force Base to Matagorda Island, off the Texas coast.
ATLANTA, Feb. 29 (AP)-The Presbyterian Church in the U. S. has pledged up to $227,500 in emergency funds to fight the causes of race riots.

TRENTON, Feb. 29 (UPI)-Twenty to 50 students will be expelled from Trenton City High because they took part in racial fighting in the school yesterday, School Board President John De Sauro said today.

CAROL CHANNING'S special, postponed from last November because of the technicians' strike, reached the American Broadcasting Company's network last night as an hour of rather conventional musical variety. Admirers of Miss Channing no doubt appreciated her rendition of "Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend" and her dancing through a briefly diverting tableau variation on "Hello, Dolly!"
BOSTON, Feb. 29 UPI) -Derek Sanderson, a rookie, slapped in two goals in the third period tonight carrying the Boston Bruins to a 4-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

"Virtues," an eight-part theatrical film described as "an uninhibited look at America today," will be produced for C.B.S. Films this summer by the new producing team of Raymond Wagner and Si Litvinoff. Signed to write the individual episodes are William Peter Blatty, Francis Ford Coppola, Bruce Jay Friedman, Jack Gelber, Paul Krassner, Terry Southern, Jean Claude Van Italie and Kurt Vonnegut.

An apartment house -- tentative plans call for a 38-story tower--will be erected on the site of the Mary Manning Walsh Home, a residence for the elderly, at 420 East 59th Street, extending to 419 East 58th Street, between First Avenue and Sutton Place.

James A. Farley, the former Postmaster General, was reported in good condition last night at St. Clare's Hospital after having undergone surgery to correct an abdominal hernia early in the day. Mr. Farley, who is 79 years old, entered the hospital on Feb. 20, his son, James Jr., said.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 29--The weary commuter on the New Haven Railroad is finding new hardship in his daily trek to the city despite bright promises of vast Government aid and a long-sought merger with the Penn Central.

A snowstorm snarled air and ground traffic and caused power failures in the city and its suburbs last night and early today. It also knocked out all the fire alarm boxes in Queens and many in other boroughs.
Fashion Park, Inc., a Rochester manufacturer of men's tailored clothing, is being sold by the Hat Corporation of America to Botany Industries, Inc.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 29-Clarifying its position, the National Association of Harness Drivers has notified Governor Rockefeller it is not opposed to his proposed 1 per cent increase in the pari-mutuel tax.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 29 (Agence FrancePresse) -- The North Vietnamese press agency said today that the responsibility for negotiations "rests entirely with the United States."

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., the motion picture producer, announced here yesterday the appointment of Alan Ginsberg as head of mergers and acquisitions. He was formerly assistant treasurer of the Chase Manhattan Bank.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (Reuters)--The State Department said today the United States had not received any protest from the Cuban Government concerning the incident.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 29 --Three thousand American and Canadian Jewish leaders were told today that "only maximum financial support" will enable Israel to cope with her economic difficulties and help achieve a "fair and lasting peace" in the Middle East.
LEEDS, England, Feb. 29 (AP)--Policemen put a roundthe-clock guard today on a 12year-old boy named Robin who looked out a train window and saw a woman being murdered.
Indoor track makes its last widespread stand of the winter with three major meets this weekend.

Resentment and mistrust of policemen by minority groups living in slum areas are major reasons for the city's rising crime rate, two borough presidents and the Brooklyn district attorney told a crime conference yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam Friday, March 1--Enemy forces hidden between the outer defenses of Saigon, manned by American troops, and the South Vietnamese units posted near the city limit staged several harassing attacks in the last 36 hours.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 29 -For the third time this season, in seven meetings, the St. Louis Hawks scored an overtime victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight, 105-102, before 4,462 fans at the Miami Beach Convention Hall.

PEKING, Feb. 29 (Agence France-Presse) -- Twenty per cent of all professors, teachers and other cadres at Peking's schools and universities were ousted during the Cultural Revolution, the newspaper Peking Jih Pao said today. The organ of the city's revolutionary commmittee declared that the other 80 per cent "obtained their liberation," or, in other words, were rehabilitated.

The 10,000 sanitation workers, who recently struck for nine days, received a $425-ayear increase in their rate of pay yesterday in an arbitration decision that immediately precipitated a dispute between the city and the union over the value of the award.
The Transamerica Corporation announced yesterday record earnings and the declaration of a 4 per cent stock dividend in addition to the regular quarterly payment.

Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature have turned to drastic remedies to try to put life into that gigantic fiasco, the state lottery. By vastly expanding the number of outlets for the sale of tickets and by permitting drawing to be held weekly instead of monthly they hope to recoup their--and the state's--financial disappointment.
The election of Charles F. Donnelly and Walter E. Schirmer to the board of the Bendix Corporation was announced at the annual stockholder meeting yesterday in Detroit.

GENEVA, Feb. 29--Skating with the same elegance and precision that won her the Olympic gold medal, Peggy Fleming took a commanding lead in the compulsory figures today and headed for the world figure skating championship.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 29--The big news out of Florida this spring is that the New York Mets are torpedoing their cherished image as the warm, lovable Sad Sacks of baseball.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Syracuse Blazers scored their first Eastern Hockey League victory in 20 games tonight, stopping the Long Island Ducks, 9-7.
"IF I get three hundred for the runabout," David Reitman said yesterday, "I'm going to sell it. A thousand or two for the 25-footer, and that's going to go. We settle for whatever we can get."

The possibility that United Utilities, Inc., which last summer lost an acquisition battle to the Continental Telephone Corporation, might have to compete with the giant International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the Carolina Telephone and Telegraph Company was confirmed late yesterday.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 29 (Reuters)--The first victims of Britain's immigration bill were turned back tonight at the Nairobi airport.

When the American Toy Fair opens on March 11, buyers will be getting a look at the ads done for the Gilbert division of Gabriel Industries by Nadler Larimer. And those of you who don't know that Gilbert makes Erector Sets and Chemistry Sets didn't have a childhood.
LONDON, Feb. 29 (AP)--The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended Wednesday (in thousands of pounds) follows;

Precious metals--platinum, palladium and silver--attracted the interest of speculators yesterday, as they have for some time. Volume was quite heavy in all three metals and prices rose, reflecting uncertainties about the international situation.

Interpex, New York's annual spring stamp show, will open this morning at 10 o'clock at the Americana hotel, 52d Street and Seventh Avenue, at which time a new United States air mail envelope and two new United Nations stamps will have their first-day sales. Tomorrow and Sunday the Universal Autograph Collector's Club will hold its annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -Efforts by his backers to produce an instant expression of Presidential support for Nelson A. Rockefeller among Republican Governors yielded less than one-third of the 26 possible endorsements today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 29--The Security Council met briefly this afternoon, but agreed to adjourn debate on South Africa's defiant position on South-West Africa pending further consultations among the 15 Council members.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) --The National Space Club today named Dr. Robert C. Seamans, former deputy administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, as the winner of its Robert H. Goddard Memorial Trophy. The club is an organization of aerospace industry representatives and others interested in space activities.
The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that it was rescinding its controversial plan to charge an annual fee to its retired seamen receiving pensions.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 29 (AP)--The Pabst Brewing Company reported today that net income for 1967 reached $18.21-million, equivalent to $3.82 per share, and 19 per cent more than the profit of $15.3 million, equal to $3.22 per share, reported the preceding year. Dollar sales totaled S320.45-i million, an increase of $38.44-! million over the 1966 figure of! $282.01-million. I
Ex-convicts will conduct a weekly radio show on WBAIFM beginning Monday night. The program, "Both Sides of the Bars," will be presented at 9 P.M. and repeated Wednesday at 12:15 P.M.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 29 (UPI)--Members of the San Francisco Federation of Teachers voted a strike tonight in a dispute over pay and other issues.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 29 (Reuters) -- Archbishop Makarios was sworn in today for his second term as President of Cyprus. In a speech, he declared that Greek-Cypriots wanted to "live peacefully together with the Turkish-Cypriots in a united and undivided Cyprus."
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 29-Two Jordanians, an army sergeant and a civilian, were publicly hanged at dawn today after having been convicted by a military tribunal on charges of spying for Israel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29--An advisory committee reported today that "uncontrollable violent behavior" of drivers "almost certainly contributes to a significant number of automobile crashes."
DETROIT, Feb. 29 (AP)--Automobile production rose this week as labor problems eased in the United States car industry.

WAUSAU, Wis., Feb. 29 (UPI) --General Telephone and Electronics Corporation today announced it has accomplished the first known successful transmission of an X-ray picture over conventional long distance telephone lines.

MIAMI, Feb. 29--Angel Cordero, the Puerto Rican jockey who is on the verge of setting a Hialeah meeting record, had only one winner on today's card, in contrast to his six-victory performance yesterday.
WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 29 (AP)--A 21-year-old Holy Cross football star found dead in his dormitory room early today apparently had inhaled a lethal dose of an anesthetic, the police said.

NEWARK, Feb. 29 -- Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio rejected today the idea of a police civilian review board for this city and called instead for consideration of an ombudsman system to protect all citizens against "the abuse of power."

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 29-Four of the 23 persons arrested in a raid here last night were booked today on charges of petty larceny and assault and battery. The other 19 were accused of "obstructing justice."
W. R. GRACE CO. did a turn in the spotlight yesterday and the beam was too hot for comfort.
LONDON, Feb. 29 -- Most newspaper reviewers here welcomed, but with reservations, "Cabaret," which opened here tonight at the Palace Theater.
Joseph Papp, founder and producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, said yesterday he was planning to do both parts of "Henry IV" on July 13, 20 and 27 at Central Park's Delacorte Theater.

TRENTON, Feb. 29 (AP)-Two Trenton men and a girl from Hamilton Township were found dead today in a car parked off Carnegie Road. The deaths were ruled accidental, resulting from carbon monoxide poisoning. The police identified the victims as William T. Schaffener, 22 years old, the owner of the car, Philip J. Drum, 21, and Patricia Newbon, 17.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- Win, lose or draw on Monday night at Madison Square Garden, Joe Frazier will reward the stockholders in Cloverlay, Inc., the group that has financed his ascent in boxing, with their first cash dividend.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 29 (UPI)--The police said that at least four of those arrested belonged to a militant group seeking Puerto Rican independence from the United States.
Eight hundred rain-soaked students from Long Island University's Brooklyn Center demonstrated near City Hall yesterday to protest the proposed sale of their campus to the City University.

Mayor Lindsay and two top police officials visited a critically wounded patrolman yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. The patrolman, Paul Burke, 32 years old, had been shot in the abdomen by an unidentified man in the basement at 214 Audubon Avenue near 176th Street early yesterday. Mr. Lindsay was accompanied by Police Commissioner Howard R. Lury and Chief Inspector Sadford D. Garelik.
LONDON, Friday, March 1-The House of Lords talked past the Government's midnight deadline last night for its emergency immigration bill.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29--Two of the chief architects of a bipartisan compromise on open housing sought today to scale down their own proposal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29--Dr. George B. Kistiakowsky, a leading figure in American science and for two decades an adviser to the Defense Department, has withdrawn from all Government activities directly related to the war.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
JUST when some ski area operators were beginning to wonder whether someone in authority had placed an embargo on new snow, along came a storm last night to put such fears at rest.
A Manhattan liquor store owner felled a robbery suspect and drove a second one off with a pistol last night, the police said.
ATHENS, Feb. 29 -- The Greek regime recalled its ambassador to Sweden today and charged Sweden as well as Denmark with having made "blunt interventions in Greece's domestic affairs."

HOUSTON, Feb. 29 (UPI)-Mrs. Martha Chaffee, widow of the astronaut Roger Chaffee, was married last Saturday to a Houston real estate developer, William C. Canfield, in a quiet church ceremony, it was reported today. The bride's first husband was one of three astronauts killed Jan. 27, 1967 in the Apollo fire.

GENEVA, Feb. 29 (AP)-European Free Trade Association countries increased their imports from the United States last year by 5.5 per cent, to $3.69-billion, but their exports to the United States declined by 1.6 per cent to $3-billion.

A possible tie-up of the Long Island Rail Road was averted last night when maintenance workers and the railroad agreed to submit to arbitration a dispute about a change in working conditions. Although 1,000 members of the International Brotherhood of Teamster's Local 808 walked off their jobs yesterday morning, service was not affected.
An "informational" picket line will be placed tonight by Actors Equity in front of the Mermaid Theater, 442 West 42d Street, to protest the employment of nonunion actors in "Nighthawks."
DETROIT, Feb. 29 (UPI)-The General Motors Corporation was hit today by a second assembly line strike when allnight bargaining failed to produce a local contract settlement at Van Nuys, Calif.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 (UPI) --Howie Hughes and Ed Joyal scored 25-foot goals in the third period tonight, giving the Los Angeles Kings a 3-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 29--The price of food in Saigon, which rose from 80 to 100 per cent shortly after the enemy's recent assault on the cities, has dropped sharply.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 29--Jud Little scored on a backhand shot at 4 minutes, 10 seconds of a sudden - death overtime period tonight to give Pennsylvania a 12-11 victory over Virginia in a first-round game of the national intercollegiate polo championship.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 29 (UPI)--Davidson routed William and Mary, 107-68, and Carey Bailey led West Virginia to a 76-71 victory over East Carolina tonight to advance to the semi-finals of the Southern Conference tournament.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 29--Israel has removed the designation "enemy territory" from the areas occupied by her forces last June during the war with the Arabs.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- A worried Mexican Olympic delegation scored its point today as Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, set the stage for reconsideration of South Africa's controversial entry in the October Games at Mexico City.
Supreme Court Justice Charles Marks chided a grand jury yesterday, because it had drafted a resolution on the drug problem and made it public without the court's permission.
MERIDIAN, Miss., March 1 (UPI) -- The police have been ordered to "shoot to kill" if necessary to stop an outbreak of night rider attacks, Chief C. L. Gunn said today.
BRUSSELS, March 1 -- There is a growing feeling in Europe that the United States and other members of the socalled international gold pool will stop supporting the price of gold in the London market.

HOUSTON, March 1--President Johnson announced today that he was summoning all parties in the 231-day copper strike to an emergency conference in the White House on Monday. The President wants them to begin round-the-clock bargaining.

Federal Judge John M. Cannella granted a temporary restraining order here yesterday blocking the Federal Reserve from applying its margin regulations to a group of six city moneylenders until next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Western diplomatic circles are fearful that the recent wave of demonstrations in Cairo will undermine prospects of indirect talks between the United Arab Republic and Israel for a negotiated settlement in the Middle East.
Two reputed Maria henchmen who assaulted a member of a rival gang in the Copacabana Club in 1962 pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of third-degree assault yesterday.
A 53-year-old man went berserk with an icepick on a crowded corner in Lower Manhattan yesterday and stabbed two secretaries and two men who went to their aid before being overpowered by two patrolmn.

The program presented by Indrani and Her Dancers and Musicians of India at the downtown Anderson Theater last night was, except for three new dances, essentially the same as her Hunter College presentation a little more than a month ago.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- The New York Mets have been buoyed by a lot of tricks, gimmicks and stunts in their six seasons as the underdogs of baseball. But this year will mark the first time they have got a lift from the halfback-option play of County Training High School in Mobile, Ala.
SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 28--Some time this spring, "The Dream of the Butterfly" will have its premiere on an opera stage in Bonn.

The most disturbing aspect of the threatened boycott of the summer Olympic Games is that it provides one more example of the refusal of African nations to live by accepted rules of international conduct. They say, in effect: Run this show our way or we won't play.

Analysis of United States and North Vietnamese commentaries on the war shows how differently the two sides view the strategic development of the conflict. The United States measures military success in terms of battles won and Communist casualty rates.

IF YOU BELIEVE Matthew L. Devine, the attempt of Solitron Devices to drag Amphenol Corporation to the altar is going badly. That was the appraisal Amphenol's chairman made yesterday when Solitron announced it was extending its offer for Amphenol shares until March 11.
DOWNSTAIRS AT RAMSEY'S. By James Leigh. 250 pages. Harper and Row. $4.95.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 2--Fighting on the northern outskirts of Saigon quickened today, with the South Vietnamese and American commands reporting more than 20 engagements in the last two days.
A strike by van drivers, packers and warehousemen yesterday stopped household moves and the relocation of office equipment in the five boroughs and parts of Long Island.
The Cleveland Browns yesterday signed Leroy Kelly, their star running back, to a four-year contract and thus eased a dilemma for all of pro football.
MIAMI, March 1 -- The Flamingo Stakes, the most glamorous event on the Hialeah program, will have its 39th running tomorrow and as the popular saying goes, "it's a tough race."
TORONTO, March 1 -- The Canadian Government reported today that it had spent $113.4million in February to support the Canadian dollar in foreignexchange trading.

An overnight snowstorm followed by winds gusting to more than 50 miles an hour crippled traffic in sections of the metropolitan area yesterday, caused power blackouts and accidents and made commuters miserable.
Stock prices declined yesterday for the third consecutive session in active trading.
THE BULLET-RIDDLED costumes of "Bonnie and Clyde" were barely cold in their graves before the fashion industry had latched on to another film, "Elvira Madigan."
TORONTO, March 1 (AP) -- Tracy Smith of the United States Army broke his own world indoor three-mile record tonight in 13 minutes 15 seconds in the Toronto Telegram-Maple Leaf Track Games.
Can a Roman Catholic eat meat on Fridays during Lent? The answer is "yes" in some dioceses, and "no" in others.
ATHENS, March 1 -- Premier George Papadopoulos promised tonight that a plebiscite would be held this summer on a new constitution that would preserve the monarchy in Greece and wipe out Communism.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- This is a sporting city. Downtown, the shuffleboard disks slide endlessly along concrete alleys, urged on by the grunts and mumbles of old men whose training tables are in the Orange Blossom Cafeteria, and by the cheerful recreation aides who confide, "Isn't it so much better to drop dead on the shuffleboard court than all alone in a New York rooming house?"

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 1 (AP) -- Mike Butler, the Big Ten hurdles champion from Wisconsin, equaled two records tonight, highlighting preliminary events in the conference's 58th annual indoor track and field championship.
DETROIT, March 1 -- The Whirlpool Corporation said today that the continuation of the copper strike could force the closing of its factories in April and the laying off of 16,000 workers.

BUDAPEST, March 1 -- Rumania's dramatic decision yesterday to walk out of the world meeting of Communist parties was viewed here as a move toward a showdown between Bucharest and Moscow that might quickly lead to a Rumanian break with the Soviet Union and the camp it dominates.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -The president of the Benrus Watch Company, Inc., and one of his fellow directors have invented an atomic watch. It is designed to keep time by electronic measurement of the decay of a small quantity of radioactive material in the case.

Rockets, mortars and other new arms made by the Soviet Union and Communist China, many of them comparable in qualify to United States weapons, have turned the guerrilla war in Vietnam into a largely conventional war.
The designer Valentino is expected to fly in from Rome to present his spring collection at a fashion show to be held March 12 at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof to benefit the Kips Bay Boys' Club.
A Manhattan housewife, speaking at a hearing, made the talk-weary State Board of Social Welfare perk up yesterday by proposing that low-income women be given $500 a year not to have babies.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--In city after city across America, the police are stockpiling armored vehicles, helicopters and high-powered rifles.

BEAUMONT, Tex., March 1 -- President Johnson took off on another of his weekend excursions around the country today, touching not only several bases but also all of the live political issues of this election year.

SCRIMSHAW -- decorative work in whalebone and ivory produced aboard whalers during the golden era of whaling -- is an important medium of American folk art. A fine selection is now on view at the Museum of American Folk Art at 49 West 53d Street.
LONDON, March 1 -- The United States dollar came under renewed attack today with heavy buying of gold for dollars in the London gold market.
New Yorkers reported 12.4 per cent more crimes in January than in the same month last year, the Police Department announced yesterday.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation, which is centering its interests in nonfood consumer goods, is planning to acquire the Electrolux Corporation, maker of floor-cleaning equipment. If the transaction is consummated, it would involve stock with an approximate value of $150-million.

Ballets, fairly or unfairly, are often judged by the company they keep. In the repertory of the New York City Ballet, for which it was created, Ruthanna Boris's "Cakewalk" was never fully appreciated. But nestled comfortably with the City Center Joffrey Ballet's for the past three years, it finds itself properly recognized as an authentic re-creation of a more innocent time in the American sensibility.

THERE were five other visitors in the Leo Castelli Gallery, 4 East 77th Street, when I went to see the new paintings by Jasper Johns now on exhibition. One visitor was a frail-looking, paint-stained young man with dirty hair, not warmly enough dressed for the cold day, who seemed to have been exalted to a state of mystical bliss by the show.

Under fierce attack from many directions, Britain's Labor Government earlier this week made what seemed to be a major concession in the discriminatory immigration bill that has now become law. Home Secretary James Callaghan said Britain would accept British citizens of Asian origin who lost their jobs under Kenya's "Africanization" drive and had no other place to go.
The American Dock Company's major pier and warehouse complex on Staten Island has been purchased by the General Property Corporation.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 1 -- The State School Superintendent tonight abandoned at least temporarily his efforts to persuade the State Board of Education to give county school boards the right to negotiate teacher contracts with the Florida Education Association.
Despite outside temperatures, an atmosphere of spring will pervade the interior of the New York Coliseum beginning at 10 A.M. today.

The community board that is scheduled to govern Intermediate School 201 was told yesterday that it would not be granted official status as long as it retained Herman B. Ferguson, a suspended assistant principal, as a paid adviser.

UNTIL recently Ken Isaacs's double-decker, multipurpose environment might have won a prize for being the biggest piece of living room furniture extant. The designer's 72-inch cube sleeps two, dines six and, in a pinch, a dozen or more could party in it.
Rumors originating in Europe swept through the foreign exchange markets here yesterday and put pressure on several key currencies, including the dollar.
The Metropolitan Opera's production of "L'Elisir d'Amore," one of the most genial in its repertory, returned last night after a season's absence.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 1 -- The head of the Israel Bond Organization emphasized today that the technical and scientific aid being extended by Israel to newly emerging African and Asian countries would be made immediately available to the Arab states as soon as a permanent peace settlement were reached in the Middle East.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 1 -- The South Vietnamese House of Representatives today rejected a request by President Nguyen Van Thieu that he be given emergency powers to rule by decree for one year.
ALBANY, Mar. 1 -- The chancellor of the State University appealed to the Legislature today to increase security forces on state campuses from 328 to 450 to cope with "general unrest and activism."

JUDGING from the applause at Janet Baker's Carnegie Hall recital last night, New York audiences have found a new lieder singer to love. It was not merely polite applause. It was warm, full, appreciative, the kind that lets an artist know she is adored.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A 97.2-mile urban rapid transit system was authorized today for traffic-clogged Washington and its Maryland and Virginia suburbs.

Students at the City College of New York, once one of the nation's major basketball powers, are rooting these days for a new type of campus hero. He -- or she -- is a member of the school's four-man team that competes at 6 P.M. tomorrow against the University of Southern California on "College Bowl," the National Broadcasting Company's television quiz show.
Platform tennis, a winter outdoor sport that combines lawn tennis, squash racquets and handball, opens the biggest tournament in its 40-year history today.

SEATTLE, March 1 (UPI) -- Harry Edwards, the man behind the move to boycott the Olympic Games, said tonight a second set of games will be staged this year in an African country "in the true spirit of the Olympic movement."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A few days ago a staff member of the President's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders pointed to a stocky, brown-eyed man rushing down a Capitol corridor with his hands stuffed in his coat pockets and said: "There goes my favorite commission member.
BUENOS AIRES, March 1 -- Jorge Antonio Vago, director and editor of two publications closed by the Argentine Government last year, has been released from jail after nearly three months' imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -The report of the President's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, finding white racism to be the chief cause of riots and making costly recommendations to stop them, stirred a controversy in Congress today.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Senate jolted backers of an open housing compromise today by refusing to halt debate on civil rights.
BUENOS AIRES, March 1 -- The taxi driver snarled. "No member of my family will ever wear the filthy things."

Robert Moses lost his last chairmanship yesterday as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority formally took over the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority he headed. It also took over the city's subway system.
Bond prices declined slightly yesterday amid a flurry of uncertainty in the foreign exchange market here and the market for gold abroad.

THE erratic migration habits of fish make interesting study material for ichthyologists but pose problems for fishermen around the world. In recent years, a shortage of shrimp in northern European waters has upped the price of the delicacy, which is a much-prized part of the smorgasbord in Scandinavian countries.

CLEVELAND, March 1 (AP) -- Martin McGrady, the world's indoor record-holder in the 600-yard run, posted his 18th straight victory tonight with a meet record clocking of 1 minute 10 seconds in the 28th Knights of Columbus track meet.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- A $48.3-million authorization sought for development of a nuclear rocket for interplanetary space flight was rejected today by a House space subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -Governor Rockefeller of New York said today that he would run for President if the Republican party wanted him, but he said he would not divide the party by competing in any primaries.
PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (UPI) -- High winds tore three holes in the roof of the new Spectrum today and caused an indefinite closing of the $12-million sports arena by city officials.

MARIETTA, Ga., March 1 (AP) -- Aviation industry representatives from around the globe will be on hand tomorrow when the C-5A galaxy, the world's largest airplane, is rolled out and christened in elaborate ceremonies.

The jitters over precious metals have been ruffing traders' nerves and sending futures prices higher in recent sessions. Yesterday continued talk about possible currency devaluation in other nations and a possible halt to the sale of gold by the United States managed to shake wheat, corn and soybeans out of their doldrums.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Federal Communications Commission today said it would consider revising its "personal attack" rules as an outgrowth of a law suit challenging the new policy of requiring a station that criticizes an individual over the air to offer him an opportunity to reply.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- There were no medals, no speeches, no honor guards and no public words of praise from the President of the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- Columbia, which has not won the Ivy League basketball title since 1951, clinched at least a tie for that championship tonight when the Lions broke open a tight game midway in the second half and went on to beat Pennsylvania, 59-43, at the Palestra.
Because of a rearrangement of show dates, it may be hard to tell the flowers from the forest today at the Coliseum.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 -- A strike of unionized teachers today led to minor vandalism and to the closing of San Francisco's public schools at mid-day. It was the first walkout of public school teachers in the city's history and was participated in by about one-fourth of the 4,497 teachers.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 1 -- Princeton University's defending Ivy League basketball champions, playing their best game of the season, blasted Cornell off the Dillon Gymnasium floor tonight, 89-52.
The new motor vessel Newtown Creek, the latest addition to the fleet of municipal craft active in the port, made her debut here yesterday.
AN honor card is sometimes an embarrassment to a defender, but the situation may not be clear to him until the post-mortem.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 1 -- There was strongly negative reaction today to the Israeli announcement yesterday that Arab territories occupied last June were no longer "enemy territory."

The scheduled appearance of Secretary of State Dean Rusk before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on March 11 led yesterday to a new chapter in the running controversy over multiple network coverage of the same event.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., March 1 -- Quietly, in a change of scenery and a change of atmosphere, Nino Benvenuti is preparing to challenge Emile Griffith for the world middleweight title in a "preliminary" bout Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

The Sperry Hutchinson Company reported yesterday consolidated net earnings of $28,160,000, equal to $2.62 a share, which includes $3,861,000, or 36 cents a share, of the earnings of Bigelow - Sanford, Inc., since March of last year, when it was acquired for $73million cash.

BUDAPEST, March 1 -- The Rumanians who stalked out of the consultative conference of Communist parties here last night left for home in a special plane early today to report to an emergency meeting of their party's Central Committee.

LE PAVILLON, mother of New York's finest French restaurants is undergoing reorganization and refinancing. Claudius C. Philippe, the hotelman, and charity-ball promoter, has withdrawn as a part-time owner and unsalaried manager of the restaurant.
ROME, March 1 -- Two journalists in Rome were sentenced to prison today for the criminal libel of an Italian general whom they had accused of preparing a right-wing coup d'etat in 1964.

WESTBURY, L. I., March 1 -- A 10-man crew, working overtime with plows, bulldozers, payloaders, trucks and graders removed about five inches of snow today from the main track and assured a harness racing program tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Treasury announced steps today to insure that the Government can continue to sell two million ounces of silver a week to the private market.

DUE partly to the influence of Richard Bellamy, an associate of the Noah Goldowsky Gallery and possibly the most talented talent-spotter from here to the Coast, the unpretentious little group shows staged by the gallery, 1078 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, rank among the freshest of the season.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1 -- A qualified diplomatic source reported tonight that Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, Secretary General Thant's special representative in the Mid dle East, would invite Israel, the United Arab Republic and Jordan to send representatives to negotiations on a peace settlement.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 1, -- The breakup of thousands of Asian families in Kenya holding British passports was forecast by Asian community leaders today.
A Federal court upheld yesterday state and city welfare regulations that take certain assets from welfare recipients to compensate for relief payments they have received.

Mayor Lindsay ordered top city officials yesterday to examine the 1,400-page report of the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders to see what new steps the city could take toward ending racial tensions.

Civil rights leaders, generally pleased with the report of the President's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, expressed particular satisfaction yesterday with the panel's conclusion that white racism was primarily to blame for the conditions that led to rioting in the cities.
The United States Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday that the Port Authority Bus Terminal was an appropriate public place for peaceful political expression.

PUERTO ASIS, Colombia -The largest capital project in this country today is the development of the Orito oilfield, in a dank wilderness where the Andes plummet from their chill clouds to meet the Amazon jungle.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Some police officials decried today a Presidential commission's warning that equipping police departments with "mass destruction weapons" poses grave dangers for the nation's cities.
LONDON, March 1 -- The emergency immigration bill, designed to stop the influx of British citizens of Asian ancestry from Kenya, became law today.

NEWARK, March 1 -- On a sultry summer night eight months ago a Negro mob, incensed by rumors that the police had beaten a Negro taxi driver to death, pelted the Fourth Precinct station with bricks, bottles and firebombs.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- President Johnson warmly welcomed his long-time friend and adviser Clark M. Clifford into his Cabinet today as Secretary of Defense.
BONN, March 1 -- President Heinrich Lubke went on television and radio tonight to repudiate charges that he had participated in building German concentration camps during World War II.

THE Queens of England are enjoying a revival of interest in many media. While the Broadway stage earlier in the week welcomed Dorothy Tutin's portrait of Victoria, the National Educational Television Playhouse last night imported a study of Elizabeth I in the years prior to her accession.

Radmila Bakocevic, a Yugoslav soprano, will make her Metropolitan Opera debut on April 5, during the 29th week of the company's season, in the title role of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly." Barry Morell will appear as Pinkerton, Nedda Casei will take the part of Suzuki and Theodor Uppman will be Sharpless.
DETROIT, March 1 -- Walter P. Reuther, the president of the United Automobile Workers, has decided to postpone the showdown in his fight with the labor federation and its president, George Meany.

GENEVA, March 1 -- Emmerrich Danzer, a husky Viennese salesman, defeated Tim Wood, an American college student, for the world figure-skating championship tonight with a brilliant display of free skating.

ROCHESTER, March 1 -Pickets paraded today in front of the headquarters of the Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Roman Catholic Bishop of the Rochester Diocese, to protest the gift of parish buildings to the Federal Government for use by the poor.

Elvin Hayes, the 6-foot-8-inch scorer and rebounder for the top-ranked University of Houston Cougars, was voted the college basketball player-of-the-year for 1968 yesterday in a landslide over Lew Alcindor of the University of California Los Angeles.

THE New York theater has now not one but two fabulous invalids: The same pessimistic physicians who see Broadway in the terminal phase of a chronic illness nowadays offer a similar prognosis for Off Broadway.

The outline of a fascinating jazz experience surged through Washington Square Church at 133 West Fourth Street last night when Roswell Rudd and his Primordial Jazz Orchestra presented "Blues for the Planet Earth."

Your Feb. 23 editorial calling attention to the desirability of settling labor disputes of public employes by binding arbitration as a last step in the present no-strike law, provides a useful starting point for new legislation.

OTAVALO, Ecuador -- Tucked away for centuries in a forgotten fold of the Andes, this market town of about 10,000 people is developing into the showplace of Indian cultural and economic life.

NORMALLY, the Sunday before examination week is a lean one at college chapels; rather than pray for good grades, students tend to stay home and study for them. At Smith College, in Northampton, Mass., the second Sunday after Epiphany was an exception. Scrubbed and sleek in demure below-the-knee dresses and suits, hundreds of Smithies slogged through several inches of snow to pack Helen Hills Hills Chapel to the balcony.

KANSAS CITY, March 2 (AP) -- The Big Eight voted today to permit freshmen to compete in all varsity sports except football and basketball, effective with the 1968-1969 school year.

BONN, March 2 -- West Germany's Chamber of Commerce and Industry asserted this week that the country's economy and social structure were threatened by one-sided school policies that concentrated on turning out well-educated people.

ROME, March 2 -- Instructors and research assistants at Rome University took over today for students who have been agitating for educational reform.

BERLIN, March 2 -- Mayor Klaus Schutz of West Berlin asked the Premier of East Germany this week to arrange an agreement enabling West Berliners to visit relatives in the East during the Easter holidays in April.

NEARLY everyone knows that Walt Whitman is America's greatest poet, yet there is always an uneasiness about his position. Professional Americanists protest too much, and their opponents say too little. Even the poets have not been very helpful about him.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 2 (AP) -- Anil Nayar of Harvard, the defender, swept through two matches in the opening rounds last night in the 35th national intercollegiate squash racquets championships at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -Richard Nixon was overstating it when he said that the withdrawal of George Romney had made the race for the Republican Presidential nomination "a new ball game." It has been plain for months that the real showdown probably would come between Nixon and Nelson Rockefeller, and Romney's surprise departure only confirmed that fact.
CADIZ, Ohio, March 2 -Deeds covering more than 200,000 acres in Harrison County have been filed at the courthouse here indicating the oil boom in Stark County to the north is slowly moving southward.

Maintenance can be kept low with a limited group of plants, probably not the showiest, definitely not the most unusual or hardest to grow, but rather native plants or those which are tolerant of a wide range of growing conditions.

ROME, March 4 -- A Columbia University professor said tonight that he and colleagues of an investigating committee had recommended the withdrawal of a Columbia doctoral degree from a Greek bank official on the ground that his thesis was a work of plagiarism.

MIAMI, March 4 -- When Hank Bauer, the battle-hardened ex-Marine, surveyed his troops for the first time last spring, life seemed wonderful. His Baltimore Orioles were the champions of this and every other planet, having pulverized the Dodgers in a sweep of the 1966 World Series.
PITTSBURGH, March 4 (AP) -- A judge who issued an injunction that failed to block a strike of school teachers here said today that he was "attempting to get the two parties together."

In a $1-million leasing agreement, Steiner House, an international hair-styling establishment, has taken a long-term lease on a three-story building at 149 East 57th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues.

ATLANTA, March 4 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today set Monday, April 22, as the starting date of his "nonviolent poor people's march on Washington." For the first time he decisively linked its antidiscrimination and antipoverty objectives to a campaign to end the war in Vietnam.
A private survey of the 60 largest cities and towns in New Jersey was reported yesterday to have found a widespread misuse of Federal funds for disadvantaged parochial school children.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic who refused to be inducted into the Army, saying he was prohibited from participating in an "unjust war." was refused review today by the Supreme Court of his two-year jail sentence.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 -Striking public school teachers returned to their classrooms here today after a one-day walkout ended by a peace formula worked out in weekend conferences.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 4 -- Jack R. Robinson Jr., 21-yearold son of Jackie Robinson, the former baseball player, was arrested today on a charge of possessing heroin.
NEW DELHI, March 4 -- For the second time in two weeks, the Indian Parliament has worked itself up to fever pitch over a disputed stretch of barren, uninhabited land.

Bond prices declined yesterday in a reaction that dealers pinned mostly to increased uncertainly in gold and foreign exchange markets.
Goodbody Co. greeted the return to regular trading hours yesterday by putting into operation an electronic system to speed the reporting of transactions from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -The Treasury is considering the possibility of ending the tax exemption of the interest on industrial revenue bonds by administrative ruling rather than legislation.

LONDON, March 4 -- Continuing speculation over a possible change in the dollar price for gold produced heavy demand in the London gold market again today. Volume, however, was below the level of Friday's rush to buy.

OTTAWA, March 6 -- The Government announced today that it would cut spending and try again to raise taxes to stop inflation and strengthen the Canadian dollar.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The House voted today to extend the life of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency but trimmed both its funds and the length of its authorization.

TORONTO, March 6 (AP) -- Norm Ullman, Paul Henderson and Floyd Smith, newcomers, scored a goal each and Bob Pulford, seasoned star, tallied twice tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs crushed the Philadelphia Flyers, 7-2.

Two captains, a lieutenant and a sergeant have been transferred out of the Police Department's Narcotics Bureau as the department continues to investigate charges that the bureau is "riddled with corruption."
TOKYO, March 6 -- The focus in Japan's defense secrets scandal turned today to former armed forces officers who have joined private companies that hold defense contracts.

The annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies will be held from April 25 to 27 at the grand Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va. It is usually a time for big meals, golf, tennis, riding, trap shooting, speeches, and talk about the business.
Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation, a subsidiary of Litton Industries, has won a $113,072,000 Navy contract for the design and construction of four ammunition ships, the company confirmed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- A new investigation of corruption in the South Vietnamese Government was promised today by Senator Ernest Gruening, chairman of the Senate foreign aid expenditures subcommittee.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- Arthur J. Goldberg formally protested to the Commission on Human Rights today against the suppression of free speech in the Soviet Union through the imprisonment of dissenting writers.

IN the chilled, early minutes of last Tuesday morning, Buster Mathis stood on the curb of 33d Street wrapped in a red windbreaker, waiting for a car to take him away. He never turned as Joe Frazier burst out of Madison Square Garden and swept down the street in a roaring crowd of friends. Mathis just stood there, hunched and silent, surrounded by a few friends and members of his family.
When investors let off steam and sell their stocks, the pressure is often felt in commodity markets, where prices of "hedge" precious metals rise.
NEWARK, March 6 -- New Jersey railroads protested today a cut of $18.6-million in the proposed state budget for improved commuter rail service.

With or without a tax increase, the revenue-producing cry of "They're Off!" appears virtually certain to sound next Monday at Aqueduct.
Eight new members have joined the New York Film Critics, it was announced yesterday after the group's monthly meeting.
Faced with early losses "in excess of $100,000," World Championship Tennis, Inc., is preparing a new format under revised management for its eight-player professional tour.

CLOVIS, N. M., March 6 -- An Air Force law officer ruled today that a general court-martial here would not be a testing ground for a challenge of the constitutionality of the service's regulation on conscientious objectors.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 5 -Barry Goldwater today avoided newsmen seeking clarification of his position on the possible Republican Presidential nomination of Governor Rockefeller.
DETROIT, March 6 (UPI) -- Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh called striking Teamsters and the city's two newspapers into a meeting with state and Federal mediators today.

LONDON, March 6 -- The rush to sell dollars and buy gold continued unchecked on the London gold market today. Since the rush began a week ago, purchases of gold have totaled about $200-million, 10 times a normal week's demand.
" The girls uptown are prettier than the ones down here," a Wall Street broker observed yesterday. "Their miniskirts are shorter, too."

The United States riot commission report, issued by Bantam Books in association with The New York Times as a $1.25 paperback on Monday, is selling at a rate equaled only by "The mission on the Assassination of President Kennedy."
