An armed man was shot and killed yesterday afternoon in the Bedford-Stuyvesantsection of Brooklyn as he attempted to hold up a Rand dry cleaning store where two detectives were staked out in a rear room.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (Reuters) -- The State Department objected today to Russian charges that protection was not adequate at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, damaged by a bomb explosion Feb. 21.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Something terrible is happening to the Presidential campaign this year. It is all being settled in the press before anybody has had a chance to cast a vote.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Johnson has decided not to enter any of the 15 Presidential primaries except those three where state law would make his candidacy automatic.
The Vietnam war and the plight of Negro ghettos dimmed the sense of celebration of the annual National Book Awards ceremony at Philharmonic Hall last night.

Gold-mining shares were down on profit taking, yester day on the London Stock Ex change, although a rush to buy gold bullion continued in the British capital. Industrial is sues turned mixed in moderate trading.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 6 -The State Supreme Court ruled today that North Carolina could not issue industrial revenue bonds as an enticement for new industry to locate here unless the state constitution is changed.

A 48-year-old truck operator employed by the city was electrocuted yesterday and his helper critically burned in a freak accident at the Queens municipal dump, Lefferts Bouleard and 164th Place, Jamaica.
A wave of primary fights in New York unequaled since the 1912 campaign now appears likely within the Democratic party.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Donald H. Elliott, the chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, is expected to be named to one of four new positions on the expanded board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

The largest garden apartment group in Nutley, N. J., consisting of 39 brick buildings on a tract of 9 1/2 acres, has been sold by Alexander Muss Sons to a group of Essex County investors.

The narrow hallway in 102 Herzl Street is as dark and chill as the wintry street outside. Most of the apartments in the building have been abandoned and stripped bare by vandals. Plaster crumbles at the touch and the stairs groan ominously.

Several hundred New York University students and faculty members, angered by an alleged "brush-off" of student demands to end job recruiting by the Dow Chemical Company, demonstrated against the school administration yesterday.

CURTISS-WRIGHT has finally had to show its hand and it is full of Dorr-Oliver shares.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- President Johnson said today that he was not satisfied with the 16 per cent increase in Social Security benefits that went to elderly citizens starting this month. He said that he would "keep on fighting" to get a total of 20 per cent and a minimum of $70 a month for every person on Social Security.

Y.; Leonid Stein, champion of the Soviet Union, and Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia, followed identical patterns, step by step, through opening, midgame and ending.
The United Parents Associations charged yesterday that it frequently took a year, and sometimes up to four years, to deliver supplies requisitioned by city schools.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it would cover live the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing Monday, at which Secretary of State Dean Rusk is expected to yield to Senator J. W. Fulbright's demands that he submit to questioning on the Vietnamese war.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 6 -- A controversy is continuing to build here over a National Guard riot training exercise during which National Guard troops will be concentrated in the state's four metropolitan areas next weekend.
PARIS, March 6 -- An ItalianFrench syndicate has won a contract to build the world's largest earth dam, on the Indus River in West Pakistan.

LONDON, March 7 -- John Freeman, Britain's High Commissioner to India, was named today as Ambassador to Washington. He will replace Sir Patrick Dean there early next year.

CONWAY, N. H., March 7 -- As Richard M. Nixon nears the end of his month-long quest for victory in the first of the nation's Presidential primaries, his campaign speeches are showing subtle and perhaps lasting changes.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Senate critics of the United States' Vietnam policy opened a new offensive against the Administration today by demanding that Congress be consulted before additional troops were committed to the war.

CLOVIS, N. M., March 7--The question of mental competency was debated at length here today at the general court-martial of an Air Force officer who refuses to train pilots to fly in Vietnam.

Joe Namath, the New York Jets' celebrated quarterback, will undergo "minor" surgery March 20 on his left knee -- the good knee.

CUMMINS PRISON FARM, Ark., March 7 (AP) -- Thomas O. Murton, the penologist brought to Arkansas one year ago to institute reform in the state prison system, was dismissed tonight as the state prison superintendent, effective immediately, by the state Board of Correction, apparently on orders from Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller.

KIEL, West Germany, Feb. 29 -- Skulking only 200 yards off shore from the end of the runway of Kiel's naval air station today is a Soviet oceanic tug, its masts loaded with bulbous electronic gear like grapevines in September.
Changes in senior management were made yesterday by the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad; U.S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc.; Heublein, Inc.; the U.S. Borax Chemical Corporation, and Eversharp, Inc.

MENLO PARK, Calif., March 6 -- An analysis of seismic records from the vicinity of Denver has persuaded a number of specialists that unless remedial action is taken -- and perhaps despite such action -- an earthquake of man-made origin may inflict serious damage on that city this year.

PRAGUE, March 7 -- Czechoslovakia asked the United States today to extradite a Czech general who has been linked here with an unsuccessful move to prevent the ouster of the former Communist party leader, Antonin Novotny.
BONN, March 7 -- Giuseppe Verdi knew what he was doing when he decided not to add a "Hamlet" opera to his successful series of "musicalized" Shakespearean dramas.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 7 -- Mayor Wheelock Whitney of suburban Wayzata said today a state headquarters with a fulltime director would be set up by the end of this week in Minneapolis to organize a Minnesota draft for Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Following are excerpts from the debate on Vietnam on the Senate floor today:
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 7 (AP) -- The Maryland Court of Appeals ruled today that the state's open housing law passed by the General Assembly in 1967 must be submitted to a referendum.

TOKYO, March 7 -- A communique issued in Peking at the conclusion or an agreement between a Japanese trade group and Chinese Communist representatives yesterday declared that the Japanese had agreed to three political principles for which China had been pressing during the month-long talks.

DURBAN, South Africa, March 7 -- Alan Paton, the 65-year-old author of "Cry the Beloved Country," was choked into unconsciousness and robbed by two Africans in Clermont African Township near Durban, the police said today.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended March 2 was above the corresponding period of last year. Intercity truck tonnage, however, registered a decrease.
The New York Athletic Club refused yesterday to obey a subpoena of its officers and records by the City Commission on Human Rights.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The nation is letting money decide who shall live and who shall die when certain fatal diseases are involved, witnesses told a Senate subcommittee today.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Navy planners report that a new plane has been thrown into the campaign against the North Vietnamese troops threatening the Marine outpost at Khesanh.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Manufacturers expect their inventories to increase in line with their sales during the first half of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) -- The Senate weakened today the open housing provisions of its civil rights bill.
NEW HAVEN, March 7 -- The Yale Daily News announced today it was endorsing Senator Eugene J. McCarthy in his bid for the Presidency.
U. S. Plywood-Champion Paper, Inc., has reached agreement to acquire Drexel Enterprises, Inc., the nation's third largest furniture manufacturer, for stock valued at $100-million.

BOSTON, March 7 -- Lester S. Hyman, chairman of the Democratic state committee, said today that a campaign to educate voters in how to write-in President Johnson's name in the Massachusetts Presidential preference primary on April 30 would be undertaken.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Public schools in the nation's capital were closed today while more than 1,000 teachers appealed to Congress for a pay increase.
Members of the Mafia are beset by a new problem: They are being kidnapped.
MIAMI, March 7 (AP) -- Frank Robinson, a holdout for eight days, signed his 1968 contract with the Baltimore Orioles today.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 7 -- James Dunnigan Jr., was named the new racing secretary at Roosevelt Raceway today.
OTTAWA, March 7 -- Canada announced tonight that it had secured from Washington important new help in a campaign to beat back speculation against the Canadian dollar.
CONWAY, N. H., March 7 -- Richard M. Nixon told a nationwide radio audience tonight that the nation must be prepared "to meet force with force if necessary" in the cities.
" The thing I can't tell is whether cab drivers yield to each other out of fear or respect."
LONDON, March 7 -- Emil Savundra, who headed a cut-rate auto insurance company that collapsed here in 1966, was sentenced today to eight years in prison and fined 50,000 ($120,000).

CONCORD, N.H., March 7 -- President Johnson's principal backer in the New Hampshire primary said today that the people most interested in the results of the challenge by Senator Eugene J. McCarthy are "Ho Chi Minh and his Communist friends."

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Governor Rockefeller's backers have begun to seek Congressional endorsements that push the New York Governor into an early open candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union wants to expand its training program for garment workers to assist the national poverty program, Louis Stulberg, president of the union, said yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 8--The United States military command formally announced a reorganization plan today that will give the Army a greater voice in the northernmost battle zone of South Vietnam but leave the Marine Corps in over-all charge.

BUFFALO, March 7 -- Admirers of plays with a beginning, a middle and an end may very well be disconcerted by Edward Albee's "Box-Mao-Box," which had its world premiere in Buffalo's Studio Arena Theater last night. Yet in a way, "Box-Mao-Box" is nothing but a beginning, middle and an end, for it is a play, or rather a series of plays, without intermission, in which form dominates content.

GENEVA, March 7 -- The United States, the Soviet Union and Britain formally committed themselves today to take "immediate action" through the United Nations Security Council against a nuclear attack or threatened attack on any country that renounces nuclear weapons.

DARIEN, Conn., March 7 -- Pete Orthwein scored 10 goals to lead Cornell to a 22-6 victory over Georgetown in the semi-final round of the National Intercollegiate polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club tonight and set up another showdown game with Yale.
THE clothes racked up on Alexander's third floor yesterday had almost everything going for them. They were haute-couture originals and the prices could be termed reasonable, as these things go.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -Late in 1964 Komsomolskaya Pravda, the Soviet youth newspaper, published a feature article hailing Ivan A. Yakhimovich as a model chairman of a collective farm.

Prices of platinum, palladium and silver futures were bid up yesterday. However, there was no startling news to influence the trading and no big volume. Prices of the three metals all remained below their life-of-contract highs.

Stewart R. Mott, the 30-year-old philanthropist and investor who urged support of Governor Rockefeller for President in advertisements in nine newspapers last weekend, said yesterday that as of noon he had received more than $83,000 in donations for the Rockefeller effort.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 7 (AP) -- Paul D. Speasl, the first cadet at the Air Force Academy ever called to a court-martial, was found not guilty by directed verdict today after three psychiatrists testified he was legally insane.
JERUSALEM, March 7 -- Israeli military authorities extended to Jerusalem last night their practice of dynamiting the homes of suspected Arab terrorists, to the anguish of municipal authorities.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7 (AP) -- President Nguyen Van Thieu's request for additional special powers in the face of the enemy offensive was turned down today by the South Vietnamese Senate.

Upward movement was reported yesterday by Time magazine for Robert C. Gordon, by the Allied Chemical Corporation for Robert A. Raidt, by the American Can Company for Emile Libresco and by Paramount Pictures for Mort Hock.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Crane Company of New York City notified the Securities and Exchange Commission today of a new tack in its efforts to win control of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company, Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON March 7 (UPI) -- The Federal Government brought its first suit under the Clean Air Act today in an effort to compel a Bishop, Md., animal rendering plant to comply with orders against air pollution.

THE second installment of the documentary based on William L. Shirer's book "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich" further substantiated last night that the venture is one of the season's major undertakings in historical reportage for television.

LAST evening's final presentation on the Hunter College Dance Series was not called "The Many Faces of Carmen De Lavallade" but it might as well have been. The more austere designation chosen for the Hunter College Playhouse event was "Carmen De Lavallade and Her Theatre of the Dance."

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- More knowledge more widely distributed is the best defense against abuses of the fruits of science, a Nobel Prize-winner in genetics said today.

MADRID, March 8 -- A mild-mannered Roman Catholic priest, an underground labor leader and two university students were each sentenced today to a year in prison and fined the equivalent of $215 for "directing" a protest rally in Barcelona in October, 1966.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 8 -- The widening rift between Rumania and the rest of the Soviet bloc spread today to the highest council of the Warsaw Pact, the military alliance of the bloc.

THE sculptures of Andrea Cascella, at the Betty Parsons Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, are of such technical perfection and high polish that one's first impulse is to mistrust them. The absolute symmetry of their forms from certain angles, the flawless modulations from one symmetry to another, and the precision with which the various forms are carved to interlock, are at first acquaintance all but incredible, and thus intrusive.
YONKERS, March 8 -- Yonkers Raceway announced today that the meeting there had been "suspended indefinitely" and told the horsemen to remove the trotters and pacers from the grounds.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to move faster on his antipollution and conservation programs and offered his own "priority agenda" for the effort. But it does not need a heavyweight champion.

Neither may play tomorrow when the Yankees, unbeaten untied and unscored upon, take on the Baltimore Orioles in their second exhibition game of the season.

NEW DELHI, March 8 -- The sense of futility that now grips most of the delegates at the second United Nations Conference on Trade and Development here has resulted, in large part, from the failure to make any meaningful progress toward a general agreement on tariff preferences.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- Gil Hodges got his first look at his New York Mets in action in a baseball game today, and may long remember the occasion with terror.

BOLOGNA, Italy -- The 67 - mile - long Autostrada from Bologna to Rimini has brought this ancient town considerably closer to the Adriatic. The Girls Club of New York at 312 East 30th Street will receive the proceeds of a luncheon and fashion show April 2 in the Plaza's Terrace Room.

UNITED NATIONS -- The Soviet Union and the United States enjoyed one of their few, fleeting moments of harmony last week. ADELA, a multinational investment company that aims to encourage private enterprise in Latin America and turn a profit itself, will focus its efforts during 1968 and 1969 on two targets -- economic integration and "agribusiness."

SALEM, Ore., March 9 -- About 700 inmates at the Oregon State Penitentiary here rioted today. They barricaded themselves in a recreation area after setting fire to four shop buildings. The convicts held up to 11 hostages and threatened to kill them if their demands for improved conditions were not met.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn. -- Construction of giant agro-industrial complexes built around nuclear reactors is being studied at the Atomic Energy Commission's laboratory here as a means of providing food and jobs for millions of persons in underdeveloped countries.

BRADENTON, Fla. -- Beards In Manatee County are more abundant and more luxurious this season than ever before, as the men of this Gulf Coast resort come down the stretch at, presumably, a slow clip in a beard-growing contest that began more than three months ago.

Channel 4 plans live coverage of Secretary Rusk's testimony today, beginning at 10 A.M. and lasting for the duration of his appearance. Channel 13 will present a taped summary beginning at 10 P.M. followed by a panel discussion. Channel 2 plans a special report at either 9 P.M. or 10 P.M. and will cover testimony live if warranted.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 11 -- Heavy artillery fire from North Vietnam yesterday pounded the American naval base on the Cue Viet, an estuary leading to Dongha, in northern South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Military District of Washington said tonight that Lieutenant Morrisseau had been released from custody to return to Fort Devens without escort. The spokesman said that no specific charges had been filed against him.

SEATTLE, March 10 (AP) -- Rick Chaffee of Rutland, Vt., and Judy Nagel, a 16-year-old Enumclaw, Wash., high school girl, raced to victory in the Sunlit slalom today in the wind-up of the 1968 National Alpine ski championships.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 -- A confidential report by two American experts on community organization sharply criticizes the South Vietnamese Government for what is described as the failure to involve peasants sufficiently in local decision-making.

SALEM, Ore., March 10 -- Convicts who rioted at the Oregon State Penitentiary released four shivering, blanket-covered guards today after winning major concessions, including a new warden, during all-night negotiations.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Senatorial critics of American policy on the Vietnam war meet tomorrow for a long-awaited public confrontation, just as the Administration is reviewing a set of basic questions about the future of the war effort.
Daylight Saving Time is still seven weeks away, but Daylight Losing Time starts today for New York's thoroughbred horse-players.

CHICAGO, March 10 (UPI) -- January traffic deaths for the nation were about 8 per cent below the figure for the same month last year, the National Safety Council said today. The month's national death toll was 3,420, the Council said. More than 100,000 persons suffered disabling injuries during the period. Traffic accidents in January cost the nation $650-million.
LONDON, March 10 (UPI) -- A seven-page letter writen by George Washington is among a host of historical treasures from the estate of Viscount Astor to be auctioned April 9 at Sotheby's in London.

The annual Peppermint Ball for the benefit of the Finch College development fund will be held on Friday in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza. Mrs. Winthrop Rockefeller is honorary, chairman for the event, sponsored by the Finch Club of New York.
STUTTGART, Germany, Mar. 10 (Reuters) -- Soviet space scientist, Ivanovich Sedov, said today that extensive preparations were still necessary before a manned satellite could be sent to the moon.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- General Manager John Quinn said today Richie Allen, the Philadelphia Phils' star third baseman, had been fined for leaving the team without permission. The amount of the fine was not disclosed. Allen left the club last Thursday ostensibly to have his injured hand examined by his own physician. He rejoined the club yesterday.
BOSTON, March 10 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Royals, with four players scoring more than 20 points each, posted a 137-111 National Basketball Association victory today over the Boston Celtics.

MERIBEL, France, March 10 (AP) -- Jean-Claude Killy, triple gold medalist in this-year's Winter Olympics, won the second run of the Meribel international giant slalom race today to capture the event. The triumph strengthened his hold on first place in the World Ski Cup standing.

JENSEN BEACH, Fla., March 10 (UPI) -- A shark tugged at a 20-year-old college student as he paddled his surfboard in the Atlantic today but the student escaped with minor cuts and bruises. "I saw a flash as he came under me," said Jan Icyda of Stuart, Fla. "He was big and brown and as long as my surfboard. He swerved as he grabbed my foot and was broadside to me."

AMHERST, Mass., March 10 (AP) -- Opposition to the Vietnam war and the policies of President Johnson have grown in the last year among students at the University of Massachusetts, surveys made public tonight indicate. Two polls were taken by graduate political science students.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 10 (UPI) -- Dr. J. Allen Hynek, the Air Force's special consultant on unidentified flying objects, appealed today for eyewitnesses to the "Great airship sightings" of the 1890's. He asked anyone who had seen the 19th century U.F.O.'s to provide a written description to the Dearborn Observatory Northwestern University.

HOW'S your ESP? Early in "Scarlet Lullaby," which opened last night at the Masque Theater, a call girl gets a nonbusiness call from Milwaukee. Her sister and brother-in-law have been killed in an auto accident. "Was their little girl with them?" No. "Thank God!"
Two Brooklyn youths were arrested yesterday and accused of the murder of a policeman during an attempted holdup of a Queens drugstore on Feb. 19.

McAFEE, N. J., March 10 -- A light rain and heavy fog failed today to keep Anderl Molterer, the Kitzbuhel Kid, from capturing the final event of the Professional Ski Racers Association's seven-meet season at Great Gorge.

GOTTINGEN, West Germany March 10 (Reuters) -- Nazi songs and poems that once made the hearts of millions of Germans beat faster rang out again today, but a young theater audience here greeted them with laughter.

ST. LOUIS, March 10 (UPI) -- The Detroit Pistons extended their winning streak to five games, their longest of the season, today and snapped a five-game St. Louis victory string by beating the Western Division champion Hawks, 133-121.
Hundreds of persons in Valley Stream. L. I., evacuated from homes around a lumberyard, watched for six hours yesterday as flames destroyed the yard and caused about $1-million damage.
The Waterfront Commission will open the port's work list to admit 750 new men because of manpower shortages on the New Jersey side of the port.
CINCINNATI, March 10 (AP) -- Wayne Sanders, a sixth-grade teacher from Topeka, Kan., today rolled a 279--second best game of the 23-day-old American Bowling Congress tournament.
The Uris Buildings Corporation has elected Harry Leibowitz treasurer.
A NEW kind of room is springing up in Manhattan cooperative apartments and town houses. It is called a kitchen, but it is as far removed from kitchens of yore as miniskirts are from bustles.
DAN MORSE of Houston and Paul Swanson of Morgantown, W. Va., led the field of 576 pairs into the final session of the National Open Pair Championship at the Americana hotel here last night.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 10 -- A party of American tourists, some of them elderly, was assaulted here today by blacks in an apparent outburst of resentment against executions by the Rhodesian regime.
BASEL, Switzerland, March 10 -- The United States today won renewed Western European backing for support of gold in the London market at the official price of $35 an ounce.
LOS ANGELES, March 10 (AP) -- The Baltimore Bullets kept alive their playoff hopes with a 119-89 victory tonight over a weary Los Angeles Laker quintet.
The four favorites moved into the quarter-final round of the Eastern men's indoor clay-court tennis championship yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The last man George Meany cares to see the Republicans nominate for President is Governor Rockefeller of New York. And that goes for many associates of the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. Not because they don't like the Governor, but because they do. A Rockefeller nomination would strain labor's political and emotional loyalties in the election, a condition the leaders do not suffer now.

Botany Industries, Inc., has acquired Botany G.M.R., a manufacturer of men's and women's rainwear, from Van Baalen Heilburn Company for an undisclosed amount of cash. Botany G.M.R. produces rainwear under the Botany 500 and Worsted-Tex labels in a licensing arrangement with Botany Industries.

SUFFERN, N. Y., March 10 -- A strange voice that has been breaking into services at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church here was heard again today by about 300 parishioners attending the 5:30 P.M. mass.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- President Johnson's pastor, the Rev. Dr. George R. Davis, said today that Mr. Johnson had the "interior resources" necessary to shoulder the burdens of the most difficult job on earth. The President and Mrs. Johnson attended morning services at National City Christian Church, where Dr. Davis said that Mr. Johnson had what was needed to do his job gracefully and well.

STONY BROOK, L. I., March 10 -- Students, faculty members and administrators at the State University Center here are concerned that the mass narcotics raid last Jan. 17 has left a legacy of distrust that can prove more harmful than the narcotic problem itself.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., March 10 (AP) -- A two-hour state of emergency was declared here today after hundreds of Negroes in roving gangs were reported to have caused acts of vandalism. It was lifted when the borough was quieted in the early morning hours.
Bill Lanigan of the Bronx, an Olympic team member, won his five races yesterday to capture the United States open indoor speed skating senior men's championship at Flushing Meadow Rink.

HOUSTON, March 10 -- The National Wildlife Federation reelected Dr. Donald J. Zinn of Kingston, R. L., president today as the organization ended a three-day conservation convention at the Continental Houston Hotel.

JACKSON, Miss., March 10 -- Charles Evers, the Negro civil rights leader who is running for Congress in the Third District, was subpoenaed today, on the eve of his last campaign tour, to appear tomorrow "and until released" in a case outside the district.
PITTSBURGH, MARCH 10 -- Steel officials reported a general trend upward last week but still some uncertainty in the sheet market.
LOS ANGELES, March 10 (AP) -- Formation of an international group of scientists dedicated to keeping humans from aging faster was announced today by the University of Southern California.

Representative Emanuel Celler, dean of the House of Representatives, said yesterday that he believed the civil rights bill upon which the Senate votes today would win final Congressional approval "within the next week or 10 days."

The Goucher College Scholarship Fund will benefit from a recept/on and dinner at the Pierre on Friday in honor of Dr. Marvin D. Perry. Jr., the new president of the women's college in Towson, Md. Mrs. Nathaniel Freedman is chairman for the event, which will be attended by members of Goucher alumnae clubs of New York, Long Island, Westchester County. Northern New Jersey and Princeton, N. J.
A heavy sea fog that blew over most of the Eastern Seaboard disrupted road and air travel yesterday in several states from New England to Georgia and as far inland as the Tennessee Valley.

The Board of Education's decentralization proposals might have been acceptable as a first step toward reorganization had they been put forth three years ago. But as a response to the Bundy report and its more practical revision by Mayor Lindsay, this decentralization plan must be described as offering too little too late.

The National Broadcasting Company news department asserted without qualification last night that the war in Vietnam was being lost, if it were judged against the Johnson Administration's expressed reasons for pursuit of the conflict.
Thomas C. Morrow was named marketing vice president over the weekend of the Rent-A-Car division of the Avis Rent-A-Car System, Inc.

PRAGUE, March 10 -- The leader of the Communist party of Prague, Martin Vaculik, urged President Antonin Novotny today to appear before the Czechoslovak people and ask for an expression of confidence. Mr. Vaculik implied the support of the Prague party organization.
The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that on-campus recruitment should be open to all corporations and government agencies, if it is open to any.

Charles Blitzer has been appointed assistant secretary for history and art at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, and Philip C. Ritterbush has been named the institution's director of academic programs, it was announced yesterday by S. Dillon Ripley, secretary.

Many businessmen call "home" their office, working out of a bureau drawer, a brief case, or a secretary-staffed room. No one knows how many millions of businessmen operate at home, but they cover most professions.
THE shirtdress--that sturdy American classic that has been around since the turn of the century--is achieving status again.
MIAMI, March 10 -- After struggling for nearly 4 hours and using 43 players, the New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles settled for a I3-inning 7-7 tie at Miami Stadium today.
BOSTON, March 10 (UPI) -- Jim Peters scored with six minutes remaining tonight, giving the Detroit Red Wings a 7-5 victory over Boston after the Bruins had overcome a five-goal lead.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 -- Hundreds of anti-Communist Vietnamese turned out today in religious robes and Sunday-best suits to open what they described as a major movement for unity and a sense of national purpose.

Holy Cross challenged height and scoring power with deliberate ball handling yesterday and upset LaSalle Academy, 61-40, for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball championship at St. John's University. LaSalle, previously beaten only by Fordham Prep in 21 games this season, was the defending champion and a heavy favorite to retain the title.
The First National City Bank announced over the weekend the appointment of H. Carnie Lawson and E. Wayne Nordberg as vice presidents in its trust and investment division.
Mayor Lindsay will ask the Legislature this week to stiffen the penalties for cigarette bootlegging.

French investment capital has been flowing into foreign countries over the last five years at a quickening pace, and at a rate of increase four times that of the French gross national product. Concurrently, the proportion of foreign investments in France has been declining since 1964.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- The solidarity of Florida's statewide teachers strike broke today, when the Florida Education Association said the three-week walkout would be continued only in counties where school officials refused to take back all strikers.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)--A population organization reported today that 324,000 new babies enter the world on an average day.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- An Army officer who tried today to picket the White House to protest the Vietnam war was carried away by the Armed Forces Police.
Albert Finney, star of "Joe Egg." will leave the cast April 13. He will be replaced by Donal Dinnelly, who was seen here as Patrick Bedford's alter ego in "Philadelphia, Here I Come!"
The Superintendent of Schools said yesterday that the current school year here would not be extended to make up for time lost during the 14-day walkout by teachers last September.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 10 (Reuters) -- Msgr. Dionysus Antoine Hayek, Roman Catholic Bishop of Aleppo, tonight was elected Patriarch of Syria. The Patriarch, who is 58 years old, succeeds Ignatius Cardinal Tappouni, who died in January.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- The New York Mets have been advertised this year as changed characters--cool, businesslike, ambitious. But they were as warm, wild and slack as ever today as they carried the St. Louis Cardinals 14 innings to a 1-1 tie.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 10 (UPI) -- Craig Cameron's seventh goal of the season gave the St. Louis Blues a 1-0 triumph over the Oakland Seals tonight behind the goal tending of Glenn Hall.
The opening of Eugene Ionesco's "Armedee," which was scheduled for tonight at the Garrick Theater, has been postponed until March 28.

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- Brilliant goaltending by Jack Norris and Ken Wharram's two goals paced the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-0 victory today over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a nationally televised National Hockey League game.

In his special message on health, President Johnson has recommended several new programs and fundamental changes in old ones which, together, will materially help to meet some of the nation's major health needs.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 10 -- William Scarlett and Bradley Drowne of Short Hills, N.J., won the American Platform Tennis Association's national men's doubles championship today.

MIAMI, March 10 -- In a bizarre finish seldom seen along the pro golf circuit, Gardner Dickinson won the Doral open tournament today by a single stroke. Despite a double-bogey 6 at the 18th hole and a bogey 5 at the 17th, the 40-year-old campaigner closed with a par for a 72-hole aggregate of 275.

PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, March 10 (AP) -- Three houses were set afire today in a continuation of the three months of violence between opponents and advocates of the independence that this Indian Ocean island is to receive from Britain on Tuesday.

LONDON, March 11 -- The demand for gold was heavy again today, and doubts grew that the latest international pledge to maintain the price at $35 an ounce would calm the markets.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 11--Rhodesia hanged two convicted murderers today after having rejected the men's last-minute appeals for clemency. After a late Cabinet meeting yesterday, however, the Government did grant stays of execution of unspecified duration to four men sentenced to death on charges of terrorist activities.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) -- A $200-million appropriation for summer programs in big city slums was proposed today by a bipartisan group of House members.
NEWARK, March 11 -- A new effort by businessmen to find jobs for the Newark area's hard-core unemployed and needy youths was announced here today.

ZURICH, March 11 -- Swiss bankers, who claim to handle 75 per cent of the buying in the London gold market, continued to express considerable anxiety today about the stability of the gold price despite reassurances from Basel.

THAT well-known statistician, Emile Francis, had his usual facts and figures on hand yesterday to prove that tomorrow's Ranger game with the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden was another of those "crucial" contests the New Yorkers have been playing since December.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 11 -- "I've been told that I need 42 more games to break the record," said Hoyt Wilhelm without the slightest animation in his voice. "If I can keep pitching like I've been pitching, I can do it."

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- George Meany made a surprise move today by calling the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Executive Council to a special meeting tomorrow to act on the United Auto Workers' request for a special convention.
NEWARK, March 11 (AP) -- The board of trustees of the state medical college gave final approval today to the controversial relocation of the school in Newark.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 11 (AP) -- Five of the nine members of the International Olympic Committee called today for a full meeting of the committee to reconsider the readmission of South Africa for the Games next October.

ATHENS, March 11 -- Majestic Roman baths, in which wealthy patrons relaxed in the luxury of marble-lined heated pools in the second century after Christ, have been uncovered by American archeologists in ancient Corinth, celebrated as the most beautiful and most depraved city of antiquity.

ATHENS, March 11--Constantine Thanos, deputy governor of the Bank of Greece, said tonight he intended to sue The London Sunday Times for libel for reporting that he had pirated the thesis for his Columbia University Ph.D. in economics.

Secretary of State Rusk made a strong and reasoned plea yesterday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on behalf of the Administration's $3-billion foreign-aid program. We hope it is needed. But when the Secretary responded to questions on the issue uppermost in the minds of the Senators and foremost in the thought of the nation -- Vietnam -- he sounded, as has been observed before, like a broken record.

Automation is causing as profound a revolution in printing as the introduction of movable type or the invention of the Linotype. For many years it has been clear to management and labor in New York City's newspapers and in its commercial printing industry that there can be no long-range future for either without full use of advanced technology.

The city's three general-circulation dailles, commercial printing shops and New York Typographical Local 6 announced yesterday that they had agreed to have a manpower study made to assist them in negotiating terms for the introduction of automated equipment.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's Chief of State, has again charged that Asian Communist powers are trying to overthrow his regime by promoting a Cambodian rebellion.

Frank C. Staples, Grand Master of the New York State Masonic Grand Lodge, issued the following statement yesterday after hearing the report that the Vatican had virtually discarded the church law calling for excommunication of Roman Catholic Freemasons:

The television industry and major advertising agencies were accused yesterday of contributing to racism by offering a false image of minority groups, especially Negroes, in both TV programing and on commercials. The City Council took a first step yesterday toward drawing new district lines for its members for the 1969 city election. But it did so over a Republican protest that "all Councilmanic districts will be made safe for Democrats."
A classroom building will be erected downtown by New York University for its Graduate School of Business Administration with a $3-million grant from the Charles E. Merrill Trust.

TRENTON, March 11 -- The administration of Gov. Richard J. Hughes proposed today a $1.2-billion transportation bond issue for New Jersey, a state with the nation's busiest highways and a financially troubled railroad commuter system.

A debate on the war between Ho Chi Minh and General Ky might have been more of a standoff, but even this is not certain.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11 -- The nose of the big transport plane pitched upward violently and more than 13 tons of howitzer ammunition tumbled out of the tail door to the enemy-surrounded United States Marine Corps outpost below at Khesanh.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge to payment of unemployment benefits to more than 3,000 railroad firemen.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 11 -- Dr. Mason W. Gross, president of Rutgers, accused the National Collegiate Athletic Association tonight of having made "innocent athletes the scapegoats" in a dispute between the university and the association over the controversial 1.6 legislation.

ALBANY, March 11 (AP) -- The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court held today that county welfare departments must reimburse private agencies that advance funds to doctors, dentists and druggists dealing with Medicaid patients.
ACAPULCO, Mexico -- Samuel I. Newhouse is quite frank about ruffles. They make him nervous, and sometimes he chuckles purely because he's the one who's wearing them.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury reported tonight.
The trading pace perked up a bit yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and prices did, too.

Borrowings by the United States from foreign central banks to defend the dollar rose to a record of $1.8-billion in the weeks following the devaluation of the pound last fall, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

BONN, March 11--Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger declared today that the goal of an independent Europe should be pursued in "reliable partnership" with the United States but outside what he called a "North Atlantic imperium."
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 11 (AP) -- Westley Unseld, twice an All-American, said today he would not compete in the Olympic trials because he was weary after a long season of basketball.

The "red alert" is on for traffic and parking scofflaws. The city's new "Scofflaw Redbooks" listing the worst violators went into use yesterday, enabling policemen and meter maids to catch up with six scofflaw vehicles, each having 20 to 30 outstanding tickets.
Senator Jacob K. Javits suggested yesterday that the United States accepted 50,000 to 60,000 Arab refugees displaced by establishment of Israel in 1948.
Organizers of the annual Easter Seal luncheon at the Plaza Hotel will take time off Thursday to attend a cocktail reception at the St. Regis-Sheraton.
ROME, March 11 -- The Vatican has virtually discarded an old church law under which Roman Catholics were excommunicated for joining the Order of Free Masons, Vatican sources said today.
SAN SALVADOR, March 11 -- Salvador has taken a sudden and unexpected turn toward the left by handing a stunning electoral defeat to its semimilitary Government.
TRENTON, March 11 -- The overwhelming Republican legislative majorities approved a resolution tonight authorizing a legislative investigation of organized crime in New Jersey.
MADRID, March 11 -- Seventy-six Deputies have called for a special meeting of the Cortes, the Spanish Parliament, as soon as possible for the Government to explain Spain's economic situation.
PRIME MINISTER WILSON once praised Sir Hugh Beadle, Chief Justice of Rhodesia, as a jurist noted "for his sagacity, judgment and humanity" and "a man with the courage of a lion."
WASHINGTON, March 11 The Administration disclosed today that it was taking a number of steps toward international cooperation and control of the study and use of the oceans.

RICHARD SPERO of Forest Hills, Queens, and Ronald Blau of Bellmore, L. I., won the first major championship in the American Contract Bridge League Spring National Championships at the Americana Hotel Sunday night.
Student leaders at Columbia University have called for a campus-wide boycott of classes tomorrow to protest the draft and the war in Vietnam.

GENEVA, March 11 -- The United States and the Soviet Union refused today to make any major changes in the draft treaty to halt the proliferation of nuclear weapons, leaving the battle over the final text to be fought at a special United Nations General Assembly session next month.

PITTSBURGH, March 11--Two Federal Departments--Housing and Urban Development and Transportation--have reached agreement on how they will divide responsibility for mass transit, it was announced here today. The major share will go to the transportation agency, a "substantial" amount to the housing department.

The city's policy-making Council Against Poverty said yesterday that it had gone through an "exhilarating and sometimes chaotic experiment" to share with poor people the spending of $60-million a year in Federal and city funds here.
A Los Angeles inventor has been awarded $13.5-million in damages by a Superior Court there in his suit against the United Aircraft Corporation.

Roy M. Cohn, the Manhattan lawyer, was charged yesterday with making "gratuitous and slanderous comments" in connection with a court case involving Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., which Mr. Cohn represents.

SALEM, Ore., March 11--Governor Rockefeller and Senator Robert F. Kennedy, both of whom have disclaimed Presidential aspirations this year, were named today by Oregon's Secretary of State for places on the primary election ballot May 28.
Mira Trailovic, a tall, stately, sandy-haired woman of 44, has been called by some American observers of the Yugoslav theater "the Margo Jones of Belgrade.

Jean-Claude Killy, the French skiing star with the romantic appeal, and Karl Schranz, the quiet Austrian who insists his main love is skiing, were in a delegation of 38 international stars that arrived at Kennedy International Airport yesterday.

In his editorial page column, Foreign Affairs, on March 1 C.L. Sulzberger warns us, quite rightly, I believe, that if we withdraw from Vietnam, thereby admitting military defeat, we must expect very ugly troubles at home from embittered chauvinists, both military and civilian.

JACKSON, Miss., March 11 -- Charles Evers won a reprieve today from a subpoena that had threatened to take him from the stump on his final day of campaigning for a seat in the United States House of Representatives.

Julius F. Klein, a Suffolk County figure whose record goes back 20 years, was found guilty yesterday of having embezzled $40,000 from the Long Island cesspool construction company he once served as vice president.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Retail sales rose in February by $400-million, or somewhat more than 1 per cent compared to those of January, the Commerce Department reported today. The sales total for the month, after adjustment to eliminate purely seasonal factors, was $27.4 billion.
LINCOLN, Neb., March 11 -- Richard M. Nixon's backers are engaged in an 11th-hour attempt to bring about a confrontation with Governor Rockefeller in Nebraska's Presidential primary May 14.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -The Senate passed today a sweeping civil rights bill that would strike down racial barriers in about 80 per cent of the nation's housing.
BACK in 1966, after years of, allowing two solutions for one accounting problem, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants acted to rule out one of the two techniques.

Major teaching hospitals here have obtained all of the internes they sought for the coming year from American medical schools, but many institutions with less prestige have failed to attract a single graduate.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu dismissed seven provincial chiefs today in the biggest upheaval of his administration, according to sources close to the South Vietnamese Government.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- Mrs. Charles Wetzel and Mrs. Nathan Stauffer began defense of the United States squash racquets doubles championship today with a 15-10, 15-7, 15-6 victory over Mrs. T. L. Thomas 2d and Mrs. Hubert Horan at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Over Democratic cries of "It's cruel! It's callous! It's anti-people!" the minority Republicans, with the help of 17 upstate Democrats, voted final passage in the Assembly today of two measures to cut the state's Medicaid program by about $300-million a year.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 11 -- The Earl of Avon accused the Soviet Union today of falsifying the United States' position of willingness to negotiate a Vietnam settlement and of blocking efforts to strengthen supervision of the Cambodian frontier.
Thousands of schoolteachers ended strikes and returned to classrooms yesterday in Pittsburgh and across Florida. Some strikers held out in Florida.

BAGHDAD -- The countries and companies that make up the international oil business have their most sensitive antennae tuned to Iraq, because events taking place here may seriously alter the course of the industry.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee served notice on the Administration today that it would not consider President Johnson's $2.9-billion foreign aid request until it had received some satisfactory answers on the future course of policy in the Vietnam war.
The New York Racing Association won a big bet yesterday.
PRAGUE, March 11 -- The head of the Communist party in Prague, Martin Vaculik, expressed his regrets that antiliberal statements by his organization had been "imprecise'' and "misunderstood."
A surge of optimism reverberated through the stock market yesterday as traders responded to a new glimmer of hope about negotiations in the Vietnam war.
NEW HAVEN, March 11 -- Kingman Brewster 3d, 20-year-old son of the president of Yale University, has been exempted from the draft as a conscientious objector.

Eastern Airlines has applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board to replace its youth fare, which offers a 50 per cent discount to youths who stand by without a reservation, with one that offers a 33 per cent discount, but assures the youth of a reservation.

EXETER, N. H., March 11 -- The organ struck up, "There'll be a hot time in the old town tonight." Ed Morgan, a volunteer worker, pulled on a long brown string and high above his head a plastic bag released its colorful load of balloons and confetti. The crowd surged and murmured, then burst into applause. Richard Nixon entered smiling.

An effort by a group of money lenders to keep the Federal Reserve System's margin requirements for securities purchases from being applied to them was thwarted in Federal District Court here yesterday.

American business leaders called yesterday on their European counterparts to help head off a drive in this country for import curbs by backing a speed-up of scheduled tariff cuts by the Europeon Economic Community (Common Market).

Charles J. Murphy has been appointed administrative vice president of tile Cross Brown Company. Mr. Murphy joined the realty firm a year ago after having served as an administrative aide to Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes.
The Philadelphia Electric Company sold yesterday $60-million of bonds that were priced to give investors a yield of 6.50 per cent -- highest for a triple-A issue since late November.
WARSAW, March 11 -- Tens of thousands of Poles clashed with policemen today in front of Communist party headquarters and at the statue of the national poet, Adam Mickiewicz.
MADISON, Wis., March 11 -- Wisconsin's Attorney General, Bronson C. La Follette, 32 years old, said today he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor.
Leonard Blackman, 41-year-old vice president and general merchandise manager of E. J. Korvette, the discount department-store chain, has been appointed president.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 11 -- Although New York Yankee batters made 30 hits today in two cities, the club tasted defeat for the first time this spring -- twice. After a B squad had suffered a seven-inning 11-10 setback at the hands of Baltimore in Miami this morning, the regular team took an 11-7 pasting from the Washington Senators before 1,734 spectators at Fort Lauderdale Stadium

The nation's railroads filed their 76-page tariff plan yesterday in Washington with the Interstate Commerce Commission, proposing freight rate increases ranging from 3 to 10 per cent, with increases of 5 to 6 per cent on most food products.
YONKERS, March 11 -- A three-hour mediation meeting involving Yonkers Raceway and striking mutuel clerks failed to bring the issues closer to a solution tonight.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- The New York Mets and the Houston Astros staged their annual preview of the battle for ninth place today, and the Mets won it in 11 innings, 4-3.
The 1968 International Ice Patrol, undertaken annually by the United States Coast Guard, will rely even more heavily than in the past on scientific gear.

The New York Knicker-bockers yesterday announced the public sale of tickets for the National Basketball Association playoffs. The problem now is to get the faltering Knicks into the playoffs.
Snow storms struck New Mexico and the Texas Panhandle yesterday, leaving drifts of up to 4 feet. Heavy rain and hail swept over the Gulf States, The Associated Press reported.

The recent news report detailing plans of the National Council of Churches for "exposing'' the Soviet suppression of religion mentions that the action is expected to help combat the charges made by "extremists of the right who contend it [the National Council] has always been soft on Communism."
ALBANY, March 11 -- The State Judicial Conference urged the Legislature today to create 125 new judgeships to reduce court delays and prevent a "breakdown in the administration of justice."

A demonstration arts project to encourage the ranks of organized labor to assist in cultural development will be held in Minneapolis, Louisville, Buffalo and New York. The cities have been designated by the Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Unions for Scientific, Professional and Cultural Employes, with which 18 such unions are affiliated.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- the Supreme Court ruled today that Alabama could not segregate the inmates of its jails and prisons on the ground that racial separation was necessary to maintain order.

In the first effort of its kind, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced yesterday it would send out 12 assistant professors this fall to work full-time for a year with city officials on urban problems.
ROME, March 11 -- Italy's fourth postwar parliament was dissolved today at the end of its five-year term, to prepare for new national elections May 19.

For a little more than two hours last night in the Felt Forum of Madison Square. Garden, singers and actors lifted their voices in poignant protest against the Soviet Union's suppression of the cultural and spiritual rights of its Jewish citizens.

BEDFORD, N. H., March 11--The Democratic Presidential primary campaign in New Hampshire closed tonight in an atmosphere of harsh recrimination that reflected the deep divisions here and in the country over President Johnson's Vietnam policy.
CHICAGO, March 11 -- Chicago's first experiment with using Negro pupils to all-white schools was marred by a fire-bombing today.
A two-month emergency program designed to wipe out a backlog of civil jury cases got under way in Federal Court here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- World trade rose once more in 1967, but far less than in other recent years, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

A building in Woodside, Queens, containing 85,000 square feet of floor space, has been purchased by the Standard Wine and Liquor Company for a new headquarters and warehouse in a $1.5-million transaction.
CONCORD, N. H., March 11 -- The two surviving major candidates in the New Hampshire primary tomorrow closed out their noncompetitive campaigns in sharply contrasting style today.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee pressed Secretary of State Dean Rusk today to disclose whether the Administration was planning to expand the war in Vietnam.

From the ravaged redwood forests of California to the oil-befouled beaches of Puerto Rico, from the now threatened waters of Lake Baikal in Siberia to the choking, polluted air above New York and a hundred other major cities around the globe, humanity is threatened by the unintended consequences of its own ingenuity.

The Penn Central Railroad is reportedly negotiating to acquire the Kayser-Roth Corporation, the largest company in the apparel industry. In discussions said to have been going on for weeks, the newly merged Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads have been pursuing Kayser-Roth as part of the merged rail system's diversification program.
The Hartwell Campbell Fund, an aggressive mutual fund with the objective of seeking long-term capital gains, plans to change its no-load status to that of a load fund in about a month.
WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Tuesday, March 12 (UPI) -- President Johnson failed to receive a single vote early today from this first town to ballot in the New Hampshire Presidential primary.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Governor Rockefeller offered a first hint of encouragement to his supporters in Oregon today, inviting a dozen of them to meet with him here or in Manhattan next weekend.

THE National Broadcasting Company further enhanced its reputation as a network for news by carrying yesterday's appearance of Secretary of State Dean Rusk before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The live coverage extended for nearly three hours in the morning and longer than that in the afternoon; a host of regular programs were canceled and with them all the attendant commercial announcements.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11 -- A South Vietnamese regiment killed 102 North Vietnamese soldiers during an eight-hour battle just south of the demilitarized zone, a Saigon Government spokesman said today.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., March 11 -- An 18-year-old student charged today that he was forced to leave the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point last week because of his opposition to the war in Vietnam.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 11 (UPI) -- Pro-Communist forces have captured four Government outposts and are threatening strongholds in northern and central Laos, Laotian defense sources reported today.
PITTSBURGH, March 11 -- Last week, Dr. Robert L. Feller told the Phillips Memorial Gallery in Washington not to worry about a blister forming on a Renoir. Moisten with petroleum solvent, he advised.
Along the bustling blocks of Seventh Avenue in Central Harlem the little African shops stick out among the steamy restaurants, the noisy bars and the drab tenements.
Two officials arrived in New York City yesterday to try to sell a part of London Bridge, which is sinking into the Thames at a rate of one inch every eight years and is about to be replaced.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Copper strikers acknowledged today a "tentative" labor agreement with Phelps Dodge Corporation's Western Division, but they sent their negotiators back for assurance that there would be uniform contract expiration dates for all operations of the company.
Assurances over the weekend that the Government intended to maintain the price of gold helped to quiet the nervous precious metals markets yesterday.
Hans Erich Nossack, a 67-year-old Hamburg novelist whom Jean-Paul Sartre once called "the most interesting contemporary German writer," is in New York for his English debut.
BONN, March 12 -- The German Students Association has shattered the illusion held by many West Germans that the country's youth rebellion involves only a handful of hippies and Marxist radicals.

A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday that bunnies at the Playboy Club had not been coerced into joining a union there.

There was an evening of French music at Carnegie Hall last night. The change from the usual Austrian and German fare was occasioned by the appearance of the Kuentz Chamber Orchestra, a Parisian ensemble conducted by Paul Kuentz.

Cary Grant, a woman companion and their chauffeur were injured last night when the limousine they were in collided head-on with a truck on the Long Island Expressway near 39th Street in Long Island City, Queens.

After a lull on Monday, the gold crisis once more played pied piper in the futures market for precious metals yesterday. Traders, lured by the renewed interest of speculators in gold, bought actively enough to force up platinum, palladium and silver futures.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- The chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee denied today a request for an investigation of the antipoverty program.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The big debate on Vietnam in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is now over, and one thing seems fairly clear. The Vietnam conflict within the committee and between the committee and the Johnson Administration is not likely to be resolved, no matter how much they consult one another.
THE United States international team had a hard fight in the first knockout round of the Vanderbilt Cup contest at the Americana hotel here yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries was urged today to raise an appropriation for ship construction subsidies from $18-million to the $388-million originally requested by the Maritime Administration.

LONDON, March 12 -- There was continued strong demand for gold today in the key London market.

Your March 5 editorial on the latest wave of gold speculation rightly states the error of prematurely attempting to eliminate the use of gold in the international monetary system. ALBANY, March 12 -- The State Senate approved today by a 53-to-4 vote antiriot legislation forbidding the "encouraging or inciting" of violence or the "extermination" of any racial, religious or ethnic group.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia -- Twenty years ago Saudi Arabia was a land of trackless desert, camels and Bedouins. A great King, Ibn Saud Abdel Aziz, had united the country from the Persian Gulf to the Red Sea. Oil, exploited by the Arabian American Oil Company, was just beginning to flow.

A blue-ribbon panel of Government advisers, headed by former Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon, warned yesterday in a public statement that failure to increase taxes would "endanger worldwide confidence in the dollar."

PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, March 12 -- This lonely, crowded island in the middle of the Indian Ocean found itself over-teaken by independence today.

A 21-year-old youth accused of killing a policeman during a holdup in Queens was working in lower Manhattan when the slaying occurred, according to a time sheet produced by his lawyer yesterday.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 12 -- The hand-to-mouth existence of baseball's pitchers was simultaneously eased and complicated today as the new anti-spitball regulations were amended. Henceforth, the penalty for "going to the mouth" will be a balk, if there are runners on base, or a ball, if there are not, instead of ejection of the pitcher from the game.

Heart - attack victims here would be able to enter any hospital with available beds, even if their physicians did not enjoy privileges at that particular hospital, under a plan growing out of a new Federal drive against heart disease, cancer and stroke.

New York's foreign-exchange traders spent another harried day yesterday, wrestling with the sustained, unsettled conditions that have revolved around sterling, particularly, but have affected most other currencies as well.

TORONTO, March 12 -- The Canadian dollar has displayed what looks like an ambivalent reaction to the help Washington gave it last week.

ASPEN, Colo., March 14 -- Just when race officials were congratulating themselves over having a hard and fast course for the Roch Cup-World Cup races that start here tomorrow morning, along came a storm today to dump more than a foot of snow on Ajax Mountain.

ALBERTO GINASTERA'S latest opera, "Bomarzo," which received its New York premiere last night at the New York State Theater, has a reputation in more ways than one. When it received its world premiere last May 19 in Washington, it was greatly discussed pro and con as one of the biggest musical shockers since "Wozzeck" and "Lulu.
Harold Clurman, drama critic for The Nation, yesterday received the first Sang Prize for Critics of the Fine Arts from Knox College, Galesburg, III. The prize carries a stipend of $5,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- Assembly Speaker Jesse M. Unruh will head a slate of delegates committed to Senator Robert F. Kennedy in the California Democratic primary June 4, an unimpeachable source said today.
LONDON, Friday, March 15 -- In a sudden move early this morning the Government ordered a one-day holiday today in London's international gold market.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 14 -- American casualties in the Vietnamese war have exceeded those in the Korean conflict, according to a report today by the United States command.
"The difference will be that I'll get to play the guitar more," said Chet Atkins, speaking about his elevation to executive status by RCA Records.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation had net earnings last year of $15,420,000, the highest achieved by the film company since its separation from the theater operations in 1952. The earnings represent an increase of 23 per cent over the $12,504,000 cleared in 1966, Darryl F. Zanuck, president, reported yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- Directors of the Provident National Bank and the Central Penn National Bank today dropped their legal battle to merge, accepting defeat by the Justice Department.
